fields.headline: Audio
fields.standfirst: Frank McCourt is a serious fellow and he reads 'Tis seriously
fields.trailText: Frank McCourt is a serious fellow and he reads 'Tis seriously
fields.body:
'Tis
Frank McCourt
Read by the author
HarperCollins £8.99, three hours approx
Buy it at BOL

Frank McCourt brought fame to the family name when his childhood memoir, Angela's Ashes, was published in 1996. This sequel picks up where the first novel left off and 19-year-old Frank has made his journey back to New York - the place of his birth.

After a scrape with a lusty, drunken priest, he determines to lay off the booze and gets his head down to work in a hotel as a cleaner. The old troubles haunt him - his bad teeth and his sore, infected eyes but adulthood brings a pessimism to Frank's words and a lack of joy in life. It's not surprising the man is depressed after his hard childhood, but this account is far less mischievous and humorous than the days of scraping coal off the road and existing on a diet of fried bread and jam.

Unlike his brothers, Michael and Malachy, who also fetch up in New York and start a successful bar business, Frank is a serious fellow and reads his story as such. An immediate reaction is to ask why he didn't get some cheeky Irish actor to read it for him, but why should he?

This is Frank McCourt, this is how he talks. And gladly his years in America have not eroded that infectious Irish brogue. Is it as good as the first?

'Tis, to be sure.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Simon Beckett finds echoes of Catch-22 and Captain Corelli's Mandolin in Nicholas Rinaldi's tale of romance in Malta, plus Tulip Fever, What Do Women Want?, The Emigré and Diana: The Last Days
fields.body:
The Jukebox Queen of Malta
Nicholas Rinaldi
Black Swan £6.99, pp463
Buy it at BOL

Posted to Malta during the height of the German bombing campaign of 1942, New Yorker Rocco Raven, an apprentice radio operator, finds nothing to recommend the island until he meets Melita, the beautiful driver of a pink hearse, who delivers the jukeboxes her cousin constructs from old car parts and stained glass. But as food, cigarettes and just about everything begins to run out, not even their romance is immune from the absurdity and madness of war. Peopled with colourful characters and richly evocative of wartime Malta, Rinaldi's engaging blend of comedy and tragedy dabbles in the territories of both Catch 22 and Captain Corelli's Mandolin, without quite reaching the heights of either.

Tulip Fever
Deborah Moggach
Vintage £6.99, pp259
Buy it at BOL

Moggach's masterly depiction of Amsterdam in the 1630s, when a city at its artistic and cultural peak was gripped by tulipomania, is a delight from start to finish. Ageing and wealthy merchant Cornelis decides to immortalise his winter-spring second marriage to Sophia by commissioning their portrait, blithely unaware of the sexual tension that instantly blooms between his wife and the artist. Subtly erotic and as carefully crafted as the paintings of the period, Tulip Fever grows almost unbearably tense as Sophia and her lover embark on an desperate plan that will lead to disaster for everyone.

What Do Women Want?
Erica Jong
Bloomsbury £7.99, pp202
Buy it at BOL

What women want, according to Jong, are power, sex, bread and roses. 'The point of power is the freedom to cultivate roses. We have to remove the remaining obstacles to equality so that we can nourish ourselves and everyone else,' she says in her preface. And as for sex ... Jong's collection of essays and articles shares her insights on subjects ranging from censorship to being a mother, from witchcraft to America's obsession with the President's penis. By turns funny, incisive and irritating, her unwavering certainty in her own views can sometimes seem annoyingly opinionated, while at others sound like the clear voice of reason.

The Emigré
Joan Brady
Vintage £6.99, pp286
Buy it at BOL

The emigré in question is Nikolas Strakhan, son of a Russian count, failed concert pianist and successful con man. As the Conservative Party's 1984 Brighton conference approaches, the once svelte figure is 50 and fat but still intriguing enough to pique the curiosity of Eve, dissatisfied lover of his bland and overawed nephew, Harry. Coaxing the dirty details from various members of his family, Eve begins to piece together the history of the predatory, selfish and sexy Strakhan. Naturally, the more she learns, the more she's hooked. Former Whitbread winner Brady's mischievous and teasing novel is as seductive as Strakhan himself, subtly drawing us in to what's essentially a dark tale of obsession, vengeance and murder.

Diana: The Last Days
Martyn Gregory
Virgin £6.99, pp334
Buy it at BOL

TV producer and reporter Martyn Gregory's level-headed account of the events surrounding the death of Princes Diana and Dodi Fayed has been updated to include the findings of the French investigation. Impressively researched, it exposes as groundless fantasies the network of myths, misinformation and outright lies that proliferated after the 1997 car crash. Mohamed al-Fayed's attempts to convince otherwise are revealed as both blatant and breathtakingly self-seeking, but no doubt hard-core conspiracy theorists will remain unconvinced that the world's most famous princess could be killed by something so prosaic as drink-driving and failing to wear a seat-belt.

webTitle: She's young, black, British - and the first publishing sensation of the millennium

fields.headline: She's young, black, British - and the first publishing sensation of the millennium
fields.standfirst: At 24 she is already being compared to the likes of Salman Rushdie. Zadie Smith talks to Stephanie Merritt about her high-profile first novel
fields.trailText: At 24 she is already being compared to the likes of Salman Rushdie. Zadie Smith talks to Stephanie Merritt about her high-profile first novel
fields.body:
The hype began in the autumn of 1997. Zadie Smith was 21 and just down from Cambridge when her first novel was sold on a mere 80 pages for an advance rumoured to be in the region of £250,000.

Nearly two-and-a-half years on, White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99) is finished, at a weighty 462 pages, and about to be published. It is a broad, teeming, comic novel of multiracial Britain viewed through the lives of two families, and has already earned its author comparisons with Salman Rushdie and the kind of media attention not often lavished on a new writer.

Smith takes me to a caff in Willesden, north-west London, not unlike the one in which her two main characters, Archie Jones and Samad Iqbal, spend much of their time philosophising. She confesses that she has found the whole publicity whirl quite daunting.

'I didn't think the book would take two years to write,' she says, 'but I was quite lazy. And I had moments of fear, of not being able to write anything.' Because of the advance? She laughs diffidently; she has already refused to confirm the sum involved, but admits that it was big. 'Partly that. It did make my life a bit ridiculous really - it made me scared that I wasn't going to be able to finish the book, or that it wasn't going to be any good. But in the end, you just have to forget about it; otherwise you'd never write a word. These things happen sometimes, these freak events in publishing. Next year it will happen to someone else.'

Smith, still only 24, is currently enjoying the kind of success that most novelists can barely dream of. As well as wide spread publicity for the book, which has already been sold in 8 countries, she was asked to write a short story for the New Yorker's millennial fiction issue, and in April is travelling to New York to take part in a literary festival organised by the magazine and to promote the American publication of White Teeth.

Next month, she begins a stint as writer in residence at the Institute for Contemporary Arts in London. Despite all this, she is remarkably unassuming, quietly articulate though slightly shy about being interviewed, rolling cigarettes with nervous fingers and holding them, unsmoked, like a prop. She is modest, almost dismissive, about the book she has written, as if she genuinely didn't realise how good it really is, and insists that she finds it 'excruciating' to read.

She is quick to correct a recent newspaper assertion that she left Cambridge with a double First. 'Actually, I got a Third in my Part Ones,' she says, grinning. At the moment, she is still living with her Jamaican mother in Willesden, where she grew up, and where her novel is largely set.

'White Teeth is not really based on personal family experience,' she answers thoughtfully, when I ask if her own mixed-race background had furnished much of the story (her father is English). 'When you come from a mixed-race family, it makes you think a bit harder about inheritance and what's passed on from generation to generation. But as for racial tensions - I'm sure my parents had the usual trouble getting hotel rooms and so on, but I don't talk to them much about that part of their lives. A lot of it is guesswork or comes from reading accounts of immigrants coming here. I suppose the trick of the novel, if there is one, is to transpose the kind of friendships we have now to a generation which was less likely to be friends in that way.'

She is referring to the book's pivotal relationship, the 50-year friendship between Archie, a working-class Londoner, and Samad, a Bengali Muslim, whose ill-fated affair with a white woman proves a catalyst for the novel's central events. I ask if she found it difficult to write in the consciousness of a middle-aged man, but Smith is unusually confident for a young writer.

'As long as you honestly believe that people can be, say or do anything, then you stop worrying about it,' she says earnestly. 'I worried about things that were objectively anachronistic, like whether you would find a pizza place in 1975, because that jars when you read it, but to worry about whether a Bengali man of a certain age might say or think such and such, well, that's very limiting. You have to use your imagination.'

This imaginative element, I suggest, extends to the way in which race relations are portrayed in the book. Smith offers a very optimistic vision: prejudice exists, but tolerance appears in equal measure, and racist violence is only mentioned briefly and at second hand. Is this is an optimism she genuinely feels?

'It is kind of a fantasy book,' she agrees. 'There is a lot of pessimism currently about race relations in this country. I think the relationships in the book are something to be wished for, but I think they might exist now, and certainly in the future, with the amount of mixing up that has gone on. My generation, and my younger brother's generation even more, don't carry the same kind of baggage.'

But racial prejudice is still a part of daily life, especially in London. She tells me how her 16-year-old brother was stopped by the police only two days before. 'He was just walking down the street and they thought he'd robbed a house or something, so they threw him up against the car, asked him if he had any weed on him. I think it is a completely different experience for black men in this country.'

Her own experience, she says, was always softened by her academic achievements, though she hints that this might have been through a desire to overcompensate in the face of prejudice. 'When I was little, we'd go on holiday to Devon, and there, if you're black and you go into a sweetshop, for instance, everyone turns and looks at you. So my instinct as a child was always to over-compensate by trying to behave three times as well as every other child in the shop, so they knew I wasn't going to take anything or hurt anyone. I think that instinct has spilled over into my writing in some ways, which is not something I like very much or want to continue.'

Several times, she mentions a desire to change the way she writes; admiring John Lanchester's Mr Phillips, which she has just finished reading, she says: 'The best thing about it is that it's very sparse. I'd like a bit of that in my own writing.'

Smith is already well into a second novel, The Autograph Man, about which she will say little except that it is about Jewish cabbalism and is 'much funnier' than White Teeth, which she doesn't consider particularly funny (though it is). She wants to continue to write fiction, though she swears she will never write such a long book again. 'It was more than 700 pages at one point, and I think when a book gets that long, it's because you're not in control of it. Although publishers seem to like long books,' she adds. I suggest this might be because it allows them to feel they're getting their money's worth; she laughs.

She says, half jokingly, that she would like to write a 'cool' novel one day - 'I feel like a bit of a young fogey at the moment.' But she need not worry too much on that count. In her turban, thick-rimmed glasses and big trainers, she looks like a fairer-skinned version of Lauryn Hill. She is a fan of hip-hop, and the book is peppered with street language and hip-hop argot. The most animated I have seen her is when she spots an article about Madonna in the paper and pounces on it - 'I'm a huge fan'.

On the table behind us, two old men who've come in for their tea and could have been cameo characters from White Teeth, are watching with delight as John, our photographer, sets up a phalanx of equipment and Zadie poses self-consciously at a window table.

'I think she's a film star,' says one confidentially to his mate. 'I've seen her in that thing off the telly.'

'Excuse me,' says the other, 'but is she off the telly?'

'Not yet,' I say, 'but she will be.'

webTitle: Ask what your country can do for you...

fields.headline: Ask what your country can do for you...
fields.standfirst: Tom Nairn lets rip in After Britain
fields.trailText: Tom Nairn lets rip in After Britain
fields.body:
After Britain
Tom Nairn
Granta £15.99, pp318
Buy it at BOL

This is a thrilling and timely book and bloody hard work. Tom Nairn is too clever to be instantly readable; every point he makes, every paragraph, leads you into musings of your own, historical and political, so that when the eye finally returns to the page the brain is weary but hungry for more.

The subtitle of After Britain is 'New Labour and the Return of Scotland', but readers south of the border, traditionally fiercely uninterested in matters of Scottishness or the constitution (and hardly more interested traditionally in their own 'Englishness'), can, if they must, ignore the momentous upheavals in Edinburgh and simply concentrate on the lengthy chapter 'Blair's Britain'.

This is a work of such astute, vigorous import to them all that it should be turned into a pamphlet and force-faxed to every PR and spinner in the land whose sense of history begins and ends with their last coke deal, or perhaps written in foot-high Day-Glo letters on the skin of the Dome. Because the time would seem to have come for this debate.

Everywhere one turns these days, someone is trying to further analyse the state of 'Englishness' at its interregnum, with Empire long dead, the peripheries of the British archipelago splitting with indecent haste, hereditary peerages buried and the monarchy increasingly pinguid. With the old Britain dead and no new entity rising to take its place, it raises the question: what is going on in England?

Significantly enough, most of those trying to answer the question seem, at the moment, to be non-English - the Scots Andrew Marr and Gavin Esler, the Trinidadian Darcus Howe and now Nairn, a Scot living in Ireland who wrote the book in America.

Those all-English commentators who could have made an honourable stab at the subject - I'm leaving aside the obviously mad ones, the Heffers and the Hitchenses - have left it noticeably alone; Simon Jenkins, for instance, spent his fin de siècle travelling around his country to find out whether England's ancient churches were as pretty as ever.

As the debate gathers force, Nairn's work deserves to become the intellectual keystone at its centre. Others will provide valuable snapshots of the way England is today, set in the context of recent history, but Nairn, the man who correctly predicted the break-up of Britain in his 1977 book of that name, has given us the huge, sweeping historical overview, reminding us that, in the words of Lord Dacre: 'The people of these islands have seldom been united, politically or culturally. Efforts were made to unite them from the twelfth century onwards, but they only came under the same monarch in 1603, and the complete political union, which was at last achieved in 1801, endured only until 1922. Since then the process has been reversed...'

Nairn shows sublimely how the process of reversal is speeding up and predicts what must, by force of history, come next. He demonstrates, carefully, how first Margaret Thatcher, then Tony Blair, attempted to build a new élite to keep an old 'Britain' alive in the absence of the Establishment, and how their respective efforts - be it Thatcher's philistinism or Blair's 'gymnastics of sincere deceit' - were, and are, doomed.

Nairn, as an old Marxist nationalist, could hardly be expected to praise any aspect of Thatcherism; more devastating is his demolition of Blair's pretence at radicalism.

This is a government, he argues, which by determinedly failing to address any of the huge historical issues confronting Britain with increasing urgency - the need for a written constitution, the end of a confused and confusing monarchy, self-determination for its constituent countries, relationships with Europe - is 'steaming in circles', and destined only to preside, some time soon, over the final break-up, with Scotland leading the way. It needn't have been that way.

But the token nods towards such issues, often insulting in their smallness, have merely demonstrated that, far from bringing any of the necessary radicalism to Britain, Blair and his cohorts have, says Nairn, simply tried to create a new, similarly doomed, élite to keep the old ways going (albeit on life-support systems). Blair's 'totalitarianism' and control-freakery are, he demonstrates, simply 'a response to the prolonged withdrawal symptoms of collapsing Britishness', rather than any meaningful attempt to address the massive underlying constitutional problems; once again, 'radicalism [will] boil down to staying afloat'.

He goes even further, arguing that this process has been taking place since the early Nineties. The whole post-John Smith 'project' was not simply to make Labour electable but to begin the formation of this new élite which would, far from ditching the old Britain, simply tinker with the peripheral software while keeping the central processing unit intact.

It's an argument that may be giving the ahistorical Blair a touch too much credit, but it holds a surprising amount of water. It is known, for instance, that Charter 88, the constitutional reform group set up by Nairn's friend and amanuensis Anthony Barnett, was, despite the lip-service paid it by New Labour, one of the two groups of people Blair has been heard to call 'wankers' (the other being Scottish journalists).

Along the way, Nairn has a certain amount of fun. The chapter on Blair's Britain is worth reading if only for the brilliant, unsettlingly apposite analogies with A Man Without Qualities, Robert Musil's satire on the death-throes of the Austro-Hungarian empire.

He is also enough of a good old Scots leftist to let rip when truly angered, to remind us of the jaw-dropping absurdities of the unconstitutional country in which we live, such as the time when Thatcher broke a decades-old convention to press-gang a Lords vote on the poll tax: 'It was a fully Ethiopian spectacle worthy of some Disraeli novel. Bentleys and ambulances laden with Thatcher worshippers converged upon St Stephen's Palace from every decayed estate in the kingdom, so that the undead might vote through the century's most unspeakably stupid legislation.'

In the end, Nairn doesn't make constitutionalism sexy. It's not, so there would be no point in trying. What he does do, far more crucially, is make it important once more.

This is a work of such astute, vigorous import to them all that it should be turned into a pamphlet and force-faxed to every PR and spinner in the land whose sense of history begins and ends with their last coke deal, or perhaps written in foot-high Day-Glo letters on the skin of the Dome. Because the time would seem to have come for this debate. Everywhere one turns these days, someone is trying to further analyse the state of 'Englishness' at its interregnum, with Empire long dead, the peripheries of the British archipelago splitting with indecent haste, hereditary peerages buried and the monarchy increasingly pinguid. With the old Britain dead and no new entity rising to take its place, it raises the question: what is going on in England? Significantly enough, most of those trying to answer the question seem, at the moment, to be non-English - the Scots Andrew Marr and Gavin Esler, the Trinidadian Darcus Howe and now Nairn, a Scot living in Ireland who wrote the book in America. Those all-English commentators who could have made an honourable stab at the subject - I'm leaving aside the obviously mad ones, the Heffers and the Hitchenses - have left it noticeably alone; Simon Jenkins, for instance, spent his fin de siècle travelling around his country to find out whether England's ancient churches were as pretty as ever. As the debate gathers force, Nairn's work deserves to become the intellectual keystone at its centre. Others will provide valuable snapshots of the way England is today, set in the context of recent history, but Nairn, the man who correctly predicted the break-up of Britain in his 1977 book of that name, has given us the huge, sweeping historical overview, reminding us that, in the words of Lord Dacre: 'The people of these islands have seldom been united, politically or culturally. Efforts were made to unite them from the twelfth century onwards, but they only came under the same monarch in 1603, and the complete political union, which was at last achieved in 1801, endured only until 1922. Since then the process has been reversed...' Nairn shows sublimely how the process of reversal is speeding up and predicts what must, by force of history, come next. He demonstrates, carefully, how first Margaret Thatcher, then Tony Blair, attempted to build a new élite to keep an old 'Britain' alive in the absence of the Establishment, and how their respective efforts - be it Thatcher's philistinism or Blair's 'gymnastics of sincere deceit' - were, and are, doomed. Nairn, as an old Marxist nationalist, could hardly be expected to praise any aspect of Thatcherism; more devastating is his demolition of Blair's pretence at radicalism. This is a government, he argues, which by determinedly failing to address any of the huge historical issues confronting Britain with increasing urgency - the need for a written constitution, the end of a confused and confusing monarchy, self-determination for its constituent countries, relationships with Europe - is 'steaming in circles', and destined only to preside, some time soon, over the final break-up, with Scotland leading the way. It needn't have been that way. But the token nods towards such issues, often insulting in their smallness, have merely demonstrated that, far from bringing any of the necessary radicalism to Britain, Blair and his cohorts have, says Nairn, simply tried to create a new, similarly doomed, élite to keep the old ways going (albeit on life-support systems). Blair's 'totalitarianism' and control-freakery are, he demonstrates, simply 'a response to the prolonged withdrawal symptoms of collapsing Britishness', rather than any meaningful attempt to address the massive underlying constitutional problems; once again, 'radicalism [will] boil down to staying afloat'. He goes even further, arguing that this process has been taking place since the early Nineties. The whole post-John Smith 'project' was not simply to make Labour electable but to begin the formation of this new élite which would, far from ditching the old Britain, simply tinker with the peripheral software while keeping the central processing unit intact. It's an argument that may be giving the ahistorical Blair a touch too much credit, but it holds a surprising amount of water. It is known, for instance, that Charter 88, the constitutional reform group set up by Nairn's friend and amanuensis Anthony Barnett, was, despite the lip-service paid it by New Labour, one of the two groups of people Blair has been heard to call 'wankers' (the other being Scottish journalists). Along the way, Nairn has a certain amount of fun. The chapter on Blair's Britain is worth reading if only for the brilliant, unsettlingly apposite analogies with A Man Without Qualities, Robert Musil's satire on the death-throes of the Austro-Hungarian empire. He is also enough of a good old Scots leftist to let rip when truly angered, to remind us of the jaw-dropping absurdities of the unconstitutional country in which we live, such as the time when Thatcher broke a decades-old convention to press-gang a Lords vote on the poll tax: 'It was a fully Ethiopian spectacle worthy of some Disraeli novel. Bentleys and ambulances laden with Thatcher worshippers converged upon St Stephen's Palace from every decayed estate in the kingdom, so that the undead might vote through the century's most unspeakably stupid legislation.' In the end, Nairn doesn't make constitutionalism sexy. It's not, so there would be no point in trying. What he does do, far more crucially, is make it important once more.

fields.headline: A suitable novel
fields.standfirst: Vikram Seth's An Equal Music wears its sophistication lightly as it explores a triangular love story against a backdrop of European musical capitals
fields.trailText: Vikram Seth's An Equal Music wears its sophistication lightly as it explores a triangular love story against a backdrop of European musical capitals
fields.body:
An Equal Music

Vikram Seth

Phoenix £6.99, pp496

Buy it at BOL

Vikram Seth, who was born in India but educated in Britain and the United States, is contemporary literature's eminent Victorian. He first came to notice with an award-winning travel book, From Heaven Lake: Travels through Sinkiang and Tibet. Next, and to much acclaim, he published The Golden Gate, a novel in verse inspired by a translation of Pushkin's Eugene Onegin. Now his secret was out: he also considered himself a poet, and his translations of three Chinese poets together with his own slim volume The Humble Administrator's Garden followed.

In hindsight, this was merely a prolonged throat-clearing for his magnum opus, A Suitable Boy, a much admired three-decker novel on Victorian lines which dominated literary headlines during the early Nineties.

A Suitable Boy displayed Seth's love of storytelling and though it was clear he would not lightly undertake a fiction on such a scale, whatever he wrote next would exhibit his pleasure in the old-fashioned satisfactions of narrative and character. The upshot is An Equal Music, a lucid and ambitious attempt to capture the mysteries and perplexities of the musical life in prose. At the centre of the novel is a triangular love story between Michael, the violinist in the Maggiore string quartet, Michael's ex, and Julia, a professional pianist.

The unfolding of their on-off-on relationship is swathed in a highly wrought rococo construction of musical reference to Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, and virtually any composer who ever attempted a string quartet (Bartok, Shostakovich, Tippett, Carter and Ligeti) set against a backdrop of European musical capitals: Venice, Vienna and London. When An Equal Music first appeared last year The Observer characterised it as 'a highbrow cousin of Jilly Cooper's Appassionata', but this is a rather harsh verdict on a novel that wears its sophistication pretty lightly.

Seth is always highly readable, deeply sympathetic to his characters, even when they seem to have stepped from central casting, and so exquisitely versed in the English and European cultural tradition that admirers of A Suitable Boy will wonder if his writing will ever return to the India of his birth.

fields.headline: Gangsta trap
fields.standfirst: William Shaw's Westsiders follows the fortunes of seven los Angelenos as they try to launch rap careers
fields.trailText: William Shaw's Westsiders follows the fortunes of seven los Angelenos as they try to launch rap careers
fields.body:
Westsiders
William Shaw
Bloomsbury £11.99, pp388
Buy it at BOL

Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles, like much of the city, has always known where to mine for the fashionable dollar. Back in the Sixties, black musicians such as Miles Davis and Count Basie held court in the street's clubs. By the mid-Eighties, rock groups had taken over neon-lit haunts such as the Cathouse and Gazarri's. In the Nineties, Sunset Boulevard has looked further south to its black suburbs; rap music clubs now dominate the street below the Hollywood Hills.

Westsiders follows the fortunes of seven black Los Angelenos as they creep into the West Coast rap industry. In the US, LA rappers like Cypress Hill and Snoop Doggy Dogg have previously managed to overwhelm New York's as the country's black music hub. But the recent killing of Tupac Shakur - a cornerstone of Los Angeles' hip-hop - has seen the fledgling gangsta rap industry quickly oust its murder music back into the underground.

Shaw's characters are a misfit bunch - amateurs who lose their demo tapes, sell umbrellas to tourists and fail to win even minor talent contests. Like most musicians, many eventually abandon their hopes. Only Short Khop secures a management contract and record deal. Of the seven, he seems the most likely to succeed from the outset. Raised by a middle-class family, he has none of his contemporaries' gang links.

Westsiders makes a valuable assumption early on - that all the author's subjects will require the patronage of a current brand name in rap. All seven of Shaw's rappers scheme up new ideas to join already successful rap labels. But most of the celebrities who skirt the lives of his young hopefuls have, in turn, already become rap artefacts at the time of publication. Ice Cube, Snoop Doggy Dogg, DJ Pooh, Jayo Felony, the Alkaholiks are all now polite reminders of LA's urban heyday in 1994. Fickle teenage tastes, and the growing concerns of parent groups nationwide, mean that Shaw's book buries the last of the gangsta rappers.

While following the luckless young men of South Central, Westsiders sets itself on steady territory - and Shaw's is a compassionate narrative, often appalled by the violence that cradles this suburb of Los Angeles: 'South Central is a state of mind. That's just as true to white fans who have never been here as it is to young African-Americans, Latino and Asian inhabitants. To come from South Central is to come from somewhere, from a landscape in which true manhood is validated.'

Curiously, Shaw ignores the rising stock of female rappers - LA, like New York, cannot yet boast of complete equality, but precedents are being set. Record industry surveys have proved that rap music has gathered itself a strong female following which has led to a tide of female rappers, a fact that goes a little way to negating criticisms of sexism in rap.

LA's gang culture has been better probed before, in Mike Davis's defining 1990 study, City of Quartz: Excavating the City of the Future. Shaw's sociological backdrop to Westsiders owes much to Davis's ground-breaking analysis. In the chapters on housing policy, policing and the gradual escape of white householders to the hills in the early Sixties, Shaw is less sure of his own instincts. Yet he admits that in Britain he has no barometer with which to gauge LA's undercurrent of violence.

It might seem like minor criticism, but in describing a city obsessed by its own geography - for lack of any history or community - Shaw's book would have benefited from a drier analysis. It slightly spoils an otherwise beguiling account of a music industry governed by the race for cash. Mainstream pop music may have sacrificed its ideals for political influence; hip hop, according to Shaw, remains violently wedded to all notions of Americana.

fields.headline: The gremlin in the Kremlin
fields.standfirst: Leon Aron's 'definitive history' of Boris Yeltsin would be flawed even if it hadn't been overtaken by events
fields.trailText: Leon Aron's 'definitive history' of Boris Yeltsin would be flawed even if it hadn't been overtaken by events
fields.body:
Boris Yeltsin: a Revolutionary Life

Leon Aron

HarperCollins £29.99 pp934

Buy it at BOL

Of all the books about Russia, the two-part work by Beatrice and Sidney Webb has become the most derided. Their ecstatic account of Stalinist Russia was published on the cusp of the purges under the title: Soviet Communism:a New Civilisation? In the second edition, the question mark was dropped.

For many years afterwards, the visit of the Webbs became a paradigm of how well-intentioned Western intellectuals could be so blinded by the realities of a totalitarian regime which slaughtered millions of its own citizens with such gusto. How easy it became to mock the fellow travellers of the Left.

Today, we have fellow travellers of the Right, and the same excuses cannot be made for them. It is nearly nine years since Boris Yeltsin clambered atop that tank to pronounce his resistance to the August 1991 coup, in an act that was to bring about the collapse of the Soviet Union. Moscow is awash with information: on an average day, there are dozens of press conferences and as many dark, juicy conspiracy theories. Most participants in the exhausting daily drama that is Russia are willing to speak. The problem is getting them to stop.

How is it, with this daily surfeit of information, that events continually take Western diplomats, analysts, journalists and policy wonks by surprise? The collapse of the rouble, the rise from near total obscurity of Vladimir Putin, the launching of another war in Chechnya and the resignation of Yeltsin have each had the effect of challenging previously-held certainties.

Most of what Yeltsin did was conducted under the full glare of television lights, but the debate still rages: did the builder from Sverdlovsk construct a democratic edifice, albeit an unfinished one, or have the worst ways of Communist apparatchiks been transmuted into authoritarian nationalism, as prone to working out their rage on the Chechens, as previous generations had on the Jews?

Like the Webbs, and many people before him, Leon Aron, a 45-year-old US academic and commentator who grew up in Russia, set himself the grand task of writing the 'definitive' account of a man he defines as a revolutionary. To underline the seriousness of his purpose, the biography contains 100 pages of notes and 60 pages of bibliography. Yeltsin's every utterance is put under scholarly textual scrutiny.

Yet the final chapter of a narrative that ends in August 1998 contains this time bomb: 'One momentous precedent has been established: the end of the war in Chechnya. Never before had non-violent competition and free electoral choice borne so directly and effectively on the Kremlin's major national security policy.' He concludes: 'The wretched Chechen war proved that a highly imperfect democracy weakens [if it does not eradicate] the imperial urge. It revealed a Russia in which civil society is neither lethargic nor powerless.'

The cruel march of Russian history has made a nonsense of these sweeping statements. In light of today's events, Aron's text self-destructs. In charting the rise and fall of a life that he compares to Abraham Lincoln or a Charles De Gaulle, Aron relies heavily on Yeltsin's own words, which the biographer admits are flawed.

Yeltsin lied about his place of birth, and embellished the title of his college diploma: 'A path inside a coal mine and the organisation of work for its construction' became 'A Television Tower'. Yeltsin comments: 'I still do not know how I managed.The amount of mental and physical effort was unimaginable. And I could not count on anyone's help.'

Other daredevil incidents of his youth - the grenade going off in his hand, a trip into the wilds where everyone except brave Yeltsin falls unconscious with fever - are all deeply suspect but are here reproduced as fact. So, too, is the famed modesty of the Yeltsin family, ill at ease with the privileges of a provincial first secretary's life. The man who built his political reputation by attacking party privilege - the dachas, the special food, the black Volgas - established a system of state corruption which made the party's perks modest in comparison.

The narrative sidesteps that awkward moment during the 1996 election campaign when two of Yeltsin's re-election team were caught taking two boxes stuffed with dollars out of government coffers to pay off Boris's entertainment bonanza. Alexandr Korzhakov, the bodyguard and confidant who was the closest man to him for 11 years, is not interviewed. Similarly, Aron's account of the storming of the White House in October 1993 is vague. The military were reluctant to do Yeltsin's dirty work. They had to be shot at first to be spurred into action, and some of the sniper fire came not from the White House but from their own side.

The Webbs got it wrong for honourable reasons. No such idealism can be attributed to today's fellow travellers.

fields.headline: And thereby hangs a tale
fields.standfirst: Peter Beaumont admires the scenery in Stephen Venables' vivid account of his descent from Panch Chuli, A Slender Thread
fields.trailText: Peter Beaumont admires the scenery in Stephen Venables' vivid account of his descent from Panch Chuli, A Slender Thread
fields.body:
A Slender Thread
Stephen Venables
Hutchinson £17.99, pp208

There are two ways to fall off when climbing: a slow, quivering peel from the holds observed in a horrified slow motion; or a sudden unexpected slip that jars one into space. The sudden variety includes the most alarming kind of fall which comes not from a failure of strength, technique or slippery rock - it comes from a failure of an attachment point or of the rock itself.

I experienced it once when climbing on one of California's vast, big walls in the Yosemite Valley. Night had fallen. We had a rope length to the ledge where we would spend the night having climbed more than 1,000 feet. Pulling on a piece of equipment jammed into a crack, I suddenly found myself airbound as the pieces of aluminium that attached me to the wall pinged out. In that first instant, the experience of falling through the night was giddy, terrifying and mad, a sensation that was almost as quickly superseded by a sense of being gathered up into fateful eventuality.

The plummet experienced by Stephen Venables on the descent from his successful first ascent of Panch Chuli V in the Himalayas was of the kind most feared by climbers, the failure of an abseil point, an incident which usually guarantees death.

That Venables, the first Briton to climb Everest without oxygen, survived is a credit to the quick thinking and courage of his companions, Victor Saunders, Dick Renshaw and Steve Sustad, who seized and entwined themselves in Venables's ropes, stopping short his fall. By a second miracle, Venables found himself alive, although he had broken both legs. Trapped at more than 5,000 metres high, he found himself reliant on his friends, including Chris Bonington, who had remained at a lower camp, to effect a rescue from an isolated peak at the end of a jumble of glaciers.

The resulting helicopter lift by pilots of the Indian army, which Bonington had managed to call after surviving his own fall on the slopes of Panch Chuli, remains one of the highest ever successfully undertaken.

A Slender Thread establishes itself in a tradition of climbing literature that takes sustenance from the darker side of mountaineering, examining what Venables calls the 'paradox' of the moments when beauty, exhilaration and danger connect. The best climbing writing has always had its roots in the laying bare of this paradox. It is the realm where adventure exists.

But A Slender Thread is attached to a postwar tradition in mountaineering writing exemplified by the likes of Joe Tasker, Joe Simpson and, most recently, Paul Pritchard that puts the consequences of catastrophe in its proper context, in its impact on friends, on the family and on the self.

Venables's first thought on surviving his calamity is of his family. The existential moment of the fall gives way to the reassurance that he will probably make it and return home. His family looms ever larger. For the context that he supplies is his son's sudden diagnosis first with severe autism and then leukaemia, which forces him to balance his climbing with his family.

As with his previous books, Painted Mountains and Everest, The Kangshung Face, Venables writes with understated elegance, conjuring up vividly and honestly his companions while also showing an acute awareness of the environment through which he travels.

But A Slender Thread is attached to a postwar tradition in mountaineering writing exemplified by the likes of Joe Tasker, Joe Simpson and, most recently, Paul Pritchard that puts the consequences of catastrophe in its proper context, in its impact on friends, on the family and on the self. Venables's first thought on surviving his calamity is of his family. The existential moment of the fall gives way to the reassurance that he will probably make it and return home. His family looms ever larger. For the context that he supplies is his son's sudden diagnosis first with severe autism and then leukaemia, which forces him to balance his climbing with his family. As with his previous books, Painted Mountains and Everest, The Kangshung Face, Venables writes with understated elegance, conjuring up vividly and honestly his companions while also showing an acute awareness of the environment through which he travels.

fields.headline: Three's a crowd
fields.standfirst: Selina Mills finds that Sally Brampton's Love, Always is more than just a tale of unresolved love
fields.trailText: Selina Mills finds that Sally Brampton's Love, Always is more than just a tale of unresolved love
fields.body:
Love, Always

Sally Brampton

William Heinemann £16.99, pp306

Buy it at BOL

Jane Rose is lying in bed in the middle of the night, awaiting her lover's return. She worries about death. 'Not my own,' she says, 'but Rebecca's' - her lover's wife. Her lover Ben returns a few hours later to report calmly that Rebecca, with a history of mental illness, has killed herself. He crawls back into bed and makes love to Jane, a fact he fails to tell police the next day when reporting his wife's death.

So begins the story of a thirtysomething single mother, who feels she has never belonged anywhere. The tale, recounted by Jane, shifts between past and present, dipping into stories of her early childhood, her affair with Ben and her deep love of her daughter.

After a childhood of travelling around the world (because of her father's career) Jane's life begins, she says, when she arrives in London as a young adult for her first job, and meets the irresistible Ben, who is determined to become a writer. They have a brief fling, and part, only to meet eight years later when, by coincidence, Jane moves into the flat above Ben's aunt.

Much has changed, (Ben is a successful novelist, and married to Rebecca. Jane's daughter from a previous relationship has died in a car accident) but they are still drawn to what they imagine is the safety of each other and the affair resumes.

Their story, however, is not just one of unresolved love, but of how their lives are dominated by obsession and compulsion. 'Beauty is an awful compulsion,' Jane writes, when Ben confesses that his wife is so beautiful he cannot stop wanting her, despite not loving her.

Rebecca, once a promising poet and now a suicide risk, is dependent on a husband who represses her art and pays her little attention. Jane too is compelled to love a child who no longer exists - making her daughter's bed every night, despite knowing that she will never return. She also stays with Ben, she says, because she does not know how to leave him.

All three, therefore, are inextricably linked in 'an unwitting eternal triangle' where they see themselves in each other and their fear of letting go of the past. As Jane points out, it is hard to leave people, even dead people, when it means, 'you walk away from yourself'.

The novel, however, is not stuck in this suffocating world of dependence, but is driven forward by Jane's need to understand her life and her increasing distrust at Ben's behaviour on the night of his wife's death.

As she begins to reconsider Rebecca (whom she initially dislikes) and her own daughter's death, Jane realises that Ben is not all he seems and that being loved always has dangerous consequences. But her self-knowledge comes only with time. A compelling and clever novel.

webTitle: The Pope, the Sun King - with enemies like these...

fields.headline: The Pope, the Sun King - with enemies like these...
fields.standfirst: Jean-Christophe Rufin's The Abyssinian is a classic historical romance
fields.trailText: Jean-Christophe Rufin's The Abyssinian is a classic historical romance
fields.body:
The Abyssinian

Jean-Christophe Rufin

Translated by Will Hobson

Picador £14,99, pp422

Buy it at BOL

This book begins with a striking image; a portrait of Louis XIV, the Sun King, develops a number of leprose blotches, disfiguring it. The painting hangs in the French consulate in Cairo; the consul has to ask a local apothecary, Maistre Juremi, to restore the portrait, even though Juremi is untrustworthy (in the consul's eyes) because Protestant. The painting is 'cured'; and the scene not only sets up the novel's chain of events, it also highlights its major theme: the possibility of humanism (in the guise of science and medicine) crossing boundaries of religion, nationality and hierarchy.

Juremi's partner is Jean-Baptiste Poncet, a Frenchman of low birth biding time in Cairo, experimenting with herbs and curing rich and poor alike; a one-man international health service. He is handsome, reckless, libertarian, quick-thinking, and as handy a swordsman as a homeopathist - a romantic hero par excellence.

He falls in love, at first sight, with the consul's daughter, Alix. It is for this reason that he takes on a foolhardy mission from the consul; to establish an embassy with the Negus (King) of Abyssinia, as a step towards converting the Abyssinians to Catholicism. No one has ever returned from such a mission alive. But Poncet might succeed, because the Negus has an apparently incurable skin complaint, and Poncet is something of a miracle worker.

His aim is to establish the embassy, gain recognition for so doing, and to ask for permission to marry Alix. The plan is buffeted from all directions: the incompetence of the consulate; the refusal of the Negus to trust the French; interference by wily monks; and the plans of the Pope and Louis XIV. What unfolds is a classic historical romance, right down to a pleasantly antique grammar, the perfection of its hero and heroine, the beastliness of their foes, and a modesty about details of the sexual act.

Rufin describes the hardships and delights of travelling through Egypt and Ethiopia in great, almost leisurely detail, as if travelling appreciatively is as good as arriving, and this, however charming, does slow down the story. He is especially good, though, at rendering the fine detail of the bargains struck between characters, whether degrading, greedy and manipulative, or based on love, trust and respect.

Rufin's sweet, conventional adventure novel has won the Prix Méditerranée and the Prix Goncourt for best first novel. Rufin is a doctor with Médecins Sans Frontières, which has won the Nobel Peace Prize for its aid to peoples in trouble spots across the globe. The political parallels do not go much further than that, though the imperialists and monks are thwarted, the Abyssinians spared, and Alix - who develops from shy child into gun-toting, horse-riding adventuress with unrealistic but pleasing speed - gets her man. Humanism, generosity and love triumph against a background of barter, trade and treachery. This unashamedly feelgood yarn might make a ripping costume drama.

fields.headline: Anthems for doomed youth
fields.standfirst: Three vaunted debut novels explore the complex world of childhood, its sadnesses and wonders
fields.trailText: Three vaunted debut novels explore the complex world of childhood, its sadnesses and wonders
fields.body:
Helena McEwan's The Big House (Bloomsbury £12.99, pp183) opens with the stark revelation of two deaths - the suicide of James and the drowning of Kitty, brother and sister of the narrator, Elizabeth. The sense of loss resonates throughout the narrative, as Elizabeth returns to her memories of childhood in a large Scottish mansion. She describes, with breathtaking clarity and simplicity, a world of nursery teas, roaring fires, fierce nannies, hunts and a mother who sweeps in and out of the children's orbit, usually with grand visitors in tow.

It's something of a shock, then, to hear references to hippies, Tony Blackburn and 'Bridge Over Troubled Water'. This is the timeless childhood of the aristocracy, an aristocracy, it later emerges, battling with drink, death duties and imminent ruin.

It is a world in which privilege and neglect go hand in hand. Baby Annie, the latest addition to the household, is swiftly relegated from her 'cot tied with ribbons' next to Mama's bed to a 'cot with wooden bars' in the night nursery. 'Sometimes she cries such a long, sad cry,' says Elizabeth matter of factly, 'that James and I take it in turns to climb in beside her to stroke her soft, black, furry hair and hot cheek.' Mama is keen to keep things 'nice' at all costs, but barely glances at the book of pictures Elizabeth has so painstakingly stitched her for Christmas.

In prose so starkly beautiful that you want to quote great swathes of it, McEwan captures the innocence and excitement of childhood, the vivid intensity of the child's-eye view and the child's visceral delight in exploring and experiencing the world.

'I can smell the gooseberry leaves in the wet air,' she observes coolly, but just as real for her are 'the invisible beings of the house' which 'seem to draw closer to me'. Elizabeth adores her father, living for his smiles, winks and 'warm breath in the dark', but one day finds his warm gaze replaced by 'a black chasm'. Too young to understand the effects of drink and despair, she later concludes that he 'has been swallowed by the monster that lives in the great, gaping space down the middle of the staircase'.

Everything is given equal weight in her cool, clear, resonant voice: stealing the communion wafers and wine, her first, explosive encounter with Mozart, peeing in James's cowboy hat because she can't find the toilet in the dark. Touching, poetic and utterly unsentimental, The Big House is a mesmerising debut.

Most children dream of flying, but learn, after several tumbles on the stairs, to adapt to the constraints of life without wings. The unnamed protagonist of Bill Broady's extraordinary first novel, Swimmer (Flamingo £9.99, pp139), retains the dream of flight, symbolised by her profound love of butterflies. 'What you had taken for the sound of its wings was the beating of your own heart,' the narrator observes of her first encounter with a red admiral. 'You could feel its flutterings on your nerve ends.' As this quotation indicates, the novel is recounted not in the first, but in the second person, adding an additional distancing quality to a narrative already marked for its strangeness and beauty.

'You don't need to fly... that's what your imagination's for!' says the girl's father on finding his five-year-old daughter sprawled among the zinnias after leaping from the bathroom window, but she has acquired the taste for it, splashing and flying in the water at Worthing. There, she discovered that 'this new, white world was welcoming you, that these whispers and roars were a language you understood, that the tides beat with the same pulse as your circulating blood'. Water becomes her natural element, though every time she dives, she holds on to 'the vestigial hope' that she might slip 'through the roof's retracted skylight and up into the blue'.

When 'the Coach' arrives on the scene, he assesses her childish physique and announces: 'A butterfly, I think... ', allowing her to become, in a sense, the thing she loves most of all. The price she pays for her constant communion with the water, her ability to soar and fly beyond the dreams of ordinary mortals, is the competition circuit. Childhood and puberty are spent powering up and down pools, fighting pain, exhaustion and the water's changing moods.

Parents, fellow pupils and competitors remain shadowy, insubstantial figures in this tale of watery solipsism and obsession. At 19, it's all over. The Coach is swapped for a manager, who offers a new career, 'promo-ing' and a new circuit: the talk shows, catalogues and calendars of minor celebrity. When 'tits and ass' work is all that's on offer, she descends into pure madness, hurling her medals at tramps and running wildly through the city.

Echoing the aspirations of its heroine, Broady's stunning narrative seems to hover in its own distinctive element and, at times, to soar and fly. In prose of poetic precision and poignancy, he touches on the deepest dreams of the human heart: how those who dream of flying end up doing panto in Romford, how a child can swim and swim 'for Dad to let you sit on his knee again, for Mum to pour her gin away'.

There's a return to more traditional narrative in American William Kowalski's epic, Eddie's Bastard (Doubleday, £9.99, pp367). Like The Big House, it's about family, memory and piecing together the fragments of the past, but Kowalski's workaday prose couldn't be more different to McEwan's poetic compression. Its opening sentence - 'I arrived in the way most bastards do - by surprise' - is a nod at Tristram Shandy and with chapters helpfully outlining their contents - 'I Am Born'; 'I Learn To Read'; 'The Ghosts'; 'I Encounter Annie Simpson' - it self-consciously declares itself in the great storytelling tradition.

The story it tells is that of Billy Mann, abandoned on the doorstep of Thomas Mann with a label saying 'Eddie's bastard'. Recognising him as the progeny of his heroic son, Eddie, killed at Vietnam, Thomas sets about bringing up this latest addition to the glittering Mann clan. Unfortunately, he spends much of his time in a whiskey-induced stupor but does manage to squeeze out a few of the Mann stories, fuelling a growing obsession with family histories and a vocation as a writer.

Eddie's Bastard is a good read, at times quite touching, but it is marred by Kowalski's excessive fondness for schmaltz, whimsicality and homespun wisdom. Unless I missed the irony, it seems to promote a kind of New Age belief in past lives and the importance of not ignoring coincidences. 'We of small-town America still believe in placating ghosts, I guess,' announces Billy irritatingly. Kowalski has, apparently, been compared to John Irving. Perhaps they meant John-Boy. The Waltons meets The Celestine Prophecy.

Buy Swimmer at BOL

Buy Eddie's Bastard at BOL

fields.headline: Busy doing nothing
fields.standfirst: Philip Hensher wishes that John Lancaster would drop the funny voice and let Mr Phillips break his formal bonds
fields.trailText: Philip Hensher wishes that John Lancaster would drop the funny voice and let Mr Phillips break his formal bonds
fields.body:
Mr Phillips
John Lanchester
Faber £9.99, pp247
Buy it at BOL

In the past few years, the world of work has become one of the favourite topics for novels. In a way, it's surprising that work hasn't always been a central fact for the novel; after all, it's the place where most of us spend a substantial chunk of our time, where many of us meet our partners. It's an arena where power is exercised and controlled, where social encounters are forced on us, where the novelist, one might have thought, could always have found a rich source of material.

But it's only recently that this has started to be the case. Apart from a few acknowledged classics, such as Roy Fuller's Portrait of a Society, that marvellous novel of building-society politics, novelists tended to stick to a few familiar areas, preferring to regard the means by which characters earn their money as marginal to their consciousnesses. Who can remember what any of Iris Murdoch's characters do for a living? They are either schoolteachers or civil servants and that is an end to it.

A really first-rate novel of professional life, such as James Buchan's sublime High Latitudes, is as rare as it ever was, and the fabulous novelistic riches of life in the City, of law and commerce, are left by literature in the clammy hands of the Archers and the Grishams.

John Lanchester's second novel, Mr Phillips, is a brave stab at a difficult subject. It evokes the world of work through a negative perspective and feels, in the end, something like a novel about bereavement. Its hero, Mr Phillips, has lost his job as an accountant at a small, rather grubby firm where he has worked for decades. That was on Friday. The novel is set on Monday, by which time he has still not told his wife. What is he to do? Well, he gets up, puts on a suit and goes to work, or pretends to. What he really does is wander around London, with a day to kill.

He wanders in and out of adventures, glimpsing the extravagant life of the city from the unfamiliar perspective of the daytime idler. A tramp and a schoolgirl, perfect strangers, snog ecstatically on a bus; a walk round the Tate Gallery ends in an embarrassing encounter with a buttonholing enthusiast; an ecumenical meeting in a church breaks down in argument. Memory and regret play a vivid part in the day, as Mr Phillips contemplates his lost job, his past, his family and his unfulfilled desires.

The book is always engaging and interesting. It builds to a climax rich in sentiment, as Mr Phillips narrowly escapes death in a bank robbery and has a fortuitously, ambiguously heartwarming encounter with the widow of his old RE teacher. It's difficult, however, to avoid the nagging feeling that it's rather fatally lacking in ambition. Despite being in the third person, it's as much a monologue as Lanchester's first book, The Debt To Pleasure; there is no sense of cross-cutting, of the possibility of enriching the themes by turning to subsidiary characters or subplots. As a result, there is a constant danger that the blatant automatic virtuosity will submerge the human feeling, and the whole thing become something of a music-hall turn.

Lanchester isn't helped by his penchant for numerical fantasy. Mr Phillips is constantly having recourse to pointless, extravagant codification of emotional facts. How often do people have sex? A few pages of calculation balance out 'Highlanders in their distant crofts' with the thoroughly oversexed, who turn out, surprisingly, to be film critics, and produces the answer that there is 'an average daily probability of 96.7 per cent against having sex'.

These rather Nicholson Bakerish explorations are always interesting and usually funny, but are not, quite, in the right book and the reader turns back from them to Mr Phillips's long and troubled day rather unwillingly. Occasionally, there is a convincing sense that Mr Phillips is filling his head with accountants' trivia to escape bigger questions - he lies on the floor of the bank with a shotgun to his head and tells himself all the childish jokes he can remember - but one mostly feels the statistical fantasies are there because Lanchester wants to put them in.

Though there is a recurrent sense that too many formal decisions have been made before starting to write - the decision to confine the book to a single day, the artificial and unconvincing decision to refer to the main character only as Mr Phillips - these are only frustrating for the reader because the direct and indirect exploration of the inner life is often truthful and natural. It is artificial and wrong to hobble the episode of a hero's grief at his father's death by feeling obliged to go on calling him 'Mr Phillips', and it is annoying because everything else in the episode moves so naturally and feelingly.

Lanchester is a novelist easy to express an admiration for, and that is largely because of the external inventions, the constant sense of the virtuoso. Those conceits, however, are not the richest things in his writing and he would be wise to start thinking about dropping the funny voice and start talking with the periodic, rich truth which makes Mr Phillips worth recommending. His books, at the moment, are too driven by a sort of aesthetic embarrassment. When he gets over that, he is going to do something truly individual.

Who can remember what any of Iris Murdoch's characters do for a living? They are either schoolteachers or civil servants and that is an end to it. A really first-rate novel of professional life, such as James Buchan's sublime High Latitudes, is as rare as it ever was, and the fabulous novelistic riches of life in the City, of law and commerce, are left by literature in the clammy hands of the Archers and the Grishams. John Lanchester's second novel, Mr Phillips, is a brave stab at a difficult subject. It evokes the world of work through a negative perspective and feels, in the end, something like a novel about bereavement. Its hero, Mr Phillips, has lost his job as an accountant at a small, rather grubby firm where he has worked for decades. That was on Friday. The novel is set on Monday, by which time he has still not told his wife. What is he to do? Well, he gets up, puts on a suit and goes to work, or pretends to. What he really does is wander around London, with a day to kill. He wanders in and out of adventures, glimpsing the extravagant life of the city from the unfamiliar perspective of the daytime idler. A tramp and a schoolgirl, perfect strangers, snog ecstatically on a bus; a walk round the Tate Gallery ends in an embarrassing encounter with a buttonholing enthusiast; an ecumenical meeting in a church breaks down in argument. Memory and regret play a vivid part in the day, as Mr Phillips contemplates his lost job, his past, his family and his unfulfilled desires. The book is always engaging and interesting. It builds to a climax rich in sentiment, as Mr Phillips narrowly escapes death in a bank robbery and has a fortuitously, ambiguously heartwarming encounter with the widow of his old RE teacher. It's difficult, however, to avoid the nagging feeling that it's rather fatally lacking in ambition. Despite being in the third person, it's as much a monologue as Lanchester's first book, The Debt To Pleasure; there is no sense of cross-cutting, of the possibility of enriching the themes by turning to subsidiary characters or subplots. As a result, there is a constant danger that the blatant automatic virtuosity will submerge the human feeling, and the whole thing become something of a music-hall turn. Lanchester isn't helped by his penchant for numerical fantasy. Mr Phillips is constantly having recourse to pointless, extravagant codification of emotional facts. How often do people have sex? A few pages of calculation balance out 'Highlanders in their distant crofts' with the thoroughly oversexed, who turn out, surprisingly, to be film critics, and produces the answer that there is 'an average daily probability of 96.7 per cent against having sex'. These rather Nicholson Bakerish explorations are always interesting and usually funny, but are not, quite, in the right book and the reader turns back from them to Mr Phillips's long and troubled day rather unwillingly. Occasionally, there is a convincing sense that Mr Phillips is filling his head with accountants' trivia to escape bigger questions - he lies on the floor of the bank with a shotgun to his head and tells himself all the childish jokes he can remember - but one mostly feels the statistical fantasies are there because Lanchester wants to put them in. Though there is a recurrent sense that too many formal decisions have been made before starting to write - the decision to confine the book to a single day, the artificial and unconvincing decision to refer to the main character only as Mr Phillips - these are only frustrating for the reader because the direct and indirect exploration of the inner life is often truthful and natural. It is artificial and wrong to hobble the episode of a hero's grief at his father's death by feeling obliged to go on calling him 'Mr Phillips', and it is annoying because everything else in the episode moves so naturally and feelingly. Lanchester is a novelist easy to express an admiration for, and that is largely because of the external inventions, the constant sense of the virtuoso. Those conceits, however, are not the richest things in his writing and he would be wise to start thinking about dropping the funny voice and start talking with the periodic, rich truth which makes Mr Phillips worth recommending. His books, at the moment, are too driven by a sort of aesthetic embarrassment. When he gets over that, he is going to do something truly individual.

webTitle: From bleak house to great expectations

fields.headline: From bleak house to great expectations
fields.standfirst: Alan Parker's compassion and humanity shine through in a rain-sodden adaptation of Frank McCourt's Angela's Ashes
fields.trailText: Philip French: Some of the earlier parts of the story seem overly compressed, the latter parts are a trifle pat... The performances, however, are excellent, especially as we might expect from Parker, those of the children, with Joe Breen, Ciarán Owens and Michael Legge outstanding as Frankie from six to 19.
fields.body:
Compassion for the downtrodden and a concern for the vulnerability of children have been at the centre of Alan Parker's work since he burst on to the scene directing Jack Rosenthal's The Evacuees back in 1974. More recently, the low-born Evita Peron's desire to do something for the insulted and injured is clearly what redeemed her in Parker's eyes.

In Frank McCourt's memoir, Angela's Ashes, Parker has found an ideal subject - an emotionally truthful, more-or-less true story of hardship, injustice and the ill-treatment of children going on across the Irish Sea while the little evacuees of his first movie were undergoing temporary privation in Lancashire.

The events are seen through the eyes of Frankie, born in New York in 1929, the son of an alcoholic father (Robert Carlyle) from Northern Ireland, who exchanges the slums of Brooklyn for the slums of Limerick at the height of the Depression, after the death of a baby daughter. He takes with him his depressed wife (Emily Watson), six-year-old Frankie and another son, Malachy. The 15 years before Frankie returns to the States are a time of misery.

The movie establishes its central image at the outset - incessant rain pouring on a back alley - and over the next two-and-a-half hours we are told a Dickensian tale of squalor, guilt, neglect and humiliation. Primary colours rarely feature among the soupy browns, dark greens and greys of the rain-sodden Limerick conjured up by cinematographer Michael Seresin. What remains in the mind's eye resembles the black-and-white photographs Bert Hardy took for Picture Post in the Thirties.

Dad cannot hold a job down, drinks whatever he earns and leaves for England during the Second World War, never to return. Mam bears twins who die shortly after they learn to walk. The second to go, Eugene, keeps asking for his twin, Ollie, but as the narrator laconically observes: 'He died anyway.' Mam's mother and relatives are cold and spiteful. The Catholic church preaches a chilly gospel and cares little for the poor. Charity is doled out grudgingly. School is a training ground in prejudice and cruelty. This is the land James Joyce was describing when he wrote that 'Ireland is the old sow that eats its farrow' and is far removed from the exuberant working-class Dublin that Parker evoked in The Commitments.

Fortunately, the bleakness is occasionally illuminated by a touch of humour, a glimpse of hope, a gesture of kindness. Frank goes into hospital with near fatal typhoid and discovers Shakespeare. A teacher commends the solaces of literature and advises smart working-class lads to emigrate. A blind neighbour lets Frankie listen to her wireless. When Frankie cannot bring himself to go to confession, a kindly monk encourages him to pray to St Francis instead.

Not that the other people are bad or evil - they are merely the creations of an unjust society and a warped religion, and the sad, loving mother is never idealised. Her husband is a paycock, but she is no Juno. Parker, though, isn't making any obvious political points. Life is shown to be going on as indifferent to the folk of Limerick as the cold, swollen River Shannon that flows through the town.

Some of the earlier parts of the story seem overly compressed, the latter parts (the encounters with the consumptive middle-class girl and the moneylender) are a trifle pat, and Parker has not chosen McCourt's best masturbation scene, the one in which Frankie is comically at one with nature and history as he takes himself in hand on an ancient tower.

The performances, however, are excellent, especially as we might expect from Parker, those of the children, with Joe Breen, Ciarán Owens and Michael Legge outstanding as Frankie from six to 19.

What we miss in the movie is the voice of Frank McCourt, which is heard only in the intermittent voice-over narration. His wry humour and vivid turn of phrase make the book bearable. Without that authorial presence, the film is a somewhat depressing experience. Of course, we know that eventually, though not immediately after his return to New York at the end of the picture, Frank will find fame and fortune on a Dickensian scale.

fields.headline: Crisis on the wards
fields.standfirst: One of Britain's most famous doctors resurrected the NHS crisis
fields.trailText: Just as the 'flu "epidemic" was passing, Lord Winston's infamous comments in a New Statesman interview reopened the debate over the future of the NHS. Observer writers examine the most critical week of the 1999-2000 winter crisis.
fields.body:
It's not often that Downing Street likes to talk up an NHS crisis. But last weekend senior government figures made discreet calls to Sunday newspapers suggesting the NHS was under great strain because the flu outbreak was much worse than realised and heading towards an epidemic.

The Chief Medical Officer Liam Donaldson, reporters were told, was expected to reveal last week that the number of cases had spiralled to 200 per one hundred thousand - but the true number of cases was probably far higher and close to 'epidemic'.

The reason the Government was talking up a flu outbreak was simple. Reports to the NHS executive suggested elective surgery was grinding to a halt and the number of spare beds was close to zero. The NHS winter crisis, now a near annual event, had arrived.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn, one of the most media-savvy Cabinet Ministers, knew that the NHS was about to go on to the political front line. With bed occupancy so high and the number of intensive care beds and trained nurses so low, the Department of Health was on red alert for horror stories.

Ministers knew that big issues were certain to be reopened, including NHS funding. Milburn also knows how critical the NHS is to Labour's political identity. The NHS - in almost all polls - ranks as the most important issue facing voters. Yet by the middle of the week Milburn looked like he had survived the crisis. Reports were starting to arrive suggesting the flu crisis was ebbing. Milburn also knew on Friday he had figures showing that waiting lists had fallen by 8,000 during November. The corner looked to have been turned.

However, it was not an NHS horror story, let alone a skilfully aimed Opposition blow that resurrected the crisis. Instead it was an attack from one of Britain's most famous doctors, the Labour peer, Lord Winston. His remarks in the New Statesman were unambiguous and explosive, and he must have known their impact. The Government was engaged in a deceit about abolition of the internal market, he said, and warned that the NHS would deteriorate unless we pay more tax or have an insurance system.

On Friday, Alastair Campbell applied the screws using Winston's unethical revelations about Cherie Blair's pregnancy as a lever with which to force him to retract. Even his supposed recantation amounted to nothing since he again said: 'Successive governments - and this one included - have not yet paid sufficient attention to the needs for funding that are going to be required for the future.'

But Lord Winston drew sympathy from doctors, glad that someone so high-profile - and so close to Labour - had spoken out. Most of the medical bodies put out unprecedented statements of support - except for the comments on private medical insurance.

Milburn's insistence that the number of doctors was being increased met a quick rebuff from Barry Jackson, the president of the Royal College of Surgeons. He said that in surgery, and some other branches of medicine, the number of doctors is actually being reduced. The number of general surgery training posts is being cut by 25 this year, and in orthopaedics by 20. Overall the number of national training posts is being cut by 300 from April 2000.

'We desperately need more doctors, but at the present time the number of surgeons in training is being reduced,' said Jackson. He warned it could have a 'deleterious effect upon patient services'.

Professor Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, said the number of consultant posts needed to be doubled for them to offer adequate services. Consultants, working an average 62-hour week, were very demoralised. 'There are now more early retirements, partly because of the workload, partly because they are seen constantly as failing,' said Alberti.

The British Medical Association chairman Ian Bogle said: 'It's got progressively more difficult, winter by winter, to provide the healthcare that people need.'

Labour is also being stung by a backlash from raising voters' - and the medical profession's - expectations, and failing to deliver. 'You have the Prime Minister talking up people's expectations - you can have what you want where and when you want it - but people's expectations are being stretched when core service is stretching to cope,' said Stephen Thornton, the chief executive of the NHS Confederation, which represents the hospital trusts.

Part of the problem, according to Alberti, is simply that medical techniques are advancing fast, but the resources aren't available to provide them. 'A few years ago, if you had a stroke, you would have stayed at home, where as now we know you do much better in a stroke unit,' Alberti said. 'The Government has shot itself in its collective feet by not increasing resources sufficiently.'

But while doctors condemn Labour for not providing resources, they approve of many individual policies.

The internal market has been modified. National Service Frameworks and the National Institute of Clinical Excellence should go someway to ending the post-code lottery of healthcare. The biggest new hospital programme in the history of the NHS is under way; casualty departments are being modernised; nurses are being recruited back into the NHS and new services are being developed, such as the telephone service NHS direct.

But Labour's main commitment to reduce waiting lists has been widely panned for distorting clinical priorities, and even some of its innovations aren't clear winners. According to Julia Neuberger, head of the King's Fund, a leading think-tank on healthcare: 'Labour's record is very patchy. They have big ideas like the NHS Direct, which they haven't piloted or evaluated, so it's very difficult to tell where the improve ments lie.' The one point that doctors and Ministers agree on is that demand on the NHS is growing. In 1998-99 there were 450,000 extra operations for people on the waiting lists, 142,000 extra emergency cases and half a million extra outpatient appointments.

The pressure is now on Milburn to deliver. But on two issues he has been clear. He sees no role for an extension of private health insurance, and the NHS is still underfunded. He has also used the crisis skilfully to start making unusually public bids for massive extra cash. Negotiations are now under way on a further three-year spending programme, the first year of which will supersede the last year (2001-02) of the existing one. The first review covered this year, next year and the year thereafter, 2001-02, offering a cumulative £21bn. It gave the NHS real terms growth of 5.7 per cent, 4.5 per cent and 3.9 per cent in each successive year.

Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, has said the presumption will be that the figures announced for each department for 2001-02 will remain, but Milburn is reopening negotiations for 2001-02. He is seeking increases totalling more than 5 per cent in real term rises for three years. Milburn has not ruled out earmarked taxes for health - an 'NHS tax'. Referring to the difficulties in raising tax generally, he added: 'Many people would see it as a way out of the dilemma.'

Doctors, insistent that the drip feed of finance just perpetuates the crises, are determined that something radical must be done. The BMA - until recently completely wedded to the idea of a tax-only funded NHS - is considering ways, any ways, of getting more money into healthcare in Britain. BMA chairman Ian Bogle, refuses to rule out calling for more private health insurance, said: 'A few years ago, there's no way you would have got the chairman of the BMA going to his council saying we need to look at other ways of funding - and then getting a unanimous vote of support. The debate has changed, there's been a huge change in thinking on the NHS.'
