fields.headline: England miss gear change
fields.trailText: Bad news for those in the last chance saloon. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to calculate that the likes of Chris Adams and Mark Butcher are clinging on to their Test careers by the ends of well-bitten fingernails.
fields.body:
Bad news for those in the last chance saloon. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to calculate that the likes of Chris Adams and Mark Butcher are clinging on to their Test careers by the ends of well-bitten fingernails.

If the rain keeps falling as incessantly as it did yesterday at Centurion Park there may be no chance for them to produce that miraculous, redeeming innings that prompts a sudden re-evaluation of their worth as Test cricketers.

The rain was unrelenting from 11.40 onwards, five minutes before the scheduled delayed start. Umpires Hair and Koertzen called off proceedings at 2.00 pm. This should have been a frustration for the England bowlers, though the delay allowed Darren Gough's 'minor niggle' in the groin a chance for a rest.

It also permitted Dr Ali Bacher to explain at length the future of his treasured paceman Allan Donald, who will be having a break from international cricket.

The England bowlers should have been eager to atone for their performance on the first day. They were flattered by the scoreboard and it was another disturbing example of the frailty of this England side. In every Test there are crucial passages of play when the pattern of the match can be decided. The Australians, in particular, are quick to recognise these moments, and they have the capacity step up a gear during that hour or two.

The South Africans can do it as well, as they have shown in this series. Too often England falter when the door is ajar.

There was an example in Cape Town in the final session of the first day. England, if they had managed to lose no more than three wickets on that day would not have lost the game; they just might have won it. In stepped Donald; out went Stewart and Caddick. Five down. Initiative lost.

Here England had their chance on the first day in sublime bowling conditions: moist atmosphere, ball swinging and jagging off the pitch. At best South Africa could have been bowled out; if England had bowled adequately the home side should have been restricted to no more than 110 runs in their 45 overs.

Instead, they ended with 155-6 and England were grateful for one or two slack shots to take some of those wickets.

There is just time to atone - with four swift wickets today - if the weather relents. Even then the match will be in the balance; it might have been in Nasser Hussain's pocket.

fields.headline: Boon's boys slip through
fields.trailText: With the senior side continuing to disappoint the under-19 side remains a source of hope. England, 1998 Youth World Cup champions, scraped through to the Super League stages of this tournament in Colombo yesterday with a three-run victory against Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
With the senior side continuing to disappoint the under-19 side remains a source of hope. England, 1998 Youth World Cup champions, scraped through to the Super League stages of this tournament in Colombo yesterday with a three-run victory against Zimbabwe.

Having lost emphatically to West Indies on Thursday, England had to win if they were to avoid an ignominious place in the Plate League - their only win being against the Americas last Tuesday.

Up until the final four overs of the match most of those watching the game were resigned to such a fate. Zimbabwe had dominated the match from the start, allowing England only a paltry 187 for eight before proceeding to 163 for five in 45 overs.

However, Tim Murtagh and Nick Warren bowled heroically in their last two overs. Apparently oblivious to the tension in the ground, and driven on by adrenaline, they piled the pressure on to the Zimbabwean batsmen.

webTitle: West drives Africa and Benni to crossroads

fields.headline: West drives Africa and Benni to crossroads
fields.trailText: The African Nations Cup gets an unfairly bad press, although one can see why it does. Nigeria, one of the co-hosts of the tournament that starts on Saturday, is a tough place.
fields.body:
The African Nations Cup gets an unfairly bad press, although one can see why it does. Nigeria, one of the co-hosts of the tournament that starts on Saturday, is a tough place.

The British Foreign Office warns visitors against armed robbers, unsafe aeroplanes and piracy. If none of those get you, the police might. Oh, and more than two dozen Britons have been kidnapped in the Niger Delta so far this year, although all have been released unharmed, says the FO. The other co-host, Ghana, is a quieter country. However, when Samuel Kuffour of Bayern Munich went home to Accra for New Year his house was burgled by armed robbers, one of whom got shot in the arm.

To travel between Ghana and Nigeria you have to cross Togo and Benin and deal with customs officials, so always travel in a sponsor's private plane if you can (provided you've managed to get a visa). The Foreign Office does not warn visitors about bad driving or driving in the dark without lights, although both are major causes of death and injury in Africa, and, indeed, have kept a couple of potential players out of the present tournament.

Then there are the players themselves. The big challenge is getting them to turn up. It took Nigeria weeks to procure their 'Lucky Skipper', Nwankwo Kanu, from Arsenal, and even after his release from London he and travelling companion Celestine Babayaro, of Chelsea, mysteriously took four days to find the pre-tournament training camp in Spain.

And it was with the greatest reluctance that Leeds released their captain, Lucas Radebe, to South Africa. These three will be gone about five weeks. 'I just wish I could be in two places at once,' mused Radebe, or Radderby as he is known to British television commentators.

Procuring him was a cinch compared to the trouble South Africa had getting hold of Benni McCarthy, the 22-year-old striker who was player of the tournament at the last Nations Cup, in 1998. He had since retired from international football because he said it was interfering with his club game. What that meant was that Benni's Spanish club, Celta Vigo, told him to stop going to Africa or else.

African players who disappear for weeks to play in a tournament no one in Europe cares about sometimes find on returning to their club that someone has taken their peg in the changing room. So the squad list that South Africa faxed to the Confederation of African Football on Wednesday did not include Benni's name. But then Benni changed his mind.

On Thursday the South African FA announced that he would play after all. The deadline for registering players had expired, conceded Safa, but happily the fax it had sent to CAF had turned out to be illegible. Safa would have to send a new fax, this time, one got the impression, with Benni's name on it. Yet a few hours later the South African coach, Trott Moloto, said he did not want Benni. The player had volunteered too late.

Accordingly, South Africa, winners and runners-up in the last two Nations Cups, travel to this one without their Michael Owen.

Events like these make the tournament look like an irritating farce. 'Why,' western managers are asking, 'do they have to organise this thing in the middle of our league season? And do they really have to hold it every two years?' That is western arrogance. The Africans might as well ask why the Europeans have to organise league games in the middle of the Nations Cup.

The tournament is the only time Africans get to see top-class football in Africa. It matters to them. As Kanu told a Nigerian radio station, when Arsenal were hanging on to him: 'As soon as Arsenal release me, I will join the team. Nigeria is my fatherland and I am always happy to play for the Eagles.' (He's obviously not quite so happy training with them.)

Radebe asks: 'How could I refuse to play for my country in a tournament as important as the African Nations Cup?' And he points out that South Africans have waited decades for this. Arsenal seem to be saying that Kanu should play for them because they pay his salary. That is a narrow argument. Imagine, if you can stretch your imagination a little, how English fans would feel if Tony Adams, under contract to Eagle Cement of Nigeria, missed Euro 2000 because Eagle Cement had to play a fourth-round cup tie. Or if Michael Owen's employer, Orlando Pirates of Soweto, made him retire from the England team.

It is western clubs who are turning the Nations Cup into a farce. 'Africa matters,' said Richard Holbrooke, US ambassador to the United Nations, explaining why the organisation is dedicating this month to the continent. He says it because he knows that, to the west, Africa doesn't matter in the slightest. The Kanu affair is the least of it

fields.headline: Fergie, the last big boss
fields.trailText: Yes, Alex Ferguson said, he would grant me an interview but I had to be at Old Trafford for 9am on a Bank Holiday Monday. The celebrated early riser duly bounced in, saying that he needed only some five hours sleep a night. 'Like Margaret Thatcher,' I ventured. 'Don't compare me with that woman,' he snarled.
fields.body:
Yes, Alex Ferguson said, he would grant me an interview but I had to be at Old Trafford for 9am on a Bank Holiday Monday. The celebrated early riser duly bounced in, saying that he needed only some five hours sleep a night. 'Like Margaret Thatcher,' I ventured. 'Don't compare me with that woman,' he snarled.

Much as he might hate it, there is another similarity, though. No matter the - how shall we describe it? - advice offered by press or public about the image and performance of his football club, he is certain he knows best. And just as Thatcher was the last of the 'My Way' politicians disdainful of any need for spin doctors to sweeten the pill, so Ferguson may be the end of the line for off-message Manchester United managers.

After a fortnight which has proved that there's an awful lot of copy in Brazil, Ferguson will undoubtedly return to England refreshed and ready for a new round of jousting with Premiership, press and fellow managers. Expect a week of psychological point-scoring with Arséne Wenger in the run-up to next Monday's mouth-watering contest between United and Arsenal.

Like his team, Ferguson has hardly covered himself in glory in Rio, however. There was the public spat with a journalist and his defence of the indefensible in the shape of David Beckham's sending off. To the outside world, it has been a public relations nightmare. Ferguson might even been grateful for the night moves of the club's chief executive Martin Edwards last week.

Ferguson has never been averse to berating a journo in public 'pour encourager les autres'. Most stay onside out of fear that his angry tongue will turn on them and such overt displays help in that process. In addition, his policy of always supporting his players in public - with the impression cleverly given that it is much different in private - makes him a player's manager of the sort they want to sign and play for.

He has been criticised for such tactics of late, though Edwards's nocturnal affairs which were exposed in The Mirror when it was probably not the inflation rate in Brazil he was discussing with an enterprising young local lady, have occupied more of the attention of an alarmed plc board back in Britain.

Suffice to say that Edwards is unlikely to become United's third knight after Ferguson and Sir Bobby Charlton, whose function at the club as the cheery and acceptable face of Manchester United has been more valuable than ever of late. After all, there is only room for two knights on a chess team, which the club comes more to resemble as strategy on and off the field evolves with their growing world profile.

The word last week was that Edwards's sleazy indiscretions are also likely to cost him the new chairmanship of United plc and he may be forced to walk away - finally, having twice tried to sell out - with the consolation of his millions.

Ferguson, having won a battle over the finances of the club, both for his own salary and that of Roy Keane, wins again over a man with whom there has been little love lost. What may then change in the political climate at Old Trafford is that the flame of attention returns to Ferguson and he will have no-one else to deflect any heat.

What has been interesting in Rio is how bad results have made Ferguson fair game for criticism of his methods. Much more of the same back home, and he can expect some old scores to be settled in the media.

Not that he is likely to care. In that interview with me, he spoke of the need for a club to have a cause that drives them, whether it be to prove the press wrong or to respond with a victory to a chanting, antagonistic crowd fuelled by jealousy. He is likely to use the so-called 'Fiasco in Rio' as a rocket-up-the-backside launchpad for the rest of the season.

His results have made him perhaps the greatest manager of all in the English game, certainly assured him his place in the pantheon. As such, his methods are virtually beyond the reproach of any plc board. It is, after all, results rather than image that provide the best marketing tool for the merchandisers and keep the share price high.

What looks likely, though, is that when the time finally comes to appoint a successor to Sir Alex, the new man is likely to be more media-friendly - if not as adept as using it to his advantage - more likely to make things look and sound good; maybe a groomed New Coach rather than a growling Old Manager. Bearing in mind the growing global implications, the board's appointment will surely be more 'Our Way'.

Whoever it is, there is unlikely to be as much substance beneath, however. There are many who see Ferguson as a whinger, who grow annoyed by his justification of self and erring players, but this is a man who knows inside-out the game, its players and how to mould, meld and motivate them. As with any great sporting figure, we will miss him once he is gone.

webTitle: How the Parkes effect took root back in '79

fields.headline: How the Parkes effect took root back in '79
fields.standfirst: Paul Wilson  sees Howard Kendall's work bear fruit
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers' stunning cup victory at Anfield was the latest and most convincing example yet of the Tony Parkes effect. The Ewood Park stalwart has shed his customary caretaker label this time, but he still appears able to galvanise his players and maximise the team's potential in a way which proved quite beyond some of his illustrious predecessors.
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers' stunning cup victory at Anfield was the latest and most convincing example yet of the Tony Parkes effect. The Ewood Park stalwart has shed his customary caretaker label this time, but he still appears able to galvanise his players and maximise the team's potential in a way which proved quite beyond some of his illustrious predecessors.

Parkes is a modest man, naturally self-effacing, though not the sort to let anyone take liberties. Just like his team on the pitch, he stood up for himself at Liverpool by insisting Blackburn had not 'nicked' a result, but fully deserved their place in the fifth round by virtue of stout defending and incisive play on the break.

That was exactly how Blackburn's victory struck the watching Howard Kendall, who in addition to being voted Everton's manager of the millennium recently, can now number launching the Parkes managerial career among his various claims to fame. Ewood was where Kendall took his own first steps in management, taking over as player-manager in 1979 after being player-coach at Stoke, and he briefly played alongside Parkes in midfield before the latter hung up his boots to take charge of the youth team.

'Tony was always a great clubman and a tremendous pro,' Kendall recalled. 'As a player he was consistent, would never give anything less than his best, the type of guy you could depend on. I think he has brought those qualities to his spells in management over the years. You won't meet anyone who knows more about his players or what's good for Blackburn Rovers, and that's why the club has been able to turn to him so often.'

In one sense Blackburn have hardly been fair to Parkes over the years. Every time they have turned to him they have been in trouble, then after watching him effect an immediate improvement they have repeatedly turned to someone more famous as the next manager. Yet since that was always by Parkes' own wish, Blackburn have done the right thing by managing to hold on to a valued employee whose heart is obviously in the club.

'It's so easy to lose people like that,' Kendall said. 'I've seen it happen time after time. You get a loyal clubman doing a good job who is persuaded to take over as manager because he passionately wants to help, then the club feels obliged to sack him when things don't work out and the new manager wants a fresh start. I think it says a lot about Blackburn and Tony Parkes that the two are still together.

'But Blackburn is still unique in spite of everything that's happened over the last 10 years. When I was there the streets out side were still cobbled and the club's financial plight would always be the main topic of discussion at board meetings. I don't suppose it's like that now, but the great thing is that the people haven't changed. Blackburn is still run by mostly the same people, and they all love the club.'

Parkes certainly falls into that category, having been so impressed by Jack Walker's lavish refurbishment of the club he happily suppressed his own managerial ambitions. 'If Jack Walker hadn't come along and transformed the club there might have been a time, if we had stayed a mid-table first division side, when I might have been offered the job and would probably have jumped at it,' he said. 'But I've never been under any illusions. I never wanted the club to be small and unambitious just so I could be the manager. What we have at Blackburn now is incomparably better than what we had in the old days.'

Walker's millions proved a mixed blessing for recent Blackburn managers - Kenny Dalglish invested them astutely, others seemed to suffer from lottery-winners syndrome in allowing instant wealth to cloud their judgement - and though Parkes has made the occasional purchase he is still to be judged in the transfer market. His knack of always appearing to know which players to pick and which to leave out is not just down to hard work and close attention on the training pitch; it also helps that he has not brought any of the players to the club. The situation becomes more complicated if you are a manager whose has spent a few million on a striker who can't score or a defender prone to lapses of concentration. Parkes has all that to come.

Walker has said that once he gets Blackburn back into the Premiership he envisages winding down his financial support, so it sounds like a case of now or never for Parkes.

'I'm sure he'll cope,' Kendall said. 'From what I saw at Liverpool he has no worries on the playing side, I was very impressed with the way he prepared Blackburn for that game. Money is a trickier thing altogether. It's not as easy to spend as some people think, but I've never met a manager who didn't want it.'

webTitle: Sheffield Four will only earn contempt

fields.headline: Sheffield Four will only earn contempt
fields.standfirst: FOOTBALL
fields.trailText: With most of Westminster focused on the crisis in the NHS and whether or not Cherie will have a caesarean, Sheffield MPs have found time out to demand that Wednesday manager Danny Wilson be sacked.
fields.body:
With most of Westminster focused on the crisis in the NHS and whether or not Cherie will have a caesarean, Sheffield MPs have found time out to demand that Wednesday manager Danny Wilson be sacked.

This is not the first time that politics and football have hit the headlines. Last year we had the Prime Minister telling the world live on TV that Hoddle should be sacked as England manager. His press secretary's denial that Blair had said anything of the sort was about as believable as Blair's claims to be a genuine Newcastle United fan. The reason they denied the story was that Blair did not want to be seen to be getting involved in the Hoddle affair. This is highlighted by the scorn poured on the four Sheffield MPs who have demanded the sacking of Danny Wilson.

I believe Blair was entitled to his views on the England manager. Everyone else in the country had a view and when asked a question it would have looked ridiculous if, as an alleged football fan, he hadn't given one himself.

The case of the Sheffield Four - David Blunkett, Clive Betts, Joe Ashton and Bill Michie - is entirely different. No one would object much if, on BBC Radio Sheffield, one of the MPs had been asked if Wilson should be sacked and had said yes. What people object to is the calculated conspiracy of the quartet in making a public statement to the media hours before yesterday's important match at home to Bradford.

Sheffield Wednesday fans, who may or may not agree with the MPs, will not be impressed with such blatant political interference in the club. Most fans think politicians use football for their own ends and, like little boys and girls, should be seen and not heard.

I know for a fact that Joe Ashton is a genuine supporter of the Owls, pays for his own season ticket and does not blag freebies like some MPs. Ashton may think that now he's decided to quit politics since being caught in a Thai massage parlour he should become more involved in football. But being a genuine fan of the club does not give an MP the right to make demands on the board in connection with the playing staff or the manager.

I can't say that I ever recall having a discussion with Bill Michie about football, nor for that matter with David Blunkett. As a Cabinet Minister he should have known better than to get involved in such a silly stunt. He will be much better employed working on implementing New Labour's education election pledges.

Roy Hattersley, Wednesday's most famous fan, who has much more media savvy, has not been slow to exploit the situation; he released a statement contradicting the MPs and stating that Danny Wilson should not be sacked. Knowing Hattersley he probably doesn't believe that but he knows when someone else has made a gaffe. He will be secretly pleased to see Blunkett in trouble given his recent political spats with him over education policy. Hattersley, being a wise old bird, will also know that the MPs demands will probably ensure Wilson stays on as manager.

Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's press secretary, has not had a good week. It started badly when his beloved Burnley got stuffed by Coventry. Having seen off the debacle over Mike Tyson and with his hands full over the NHS crisis, the last thing that Campbell would have wanted was a row over football. Up until now New Labour and football have had a long honeymoon. Indeed it is likely that these four MPs thought that it was 'very New Labour' to demand the sacking of a football manager. They couldn't be more wrong. Campbell and Blair will be rightly furious and football fans will have even more contempt for politicians than before.

fields.headline: Marsh on Manchester City
fields.trailText: I think Manchester City are better equipped than Fulham overall - at the moment anyway - to get into the Premiership. And in Joe Royle they've got a manager who has been there and done it. He's been there with Everton and he's won promotion with Oldham. He has an outstanding knowledge of the game and was a great appointment by the City board. It's my firm belief that given the time and the resources Joe Royle can make City great again. They have to get over being stuffed 5-2 by Leeds last weekend, but then Fulham also had a devastating loss against Leicester in the Worthington Cup in midweek. The fact that today's match is at Maine Road is obviously a plus for City and so if I had to pick a winner I would go for City. A good result could catapult them all the way to promotion.

webTitle: Players to charge for TV goals

fields.headline: Players to charge for TV goals
fields.trailText: English football's top stars such as Michael Owen and Ryan Giggs are ready to cash in by copyrighting their favourite goals and charging fees every time 'their' strike is shown on screen.
fields.body:
English football's top stars such as Michael Owen and Ryan Giggs are ready to cash in by copyrighting their favourite goals and charging fees every time 'their' strike is shown on screen.

According to lawyers, agents and players themselves, the Premiership's big names could soon mount legal challenges to try to win a larger share of income from the sale of television rights by registering spectacular strikes as their own 'intellectual property'.

It would mean their being paid for each occasion a particular goal is used by their own club or broadcasters for promotional purposes. In essence, similar to actors' 'repeat' fees.

Top players such as Owen and Giggs could earn a fortune if goals - like Owen's much-screened England effort against Argentina and Giggs's FA Cup semi-final winner for Manchester United against Arsenal - racked up royalties.

The likelihood of claiming cash for the screening of special goals was just one possibility advanced at a recent conference on the commercialisation of football held in London. Also on the agenda were new efforts by players to earn a cut from the sale of replica team shirts and other club merchandise.

Wimbledon skipper Robbie Earle, among those addressing the one-day seminar, said the distribution of TV cash was now a hot topic among players. 'Players like Michael Owen, David Beckham and Alan Shearer are on a par with the likes of Tiger Woods or Michael Jordan as the biggest names in sport in their own countries. As the Americans have been able to control particular images of themselves and use them in marketing, so I believe it will not be too long before our footballers do likewise, including copyrighting goals.

'People are forever talking to me, for example, about my having scored the first goal for Jamaica in a World Cup finals two years ago. If I had a pound for every time that goal had been on television, I would have earned a lot of money. But it's not just about cash, it's about players taking control of their own affairs.'

Chris Farnell, a Manchester-based sports lawyer specialising in intellectual property cases, also feels that the prospect of players taking action is very real. Farnell's firm - Halliwell Landau - represents more than 20 footballers and believes there is nothing in law to stop players taking on the game's authorities.

'There is,' Farnell said, 'a legal principle that what is worth copying is worth protecting and it's certainly the case that the best goals are shown on TV over and over again. They're used to sell things such as satellite coverage and it's only fair that players should try to get a percentage of that money from the broadcasters. Under copyright law there is plenty of room to argue that a goal is something particular to a player and he should have the power to exploit it. I won't even hazard a guess on the sums of money that are potentially at stake, but I do believe that it may well happen in the near future.'

Only two top current players - Paul Gascoigne and Alan Shearer - are thought to have been able to insert clauses in their contracts allowing them to take a percentage of merchandising income.

The other notable case featured Eric Cantona, whose retirement from playing was soured by a bitter dispute with Manchester United. He claimed he was owed money from the sale of goods bought by fans on the strength of his appeal. The reluctance of United officials to pay him the £1million he was seeking led to his decision to cut ties without bidding an immediate farewell United fans.

The Observer has learned that football's authorities are starting to take commercial player power into account. Officials from the Premier League and the Football Association have been in discussion with the Professional Footballers Association for the past year about amending the standard contract players have to sign.

The new version, which may be introduced before the end of this season, is to include additional clauses allowing players more lee way in getting a share of the merchandising revenues.

But Premier League spokesman Mike Lee last night tried to swiftly dismiss attempts by players to copyright their goals.

'It's a nonsense,' he remarked. 'Under the collective negotiating agreement ownership of the rights for Premiership games rests with the League and the teams within it. This is just not going to happen. Many ideas are discussed but few are worth taking seriously. This is one of those.'

Farnell, however, takes a directly opposite view. 'This whole area of copyrighting skills and performances is obviously untried, not tested in law. There will have to be a test case to establish the principle but there's nothing in law to rule it out. It will happen.'

fields.headline: Marsh on Fulham
fields.trailText: I have seen Fulham play quite a lot this season and at the moment they are just short of Premiership quality. I wouldn't want to undermine Paul Bracewell, because I recognise that he has done a fantastic job as manager since taking over from Kevin Keegan, but I'm pretty sure that Mohamed al-Fayed is aiming for bigger things. It would be difficult for Bracewell to sign a Ravanelli or a Juninho and no matter how well he is doing, which he is, I think that Fayed is probably looking to bring in a Ruud Gullit-type manager. If they lose this afternoon, following that defeat at Filbert Street on Wednesday, I can't see them getting back into contention this season. From my point of view it would be nice if the match could be a draw, but, as I say, with the crowd behind them I reckon City may just have the edge.

webTitle: Richards - no move, no moan, few regrets

fields.headline: Richards - no move, no moan, few regrets
fields.trailText: For Southampton's defenders preparing for today's game at Newcastle, it has been a case of out of the frying pan or into the fire.
fields.body:
For Southampton's defenders preparing for today's game at Newcastle, it has been a case of out of the frying pan or into the fire.

You can almost hear Dave Jones giving Saints' injury update: 'Doddy's got an ankle, Deano's Achilles should be okay but Claus has got a frying pan.' It's one way of brightening up the team news.

Claus Lundekvam's bizarre back injury - sustained while cooking his breakfast and over-reaching for said cooking utensil - clears the way for Dean Richards to return to the ground he had hoped to call home.

And Southampton could do with as many defenders as possible against an in-form partnership of Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson. Newcastle have the hottest home form around, unbeaten in front of their own supporters under Bobby Robson and scoring 14 goals in their last four games.

Former England under-21 captain Richards, signed on a Bosman free from Wolves last summer, has been one of the bright spots for Southampton in a nose-diving season. After missing his first game of the campaign with an ankle injury in last Saturday's FA Cup defeat at Aston Villa, Richards is determined to show the Newcastle supporters what they are missing. Because, but for a managerial whim, Richards could have been lining up for Newcastle today.

The classy central defender was closely monitored by Liverpool and Arsenal last year after announcing he was to leave Wolves when his contract expired at the season's end. Yet it was Newcastle he came closest to joining after meeting Ruud Gullit last March, well before Southampton offered him his Premiership break.

Richards, 25, was ready to pay back Gullit for an 'outrageous' discourtesy when Newcastle visited The Dell in August. Richards' duly starred in a 4-2 win which eased the Dutchman towards the exit door.

Richards, having started his career with hometown club Bradford, became Wolves' record buy when signing for £1.85 million five years ago. But it was always his intention to reach the Premiership sooner rather than later and, with Wolves missing promotion last year, he would have loved to join Newcastle. He has since settled well at Southampton and is enjoying his life and his football. But there is a thought for what-might-have-been.

'I actually spoke to Ruud Gullit and I don't really know what happened next,' said Richards. 'I went up to St James's the week before transfer deadline and he said he'd get things moving straight away. And then I never heard another thing.

'I was gutted. I'd been up to a game, and sat and watched in this marvellous stadium, where the atmosphere was incredible. It's a great club and it would have been a great move for me at the time. I was devastated. I spoke to Newcastle's chairman and it was a matter of waiting until after the weekend because the deadline was coming up.'

When the phone went quiet, Richards saw out his time at Molineux and took up Southampton's offer to join them in the close season. Lo and behold, the fixture schedule soon offered him another meeting with Gullit.

'Obviously when he was still manager it spurred me on a great deal. When Newcastle came down to The Dell, I wanted to show him what he'd missed. We really turned them over in the second half. The way I was treated by Ruud Gullit - it was outrageous, really. I couldn't believe he'd just left me like that.

'But now he's gone, there's no bitterness. That episode was between me and that manager, not me and Newcastle, the club. Obviously Newcastle are a bigger club than Southampton. But I've no regrets on the choices I've made.'

fields.headline: Yorke call-up blow for United
fields.trailText: Manchester United could be without Dwight Yorke for as long as seven weeks if Trinidad & Tobago use Fifa powers to force his international release next month.
fields.body:
Manchester United could be without Dwight Yorke for as long as seven weeks if Trinidad & Tobago use Fifa powers to force his international release next month.

In an echo of Arsenal's recent wrangle with Nigeria over Nwankwo Kanu, Trinidad are considering using Fifa regulations to secure Yorke for their World Cup preliminary matches which follow next month's Gold Cup, the biennial tournament for North America and the Caribbean.

Trinidad manager Richard Braithwaite, speaking to The Observer last night, said he would press for Yorke's involvement 'within the Fifa regulations' - which means as many games as they like. 'We would like the English based players for as many matches as possible. I spoke to Sir Alex Ferguson two weeks ago, and we want to reach a sensible compromise. But these are Fifa competitions with certain rules and regulations to be considered.'

Fifa forbid more than seven international call-ups per calendar year - but a special clause requires 'the compulsory release' of players for any additional matches in World Cup qualifying. 'We prefer to negotiate directly with the clubs,' says Braithwaite, 'but the guidelines must be recognised.' He must name his Gold Cup squad by 28 January.

The England-based players likely to be affected are Yorke, West Ham's Shaka Hislop, Nottingham Forest's Stern John and Chester City's Angus Eve and Kamu Laird.

Trinidad's Gold Cup programme opens on 13 February against Mexico. Two days later they face Guatemala before possible knockout games up to 20 February. World Cup qualifiers begin on March 4 against Netherlands Antilles - and could extend to four more games this season. Regional World Cup games are scheduled for six weekends between 4 March and 13 May. If involved in both competitions, Yorke could miss up to 10 Premiership matches.

webTitle: No point complaining about cosmic call-ups

fields.headline: No point complaining about cosmic call-ups
fields.trailText: When it comes to stars putting their countries on the world football map through their success in other environments, Liberia's renowned George Weah is one of the first names to spring to mind. But even Weah, now on loan at Chelsea from Milan - where his achievements include that of once being voted the world player of the year - might consider that he's in very good company.
fields.body:
When it comes to stars putting their countries on the world football map through their success in other environments, Liberia's renowned George Weah is one of the first names to spring to mind. But even Weah, now on loan at Chelsea from Milan - where his achievements include that of once being voted the world player of the year - might consider that he's in very good company.

I am hard pressed to think of any foreign stars in the Premiership who are doing more to stimulate interest in English football than Morocco's Mustapha Hadji and Youseff Chippo at Coventry, South Africa's Lucas Radebe at Leeds and Nigeria's Nwankwo Kanu at Arsenal. However, there is a price to be paid for the fascinating ultra-cosmopolitan element that such men have brought to our game - as will be emphasised in the next few weeks, when a number of the players from countries outside Europe and South America will be missing from their club teams in order to play for their nations in the African Nations Cup in Ghana and Nigeria, and the Gold Cup in Miami, Los Angeles and San Diego.

It says much about their impact in England that their enforced absence has generally not gone down very well among their club managers. Having lost two players of the calibre of Hadji and Chippo, I feel I have been harder hit than anyone.

My own view on the matter, though, is quite philosophical. While I hate to think how many Coventry matches these two might miss - the African Nations Cup is from 22 January to 13 February -I think the point has to be made that, as I was aware that this was liable to happen when I signed the pair, I can hardly moan about it now.

And let us get it straight - these are not 'tin pot' tournaments. To those nations concerned they are highly important and deserve to be respected. But if there is one justified bone of contention from managers and the clubs it concerns the rule that we must release players two weeks before the start of the competitions.

Obviously, I can appreciate the importance of national teams having their players together for as long as possible but the African Nations Cup and Gold Cup take place at a time in the season when the players are already at peak fitness - there has to be room for compromise.

For example, it was difficult to understand the stance of the Nigerian Federation over Kanu, who only became available to play for Arsenal against Leicester last Sunday on the intervention of the country's High Commisoner in London. It seemed that we at Coventry had experienced better luck in getting Hadji and Chippo back for yesterday's match against Wimbledon.

I initially asked Hadji if it would be possible for Chippo and him to return to England from Rabat for this game; he made the request personally to the Moroccan Federation; and they, conscious of the pair's popularity in England, seemed happy to agree to it. However, on Thursday night, the Moroccan coach said 'no' on the grounds that they might get injured.

All of which has inevitably made me more conscious than ever of the need to integrate competitions such as the African Nations Cup and Gold Cup into the world soccer calendar more smoothly. In view of the tremendous talent in the countries concerned - and especially throughout Africa - the potential problems for clubs prepared to give players the chance to make a name for themselves in the more traditional professional football strongholds can surely only get bigger.

I have to admit that the challenge of harmonising the commitments of national teams with those of club sides would not be something I'd like to tackle. If we have to have international matches mid-season (and consequently club matches postponed), it cannot be beyond the realms of possibility for Fifa to get them all played in one or two special 'international months' simultaneously throughout the world, as opposed to a number of separate 'international weeks'.

In terms of skill, there can be no better advertisement for African players than Kanu. If anybody epitomises the view of Nigerians as the African equivalents of the Brazilians, it is him. He does not really come from Nigeria as far as I am concerned - he comes from another planet called Cosmic Football.
fields.bodyText: When it comes to stars putting their countries on the world football map through their success in other environments, Liberia's renowned George Weah is one of the first names to spring to mind. But even Weah, now on loan at Chelsea from Milan - where his achievements include that of once being voted the world player of the year - might consider that he's in very good company. I am hard pressed to think of any foreign stars in the Premiership who are doing more to stimulate interest in English football than Morocco's Mustapha Hadji and Youseff Chippo at Coventry, South Africa's Lucas Radebe at Leeds and Nigeria's Nwankwo Kanu at Arsenal. fields.headline: For the love of Rodney
fields.standfirst: Fans worshipped him and, even at 55, Mr Marsh will tell you why
fields.trailText: Can Rodney Marsh, I wonder, remember his first game in the Football League for Fulham? 'Against Aston Villa. 1963. At Craven Cottage,' he fires back immediately. 'We won 1-0. And I scored the goal.' Was it a good goal? 'No, it was a brilliant goal. Right-foot volley, 25 yards, top corner. In the 61st minute.'
fields.body:
Can Rodney Marsh, I wonder, remember his first game in the Football League for Fulham? 'Against Aston Villa. 1963. At Craven Cottage,' he fires back immediately. 'We won 1-0. And I scored the goal.' Was it a good goal? 'No, it was a brilliant goal. Right-foot volley, 25 yards, top corner. In the 61st minute.'

Marsh, at 55, has lost none of the engaging brashness that an East End upbringing infused in him and marked him out in the Sixties and Seventies as one of the English game's greatest ever entertainers, a player who revelled in his genius rather than cloaked it in the self-effacement of a Moore or Charlton. He loved football with a passion - still does - as his recollection of another goal bears out.

Now he is addressing the greatest thing he ever did on a football field, having at first declined on the grounds that he did so many great things it was impossible to choose. He relents to tell the story of his equalising goal in Third Division Queen's Park Rangers' 3-2 1967 League Cup final win over a formidable West Bromwich Albion side. 'They were a tremendous team and were 2-0 up at half-time against the old scallywags of the Third Division.

'I picked up a long pass out of defence, about 40 yards from their goal, turned my marker, went to the left, went to the right, beat a couple of other players along the way and then suddenly, from 25 yards, just hit a shot that skimmed across the Wembley surface, hit the inside of a post and went in. There was pandemonium. And I can still actually remember the flow of adrenalin and blood through the veins in my throat. I thought my head was going to explode.'

Fortunately, his cranium withstood the pressure and he graced the English game for 10 more years as he moved from QPR to Manchester City and then back to Craven Cottage in 1976 for a valedictory season in Fulham's famous showbiz side that also included George Best - 'the greatest footballer who ever lived' - and Bobby Moore - 'a lovely man, a real gentleman and a privilege to play with'. After that he carried on playing in the United States for the Tampa Bay Rowdies, scoring 48 goals in 94 games between 1976-79, and coached New York United and Carolina Lightnin' before club football in the US 'folded under the strain of not being competitive'. The eve of a meeting between two of his old clubs - Manchester City against Fulham in today's key First Division fixture at Maine Road - seemed an appropriate moment to invite him to indulge in a little reflection and he proved the most amiable of company over coffee in a cafe close to his Wimbledon home - before driving off in his Porsche to play tennis.

Marsh's surprisingly modest haul of nine international caps almost certainly reflected his insistence on playing his own game. Was he, perhaps, a difficult player to coach? 'I was an impossible player to coach. I always like to be completely honest in assessing myself and the faults I have - as well as the good things - and part of my philosophy as a footballer was that the other 21 players were there to support me. That sounds arrogant, I know, but that's the way I looked at football. They were all there as extras in a play, and I was the star. They had to come along to be my supporting cast. But that's a negative thing as well.'

Returning to the subject later, he says: 'I always felt that coaching was only for certain players. I didn't believe that coaching was for me. Creative players cannot be restricted to doing mundane team things. You have to let talented players like Glenn Hoddle or Matthew Le Tissier play. You cannot tell them to go and chase the full-back or come back goal-side of so-and-so. Every time I heard that from managers and coaches I just switched off. My energy was needed to create things. Anybody can be a destructive player.'

He was, though, not entirely incapable of learning from others and admits that when he started at Fulham in 1962 he was in awe of Johnny Haynes, famously the country's first £100-a-week player. 'What I learnt particularly from him was passing, long-range and short-range. He always had the same attitude, he was never sloppy. He hit a 50-yard pass with the same deliberation that he hit a five-yard pass. His standards were incredibly high, both in what he asked of himself and of others.'

But it is as a maverick genius that Marsh will be best remembered, the man who arrived at Manchester City in March 1972 when the club were leading the First Division and proved such a disconcerting presence that they were caught by the pack. Accurate?

'Very accurate. I changed the way Manchester City played football. When I joined them they were a well-oiled machine, well coordinated, well organised. But what they didn't have, and I hate to say this, was star quality and that was what I was supposed to provide. And although I provided it, it was to the detriment of team play. They started to play around me and we lost the focus of what we were trying to do. I hold my hand up to say I was responsible for City losing the championship in 1972.

'Having said this, I played some incredibly brilliant football at Manchester City. I didn't sustain it - and nor did the team - but on occasions, a lot of occasions, we played magnificently.'

He says he played his best football 'in a team environment' during his time at QPR, after he left Fulham in 1965 and before joining Manchester City in 1972. 'There was a time during the period from 1967 to 1969 when QPR were unbeatable. It was the old Third Division, then the old Second Division, and we got promoted from both - and won the League Cup.

'We would go away from home and beat teams by huge scores. I remember once we travelled to Mansfield, who were a tough team at home, and people were saying this was the end of the QPR run and that Rodney Marsh was going to get kicked all over the pitch. We beat them 7-1.'

These days Marsh divides his time between his base in Wimbledon and the family home in Odessa, Florida, where his wife lives permanently. He says that although he remains loyally British - 'You can take the boy out of the East Ender, but you can't take the East Ender out of the boy' - he cannot help liking the quality of life in America. 'It's what I call the 5.30 syndrome. At 5.30[pm] in London on any given day it's usually overcast and damp and you're either on your way home from work or in the pub. In America, you're going out to play nine holes of golf or to have a game of tennis or to swim before you have a barbecue at 7.30.'

When in Britain, he works for Sky's Soccer Saturday programme as a pundit who is predictably forthright; in America, he works for his son, Jonathan, who has a group of Tampa-based companies whose interests range from public relations to property. As an extension of his son's businesses he has helped to set up a management company in Britain that will take Soccer Saturday on the road, starting with a show in Camberley on 2 March. The project will, incidentally, support the Bobby Moore Fund for Imperial Cancer Research.

Marsh's has already been a rich and varied life, and there is more to come. The Poplar lad's done all right.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: go fix ends Brazil 2006 bid
fields.body:
go fix ends Brazil 2006 bid

So why were Manchester United really in Rio? According to Gerson, Brazil's 1970 World Cup winner, they had a clear focus. 'If the foreign games were good, the Brazilian fans would have stayed to watch,' he wrote in a newspaper column last week. 'But they weren't. United came here to drink whisky, make the most of the sun and see if our liquor is as good as theirs. What they did was a joke. They were rubbish.'

Gerson's comments - he also called Real Madrid 'jokers' and accused Al Nassr of playing 'grotesque Arabian football' - came a day after Eurico Miranda, director of defeated finalists Vasco da Gama, boasted that not a single United player was good enough for his team. But Miranda's famed arrogance may now have backfired: it seems his misbehaviour at the Maracana last Wednesday has cost Brazil, and Gerson, their dream of playing host to the 2006 World Cup.

The incident came after Vasco's 2-1 win over Necaxa when Miranda's son was refused entry into the team dressing room by Fifa officials. His father reacted by setting Vasco's 'security men' on the officials, leaving chief media officer Ricardo Setyon with a dislocated shoulder. Fifa confirmed that Miranda, who last year caused a match to be abandoned when his men tried to attack a referee, will now face disciplinary action.

Fifa have also taken note of the way supporters seeking tickets for last Friday's final were dealt with: four ticket windows opened for 40,000 hot, angry supporters, resulting in several injuries. 'This is normal,' admitted the Brazilian Football Confederation afterwards, 'there was big demand.' United's efforts in Rio on behalf of the England 2006 campaign may well have been 'rubbish' - but Brazil have left their own bid dead in the water.

George, come home

George Weah's former Milan team-mates have asked the striker - on loan at Chelsea - to 'come home'. The request came just one day after Weah began by scoring the winner against Spurs. On the same night, Milan lost 3-2 to Inter . 'The players at Milan want me back,' says George. 'I spoke to some of them on the telephone after Wednesday's game and Paolo [Maldini] said: "We need you back and we miss you", and that I was good for the team. They said they hoped I could come back as soon as possible.'

Wide-eyed Hammer misses the point

First Alex Ferguson tried to lure teenage sensation Joe Cole away from Upton Park. Now Newcastle United president Sir John Hall wants to do the same with Michael Carrick, the latest adolescent prodigy to emerge from the Hammers' youth scheme. When the Irons visited St James' Park on 3 January, Hall came into their dressing room before kick-off. He chatted to Shaka Hislop, the keeper he released to West Ham, before asking: 'So where's this lad Michael Carrick everybody's talking about?' Once he found the youngster, our sources explain, Hall enthusiastically extolled the virtues of Newcastle as a club and city to the attentive 18-year-old. Carrick, who was coveted by all of the North-East's big three as a product of Wallsend Boys Club where Alan Shearer and Peter Beardsley honed their skills, engaged in polite conversation with his elderly admirer. Hall, however, will be crushed to learn that as soon as he left, Carrick turned to his team-mates and asked: 'Who was that, then?'

Betis lock-in latest

Desperate times in the primera division. Spanish side Betis, just two points off the relegation zone, have been locked inside a hotel by their furious president until they win a league game. The imprisonment, agreed by Manuel Ruiz de Lopera with coach Carlos Griguol, came after Betis crashed out of the cup on Wednesday to tiny second division Merida. It's the latest in several attempts to get the team in order - de Lopera has already tried offering win bonuses of between £10,000 and £40,000 per player, but all to no effect. The players' first chance to get out of jail comes this afternoon against Athletic de Bilbao.

Anelka: French rap music and me

With Nicolas Anelka now injured for two months (video footage of his operation available on the internet at http://www.marca.es/ he's found plenty of time to maintain his own personal web-site, www.nicolasanelka.net.Free from the 'interfering medium' of press interpretation, Nicolas speaks directly to his many fans about why he left Arsenal. 'The Arsenal players really drove me crazy. They would never let me play my French rap music, which they ought to have done because it is so good.' Nicolas also explains why he took and missed the penalty that cost Real Madrid victory over Corinthians - it was his agent-brother Didier's idea: 'Besides, Hierro had missed a couple and Savio, next in line, was hesitating. So I had a go. Anyway, we drew 2-2 and both goals were mine'.

fields.headline: South Africa deserve WorldCup
fields.trailText: Without wishing to appear disloyal or sound unpatriotic, I have to say that the South Africans have a very good case for staging the 2006 World Cup finals.
fields.body:
Without wishing to appear disloyal or sound unpatriotic, I have to say that the South Africans have a very good case for staging the 2006 World Cup finals.

I know we in England are desperate to beat South Africa, Morocco, Brazil and Germany for the right to host the finals, and nothing would give me greater pleasure as an Englishman than to have the World Cup here again.

But I doubt that the finals would have anything like the same sort of impact on our development as a nation as they would on South Africa.

I have just returned from a short visit to the country where I saw the England cricket team lose again. But the main purpose of my visit was to look at the football facilities in South Africa, which have come on in leaps and bounds since the apartheid state was dismantled.

I remember taking Crystal Palace there in 1993, when we became the first 'white' team to play a black side - Kaiser Chiefs. We won both games comfortably, but I very much doubt if an English team would win now.

The new professionalism in the game, the ability of South African players and the huge support of the people means the level and quality of football is not far behind Europe and South America.

Pele once predicted that an African country would win the World Cup by the year 2000 - I would say that was too optimistic but only by six years. The will to win is incredible. We have seen it from their rugby and cricket teams in the past, but football is the number one game.

There are four professional clubs in Cape Town, all regularly attracting crowds of more than 20,000 and there is huge interest in English football. The African Nations Cup starts this week and there will be unprecedented interest from the rest of the world.

A few years ago you might have had a handful of scouts from European clubs out there, but now there will be plenty going to see if they can discover another Lucas Radebe or Quinton Fortune, who has just started to make his mark at Manchester United. There are scores of other talented African players in the European game.

Ajax and Feyenoord have set up academies in South Africa and Ghana, and French clubs have similar set-ups in Senegal and Burkina Faso. I see no reason why English clubs could not do the same. If clubs like West Ham can manage an academy in Australia, for example, why not South Africa, which is far more accessible?

The players are certainly good enough, and they are mentally very tough as you would expect from their experiences. The coaching set-up from grassroots level upwards is first-class in South Africa. The violent crime is something that concerns many, and Sir Bobby Charlton, who will be in Ghana this week to promote England's 2006 bid at the Confederation of African Football conference, voiced his reservations again this week.

I am sure that if they get the World Cup, a major security operation will be put in place. After all, they have had a rugby World Cup without any serious problems.

My one concern is the inadequate transport system. That apart, the rest of the infrastructure is in place and a lot of hotels are being built, whether they get the World Cup or not.

There is a great deal of campaigning going on, and there is a structure and professionalism to their football that was not there 10 years ago. I remember back then someone was appointed national coach simply because he had the same name as a former Norwich player - obviously he had not pointed out to his employers that he was not a leading former professional!

That could not happen now, not least because the knowledge of and interest in English football is phenomenal. Premiership games are shown most nights of the week, and last weekend I was able to watch Fulham's superb FA Cup win over Wimbledon broadcast live while I was waiting for a flight.

So while I would love to see England win the right to host the World Cup in 2006, I would not be too disappointed if it was awarded to South Africa.

The people have a fierce pride in their country and what they are trying to do after so many unhappy years is positive. They really believe having the World Cup would take them forwards as a nation.

Can we say the same in England?
fields.bodyText: Without wishing to appear disloyal or sound unpatriotic, I have to say that the South Africans have a very good case for staging the 2006 World Cup finals. I know we in England are desperate to beat South Africa, Morocco, Brazil and Germany for the right to host the finals, and nothing would give me greater pleasure as an Englishman than to have the World Cup here again. But I doubt that the finals would have anything like the same sort of impact on our development as a nation as they would on South Africa. I have just returned from a short visit to the country where I saw the England cricket team lose again. But the main purpose of my visit was to look at the football facilities in South Africa, which have come on in leaps and bounds since the apartheid state was dismantled. I remember taking Crystal Palace there in 1993, when we became the first 'white' team to play a black side - Kaiser Chiefs. We won both games comfortably, but I very much doubt if an English team would win now. The new professionalism in the game, the ability of South African players and the huge support of the people means the level and quality of football is not far behind Europe and South America. Pele once predicted that an African country would win the World Cup by the year 2000 - I would say that was too optimistic but only by six years. The will to win is incredible. We have seen it from their rugby and cricket teams in the past, but football is the number one game. There are four professional clubs in Cape Town, all regularly attracting crowds of more than 20,000 and there is huge interest in English football. The African Nations Cup starts this week and there will be unprecedented interest from the rest of the world. A few years ago you might have had a handful of scouts from European clubs out there, but now there will be plenty going to see if they can discover another Lucas Radebe or Quinton Fortune, who has just started to make his mark at Manchester United. There are scores of other talented African players in the European game. Ajax and Feyenoord have set up academies in South Africa and Ghana, and French clubs have similar set-ups in Senegal and Burkina Faso. I see no reason why English clubs could not do the same. If clubs like West Ham can manage an academy in Australia, for example, why not South Africa, which is far more accessible? The players are certainly good enough, and they are mentally very tough as you would expect from their experiences. The coaching set-up from grassroots level upwards is first-class in South Africa. The violent crime is something that concerns many, and Sir Bobby Charlton, who will be in Ghana this week to promote England's 2006 bid at the Confederation of African Football conference, voiced his reservations again this week. I am sure that if they get the World Cup, a major security operation will be put in place. After all, they have had a rugby World Cup without any serious problems. My one concern is the inadequate transport system. That apart, the rest of the infrastructure is in place and a lot of hotels are being built, whether they get the World Cup or not. There is a great deal of campaigning going on, and there is a structure and professionalism to their football that was not there 10 years ago. I remember back then someone was appointed national coach simply because he had the same name as a former Norwich player - obviously he had not pointed out to his employers that he was not a leading former professional! That could not happen now, not least because the knowledge of and interest in English football is phenomenal. Premiership games are shown most nights of the week, and last weekend I was able to watch Fulham's superb FA Cup win over Wimbledon broadcast live while I was waiting for a flight. So while I would love to see England win the right to host the World Cup in 2006, I would not be too disappointed if it was awarded to South Africa. The people have a fierce pride in their country and what they are trying to do after so many unhappy years is positive. They really believe having the World Cup would take them forwards as a nation. Can we say the same in England?

fields.headline: Keepers punished for handling
fields.trailText: Three goalkeepers were sent off for handball yesterday - Nottingham Forest's Dave Beasant, Norwich's Andy Marshall and Brentford's Andy Woodman.
fields.body:
Three goalkeepers were sent off for handball yesterday - Nottingham Forest's Dave Beasant, Norwich's Andy Marshall and Brentford's Andy Woodman.

Beasant was shown the red card at Grimsby after Forest, having fought back from two goals down to 2-2, were trailing 3-2. Grimsby's third goal had come from a Lee Ashcroft penalty following a professional foul by John Olav Hjelde - an offence for which the latter was also sent off.

As if to emphasise that this was one of the most incident-packed matches of the afternoon, the final score was 4-3 to Grimsby.

At the time of Marshall's banishment at Birmingham. the home team were 2-0 ahead courtesy of two goals from Martin Grainger - not bad going for a full-back.

Fortunately for Norwich, Birmingham then took their foot off the pedal and the visitors were spared a more embarrassing defeat.

Another player sent off for using his hands was Barnsley's central defender David Tuttle in the 2-0 win at Crystal Palace. Ironically, Tuttle is a former Palace player. Another ex-Selhurst Park man, Bruce Dyer, had given Barnsley the lead.

Apart from Grimsby, the other particularly exciting contest in the First Division could be found at Portsmouth, where the home team - in their first match under the management of Tony Pulis - slumped to a 3-2 defeat against Wolves after being two goals ahead.

Graham Stuart scored his fifth league goal of the season to give Charlton a 1-0 win over Crewe and push them four points ahead at the top.

Ipswich, who had defender Gary Croft making his first appearance for them since his release from prison - as a substitute - had little difficulty in brushing bottom-of-the-table Swindon aside. The match was effectively over as a contest by the end of the first half, with Mike Stockwell having put them ahead in the 27th minute and Richard Naylor adding another 10 minutes later. Naylor made it 3-0.

There are more glamorous environments for a Premiership footballer than that of Scunthorpe United. But then anywhere outside London - and especially east London - would be a good place to be for Manny Omoyinmi, the 22-year-old Nigeria-born forward at the centre of the ineligibility controversy that has led to his club, West Ham, being bundled out of the Worthington Cup. Omoyinmi's perceived accountability over this bizarre affair - which has reportedly caused him to be subjected to death threats from West Ham followers - is a sensitive subject even at Scunthorpe.

The player has kept a low profile off the field since the struggling Second Division club took him on a month's loan, and their manager, Brian Laws, is clearly intent on keeping it that way following West Ham's Worthington Cup quarter-final replay defeat by Aston Villa. The day after the tie, when the animosity towards Omoyinmi was inevitably at its most pronounced, some of the numerous media telephone calls to Laws did not even get past the Scunthorpe switchboard operator.

'Are you ringing him about the West Ham player?' she asked. 'He will not speak to you about the player at all.' As it happens, Laws is happy to talk about Omoyinmi's ability, and why he hopes that the present loan arrangement - which has another week to run - can be extended for another month.

Indeed, amid all the fuss about Omoyinmi's failure to stop himself being used as a substitute in West Ham's first match against Villa, because he had already appeared in the competition as a loan-player with Gillingham, his footballing expertise has been largely overlooked.

Laws, for example, talks glowingly about his pace and ability to operate on either flank. 'All teams need players who can beat people and stretch defences,' Laws says, 'and the other good thing for us in having Manny is that he is a natural right-side player. When it comes to having players who can balance our play, we are in the unusual position of being OK on the left but not the right. He is doing a good job for us.'

At the other end of the table, Wigan, having lost the distinction of being the only unbeaten league team in England, showed their determination to avoid another defeat in an absorbing match at home to Millwall.Their captain, Stuart Barlow, was sent off in the 18th minute and this was followed by Millwall taking the lead through David Livermore. But Wigan were deservedly brought back on level terms by Michael O'Neill three minutes from the end.

Eric Harrison , the Wales assistant-manager and one of Manchester United's longest-serving coaches, is in hospital after collapsing with a thrombosis and a chest infection.

The 61-year-old Harrison, who as Manchester United's youth team coach played a big part in the development of players like David Beckham and Paul Scholes, joined Mark Hughes in the Welsh international set-up last year.

fields.headline: Wise guy steals a point
fields.trailText: Leicester ruined Chelsea's championship challenge last season when they managed to grab a draw and they repeated the effort again, this time denting the Londoners' desperate tilt at third place and a Champions' League berth.
fields.body:
Leicester ruined Chelsea's championship challenge last season when they managed to grab a draw and they repeated the effort again, this time denting the Londoners' desperate tilt at third place and a Champions' League berth.

A goal five minutes from time by Dennis Wise rescued Chelsea from an embarrassing defeat but put a halt to their revitalised season.

Liberian George Weah made his full debut following his loan signing this week. The man who made way for him this time was Chris Sutton, ostensibly injured following his 30-minute foray against Tottenham Hotspur on Wednesday evening and leaving Vialli with no choice but to restore Gianfranco Zola.

Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill restored Matt Elliott to his more customary centre-back berth after his goal-scoring exploits of recent weeks, while veteran striker Ian Marshall, looking more like a plumber than a footballer of late, partnered England under-21 international Emile Heskey up front.

On paper, this was a game of artists versus artisans. All the initial action centered around Leicester's penalty area as Zola produced a trademark free-kick just just before the half hour - that Pegguy Arphexad saw late but held expertly.

By contrast, Leicester's singular tactic seemed to involve sitting back, conceding possession and then breaking quickly.

But it was a tactic that eventually reaped dividends four minutes before the break as Stefan Oakes sent in a looping right wing cross that found Gerry Taggart free in the six-yard box. His header rebounded off De Goey's right post, the Dutchman then flapped the ball into Taggart's path and he fired a left-footed shot home with ease.

Vialli, realising that a defeat by Leicester would both end any outside chance of the championship and imperil a Champions' League berth, rang the changes at half time. On came Gustavo Poyet and Gabrielle Ambrosetti for Didier Deschamps and Dan Petrescu.

However, changes take time to bed down and Leicester almost took an instant advantage. Emile Heskey sprung the offside trap and marauded towards goal. Only quick reflexes by De Goey thwarted the striker from extending the lead.

Vialli was then forced to bring on his third striker, Tore Andre Flo, on 62 minutes when Spanish defender Albert Ferrer limped off. Seeing Chelsea entering reckless attacking mode, Leicester pushed themselves further forward. However, this only allowed the Londoners greater space and substitute Poyet had a fine header well saved by Arphexad two minutes later.

When Flo's header from close range was charged onto the bar and out again by Guppy, it seemed all over. But Zola, the midweek misfit, became the weekend hero by curling a free-kick into the path of Dennis Wise.

The Chelsea captain's glancing header from six yards bisected goalkeeper and Taggart and nestled into the back of the net five minutes from time.

A mad cap last charge towards the Leicester goal proved fruitless and ultimately Martin O'Neill's side got what they came for - a point.

fields.headline: Vote winner for Wilson
fields.trailText: Danny Wilson may now carry a Government health notice - 'Warning: this manager will get you relegated' - but if this performance was anything to go by reports of Sheffield Wednesday's decline appear to be as exaggerated by the politicians as some critics claim the flu crisis has been.
fields.body:
Danny Wilson may now carry a Government health notice - 'Warning: this manager will get you relegated' - but if this performance was anything to go by reports of Sheffield Wednesday's decline appear to be as exaggerated by the politicians as some critics claim the flu crisis has been.

However, even a new Labour spin doctor would struggle to put a positive slant on Wednesday's decline this season. Reported to be £15 million in debt and rising, this win against one of their closest relegation rivals was vital.

Fired up by calls from a gang of four Sheffield MPs - Joe Ashton, Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett, Bill Michie and Clive Betts - for Wilson to be sacked, the city was on a knife-edge.

Even after this victory they are still marooned at the bottom, but there is at least now some hope. Wilson can indeed see the green shoots of recovery.

Why the secretary of state for employment is calling for someone who works in his constituency to be added to the jobless figures is a question the Wednesday might be entitled to ask.

The MPs all claim to be Wednesday supporters, indeed three of them are shareholders, but their views were not echoed by others on the terraces who rally enthusiastically behind Wilson's team.

But it was Bradford, who had not won here since Lloyd George was Prime Minister in 1913 and new Labour really did mean just that, who nearly shocked the home side after three minutes. A poor Andy Hinchcliffe back pass was seized on by Dean Saunders but he put his shot the wrong side of the post.

Then Wednesday hit the woodwork twice in five minutes.. First, after nine minutes, Gerald Sibon battled his way on to a Steve Haslam header only to poke his shot against the base of the post; then, Peter Atherton met a Hinchcliffe corner with a glancing header that hit the underside of the bar.

The goal Wednesday deserved finally arrived in the 53rd minute. The much-maligned Sibon swapped passes on the edge of the penalty area with Gilles de Bilde, who opened Bradford up. Former Wednesday keeper Matt Clarke saved at Sibon's feet but Niclas Alexandersson struck the rebound home.

More chances went begging before Wednesday were able to truly relax following an own goal 15 minutes later from Bradford's Andy O'Brien, who volleyed Ian Nolan's well-struck cross into his empty net.
