fields.headline: Smicer finally pops up
fields.trailText: Two newcomers to the English game made their mark on a pulsating game that was - thankfully - a million miles from the Maracana. First the iceman cameth, with Heidar Helguson, Watford's record £1.5 million signing , capping a revival from two goals down with an equaliser. Then Vladimir Smicer popped up with a winner for a wasteful Liverpool.
fields.body:
Two newcomers to the English game made their mark on a pulsating game that was - thankfully - a million miles from the Maracana. First the iceman cameth, with Heidar Helguson, Watford's record £1.5 million signing , capping a revival from two goals down with an equaliser. Then Vladimir Smicer popped up with a winner for a wasteful Liverpool.

Smicer has been at Liverpool all season as Steve McManaman's replacement but you would never know it - yesterday saw the Czech's first goal for the club to give them a welcome three points after recent stumblings. It was a little hard on the 22-year-old Icelander signed from Lillestrom and his spirited team, but still they gift goals.

Theoretically, this should have been a fixture to soothe Liverpool after the shock to the system of defeat by Blackburn Rovers, especially with Michael Owen back after a hamstring injury. That overlooked the fact Chelsea had been beaten here by a side scrapping for their lives and that Watford had won 1-0 at Anfield in August to record their first Premiership points.

That Liverpool were given the early fillip they needed to restore some confidence - they had also lost to Tottenham before Blackburn to end a run of four wins in five unbeaten matches - said much about why Watford have taken root in the bottom three since the Anfield win.

Patrik Berger sent in a poor low cross from the right, but the Watford defence merely dabbled with it instead of dealing with it decisively. Up it bobbled to David Thompson and all 5ft 7in of him twice won headers before it fell to Owen. He picked out Berger for a more emphatic low attempt, this time into the back of the net.

Initially Liverpool had looked bright enough, with Dieter Hamann the puppetmaster in midfield as they assembled some neat passing movements, but there was a hesitancy to them. Owen looked concerned, naturally enough, about stretching out his legs, and at the back they were clearly nervous about conceding early on, having lost the previous two games by a single goal.

Helguson had made his first impact on the game with a header into the side-netting from Charlie Miller's free-kick and Richard Johnson was not far wide with a drive from 20 yards. The goal, however, served to douse home spirits and lift Liverpool's.

Berger might have doubled the lead when Hamann slid a beautifully weighted ball into his path, but as Alec Chamberlain dived at his feet, he clipped the ball wide. Berger then played an equally astute pass into the stride of Owen, now beginning to relax, but although his shot fizzed past the goalkeeper, it rebounded from the crossbar.

The second goal Liverpool had threatened duly came just before the interval. Johnson fouled Titi Camara, for which he was booked, some 35 yards out and as Hamann's low shot was bound for goal, Thompson intervened to deflect it past a wrong-footed Chamberlain.

Johnson quickly made amends, however. Receiving the ball some 25 yards out, he took a step and drilled in a low shot which found the corner of Sander Westerveld's net. From looking comfortable, suddenly Liverpool looked vulnerable.

Watford clearly scented it too. Within 30 seconds of the restart they won a free-kick on Liverpool's left and David Perpetuini swung in a curling left-footed kick. Helguson escaped Sami Hyypia and rose to meet it ahead of Westerveld, glancing the ball home with his head.

Now Watford were steaming, looking like one of Graham Taylor's direct old teams in forcing Liverpool to turn with long balls, and winning the knock-downs, all fuelled by adrenaline. Luckily for Liverpool, there is not the same quality in this Watford side and gradually they eased themselves back in the game.

After a mazy run across the penalty area, Owen sent in a shot that Miller kicked off the line. Steven Gerrard also headed at Chamberlain and Thompson was close with a 20-yard shot. Then came that decisive contribution by Smicer. From wide on the right, Owen picked him out. From the pass, Smicer looked up and deliberately slotted a low shot just inside Chamberlain's left post. Now Owen departed the piece, after a more than satisfactory return, and what they had, Liverpool held.
fields.bodyText: Two newcomers to the English game made their mark on a pulsating game that was - thankfully - a million miles from the Maracana. First the iceman cameth, with Heidar Helguson, Watford's record £1.5 million signing , capping a revival from two goals down with an equaliser. Then Vladimir Smicer popped up with a winner for a wasteful Liverpool. Smicer has been at Liverpool all season as Steve McManaman's replacement but you would never know it - yesterday saw the Czech's first goal for the club to give them a welcome three points after recent stumblings. It was a little hard on the 22-year-old Icelander signed from Lillestrom and his spirited team, but still they gift goals. Theoretically, this should have been a fixture to soothe Liverpool after the shock to the system of defeat by Blackburn Rovers, especially with Michael Owen back after a hamstring injury. That overlooked the fact Chelsea had been beaten here by a side scrapping for their lives and that Watford had won 1-0 at Anfield in August to record their first Premiership points. That Liverpool were given the early fillip they needed to restore some confidence - they had also lost to Tottenham before Blackburn to end a run of four wins in five unbeaten matches - said much about why Watford have taken root in the bottom three since the Anfield win. Patrik Berger sent in a poor low cross from the right, but the Watford defence merely dabbled with it instead of dealing with it decisively. Up it bobbled to David Thompson and all 5ft 7in of him twice won headers before it fell to Owen. He picked out Berger for a more emphatic low attempt, this time into the back of the net. Initially Liverpool had looked bright enough, with Dieter Hamann the puppetmaster in midfield as they assembled some neat passing movements, but there was a hesitancy to them. Owen looked concerned, naturally enough, about stretching out his legs, and at the back they were clearly nervous about conceding early on, having lost the previous two games by a single goal. Helguson had made his first impact on the game with a header into the side-netting from Charlie Miller's free-kick and Richard Johnson was not far wide with a drive from 20 yards. The goal, however, served to douse home spirits and lift Liverpool's. Berger might have doubled the lead when Hamann slid a beautifully weighted ball into his path, but as Alec Chamberlain dived at his feet, he clipped the ball wide. Berger then played an equally astute pass into the stride of Owen, now beginning to relax, but although his shot fizzed past the goalkeeper, it rebounded from the crossbar. The second goal Liverpool had threatened duly came just before the interval. Johnson fouled Titi Camara, for which he was booked, some 35 yards out and as Hamann's low shot was bound for goal, Thompson intervened to deflect it past a wrong-footed Chamberlain. Johnson quickly made amends, however. Receiving the ball some 25 yards out, he took a step and drilled in a low shot which found the corner of Sander Westerveld's net. Within 30 seconds of the restart they won a free-kick on Liverpool's left and David Perpetuini swung in a curling left-footed kick. Helguson escaped Sami Hyypia and rose to meet it ahead of Westerveld, glancing the ball home with his head. Now Watford were steaming, looking like one of Graham Taylor's direct old teams in forcing Liverpool to turn with long balls, and winning the knock-downs, all fuelled by adrenaline. fields.headline: Rams batter woeful Boro
fields.trailText: This scoreline does few favours for Derby. It could have been seven, so sharp was their attack and so threadbare the Boro defence. Two goals from young striker Malcolm Christie were the highlights of an embarrassingly one-sided game.
fields.byline: John Wilford at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
This scoreline does few favours for Derby. It could have been seven, so sharp was their attack and so threadbare the Boro defence. Two goals from young striker Malcolm Christie were the highlights of an embarrassingly one-sided game.

Boro welcomed back their captain Paul Ince, taking a chance on his fitness after a six-week absence for a hernia operation without even a reserve team run-out.

Gascoigne, who reputedly spent the festive season at a health farm, was on the bench but they were without the long-time injured Christian Ziege, and Brian Deane was suspended.

Derby brought in youngster Christie for his first start. And it was he who gave Derby the best possible opening with a goal after eight minutes. Johnson's corner from the right was met at the near post by Burton whose back header found the former Nuneaton Borough player unmarked five yards from goal and able to nod the ball down into the net at his leisure.

Derby belied their relegation position with some enterprising football. Darryl Powell, as usual, led by example and Lars Bohinen and Rory Delap showed nice touches in linking up with the impressive Christie.

The Middlesbrough goal had a remarkable escape when their defence failed to clear a long throw from Delap and the ball eventually found its way to Seth Johnson. His shot on the turn was brilliantly tipped onto the post by Mark Schwarzer and when the ball rebounded to Burton two yards out he somehow lifted it over the bar.

As Derby piled on the pressure a glorious pass from Johnson put Delap in the clear but again Schwarzer was at his best to deny him.

But the inevitable Derby second goal was not long in coming. After Johnson and Christie had shots blocked, Burton found the net with a clever lob over his head.

It was soon three, Schwarzer fumbling a harmless long ball from Johnson and the irrepressible Christie was there to pinch possession, dribble round the keeper and find the net from an acute angle.

It was symptomatic of Boro's dreadful afternoon when Hamilton Ricard's lazily struck penalty for a foul by Horacio Carbonari was saved by Mart Poom.

Consolation came in the 71st minute when substitute Andy Campbell fastened on to a loose ball in the area and volleyed in from 15-yards.

Then, in the final minute, Craig Burley, in yards of space, completed Boro's rout with a goal scored with something approaching arrogance.

fields.headline: Moore comes to the rescue
fields.trailText: Joe-Max Moore chose an opportune moment to open his account in English football, his injury-time scrambled equaliser providing George Graham and Tottenham with a painful, and costly, case of déjà vu. In midweek, George Weah's late goal cost Spurs a point. Yesterday, the first goal for the US international since his £800,000 November arrival from New England Revolution accounted for a further two.
fields.body:
Joe-Max Moore chose an opportune moment to open his account in English football, his injury-time scrambled equaliser providing George Graham and Tottenham with a painful, and costly, case of déjà vu. In midweek, George Weah's late goal cost Spurs a point. Yesterday, the first goal for the US international since his £800,000 November arrival from New England Revolution accounted for a further two.

Kevin Keegan's first visit to Goodison Park in his capacity as England manager was heralded as an opportunity for Everton's precocious teenage striker Francis Jeffers to stake a claim for a role in this year's European Championships.

If this was his unofficial audition, it started badly. With barely one minute gone, Richard Dunne's right-wing cross landed on Jeffers's head but he produced a wayward effort from an unmarked position 12 yards out.

He fared little better 10 minutes later when an abysmal first touch saw the ball squirm from his control when he appeared to have the beating of Chris Perry.

But Jeffers's next contribution was far more noteworthy. After 22 minutes he showed excellent footwork to sidestep Justin Edinburgh and play a superb pass down the right for Don Hutchison. The Scotsman, in turn, eluded Sol Campbell and delivered a cross that was turned into the Spurs goal via a perfectly judged stopping header from Kevin Campbell.

The manner of the goal was an example of the confidence and style with which Everton are playing. But the manner in which they surrendered that lead was a painful throwback to less fruitful days.

Within two minutes a Tim Sherwood free-kick was headed against the post by an unmarked Campbell, and Chris Armstrong tapped in his fifth goal of the season.

Worse was to follow four minutes later when David Ginola scored a highly fortuitous goal that their play had scarcely warranted until that point. Sherwood played the Frenchman into a crossing position near the right corner flag and, as he stole a yard on Dave Watson, Ginola's cross was deflected off the Everton defender's leg and looped into the goal.

Little troubled Spurs unduly, until the arrival of Moore as an 82nd minute replacement for Jeffers - a move roundly disapproved of by the home fans.

As Mark Pembridge's long throw-in brought pandemonium to the Spurs area, Watson's shot was blocked but fell nicely for Moore, who forced the ball over the line.

fields.headline: Keane finishes off Dons
fields.trailText: Coventry easily claimed a match between two depleted teams. Gary McAllister scored the 100th league goal of his career with a disputed penalty, then set up the second for Robbie Keane. With steadier finishing, the margin of victory would have been considerably wider.
fields.body:
Coventry easily claimed a match between two depleted teams. Gary McAllister scored the 100th league goal of his career with a disputed penalty, then set up the second for Robbie Keane. With steadier finishing, the margin of victory would have been considerably wider.

City covered the absence of Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo - refused permission to leave Morocco's African Nations Cup training camp - by playing Noel Whelan and 20-year-old John Eustace in midfield.

Like Eustace, Wimbledon's Damien Francis - another 20-year-old - was also making his first Premiership start in a team badly hit by injuries in attack. John Hartson, Marcus Gayle and Carl Leaburn were all missing.

Wimbledon's attacks were few and far between, although they would have almost certainly gone ahead against the run of play if Whelan had not managed to force himself in front of Robbie Earle, who was about to connect with a close-range header. When Keane made a nuisance of himself in the penalty box, the ball fell to Cedric Roussel, who was wide of the far post. The chances continued to come, with a diagonal ball from McAllister releasing Carlton Palmer, who also struck his effort wide.

Coventry's non-stop pressure was rewarded 10 minutes into the second half with McAllister's 100th league goal. But it was a goal tinged with controversy as Roussel carried on a move started by Stephen Froggatt by finding Keane, whose shot was pushed out by Neil Sullivan.

However, the referee, Steve Bennett, signalled a penalty and seemed to be indicating that the offence was handball by Hermann Hreidarsson. McAllister, as cool as ever, scored from the spot, forcing Wimbledon to commit more men forward.

McCallister then set up the second goal for Keane, who took advantage of a mistake by Hreidarsson to beat Sullivan at the second attempt.

fields.headline: Jensen's interceptor does it
fields.trailText: You know how it is. You've just got back from an away trip and the last thing you want to do is get up early next morning, go all the way up the M11 to Cambridge and watch a trialist from Saffron Walden Town playing in your reserves.
fields.body:
You know how it is. You've just got back from an away trip and the last thing you want to do is get up early next morning, go all the way up the M11 to Cambridge and watch a trialist from Saffron Walden Town playing in your reserves.

But professionalism gets the better of you and the thing you notice about your trialist is that he's running strangely. Later it turns out that he's injured his ankle in the first 20 minutes but is so keen to impress that he keeps going.

With money tight you nevertheless decide to sign the former removal man for £15,000. And lo and behold the one-time centre-half turns out to be a goalscoring midfielder.

'Boys' Own' stuff? Probably. But that is the story of Stuart Wardley's professional football career so far. And with a highly respectable nine goals in 24 League appearances before yesterday's match against Bolton, it's no wonder Queens Park Rangers' leading scorer this season is looked on by his manager, Gerry Francis, as representing 'the best £15,000 I have ever spent'.

Of course the former England captain knows a thing or two about midfield play himself. But the slimly-built Wardley lacks the physical presence to be a midfield dynamo. Instead, the 25-year-old, favours stealth and touch.

The latter attribute was in evidence after four minutes. The ball looped up and Wardley was first to react with an instinctive sidefoot volleyed pass, that left Rob Steiner with a clear run on goal, the Bolton defence static.

Sadly for Rangers' the linesman on the far side spared the visitors' blushes by raising his flag.

Before then Wardley had defensive duties to perform. For someone who used to be a centre-half it was curious that this seemed to be the weaker part of his game. In fairness to him, Rangers have had a run of injuries that would do justice to a flu ward and started this game without the experienced Tim Breacker, Danny Maddix and Steve Morrow at the back.

And their absence proved costly on 64 minutes when Wardley and Paul Murray got in each other's way, allowing Jensen a clear run on goal before he calmly steered the ball past Lee Harper.

Six minutes later Wardley had the chance to atone. But from Kiwomya's flick on he blasted over the bar, barely five yards out. Football was no longer seeming quite so sweet, especially as an attempt to volley a high-bouncing ball, a difficult skill, on 52 minutes was also high and handsome.

Bolton, without a league win since November, who should have opened the scoring after 15 minutes when Dean Holdsworth was played in by Michael Johansen. But Harper saved well with his legs. Meanwhile someone must have told Eidur Gudjohnsen that Loftus Road is also the home of Wasps, so often did he finish good approach work with shots worthy of a rugby goalkicker.

Buoyed by these misses Rangers finished the first half the stronger and just before the break Paul Bruce's powerful shot from the left-hand-side of the area was deflected onto the far post by Bolton's Jimmy Phillips.

As for Wardley he had one of those days, summed up when an 88th minute header looped over the bar. But don't bet against some of his old colleagues helping him move house soon.

fields.headline: Henry and Suker sink Reid
fields.trailText: Arsenal presented Steve Bould with a silver cannon on his first return to Highbury after 11 successful seasons at the club. After 90 minutes of being run ragged by Thierry Henry and out-passed by Davor Suker, he possibly felt like using it.
fields.body:
Arsenal presented Steve Bould with a silver cannon on his first return to Highbury after 11 successful seasons at the club. After 90 minutes of being run ragged by Thierry Henry and out-passed by Davor Suker, he possibly felt like using it.

Considering this was only Arsenal's second-string strike force, and that Henry and Suker passed up as many opportunites as they accepted by over-elaborating or misunderstanding each other's subtleties, Sunderland could consider themselves fortunate to get away with only a four-goal drubbing.

The visitors were never in the game, barely worthy of the compliment paid by Arséne Wenger when he described them as genuine top three material, and this may be the point in the season when Sunderland stop dreaming about Europe and start congratulating themselves on the number of points already in the bag. Certainly Peter Reid must be concerned at a sudden slump in form which has brought only one Premiership point from the last 12. Including last week's defeat at Tranmere, Sunderland have lost their last four away games.

Arsenal themselves were concerned about the loss of leading players and a slight dip in form since their defeat of Leeds, but their first win this year takes them level on points with Manchester United, albeit after playing three games more. They were ahead after just three minutes, and Bould will not be counting Henry's opening goal among his most pleasant Highbury memories. The 37-year-old Sunderland captain was in position to check the Frenchman's run up the left wing, but Henry simply cut inside and left him for dead, before producing a shot which surprised Thomas Sorensen with its ferocity.

Henry had forced a save from Sorensen inside the first minute, and Suker wasted a good chance midway through the first half by wanting too much time to transfer the ball to his left foot. But already it was clear Arsenal's passing and movement was stretching Sunderland's defence. It was surprising, in the circumstances, that the next goal took almost half an hour to arrive, but Suker's 27th-minute strike was worth the wait. This was direct football of the highest class. Henry showed exquisite control in bringing down Seaman's clearance, and perfect awareness in finding Suker at the left corner of the penalty area, for the Croatian to take one touch to kill the pass and a second to lift a stunning lob over Chris Makin and beyond Sorensen via the far post.

As if that was not bad enough from Sunderland's point of view, the visitors then gifted Arsenal a third within four minutes. Paul Butler was tring to shepherd the ball over the line for a goal-kick, but the lively Henry stole in and with Sorensen racing out to intercept, it was a simple matter to square a cross for Suker. He tapped into an empty net. Sunderland attempted to protest that the ball had gone out of play, but replays confirmed Henry's steal had been perfectly legitimate. Niall Quinn pulled a goal back from Michael Gray's cross early in the second half to make his own return to Highbury a little less painful, but it scarcely amounted to a fightback.

Patrick Vieira headed against a post, and Petit, Henry and substitute Stefan Malz missed presentable opportunities before Arsenal finally put the gloss on a stylish victory nine minutes from the end. Once again Henry was the scorer and once again he embarrassed Bould, this time flicking Lee Dixon's pass over his head and catching the old man on the turn before putting a low shot under Sorensen. With two goals and two assists, Henry in this form might take some shifting.

fields.headline: Duff delight for reborn Rovers
fields.trailText: Blackburn's amazing revival under Tony Parkes continued as they brushed aside former league leaders Huddersfield with a confident display.
fields.body:
Blackburn's amazing revival under Tony Parkes continued as they brushed aside former league leaders Huddersfield with a confident display.

'You should have stayed in Brazil,' sang the jubilant Rovers fans at Huddersfield manager Steve Bruce. Perhaps he wishes he had after watching his injury-ravaged side somehow keep the score down to two goals with a combination of luck and another excellent display from goalkeeper Nico Vaesen.

Rovers have lost just once in 14 games since Parkes took over, a run which has catapulted them not only into play-off contention, but also into the fifth round of the FA Cup after last week's stunning victory over Liverpool.

Anfield goal hero Nathan Blake claims Parkes has brought the fun back into the club, Parkes himself points to stability as being the key - he has been at Blackburn for almost 30 years.

Huddersfield, with just one point in nine, arrived without five regular centre-halves. Kevin Gray, Chris Lucketti, Ken Monkou were all injured, Jon Dyson was suspended and manager Steve Bruce's former Manchester United colleague David May has return to Old Trafford with a hamstring strain. Bruce, however, did not succumb to the temptation of playing himself.

The transformation Parkes has brought to Blackburn was immediately apparent, Rovers attacking without fear directly from the kick off. Per Frandsen almost got them off to the perfect start after four minutes, shooting from the centre-circle with Huddersfield keeper Nico Vaesen off his line, but the ball trickled narrowly wide.

A minute later, the Dane threaded an inch-perfect pass to send Nathan Blake clean through and his angled shot was parried by Vaesen for a corner.

Huddersfield fought back and Marcus Stewart should have done better from 15 yards when a vicious in-swinging free-kick from Jamie Vincent created panic in Blackburn's defence before Kenny Irons rifled over from the edge of the box.

Blackburn then scored almost against the run of play. Blake turned provider this time, sending Damien Duff free on goal. The Irishman rode the challenge of makeshift centre-half Steve Jenkins and slotted the ball neatly under the advancing Vaesen for his fourth of the season.

Blackburn keeper John Filan, in only his third game back following a lengthy injury, had to be replaced by Alan Kelly, but Rovers finished off the half with a piece of absolute magic. From Lee Carsley's pass, Duff somehow managed to cross from near the corner flag, and Damien Johnson sprinted in at the far post to meet the ball with a spectacular diving header which gave Vaesen no chance.

Huddersfield emerged for the second half chasing an early goal, but they were unable to settle as Blackburn ran down every ball, creating openings every time they were in possession.

Duff stretched the visitors to the limit with another mazy run down the left, but this time the shot was deflected for a corner. Then Blake broke clear, but fired disappointingly into the side netting before another dazzling Duff run and cross again had Huddersfield back-pedalling once again.

Blake should have scored the third when he seized upon Craig Armstong's hesitancy and raced clear, but his chip over the advancing Vaesen was just wide.

Huddersfield made a double substitution in an attempt to wrestle back the initiative with former Blackburn winger George Donis and ex-Manchester United midfielder Ben Thornley introduced with just over 20 minutes left to play.

But Blackburn continued to dominate. Duff won a free-kick on the left, floated the ball in and an angled header from Blake forced Vaesen to save brilliantly at full-stretch.

Lee Carsley should have made absolutely certain of the points when Frandsen's cross was only half cleared and fell to him ten yards out. He made a powerful connection but the shot hit the side netting.

fields.headline: Di Canio to the rescue
fields.trailText: In a game of two howlers, David James made the most costly blunder when his goalkeeping error 12 minutes from time allowed Paolo Di Canio to equalise for West Ham and rob Villa of all three points. James came flying out to take a cross that he didn't need to challenge for, dropped the ball and allowed Di Canio to hook home his 11th goal of the season. Earlier, Di Canio's strike partner Paulo Wanchope had missed one of the easiest chances he will ever get when he hooked the ball over an empty goal from three-yards out.
fields.body:
In a game of two howlers, David James made the most costly blunder when his goalkeeping error 12 minutes from time allowed Paolo Di Canio to equalise for West Ham and rob Villa of all three points. James came flying out to take a cross that he didn't need to challenge for, dropped the ball and allowed Di Canio to hook home his 11th goal of the season. Earlier, Di Canio's strike partner Paulo Wanchope had missed one of the easiest chances he will ever get when he hooked the ball over an empty goal from three-yards out.

Poor Wanchope. The West Ham striker has been out of form and favour with his own supporters, and in the first half here he illustrated just how low his confidence has sunk.

West Ham, trailing to Ian Taylor's 24th-minute goal for Villa, were desperately seeking a way back into the game when Joe Cole burst through to the byline on the left side of the penalty area. The youngster arrowed a low cross past James in the Villa goal, and when it arrived at Wanchope's feet, just three yards from an open goal, the home supporters were already beginning to celebrate. But Wanchope managed to scoop the ball up and over the bar when a simple tap-in was required, and West Ham's chance to equalise went begging. It would have been an injustice after the Midlands side continued where they had left off on Tuesday, when they beat West Ham in their replayed Worthington Cup quarter-final.

The second half followed the same pattern as the first, with Villa content to soak up West Ham's pressure and attack on the break while the home side enjoyed most of the possession. Joachim was unlucky after a quick burst took him past Javier Margas but his shot was saved by Shaka Hislop.

West Ham threatened to equalise in the 51st minute when James dropped the ball at the feet of Wanchope but the luckless striker had his shot blocked.

fields.headline: Executive 'on road to collapse'
fields.trailText:
A senior ally of David Trimble, Northern Ireland 's First Minister, has predicted that the power -
           sharing Executive will collapse by the end of next month.
fields.body:
A senior ally of David Trimble, Northern Ireland 's First Minister, has predicted that the power - sharing Executive will collapse by the end of next month.

Trimble's aide told The Observer he believes the Ulster Unionist leader will resign his post and precipitate the Executive's fall because the IRA will not decommission by the middle of February.

The UUP's 860-strong ruling council meets on 12 February to review participation in the new government. Trimble is under obligation to resign as First Minister if the IRA has not started to decommission arms by then. The critical UUP council vote was originally scheduled for 5 February but party officers postponed it for a week at a meeting in Belfast on Friday to allow the IRA more time to start decommissioning.

'We are in a very dangerous situation, because I have no doubt that David is ready to resign if there is no progress. There is a real feeling within the entire unionist community that, if there is no decommissioning by then, we should pull out.'

He added that the Ulster Unionist delegation which visited Downing Street last Thursday warned the Prime Minister that the UUP council would probably vote to pull out of the executive in the absence of decommissioning. Tony Blair was understood to have been taken aback.

Trimble's aide went on: 'The executive will be suspended for a few months until people are brought to their senses and we reach the final decommissioning deadline at the end of May.'

Although Irish and British government sources believe the IRA will eventually start to decommission, there is growing doubt that the Provisionals will do so before the Ulster Unionist Council meeting. The IRA does not want to create the perception it has bent to unionist pressure.

webTitle: Perils of picking from the top

fields.headline: Perils of picking from the top
fields.trailText: Past performance is no guide to the future. Investors may read that warning daily but far too few pay any attention to it. Too often, investors pile their money into whichever trust, sector or region has been leading the league tables. And far too often, that is the wrong decision.
fields.body:
Past performance is no guide to the future. Investors may read that warning daily but far too few pay any attention to it. Too often, investors pile their money into whichever trust, sector or region has been leading the league tables. And far too often, that is the wrong decision.

Last year was typical. At the end of 1998 trusts investing in Europe and government bonds were powering ahead. Investors rushed to buy them, and fund managers, never slow to spot the chance to make a fast buck, rushed to launch them. Twelve months on, these funds are at the bottom of the league tables and, in the case of gilts, the average fund is now worth less than it was a year ago.

Those now topping the league tables - Japan, the far east and smaller companies - were propping them up 12 months ago. And statistics from performance analysts Lipper Hindsight reveal that, in all but one of the last 10 years, the best-performing fund ended up in the dog house the following year - and often for some time afterwards.The worst-performers usually stayed that way.

The Financial Services Authority, which ruled out using performance information in its proposals for providing comparative information for investors says: 'The fact that a product did better than average in the past could have been because it was luckier on average, because its asset mix did better under the prevailing market conditions than others, or because it was fortunate enough to employ a particularly good fund manager at the time.'

Jason Hollands of Best Investment, who bemoans the tendency of investors to follow fashion, points out that a year ago, no one wanted to touch Japan or smaller companies. For most of the 1990s, that would have been justified. There is little sign that investors have learned their lesson. But if past performance is such a poor guide, how are investors supposed to decide where to put their funds? Hollands says the only way is fundamental analysis: where is the British economy going? How are overseas markets performing? What is likely to happen to the value of sterling?

Making such assessments is way beyond the ability of most private investors, even if they had the time and resources. Instead, they must consult financial advisers - and there will often be a fee for doing so. Alternatively, it is worth considering a balanced fund, leaving the managers to take the key decisions on countries, industries and companies. That would include the large generalist investment trusts like Alliance Trust, Witan or Foreign & Colonial, or unit trusts like Schroders UK Enterprise or Gartmore UK Growth.

Such balanced funds are unlikely to appear at the top of the league tables but nor will they sink to the bottom.

fields.headline: Here's that rainy day
fields.standfirst: Some of us save for Christmas and birthdays; most of us don't bother at all. But with cuts in state protection, it's time to start, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Some of us save for Christmas and birthdays; most of us don't bother at all. But with cuts in state protection, it's time to start, says Maria Scott
fields.body:
If you had been around in 1918 to put £100 into the stock market, you would be a millionaire by now. If you had invested £250 a month since 1975 in one of the largest stock market funds for small investors, you would be in the same happy situation. So much for the lottery. Eat your heart out, Chris Tarrant.

The idea of saving is not as beguiling as that of instant, effortless wealth, but small sums saved regularly in the right place can make a difference to your life in the long run.However, if you are not a natural saver, you can take some comfort from the knowledge that you are not alone.

Research by the Institute for Fiscal Studies showed last year that half the population has less than £750 in savings accounts and investments. About one in 10 households has no savings at all.

A survey of 1,000 UK adults run before Christmas by Birmingham Midshires found that only 15 per cent had resolved to save more in the New Year. Only 8 per cent were already saving on a regular basis. More than a third, however, said they considered saving to be important.

But does it matter whether we save or not?

Sarah Tanner, co-author of the IFS report, believes it does, because of the way the welfare system is being privatised. Several types of social security benefit have already been cut back under the last Government and the current one, and there will be further reductions. Protection once provided by the state must now be provided by individuals.Tanner says: 'There is something worrying about the fact that so many people have no money for if they become unemployed.'

Tanner says the truth, for many people, is that they simply do not have enough money to save any of it. The IFS is conducting further research into saving through focus groups, where people are questioned about their saving habits. 'The interesting thing that emerges among low-income households is that they save for Christmas or birthdays rather than for the long term.'

People on lower incomes also wonder whether it is worthwhile saving if the sum they accumulate will merely disqualify them from receiving state help through means-tested benefits. Income support, for example, is not payable to anyone with savings of more than £8,000. Savings between £3,000 and £8,000 will bring reductions in benefit and only those with less than £3,000 get the maximum benefit. Tanner says: 'People think they have contributed to the Government and the pension, so why should they save for themselves?'

For other people, the main deterrent to saving is the bewildering choice of savings schemes on the market. The current government has added to the complexity by scrapping the Tories' tax-free schemes, Peps and Tessas, and replacing them with the Individual Savings Account. For some, saving would be possible, but requires effort. In the Birmingham Midshires survey a third of respondents recognised that saving was important, but said they found it too easy to spend. Saving money can be hard graft unless you are a natural penny-pincher. But there are reasons to make a start:

 There is likely to be less help from the state for welfare in future than is available even now. A cushion of savings can enable you to make choices about your life.

 Saving enough to allow you to survive without work for a time can give you the freedom to throw in a job you hate, or work part-time, perhaps, while finding something better, or gaining new skills.

 Savings can give financial flexibility. For example, savings may allow you to cut the cost of insurance by choosing to insure fewer possessions on the basis that if you were burgled, or the possessions damaged, you could afford to replace them. This will always be a gamble, but in areas where insurance is expensive, it may be one worth taking. Similarly, private medical insurance is beyond the reach of many people and seems an expensive millstone to others. But hospitals will increasingly offer fixed-fee treatment if you have the cash.

 Most of the best mortgage deals are available to people who can put down substantial deposits. First-time buyers should try to save a deposit.

 If you develop a savings habit early, you may set yourself up for building relatively effortless wealth in future. Motley Fool, the Internet-based financial information service, gives the fictional example of a couple with very different savings patterns: Fay invests £100 a month in a fund tracking the stock market throughout her twenties and stops in her early thirties when she has children. Husband Ferdinand, a former Hooray Henry who likes to spend, does not start saving until he is 30, putting £100 from then on into the same index tracker fund as diligent Fay. But Fay leaves her money to grow until she is 60, when she has £1.3 million, against Ferdinand's £489,000. The figures assume stock market growth of 14 per cent a year, which is a reasonable reflection of the past, but not necessarily the future. Nevertheless, the lesson is that compound growth over many years makes a huge difference.

 Information on investment savings schemes: Association of Investment Trust Companies: 0171 2825555; Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds: 0171 831 0898

webTitle: Endowments: the worst is yet to come

fields.headline: Endowments: the worst is yet to come
fields.trailText: If homeowners were to rely on insurance company publicity to assess the state of their endowments, they would end up confused at best, but more likely downright misled. Last week the annual bonus declaration season got into full swing.
fields.body:
If homeowners were to rely on insurance company publicity to assess the state of their endowments, they would end up confused at best, but more likely downright misled. Last week the annual bonus declaration season got into full swing.

Friends Provident starts its announcement with the statement that those with policies maturing from February 2000 will receive a 'competitive' return. It only becomes clear a page in that bonuses have come down.

Norwich Union leads into its declaration by telling us that it is breaking records 'yet again'. Further into the release it becomes clear that bonuses and payouts are down. In neither case are there lies involved; they can justify their statements.

This year, because of increasing controversy, insurers will be required to start a programme of communication with endowment customers, with a timetable for reviewing individual policies. And the criteria for the wording of the statements must be tight to avoid the temptation to spin the facts.

The reductions in bonuses will continue to puzzle policyholders, given the strong performance of the stock market. Insurers admit that it has been a good year, but still think the future is less rosy.

And they are probably right. The row over falling returns on with-profits investments still casts a shadow over this form of investment. They have been sold as low-risk, but anyone contemplating one now should question whether the difficulties of the long-range forecasting that they rely on, and the discretion managers have over their outcome, make them riskier than insurers like to admit.

fields.headline: Information overload
fields.standfirst: Voicemails, emails, faxes, backlogs of newspapers and magazines   and 24-hour rolling news updates... There's too much information,   says Nick Paton Walsh, and it's making us sick
fields.trailText: Voicemails, emails, faxes, backlogs of newspapers and magazines   and 24-hour rolling news updates... There's too much information,   says Nick Paton Walsh, and it's making us sick
fields.body:
You're halfway through another magazine; another blizzard of words, and spurious statistics corroborated by society gurus with Hollywood names. What's truly important? What's true, even? Why couldn't you get to the information you wanted straight away?

The main shortcoming of our information culture is not the availability of 'facts', but their quality and relevance to you. Information overload, also known as the now medically recognised 'information fatigue syndrome', is the new flu. (Trust me here.) We're bombarded by news, faxes, phone-calls, emails, and the junk equivalent of all of these, until the information we need to operate eludes us. Average Britons find themselves exposed to 2,500 advertising messages a day. We have too much information thrown at us - more than we know what to do with. Occupational psychologist Professor Cary Cooper recognises that stress, RSI and eye damage are all part of the problem we face. 'It results in a lack of mental wellbeing as it takes us away from other people,' he says. 'We're not sustaining our relationships, and, sedentary, we get no exercise.' We live in an age where information, whether it's delivered on the dirty pages of an ever-widening newspaper or on a gaudy, repetitive cable station, is measured by volume as opposed to quality - the final word in style over content.

Here's some information about information: The script for a 30-minute broadcast by CNN would barely fill the front page of a newspaper. A weekday edition of a newspaper contains as much information as the average person in the 17th century would be exposed to in their entire lifetime. In 1971 the average American encountered 560 advertising messages a day; by 1997 that had grown to 3,000. Gallup and the Institute For The Future calculated last year that the average British working day consists of 171 messages, 46 phone-calls, 22 emails, 15 internal memos and 19 items of external post.

Even Ted Turner, head of CNN, one of data smog's biggest proponents, thinks the info-glut has gone too far. 'It's killing people,' he said, not unconnectedly at the launch of CNN's new Custom News service, which will filter the news to your own tastes.

A number of ailments beset the modern worker, such as busy lethargy, where the sheer number of things to be done results in indecision and inaction. Dr David Lewis, a psychologist who has recently published a book, Information Overload, recognises that the 'sheer volume of information we have to deal with daily means that work stress spills out into home life, our sex drive is impaired, we cut back on sleep, and our heads become so full of data that we find it hard to sleep'. The final result of this can be Burnout Stress Syndrome (BOSS) that was formerly most common amongst psychiatric nurses in the States. 'As deadlines get tighter due to the speed of information, people are always inclined to feel the information they have is out of date.'

He refers to one financial director who installed a new system as it gave him a 100th of a second on his competitors; he's also met a manager who rather cynically referred to the fact that 'there wasn't always enough time to do something right, but always enough to do it again'. So surely there is a solution? He isn't optimistic: 'There isn't one,' says Lewis. The information glut isn't going away, so it's vital that we become better at managing it.

Recognising if you're experiencing overload

1. Many of us may have become so used to a daily glut of information that it's hard to accept that something is amiss. One simple test is, at the end of the day, to pause and try to recollect every instance when you were exposed to information that you'll still need tomorrow. How much of it can you remember in detail? If you can't remember all of it, then something has to change.

2. Do you take work, or related reading material, to bed with you? If so, you are not handling your information properly during the day.

3. Do you find individual names, numbers, or ideas blur together, or get mixed up with each other? For example, do you call James Bradley by the name James Tuck, simply as he's the person you've been reading about all afternoon?

4. Do you overcomplicate issues by immersing them in details? 'It's about getting to the core of the matter,' says Lewis. 'Einstein said "Simplify, simplify." We tend to drown in detail, and fear leads us towards perfectionism.' The details some of us crave can simply contribute to the overload.

5. Do you feel as if you are wasting time when you are just sitting somewhere and not reading? Some perceive such moments as idleness, but essentially, the brain needs time to assimilate some of the day's intake, as opposed to be flooded with more information.

Handling Information Overload at home

1. Turn off the television for two hours every day. This is a simple way of stopping pointless information slipping into your subconscious. And it might stop you whistling inane theme tunes, too.

2. Spend some time of every week with your mobile phone and pager switched off. Ensure that you can't be contacted and give yourself time to clear your mind. If something's that urgent, then someone will be able to find you in person, or deal with the matter themselves.

3. Go on what David Shenk calls 'data fasts'. Take a week in the country away from all the noise to clear your head. Take a big novel with you, preferably by an austere Russian from the 19th century.

4. Cary Cooper suggests we ensure that in our time off we spend time with people 'the one thing that info overload often deprives us of. This can take many forms - you might even try leaving work at 3.30pm to pick up kids from school. You can then work at home, or return to the office, if you must.'

5. Realise that the overload affects everyone and your performance is best enhanced by learning to ignore parts of it.

Clearing the data smog at work

1. Your email program can be set to filter your emails. For example, junk can go in one file (say the trash), personal messages can fill another, and messages from your boss can drop into the 'urgent' folder. It will help save you time as you avoid reading messages that could be saved until later or ignored.

2. Rip out the magazine articles and newsletters that you really want to read. Once they're detached from the main body of the publication, you don't run the risk of reading the same useless stuff again, by accident.

3. Learn to ignore junk emails and unsolicited messages. You might miss something, true, but in the long run you'll be more focused and effective. Go through this procedure with every email message you receive: Read, Action, Forward, Trash (RAFT). Don't leave the message sitting in your inbox - take action on it immediately so as not to open the same messages more than once.

4. Employers should recognise that people are not computers and that mistakes are more likely to occur under extreme pressure, says Professor Cooper.

5. Learn how to use search engines efficiently. Most have help sections that will teach you how to search best.

How not to contribute to the smog

1. Always think about how best to contact someone. Is the information best delivered as a voicemail message, an email, or a fax? Or can you just drop it in the post? What's quickest, likely to be the most direct, and efficient?

2. Write economically and concisely. Don't be verbose as this simply wastes everyone's time.

3. Change the words in the subject field of an email. This helps suggest how the conversation has moved on, so the recipient can briefly assess whether they have to read the message now or later. Blank subject fields and 'Re:' messages are often ignored.

4. Do not forward chain letters, urban legends, urgent messages about email viruses, or claims that Bill Gates will send everyone thousands of dollars. These things clog up inboxes with worthless stuff.

5. Check the 'To:' field of your emails. This will mean that unnecessary recipients will not receive irrelevant emails, and that you'll save the embarrassment of sending someone a private message.

fields.headline: Happy Families
fields.standfirst: This week, Eileen Mulligan takes us through a programme for improving family relationships.
fields.trailText: This week, Eileen Mulligan takes us through a programme for improving family relationships.
fields.body:
What is life coaching? Life coaching is the newest, fastest and most effective way to reassess and rework any area of your life. What a personal trainer does for your body, a life coach does for the rest of your life. Your coach will meet you, get to know you, discover what areas of your life you feel dissatisfied or confused about, then help you develop a strategy for improving them.

After an initial meeting, most coaching is done by telephone, with your coach pushing you, encouraging you and generally watching over you, making sure that you turn your plans into action.

Coaching is not therapy. 'Coaching is more pragmatic and goal-orientated,' says Eileen Mulligan, our life coach for this series. 'We don't focus on the roots of problems, but on their solutions.' Whatever your problems, the techniques of life coaching can help you become your own life coach, and give you new and effective ways to deal with them.

Before you begin

Most of us experience some kind of issues in our family lives. No matter what your problem, it is very important to have boundaries in your family relationships. These will be the boundaries you set for yourself - what you do and don't want to do/be/engage with in your family - and the boundaries that other family members set.

Much of this lesson is about understanding what you want your boundaries to be, and finding appropriate ways of establishing them. If you can achieve this, it gives you an excellent framework for resolving individual problems and disputes.

The list

Every life-coaching lesson begins with the list. On a piece of paper write down these five headings: goals, personal strengths, immediate challenges/blocks/problems, development skills, achievements.

Whatever area of your life you have issues with, Eileen divides it up into these five key areas. That helps you get a real picture of where you are, where you want to be, what stands in the way of your getting there, and what tools you may already have - or need to acquire - to overcome your obstacles. As we are dealing with family issues this week, Eileen recommends that you fill in your list using these guidelines:

Goals

These should always be positive, so: 'I want to spend more time with my children', not 'I don't want to work such long hours'. Even if your family issue is a negative one, you need to express your goal as a positive. For example, if you feel that your family wants too much of your time and attention, don't express it as 'I want to spend less time with my family', but 'I want to make more time for myself'.

Your goals should also relate directly to you and your issues, and not to anyone else, so: 'I want to resolve an argument with my brother', not 'I want my brother to stop treating me like a child'. And remember that you can't make goals for other people, only for yourself. The kind of goals to avoid might include: 'I want my child to do well in exams', 'I want my family to be less demanding', or 'I want my parents to get on better'. Some other family goals might include: 'Improve my relationship with my in-laws', 'Spend more/less time with my parents', 'Have children'.

Personal strengths

Look for the strengths that help to support your goals and that will help you overcome your challenges. If your problem is a difficult relationship with your stepchildren, or an overbearing mother, your strength could be your willingness to work through the problem.

If you have qualities such as patience, or acceptance of others' points of view, or a commitment to resolving problems, you could also list these. Other strengths might include: 'I love children', 'I make an effort to get on with all my siblings', 'I accept that my family don't have to agree with my views and opinions'. It's important to be aware of your personal strengths in family situations, where disputes and problems can cause feelings of guilt or low self-worth.

Immediate challenges/blocks/problems

This is your list of what is making you most unhappy, or frustrated, or confused about your family. It's very important to keep your focus on the issues that directly affect you - that way you will be able to find a solution.

If your problem is 'caused' by someone else, you have to turn it around to see it as it affects you. So your problem is not 'My mother nags me and makes me feel inadequate', but 'I allow my mother to make me feel inadequate'.

Development skills

Your development skills are areas where you can develop and improve, and gives you ways to go forward. Focus again on the kind of skills that you will need to overcome your problems and achieve your goals, and which relate to the issues you are dealing with.

As we are looking at family issues, some suggestions might include: 'Learn to say "no" more', 'Become less affected by family opinion', 'Ask for help when I need it', 'Accept other people as they are', etc. This sounds much easier to say than to do, but acquiring a new set of development skills gives you a new set of tools for dealing with your problems.

If you feel that you can't get these development skills by yourself, look for ways to get help. You can start by reading around your particular area: notice articles in the press that seem relevant; there are some excellent books that can help; or you might choose to take a course, or even see a professional. Once you know what development skills you want to have, you can find ways to get them.

Achievements

No matter what state your family relationships are in, you will have achievements you can feel proud of. Do you see your family for Christmas and holidays although you don't really want to? Your achievement could be: 'I am committed to keeping in touch with my family'. Do you disagree with your siblings' views or lifestyle? Your achievement might be: 'I accept that my siblings are different to me'. Or perhaps: 'I have kept my family together', or 'I am always there for my children', or perhaps 'I have shown that I have the strength to live without some of my family members'.

Add to your achievement list as you go through the process of working on your problems. Family relationships are complicated, and it is normal to experience setbacks along the way. Listing your achievements helps you see the progress you are making, even in the difficult times, and helps to put your problems in perspective.

Finding Solutions

Think about your problem and then ask yourself these questions: How does this affect me? Is this really my problem? How can I turn the situation around? Am I taking too much responsibility for the situation? Am I dealing with the problem generally, or the affect the problem is having on me?

You need to see your problem in a way that gives you control over it, and allows you to influence the outcome. Asking these questions, and keeping the focus on you and the effect it has on you, helps to do this.

One of the most common family problems is: 'My family is too demanding'. Looked at that way, it seems as if you have very little control over your problem. You can't change your family, so... But look at it another way. Start by dealing with the effects of this problem, which you can control. For instance, you could choose to be less affected by family pressure. At present you are taking responsibility for your family's demands, and allowing yourself to be affected by that pressure. Maybe that's one part of the problem you haven't considered until now.

Here are some techniques for breaking down this particular problem:

 Make a list of the ways your family puts pressure on you.

 Divide the list into the pressures you think are reasonable and unreasonable.

 At the bottom of the first list write 'This is what I'm prepared to take on' and at the bottom of the second one 'This is what I'm not prepared to take on'.

 Using your list, start to write out some boundaries. For example, 'I will make myself available for these family functions', 'I will not take non-urgent calls at work from my family'. This will clarify in your mind exactly which aspects of your family's demands you find most burdensome. If you aren't clear, you may have been sending out mixed signals.

 If some family members put you under more pressure than others, write down who they are. Look for patterns. Do other family members get the same treatment as you? Do they always use the same techniques to make you feel guilty?

 If you can see patterns, write them down, then list ways you could break them.

 Once you're clear on what you want the boundaries to be, find ways to communicate them to your family. 'No' may be enough. Using this technique, you reduce your problem to a series of smaller challenges which can then be dealt with in turn.

Final checklist

 You may have aspirations for other family members, but remember that they have their own goals.

 Set clear boundaries. It's up to you to say what you do and don't want.

 Respect the boundaries of others.

 If you decide on a solution to a problem, be prepared to take the consequences.

 Break your problems into pieces.

 Remember that you don't have to take responsibility for everyone else's problems.

Michael's story

Eileen (the coach)

Michael is in his mid-30s and came to see me because he felt that his family was too big an influence on him, and holding him back from becoming his own person. He is the youngest of six children, in what he describes as a close and loving group. His father was a problem for the family, being a bullying and dogmatic person.

Michael felt that the negative influence of his father had served to 'bond' the siblings even more, creating an 'us and him' situation. Michael felt that one sister and brother in particular had taken on more parental roles in his life as he was growing up, and that those roles continued to some degree to this day.

Although very fond of them, he felt that he relied too much on their approval. He is a writer and musician - as he talked about this, his hand would often move towards his heart, indicating how passionately he felt about this. But there is a family tradition of writers, and he often felt overshadowed, that he made choices about work designed more to live up to the family group than to follow his own desires.

When he wrote out a list of his personal core values, passion was his number one, indicating that trying to please his family - and not himself - was causing him a lot of personal conflict. Although Michael felt he had a family problem, being able to acknowledge and pursue his own passions in his own way was his biggest issue.

We set a series of goals which involved him producing work independently of his family. He would not show anyone this work until it was ready for publication or recording, as he has a tendency to seek approval for his ideas before embarking on them. Although money is not a core value for him, we also agreed that he would contact an agent and establish a good monetary value for his work. This would give him a sense of self-worth, legitimacy and value about his own work within the family.

Michael (the client)

My family is very close; sometimes I think we're too close . On the one hand, I really like that, but I also find it claustrophobic. I like and admire my siblings, and I've always sought their input and approval for my ideas and work. But if they didn't like or believe in something, it would put me off, even where it was something I loved. I felt I was still too dependent on them for everything.

Talking to Eileen about values and boundaries made me see that my real area of difficulty with my family is with my work. There's a lot of creativity in the family, and also a lot of professional success. I need to ignore that, and just walk my own path.

Setting the goals worked for me in two ways: one, it made me see just what my problem is and how simple it could be to fix, as I'd got bogged down in all the ins and outs of our family relationships and couldn't separate exactly what bothered me and what didn't.

And two, the goals produced a set of tasks, including writing an outline for a novel and finding an agent, both of which I've done. I'm usually a terrible procrastinator so I'm really impressed with myself being able to achieve so much so fast. It's something I wanted to do for ages, but it was the thought of having to phone Eileen and say I hadn't done it that made me do it.

Looked at that way, it seems as if you have very little control over your problem. You can't change your family, so... But look at it another way. Start by dealing with the effects of this problem, which you can control. For instance, you could choose to be less affected by family pressure. At present you are taking responsibility for your family's demands, and allowing yourself to be affected by that pressure. Maybe that's one part of the problem you haven't considered until now. Here are some techniques for breaking down this particular problem:  Make a list of the ways your family puts pressure on you.  Divide the list into the pressures you think are reasonable and unreasonable.  At the bottom of the first list write 'This is what I'm prepared to take on' and at the bottom of the second one 'This is what I'm not prepared to take on'.  Using your list, start to write out some boundaries. For example, 'I will make myself available for these family functions', 'I will not take non-urgent calls at work from my family'. This will clarify in your mind exactly which aspects of your family's demands you find most burdensome. If you aren't clear, you may have been sending out mixed signals.  If some family members put you under more pressure than others, write down who they are. Look for patterns. Do other family members get the same treatment as you? Do they always use the same techniques to make you feel guilty?  If you can see patterns, write them down, then list ways you could break them.  Once you're clear on what you want the boundaries to be, find ways to communicate them to your family. 'No' may be enough. Using this technique, you reduce your problem to a series of smaller challenges which can then be dealt with in turn. Final checklist  You may have aspirations for other family members, but remember that they have their own goals.  Set clear boundaries. It's up to you to say what you do and don't want.  Respect the boundaries of others.  If you decide on a solution to a problem, be prepared to take the consequences.  Break your problems into pieces.  Remember that you don't have to take responsibility for everyone else's problems. Michael's story Eileen (the coach) Michael is in his mid-30s and came to see me because he felt that his family was too big an influence on him, and holding him back from becoming his own person. He is the youngest of six children, in what he describes as a close and loving group. His father was a problem for the family, being a bullying and dogmatic person. Michael felt that the negative influence of his father had served to 'bond' the siblings even more, creating an 'us and him' situation. Michael felt that one sister and brother in particular had taken on more parental roles in his life as he was growing up, and that those roles continued to some degree to this day. Although very fond of them, he felt that he relied too much on their approval. He is a writer and musician - as he talked about this, his hand would often move towards his heart, indicating how passionately he felt about this. But there is a family tradition of writers, and he often felt overshadowed, that he made choices about work designed more to live up to the family group than to follow his own desires. When he wrote out a list of his personal core values, passion was his number one, indicating that trying to please his family - and not himself - was causing him a lot of personal conflict. Although Michael felt he had a family problem, being able to acknowledge and pursue his own passions in his own way was his biggest issue. We set a series of goals which involved him producing work independently of his family. He would not show anyone this work until it was ready for publication or recording, as he has a tendency to seek approval for his ideas before embarking on them. Although money is not a core value for him, we also agreed that he would contact an agent and establish a good monetary value for his work. This would give him a sense of self-worth, legitimacy and value about his own work within the family. Michael (the client) My family is very close; sometimes I think we're too close . On the one hand, I really like that, but I also find it claustrophobic. I like and admire my siblings, and I've always sought their input and approval for my ideas and work. But if they didn't like or believe in something, it would put me off, even where it was something I loved. I felt I was still too dependent on them for everything. Talking to Eileen about values and boundaries made me see that my real area of difficulty with my family is with my work. There's a lot of creativity in the family, and also a lot of professional success. I need to ignore that, and just walk my own path. Setting the goals worked for me in two ways: one, it made me see just what my problem is and how simple it could be to fix, as I'd got bogged down in all the ins and outs of our family relationships and couldn't separate exactly what bothered me and what didn't. And two, the goals produced a set of tasks, including writing an outline for a novel and finding an agent, both of which I've done. I'm usually a terrible procrastinator so I'm really impressed with myself being able to achieve so much so fast. It's something I wanted to do for ages, but it was the thought of having to phone Eileen and say I hadn't done it that made me do it.

fields.headline: A budget work-out
fields.trailText: Morgan Price
fields.body:
At this time of year, thousands sign up for monthly subscriptions to gyms as they prepare to implement new year get-fit resolutions.But Morgan Price, 28, has cancelled his gym membership and is putting the £50 that this was costing him each month in an Isa with Nationwide building society. To keep fit he is riding his bicycle. Morgan, who qualified as a solicitor 18 months ago, says he is not a natural saver. 'My family has always saved, but I was the black sheep in that I always spent.'

Morgan has a mortgage and does not have a lot of money to spare each month. But he was not using his gym membership, so decided to divert the money into saving.

'If I don't, I spend everything in the account every month. I am getting older and need to start putting a bit of money aside instead of spending it every month. Every job has the potential for stopping, and I would like a bit of a safety net.'

Morgan chose a cash Isa because he was concerned about the risk involved in stock market investment. He also wanted instant access to his money.

webTitle: Blair in the doghouse on waiting lists

fields.headline: Blair in the doghouse on waiting lists
fields.standfirst: Two in three don't trust Ministers, says  Peter Kellner
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is lucky to have such weak opponents. Were the Tories more credible and the Liberal Democrats more popular, the Government would be in serious trouble over its stewardship of the Health Service.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is lucky to have such weak opponents. Were the Tories more credible and the Liberal Democrats more popular, the Government would be in serious trouble over its stewardship of the Health Service. Two out of three people flatly disbelieve Ministers' claims that waiting lists are getting shorter.

Clear majorities support key Tory and Lib Dem policies for boosting spending on health care. Yet the Conservatives are still distrusted on the NHS, and Lib Dem support lags well below its 1997 level.

ICM conducted its exclusive poll for The Observer on Friday evening, following the rows over the flu outbreak and intensive beds, and over the criticisms of health policy by Lord Winston, the Labour peer and fertility expert.

The survey makes grim reading for Tony Blair and Alan Milburn, his Health Secretary. Few people believe their claim to have started repairing the NHS, to have reduced waiting lists and to preside over a service as good as any in Europe.

Ministers are also badly out of tune with the public over the funding of the NHS. By four to one they think Gordon Brown should scrap the planned cut in income tax, due to take effect in April, and give the money to the NHS instead. A clear majority think the Government should give tax breaks on private cover.

ICM repeated a pair of questions that Gallup asked in June 1998, the fiftieth anniversary of the birth of the NHS: did people think the service had recently improved, and did they expect it to get any better in the following three to four years?

Waiting lists then were higher than at the election a year earlier. Unsurprisingly, just 11 per cent thought the service had improved; more - but still a minority of 37 per cent - expected it to get better in the years ahead.

Eighteen months on, with extra money being spent and in-patient waiting lists down, Ministers might expect a rosier verdict. In the event, the public is harsher. Only 8 per cent think the NHS is providing a better service.

The immediate controversies over intensive care beds may have had some effect, but only 14 per cent agree that 'waiting lists for operations are getting shorter'; 69 per cent disagree.

Labour supporters, who might be expected to endorse the Government's claims, in fact reject them by three to one. So do people with the most direct experience - the one in five with a family member who has needed in-patient treatment in the past year.

More generally, by a margin of three to two, people agree that 'most other West European countries have a better health service'.

Most voters agree that the Chancellor should scrap the 1p cut in income tax planned for April, and give the money to the Health Service. But there is less enthusiasm for raising tax, with the public evenly divided. Again there is little difference between Labour and Tory voters.

Tax relief on medical insurance premiums are backed by 57-37 per cent. Labour supporters back the idea almost as strongly as Conservatives.

ICM asked whether 'people on average and above average incomes' should be required to contribute to the cost of their stay in hospital. Four out of 10 now agree. Labour supporters are evenly split, while Tories divide almost two to one against the idea.

The Tories still come out worst, however: just 25 per cent trust them - 69 per cent do not, including as many as four in 10 Tory supporters.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 542 adults throughout Britain by telephone on Friday.

webTitle: Voters demand health cash in snub to Blair

fields.headline: Voters demand health cash in snub to Blair
fields.trailText: A huge majority of voters want Tony Blair to abandon plans to cut income tax in April and instead pour money into the ailing NHS, according to a poll for The Observer.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Peter Kellner and Anthony Browne
fields.body:
A huge majority of voters want Tony Blair to abandon plans to cut income tax in April and instead pour money into the ailing NHS, according to a poll for The Observer.

The survey, coming after a disastrous week for government strategists, shows Blair may be making a political blunder by insisting on cutting the basic rate of tax by 1p.

Three out of four voters want the Government to put the revenue into the NHS. Holding back the planned reduction of the basic rate to 22p would raise £5.05 billion over the next two years.

Chancellor Gordon Brown announced the cut in last March's Budget but it now looks as if the Government has badly misread the public mood. The poll uncovers widespread disenchantment with the Government's record on the NHS. Only eight per cent think it has improved over the past year, despite receiving what Alan Milburn, the Health Secretary, calls its 'biggest ever cash injection'.

Two-thirds of the public don't believe ministerial claims that waiting lists for operations are getting shorter, and only one in three expects the NHS to improve over the next three to four years.

Ministers have already begun fighting their corners in the next three-year spending review, due to be announced in the summer. Milburn is pitching for real terms rises of more than five per cent for the three years starting on 2001-2, amounting to a cumulative increase of over £30bn. He also wants extra cash for the coming financial year in the spring Budget.

Milburn was Treasury Chief Secretary until only three months ago, and according to one ministerial source 'knows where the surpluses are buried because he buried them'.

Calling for the Chancellor to heed The Observer poll findings, the Labour chairman of the Health Select Committee, David Hinchliffe, said: 'I would have no problems if the Chancellor was to say he had changed his mind on the tax cut and the money will go to health. But we have got to be realistic and admit we are not going to see any impact for four to five years, even from the £21bn already committed to the NHS.' Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has written to all Labour MPs saying they had a duty to block the tax cut or 'lose their credibility as self-appointed custodians of the NHS'.

Professor Sir George Alberti, President of the Royal College of Physicians, called on the Government to hold a referendum on introducing a special 'NHS tax'.

But the Prime Minister's spokesman said the findings - after a week of headlines about the NHS - were not surprising. He insisted the 1p cut was part of a careful package and the Government was already under attack from the Tories over a rising tax burden. 'It's not a case of either public spending or tax cuts. We can do both,' he said.

Blair will try to assuage public opinion by promising today more cash will be put into the NHS in future years. He will also reveal some senior nurses will be handed rises of seven per cent, more than double the basic rise for most nurses of 3.6 per cent.

The NHS trusts said they would need extra government cash to fund such big increases. Sir Alan Langlands, NHS Chief Executive, admitted yesterday that a shortage of properly trained nurses meant not all the 100 extra intensive care beds provided this winter could be used at one time.

The ICM poll finds that the public is evenly divided on whether to trust Labour to develop the right health policies. The one crumb of comfort for Blair is that only one person in four trusts the Tories; seven out of ten 10 William Hague's party 'not very much' or 'not at all'. Tory chiefs are considering appointing Michael Portillo to the post of Shadow Health Secretary to give the party more weight on the issue.

Fifty-seven per cent of the public - and they include a majority of Labour voters - think the Government should give people tax incentives to go private on health (a Tory policy); only 37 per cent disagree. Ministers strongly oppose this policy. On coming to office, Labour scrapped the tax relief that older people enjoyed on private medical insurance premiums.

Despite being reminded that the 1p tax cut is worth £140 a year to a typical family, 76 per cent think the money should be used instead to boost the NHS. Only 19 per cent want Brown to go ahead with his planned tax cut.

Public opinion is more evenly divided on other proposals to increase health spending - 46 per cent say they would support a new, tax specifically for the NHS; 50 per cent think this would be a bad idea. And 41 per cent would like people on above average incomes to be required to contribute to the cost of treating them when in hospital. However, a three-to-one majority rejects any notion of making better-off patients pay to see their doctor.
