fields.headline: King of spin
fields.trailText: Access all areas continued
fields.body:
We meet the morning after the Bridget Jones party in the central London offices of Freud Communications, the PR company he set up in 1985. Freud is dressed in a black jumper, black casual trousers and black boots. One TV presenter had described him to me as 'the most exhausted-looking person in public life'. Yet he looks in better shape than the previous night, more relaxed, fresher faced, younger, even.

He talks in the west London demotic common to thrusting media and music executives, a kind of downbeat earthiness interspersed with sales jargon. For instance, of his growing profile in the press, he says: 'I've had awareness before, but never anything approaching equity.'

Another sign of his salesmanship is a conversational tic of asking rhetorical questions to which he then supplies pithy answers. 'Is there such a thing as bad publicity? Fuck, yes.'

He is bright, rather than intellectual, and, deliberately or not, has successfully shed any vestiges of his public school education at St Anthony's prep school in Hampstead and Westminster. At 36, he is still youthful, at least in terms of the business world. He has talked about leaving public relations by the time he turns 40. 'Old PR men are deeply sad individuals. I don't think I would want to spend my life in a derivative business.' He has also made clear his reservations about the fame game, speaking of the 'primary narcissism of many celebrities'. Piers Morgan, for one, is highly doubtful that Freud's future lies elsewhere. 'He likes to think of himself as an internet entrepreneur but he's the Alastair Campbell of showbusiness: ruthless but sharp. I think he's a serial networker, a social butterfly who loves to be around celebrities.'

Freud, it should be said, does not give the impression of someone who is starry-eyed. He's too clever for that. He talks about celebrity dispassionately, in terms of 'equity' and 'leverage'. His expertise lies in encouraging a brand to buy into the equity of a celebrity's fame, thus enabling Freud to leverage editorial exposure for both the brand and the celebrity. It's an arrangement that he first perfected, spectacularly, with the publicity surrounding the opening of Planet Hollywood in London in 1992.

Before that launch, showbusiness was largely a contained enterprise. Afterwards, it leaked into everything - drenching the tabloids and diluting the broadsheet agenda, spreading like a stain across the TV schedules, T-shirts, baseball caps and hamburgers. The effect was that the public's appetite for celebrity stories grew swiftly more bulimic on a diet of manufactured publicity.

Of course, Planet Hollywood was not the first showbusiness concern to shift merchandise, but it was the most self-conscious and deliberate and, arguably, the first to have no other purpose, artistic or otherwise, than to shift merchandise. In Freud's words: 'It was the ultimate transfer of celebrity equity into a T-shirt.'

Morgan, who was then the Sun 's showbusiness reporter, can recall the seismic effect of the opening night. 'It was the biggest party London had seen for 20 years and Matthew handled it with aplomb. There was Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Eddie Murphy, Bruce Willis, Michael Douglas, to name but a few. That was the moment that people started to take Matthew seriously. We splashed on it in the Sun.'

A couple of months ago, Planet Hollywood announced that it had gone bust. Freud laughs when I ask if he still represents the company. 'Er, yeah. I mean, that's a fantastic story. It's a parable of empty foundations. Celebrities were brought in to kick-start something that otherwise would have taken a long time. So you went from nothing to an overnight sensation by transplanting all these famous people on to a logo. Planet Hollywood went from nothing to a $3.5 billion operation to nothing again in a seven-year period. The fact is, the tabloids were completely conspiratorial in building the Planet Hollywood brand, because we gave them something they'd never had before, which was absolutely unfettered access to huge celebrities who would do almost anything to sell a burger and a T-shirt. It was remarkable to see these titans of the screen throwing out baseball caps to crowds and saying the apple strudel's really good.'

In some ways, the rise and fall of Planet Hollywood traces the arc of our obsession with celebrity. It probably peaked mid-decade, but while it hasn't yet fizzled out, there are signs that interest is waning. First of all, the celebrities themselves are becoming smaller and more transient, as they vainly attempt to fill the space created by that initial Planet Hollywood blitzkrieg, and secondly, the tabloids are beginning to step back from the frenzied overexposure of a few years ago.

Freud readily acknowledges that we have reached a state of celebrity overload. 'Oh, we're so far past it. We're so overloaded, I think the definition of celebrity has changed. I think the media cycle is such that now, with very few exceptions, the famous are no longer interesting.' Which, of course, is one explanation of why attention has been redirected towards those, like Freud, who are behind the curtain, pulling the levers. Morgan suspects that the Planet Hollywood model may be indicative of the effect of Freud's kind of branding. He mentions the Pepsi relaunch a few years back to announce the new blue livery of the drink's can, which Freud took care of. There were acres of media coverage but the sales were not deemed a success.

'It would be interesting to analyse exactly how well the companies have performed that Freuds have worked for,' says Morgan. Freud's own calculation is that 90 per cent of newspaper coverage has no effect. But he thinks that we 'still read editorial as truth, or at least as partial truth'. At the same time, he agrees that the public's credulity is stretched by the tactics that people like himself have employed to boost their clients. Witness the recent Evans and Halliwell saga. So media-wise is the public nowadays that hardly anyone was prepared to believe that the union was anything but a marketing exercise. And yet, curiously, Halliwell still made it to number one in the charts.

A story ran in the Guardian 's diary, on the daythat I met Freud, suggesting that an unfavourable profile of him was pulled from the Spectator when pressure was placed on the writer by her employers at the Daily Mail. The Mail 's showbusiness editor was apparently afraid of offending Freud.

The extension of the Freud myth is that he wields enormous sway in Fleet Street because he controls access to famous people. I'd heard that he was tipped off about the slant of the piece when a friend of his overheard the writer being briefed by one of Freud's enemies. When I asked him if he had anything to do with the story's demise, he denied it and laughed unconvincingly.

'His face tells everything,' said one media consultant. 'You can see when he's anxious.' A facial tell could be seen as an occupational weakness for a PR, but Freud does most of his work on the phone, and much of the day-to-day graft is now performed by underlings. In this case, however, he seems to have falsely given himself away. Both the writer and the showbusiness editor separately confirmed that the Daily Mail simply didn't like the idea of one of their writers working for the Spectator. The rest is spin, although this time, not Freud's.

The uncertainty that Freud provokes is perhaps not unrelated to the fact that his great-grandfather was the founder of psychoanalysis. Poised as it is between 'fraud' and 'pseud', the name Freud has enough doubtful connotations without the added weight of its history. But the familial shift through four generations from psychiatric doctor to spin doctor is too tempting to ignore.

Just as Sigmund was concerned with the recesses of the mind, so Matthew operates in the background of the media. Psychoanalysis has long been viewed as a questionable 'science' and, similarly, public relations is dogged by the perception that it is an unnecessary invention. It might be said, in addition, that both Freuds know a thing or two about superegos.

The great-grandson tells a story about being introduced to well-known New York publicist Bobby Zarem. 'Are you any relation?' Zarem asked. When Freud acknowledged that he was, Zarem was immediately keen to meet up. 'My shrink's out of town,' he said. 'I need to see you at once.'

As it turned out, Zarem introduced Freud to Robert Earl, the proprietor of the Hard Rock Café, with whom he would later collaborate on Planet Hollywood. But his illustrious name, while obviously bearing advantages, is something which Freud says he has not always appreciated. 'My motivation for the first five years of my career was about trying to have a Christian name as well as a surname. My Christian name was really an irrelevance. I was somebody's great-grandson or somebody's son.'

That said, he was a smart enough publicist not to call his company Matthew Communications. In fact, he first called it Matthew Freud and Associates, although the associates amounted to his sister, Emma, later to find fame as a radio and TV presenter, and his cat. In the early days, he says, the company was close to folding every week.

Morgan recalls that the 'bullshit quotient was much higher' at that time. 'I wouldn't say that he would have sold his grandmother, but other relatives weren't safe.'

According to Freud's sister, this is only a slight exaggeration. His first adult venture into business was a singing telegram service he set up as an 18-year-old, in which he employed a girlfriend and Emma to go out and perform. 'It lasted about six months,' she remembers. 'It was a disaster. I went round to offices singing in a horrible outfit, while he sat in the office and took a couple of calls a day.'

The selling instinct was first glimpsed when he was a child on family holidays. His sister relates how he sold pet mice to other children, only to demand double the price to take them back from appalled parents. He then graduated from livestock to hot dogs - Emma insists there was a healthy gap between the two.

As a pupil, Freud was bright but uncommitted. He left Westminster public school, where he was remembered for playing the drums and being 'cool', when he was 16, and then dropped out of Pimlico comprehensive the following year. A little while after, he was charged and fined for possession of cannabis and cocaine.

'At 18,' says Emma Freud, 'you would have had very little hope for him. He was great fun, but quite wild. In his teens, he thought that if he could be in the right place at the right time, everything would fine. In his twenties, Matt learnt the connection between hard work and success.'

After a stint working for RCA as a publicist for David Bowie and the Eurythmics, he was introduced to Uri Geller by his father, Clement Freud. Geller says he was looking for someone to help in negotiating a deal with a gold-mining company. 'I thought that I would give Matthew a break.'

Apparently the deal went well, and Freud showed himself to be, in Geller's words, 'very cool and precise'. The man who had become famous by stopping watches gave the enterprising young man the benefit of his experience. 'I told him,' says Geller, 'that successful men wear a Rolex.'

He worked tremendously hard through the remainder of the Eighties, networking furiously, without great rewards. One former girlfriend claimed that he could speak to three people on the phone, in three different accents, with three different spins, switching between them on hold, 'while simultaneously having sex with me'.

It was not until 1992, however, that his company, renamed Freud Communications, started to earn Rolex money. Even so, Freud had already assumed the stature of a man who was going places. Kris Thykier, who is Freud's trusty lieutenant, recalls arriving for a job interview when the company occupied cramped mews offices housing around 12 staff. 'I remember that downstairs was a hive of activity, with all these people squeezed into a small space. Upstairs, Matthew had the entire floor to himself, with this large desk and incredibly large chair.'

He employed Thykier, then just 18, to take care of a television account for a production company called Planet 24, which was producing a new morning programme called The Big Breakfast. An often-cited criticism of Freud is that he runs a neo-Dickensian sweatshop, in which young workers are hired on low wages and then overworked until they burn out. Both Freud and Thykier argue that the company has provided opportunities for young people that they would not gain at more conventional agencies, and that staff often move on to thrive elsewhere.

Waheed Alli, who was made a peer by the Labour government, was one of the partners behind Planet 24. He can remember his first meeting with Freud. 'I instantly disliked him,' he says. 'I think I mistook shyness for coldness. He is shy, but I soon realised that when you're in a meeting with him, there's no stopping, no nerves, just pure genius. The thing that people underestimate about Matthew is that he's a brilliant strategist.'

Freud's strategy for The Big Breakfast was to sell it as a recognisable brand. 'It hadn't really been done before,' he says, not without pride. The tactics, though, were not particularly groundbreaking - simply to get as many stories as possible into the tabloids about the show and, in particular, its presenter, Chris Evans. Thykier says the company's motto is 'never knowingly undersell'.

Freud knew Evans through his sister, whom Evans produced when she was a disc jockey at GLR. One PR consultant who has crossed swords with Freud feels that Evans's media profile is the result of a misguided strategy. 'Chris Evans is one of the smartest businessmen in communications and yet the public think he's a drunken oaf. That's just bad PR.'

'Chris is great copy,' counters Freud. 'We didn't make that - he did. But if you drew a graph of Chris Evans copy over the past seven years, it is massively weighted towards the launch of each of the significant steps in his career. We don't get enough credit for being able to leverage media interest to commercial gain.'

Evans stands at the centre of what has been described as the immensely profitable 'synergy' of Freud's clients. For example, Evans, a Freud client, might have used The Big Breakfast, a Freud client, to interview a Hollywood star Freud was representing about, say, Planet Hollywood, a Freud client.

The success of Four Weddings and a Funeral, which Freud publicised (his sister is married to Richard Curtis, the film's creator), completed the annus mirabilis of 1992. Two years later, he was able to sell his company to the advertising agency Abbot, Mead, Vickers for a sum said to be up to £10 million. It was, he says, his proudest moment.

As part of the deal, he agreed to stay on in charge of the company, which now employs over 100 staff, for five years - a period that lapsed a few weeks ago. 'I think we've found a happy medium,' says Freud. 'I don't really have any plans to go anywhere else.'

During the mortgage crisis that caused a temporary break in Peter Mandelson's ministerial career, Freud offered New Labour's dark prince some consoling advice: 'The one person you can't spin is yourself.' It's a sound rule, but one that may not apply to Freud. As Thykier says: 'He has an ability to see through what he does. The level of cynicism he has about the business is one of his great strengths. He knows he's not curing cancer.'

Freud makes all the right noises about being flummoxed by the media's interest in him: he claims to hold limited influence; he has kept his profile discreetly cropped; he insists he is reasonably content with his lot. At the same time, he drops hints that he can see a world beyond tabloid headlines; says half-jokingly that PR is a young man's game; lets it be known that he is passionate about his support of New Labour and, off the record, does not deny rumours of his political string-pulling. Is he so deft an operator that he publicly pronounces his impotence while privately trading on his myth?

One clue might be found in the, presumably self-penned, biography of Freud that is part of the promotional material for his property company, Yoo. 'Matthew has played a significant role in redefining the PR industry from a second-rate hospitality function to the front-line art form of controlled media manipulation for brands, personalities and media properties.' That 'controlled media manipulation' suggests that Freud sees himself as a good deal more proactive than he affects to be.

It has been said that prior to Mandelson's appointment as secretary of state for the DTI, Freud set about galvanising support for his friend in the press. Subsequently, the rumour has spread that Freud helped Mandelson gain his cabinet job. According to one sceptical Labour insider, the so-called campaign could be traced back to one article in the Sun entitled 'Peter's Friends', which had Mandelson down as an intimate of various celebrities including some, like Tom Cruise, whom he had never met. 'Freud placed that story,' says the Labour man. 'His understanding of politics is not that deep and mature.'

Another story doing the rounds in London is that Freud approached the Labour Party and asked what exactly would be required for him to be awarded a peerage. When I asked Freud if this was true, he gave an answer that, while a denial, was frank and revealing. 'I work for the Labour Party, I work for the Dome and charities. At some point, you do get recognition. Funnily enough, though, I would not want a peerage as it currently exists. Perhaps when I'm 60, but not now. But if people are going to be appointed to the new upper house on merit, that's something I'd quite like to be considered for. I'm very interested in politics, but I don't think I want to be a Member of Parliament.'

The Dome may prove to be the turning point that Freud has been preparing for. His friend Waheed Alli told me that he thought the scale of the PR industry was not 'quite big enough to contain Matthew's abilities'. According to Freud, he landed his unpaid role on the executive board of the Dome when he told Mandelson that he was 'mad' to have appointed Saatchi's advertising agency. Mandelson replied: 'Ooh, I need your brain.'

Freud feels that he has had most impact in ensuring that the Dome is more populist. He was behind the Blackadder contribution. 'When I arrived, I looked at the plans, which were all very serious and a little dull, and said: "If you subscribe to Blueprint magazine [a rather austere design publication], this is the greatest day out in your life."'

Sam Chisholm, the tough-talking former head of Sky, is uncharacteristically fulsome in his praise. 'Matthew has a very analytical mind. He always seems to know exactly where everyone's trying to get to. He knows the end game, although attention to detail may not be his strong point. But he is always willing and able to make decisions and come up with solutions. He has an outstanding mind. I think people will see what an extraordinary contribution he's made to the Dome.'

The romance between Freud and Murdoch has already been the subject of intense speculation. Tatler devoted six pages to the Notting Hill soap opera that has developed since the break-up of Freud's marriage to Caroline 'Pidge' Hutton, the mother of his two young sons. She is now involved with Earl Spencer, and is living in the house Freud bought from his brother-in-law, Curtis, the house that featured in the film Notting Hill.

Freud says that he hasn't relished the attention, although he is philosophical about its purpose. 'What I always say to my clients is: you have to externalise it. It's like shares on a stock market that go up and down without you doing anything.'

He has plenty of opportunity to learn from close quarters about the invasiveness of press scrutiny. The experience, which he describes as 'tragic', did not undermine his respect for the British tabloid press. 'The News of the World had done a fantastic job,' he says. 'They'd got a fantastic piece of tabloid content.'

What will probably protect Freud from too much unwanted attention is the fact that his girlfriend's father owns half the press and the other half will follow the unwritten law that you don't mess with the family of media barons. Elisabeth doesn't see it that way. She feels that Freud has had to endure a rough ride. 'Sometimes,' she says, 'it reminds me of how my dad has been treated by the media.' She is fiercely proud of Freud, whom she describes as 'fantastically talented'. They met in early 1997, when she was eight-and-a-half months pregnant with her second child from a marriage that is now ended. She was instantly impressed. 'I offered him a job right away.'

Their relationship was an open rumour for some time before they 'came out' at a Royal Shakespeare Company costume ball (theme: Les Liaisons Dangereuses ) in late 1998. The couple were photographed in 18th-century finery. Most observers thought it was inspired PR, but Murdoch claims it was not a conscious decision. 'Oh, that party,' she says, embarrassed. 'Those photographs were not intentional. We broke up the next day.'

Friends agree that the relationship is now on much firmer territory, although they raise doubts over what Elisabeth's father thinks. There have been rumours that Murdoch is not best pleased with his prospective son-in-law? 'I think there are people who are threatened,' says one friend. 'I wouldn't know if Murdoch is behind the stories, but he has always been nice to Matthew in person.'

What, I asked Chisholm, does he think Murdoch would think of his prospective son-in-law. He thought for a while, as if pondering each word in print. 'I think,' he said finally, 'he'd find him a fascinating young man.'

The launch of Sky Digital in 1998 provided a tense and public forum for the two men to meet. Freud was in charge of the party, held in Battersea power station. The evening was dogged by technical difficulties, leading to a breakdown in sound. Freud was reported to have metamorphosed into 'a headless chicken'. Morgan recalls the occasion with barely hidden glee. 'My lasting memory is of Matthew drunk in the corner, alone, looking like he wanted to kill himself.'

'It definitely was not a high point,' says Freud. 'When you do something in the name of Murdoch and the function of it is to launch something to the media, there is no margin for error. When we do a premiere for Disney and they tell you Eisner's coming, you go back and relook at all the arrangements. Clearly, in the Murdoch instance there was a double factor.'

He shut down the events department afterwards. 'Jeopardising a £1 million-fee income account because a hairy-arsed roadie put a plug in the wrong place on an event on which you might make £20,000 is not smart any more.'

At the end of 1998, Freud pulled out of working for Sky and News International because of his entanglement with Elisabeth. 'It certainly became difficult when he and I started a relationship,' she concedes. 'But his company still does project work for us.'

Rebekah Wade, who is a friend of the couple, says that Freud has changed a lot in the past year. 'He's happier now than I've ever seen him. Much more open and relaxed.'

This news will come as a relief to those in the business who have been used to seeing a rather forlorn-looking character, standing in the shadows, worrying over his clients. As one media consultant said: 'I wish he was more likable. I can't see why he shouldn't be. He should be happy all day long.'

Freud is, as his great-grandfather might have said, a complex character. He is reserved and private by nature, yet he works in a hectic, public environment. He is by turns loudly self-deprecating and quietly boastful, a man with a sharp mind put to blunt use. You sense that he's not unaware of the conflict. In the Nineties, to use one of his own phrases, he helped shape the zeitgeist. At the start of this decade, the new millennium, he has already stamped his mark on its most visible symbol, the Dome. He has played the media game with consummate skill but, if he genuinely wants to make a name for himself, perhaps now is the time to put away childish things.

Freud is dressed in a black jumper, black casual trousers and black boots. One TV presenter had described him to me as 'the most exhausted-looking person in public life'. Yet he looks in better shape than the previous night, more relaxed, fresher faced, younger, even. He talks in the west London demotic common to thrusting media and music executives, a kind of downbeat earthiness interspersed with sales jargon. For instance, of his growing profile in the press, he says: 'I've had awareness before, but never anything approaching equity.' Another sign of his salesmanship is a conversational tic of asking rhetorical questions to which he then supplies pithy answers. 'Is there such a thing as bad publicity? Fuck, yes.' He is bright, rather than intellectual, and, deliberately or not, has successfully shed any vestiges of his public school education at St Anthony's prep school in Hampstead and Westminster. At 36, he is still youthful, at least in terms of the business world. He has talked about leaving public relations by the time he turns 40. 'Old PR men are deeply sad individuals. I don't think I would want to spend my life in a derivative business.' He has also made clear his reservations about the fame game, speaking of the 'primary narcissism of many celebrities'. Piers Morgan, for one, is highly doubtful that Freud's future lies elsewhere. 'He likes to think of himself as an internet entrepreneur but he's the Alastair Campbell of showbusiness: ruthless but sharp. I think he's a serial networker, a social butterfly who loves to be around celebrities.' Freud, it should be said, does not give the impression of someone who is starry-eyed. He's too clever for that. He talks about celebrity dispassionately, in terms of 'equity' and 'leverage'. His expertise lies in encouraging a brand to buy into the equity of a celebrity's fame, thus enabling Freud to leverage editorial exposure for both the brand and the celebrity. It's an arrangement that he first perfected, spectacularly, with the publicity surrounding the opening of Planet Hollywood in London in 1992. Before that launch, showbusiness was largely a contained enterprise. Afterwards, it leaked into everything - drenching the tabloids and diluting the broadsheet agenda, spreading like a stain across the TV schedules, T-shirts, baseball caps and hamburgers. The effect was that the public's appetite for celebrity stories grew swiftly more bulimic on a diet of manufactured publicity. Of course, Planet Hollywood was not the first showbusiness concern to shift merchandise, but it was the most self-conscious and deliberate and, arguably, the first to have no other purpose, artistic or otherwise, than to shift merchandise. In Freud's words: 'It was the ultimate transfer of celebrity equity into a T-shirt.' Morgan, who was then the Sun 's showbusiness reporter, can recall the seismic effect of the opening night. 'It was the biggest party London had seen for 20 years and Matthew handled it with aplomb. There was Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Eddie Murphy, Bruce Willis, Michael Douglas, to name but a few. That was the moment that people started to take Matthew seriously. We splashed on it in the Sun.' A couple of months ago, Planet Hollywood announced that it had gone bust. Freud laughs when I ask if he still represents the company. 'Er, yeah. I mean, that's a fantastic story. It's a parable of empty foundations. Celebrities were brought in to kick-start something that otherwise would have taken a long time. So you went from nothing to an overnight sensation by transplanting all these famous people on to a logo. Planet Hollywood went from nothing to a $3.5 billion operation to nothing again in a seven-year period. The fact is, the tabloids were completely conspiratorial in building the Planet Hollywood brand, because we gave them something they'd never had before, which was absolutely unfettered access to huge celebrities who would do almost anything to sell a burger and a T-shirt. It was remarkable to see these titans of the screen throwing out baseball caps to crowds and saying the apple strudel's really good.' In some ways, the rise and fall of Planet Hollywood traces the arc of our obsession with celebrity. It probably peaked mid-decade, but while it hasn't yet fizzled out, there are signs that interest is waning. First of all, the celebrities themselves are becoming smaller and more transient, as they vainly attempt to fill the space created by that initial Planet Hollywood blitzkrieg, and secondly, the tabloids are beginning to step back from the frenzied overexposure of a few years ago. Freud readily acknowledges that we have reached a state of celebrity overload. 'Oh, we're so far past it. We're so overloaded, I think the definition of celebrity has changed. I think the media cycle is such that now, with very few exceptions, the famous are no longer interesting.' Which, of course, is one explanation of why attention has been redirected towards those, like Freud, who are behind the curtain, pulling the levers. Morgan suspects that the Planet Hollywood model may be indicative of the effect of Freud's kind of branding. He mentions the Pepsi relaunch a few years back to announce the new blue livery of the drink's can, which Freud took care of. There were acres of media coverage but the sales were not deemed a success. 'It would be interesting to analyse exactly how well the companies have performed that Freuds have worked for,' says Morgan. Freud's own calculation is that 90 per cent of newspaper coverage has no effect. But he thinks that we 'still read editorial as truth, or at least as partial truth'. At the same time, he agrees that the public's credulity is stretched by the tactics that people like himself have employed to boost their clients. Witness the recent Evans and Halliwell saga. So media-wise is the public nowadays that hardly anyone was prepared to believe that the union was anything but a marketing exercise. And yet, curiously, Halliwell still made it to number one in the charts. A story ran in the Guardian 's diary, on the daythat I met Freud, suggesting that an unfavourable profile of him was pulled from the Spectator when pressure was placed on the writer by her employers at the Daily Mail. In this case, however, he seems to have falsely given himself away. 'They'd got a fantastic piece of tabloid content.' What will probably protect Freud from too much unwanted attention is the fact that his girlfriend's father owns half the press and the other half will follow the unwritten law that you don't mess with the family of media barons. Elisabeth doesn't see it that way. She feels that Freud has had to endure a rough ride. 'Sometimes,' she says, 'it reminds me of how my dad has been treated by the media.' She is fiercely proud of Freud, whom she describes as 'fantastically talented'. They met in early 1997, when she was eight-and-a-half months pregnant with her second child from a marriage that is now ended. She was instantly impressed. 'I offered him a job right away.' Their relationship was an open rumour for some time before they 'came out' at a Royal Shakespeare Company costume ball (theme: Les Liaisons Dangereuses ) in late 1998. The couple were photographed in 18th-century finery. Most observers thought it was inspired PR, but Murdoch claims it was not a conscious decision. 'Oh, that party,' she says, embarrassed. 'Those photographs were not intentional. We broke up the next day.' Friends agree that the relationship is now on much firmer territory, although they raise doubts over what Elisabeth's father thinks. There have been rumours that Murdoch is not best pleased with his prospective son-in-law? 'I think there are people who are threatened,' says one friend. 'I wouldn't know if Murdoch is behind the stories, but he has always been nice to Matthew in person.' What, I asked Chisholm, does he think Murdoch would think of his prospective son-in-law. He thought for a while, as if pondering each word in print. 'I think,' he said finally, 'he'd find him a fascinating young man.' The launch of Sky Digital in 1998 provided a tense and public forum for the two men to meet. Freud was in charge of the party, held in Battersea power station. The evening was dogged by technical difficulties, leading to a breakdown in sound. Freud was reported to have metamorphosed into 'a headless chicken'. Morgan recalls the occasion with barely hidden glee. 'My lasting memory is of Matthew drunk in the corner, alone, looking like he wanted to kill himself.' 'It definitely was not a high point,' says Freud. 'When you do something in the name of Murdoch and the function of it is to launch something to the media, there is no margin for error. When we do a premiere for Disney and they tell you Eisner's coming, you go back and relook at all the arrangements. Clearly, in the Murdoch instance there was a double factor.' He shut down the events department afterwards. 'Jeopardising a £1 million-fee income account because a hairy-arsed roadie put a plug in the wrong place on an event on which you might make £20,000 is not smart any more.' At the end of 1998, Freud pulled out of working for Sky and News International because of his entanglement with Elisabeth. 'It certainly became difficult when he and I started a relationship,' she concedes. 'But his company still does project work for us.' Rebekah Wade, who is a friend of the couple, says that Freud has changed a lot in the past year. 'He's happier now than I've ever seen him. Much more open and relaxed.' This news will come as a relief to those in the business who have been used to seeing a rather forlorn-looking character, standing in the shadows, worrying over his clients. As one media consultant said: 'I wish he was more likable. I can't see why he shouldn't be. He should be happy all day long.' Freud is, as his great-grandfather might have said, a complex character. He is reserved and private by nature, yet he works in a hectic, public environment. He is by turns loudly self-deprecating and quietly boastful, a man with a sharp mind put to blunt use. You sense that he's not unaware of the conflict. In the Nineties, to use one of his own phrases, he helped shape the zeitgeist. At the start of this decade, the new millennium, he has already stamped his mark on its most visible symbol, the Dome. He has played the media game with consummate skill but, if he genuinely wants to make a name for himself, perhaps now is the time to put away childish things.

The decision to allow a convicted rapist into Britain is set to go the whole 10 rounds, report Martin Bright, Denis Campbell and Andy McSmith

Tyson faces legal fight
Straw may have misled MPs over Pinochet decision
fields.trailText: It was supposed to be Jack Straw's big week. Last Sunday, the Home Secretary had his next five days mapped out. Last week, as he saw it, would contain two defining moments for himself and the New Labour Government.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be Jack Straw's big week. Last Sunday, the Home Secretary had his next five days mapped out. Last week, as he saw it, would contain two defining moments for himself and the New Labour Government.

Over the weekend he had decided to release the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet and, at the same time, launch a fierce attack on those who opposed his plans to reform Britain's ancient system of trial by jury - the Hampstead liberals. Both moves were bound to attract huge controversy, but he was well-prepared for the inevitable onslaught.

But the unexpected intervention of discredited former heavyweight boxing champion and convicted rapist Mike Tyson threw his carefully laid plans into complete disarray.

The fighter's imminent debut in a British ring reduced the Home Office to a state of open panic. Should Tyson be allowed in or not? The issue had not crossed Straw's radar when the fight was announced a month before, but sudden, feverish media interest in Tyson was about to provide the Home Secretary with one of the biggest headaches of his two-and-a-half years in office. If he let Tyson in, women's groups would claim Labour's toughest-ever Home Secretary was soft on rapists. But if he turned Tyson away, 21,000 people would have to be reimbursed and businesses in Manchester, where the fight was due to take place on 29 January, would lose millions. It would also mean upsetting Rupert Murdoch, Tony Blair's most influential media ally, whose BSkyB television network had the rights to screen the fight.

'It came completely out of the blue. No one was prepared for the Tyson row,' one Home Office official told The Observer.

Straw's aides had planned his week like a military campaign. They knew that the attacks on him would be fierce, but assumed that the battle was worth having in order to win the ideological war over the future of criminal justice policy.The centre of the strategy was a speech on Thursday which would mark the beginning of a concerted campaign against the critics. An interview with the veteran political editor Michael White was placed in Monday's Guardian, house journal, in his view, of woolly liberalism.

Straw's special adviser, Ed Owen, had already begun briefing journalists that the Home Secretary was planning to take on the whingers over the Criminal Justice (Mode of Trial) Bill. By then it had also become clear that a decision would have to be made on the future of Pinochet. In the box was the medical report saying that Pinochet's health had deteriorated to the point of senility. Straw decided to make a statement saying that he was 'minded' to send the old man home. He was prepared for the flak.

At the bottom of the pile was a seemingly unimportant memo from officials in the Immigration and Nationalities Directorate telling Straw he should be aware that Tyson was about to enter the country. It was a disaster waiting to happen, but the warning had come too late.

The fuse for the explosion of anger that would engulf Straw was further primed last Monday. In comments almost wilfully designed to offend the Right, he passed comment on the English tendency to violence on a Radio 4 programme about national identity.The Guardian interview defending his decision to limit the right to a jury trial by attacking the 'Hampstead liberals', meanwhile, had lit a bonfire under his opponents on the left. Ironically, by attacking 'Hampstead liberals' Straw had made certain that people would really notice his new legislation. By mid-week, being a Hampstead liberal had become a badge of pride to which figures as diverse as broadcaster Jon Snow, Labour peer Helena Kennedy and right-wing polemicist Peter Hitchens laid claim.

The announcement that Straw planned to release General Pinochet on medical grounds fanned the flames. On Tuesday, Straw's office had already faxed the news to Pinochet's lawyers and to the Chilean Embassy. Later, defending himself against accusations of insulting the Commons by not telling them first, Straw said that the law required him to inform those directly involved first.

None of this was unexpected by the Home Secretary. The real trouble began when officials in the Home Office immigration department sent a fax on Tuesday to boxing promoter Frank Warren. It warned Warren that, given Tyson's three-year stretch in jail for raping a young beauty contestant in 1991, the fighter would not be allowed into the country when he arrived at Heathrow. Warren was told that when he arrived - as scheduled this afternoon from New York - the bull-necked Brookyln boxer would have to board the first plane home.

The promoter was furious. 'Given the potential impact of cancellation, I was annoyed that it had taken so long for anyone to say that there might be a problem here,' said Warren.

In truth what Straw did not know was that his civil servants in the Home Office Immigration and Nationality Directorate had been warned in December by staff that Tyson's arrival would pose serious problems. 'It became a real talking point over Christmas,' said Martin Slade of the Immigration Service Union. 'Who was going to be responsible for telling someone like Mike Tyson that he wasn't wanted in the country?'

Straw's civil servants, however, failed to pass on these concerns to the Home Secretary himself until a short article about Tyson appeared in the Daily Mirror on Friday, 7 January. A front-page article in the black newspaper New Nation the following Monday further stoked the furore. The advice from Straw's civil servants seemed clear enough: exceptions to the ban on convicted foreign criminals could only be made on compassionate grounds. A dry note to Straw appended to a copy of the immigration rules made this doubly clear. 'A boxing match would not normally constitute compassionate grounds.'

Suddenly in real trouble from an unanticipated corner, Straw ducked the problem, insisting that the decision lay with immigration officers themselves.

Downing Street, however, was less coy. On Tuesday, Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's press secretary phoned Warren's office and left a message saying that Tyson would not be allowed in. The next day, Blair told Parliament that the Government had to 'play by the rules' and restated that it was a decision for imigration officials, not Ministers.

Tyson and Warren were having none of it. As Straw got up on Thursday morning it was to be greeted by the news in the Sun that Tyson had decided to turn up anyway. It was the nightmare scenario - the decision to turn Tyson away would be left to the officers at Heathrow.

In desperation, Home Office lawyers began dredging through the details of the Immigration Act. They discovered that the final decision rested with the Home Secretary, not with the immigration service. Just before the Six o'Clock News Straw released a statement saying that Tyson would be allowed in to the country after all.

And what happens in the two weeks between now and Tyson's fight in Manchester could make Straw regret his decision. A combination of legal challenges to Tyson's presence, protests outside the Grosvenor House Hotel, constant media attention and the presence of uniformed police officers among the security personnel who will guard the boxer are ripe with fresh possibilities for embarrassment.

More seriously for Straw, the events of the week have raised serious questions about his political programme and competence. Civil rights groups remain impressed by his determination to push through human rights legislation in October to bring Britain in line with the rest of Europe, but they are baffled by his determination to curb the rights of defendants and crack down on asylum-seekers.

'Who is the real Jack Straw? That's the 64,000 dollar question,' said Liz Parrott of human rights group Liberty. 'He is a very complex individual. He is the first Home Secretary to deal with human rights groups in any genuine way. But I find his attack on woolly-minded liberals utterly baffling. I think it's the determination of groups like Liberty to take a consistent and decidedly unwoolly line on human rights that brings them into conflict with the Government.'

Julie Bindel of Justice for Women, who plans to mount a legal challenge to the Tyson decision, says: 'The Government has made it very clear that they take violence against women very seriously, so this was a huge surprise. The man is a disaster.'

'I begged, but he turned evil'

The decision to allow convicted rapist Mike Tyson into Britain appears to contradict statements made recently by Government Ministers about the need for tough action in the campaign to reduce violence against women. In June, Home Secretary Jack Straw launched Living Without Fear, a £6 million initiative to tackle domestic violence, rape and sexual assault.

At the time Straw said the new policy 'demonstrates our commitment to reduce violence against women. We are committed to learning from and promoting practical, effective ideas which work to reduce crime and help victims.'

Desiree Washington was an 18-year-old contestant in the Miss Black America pageant in 1991 when she met Mike Tyson and, after a late-night date, was raped by him. At the subsequent trial which saw him sentenced to six years in jail, she described her ordeal: 'He kept saying, "Don't fight me, don't fight me, relax." I was telling him to get off me. I said, "No, stop!" I freaked out. I tried anything. I said I had a future, I was going to college, use a condom, I don't need a baby. He stopped for a moment when he saw I was crying. Then he turned evil.'

According to Home Office statistics:
 Every week two women are killed by their current or former partner;  Reported rape has risen by 165 per cent in the past 10 years;  One-third of young men thought they would force a woman to have sex under certain circumstances.

fields.headline: Four get fit
fields.standfirst: This week we look more closely at what that programme involves, and put our four volunteers  through their paces.
fields.trailText: This week we look more closely at what that programme involves, and put our four volunteers  through their paces.
fields.body:
THE BURNER

This is the plan to drop body fat and sculpt six packs. The man in charge is personal trainer Matt Roberts. 'It combines fat-burning aerobic work and muscle-building strength training,' says Matt. Many people on a fat-loss programme don't think that increasing muscle mass counts, so they concentrate on aerobic work, but as Matt explains, muscle building is equally important. 'Muscle burns calories even when you're sitting still.' Strength training also has health benefits, including reducing risk of osteoporosis and heart disease.

The four-week programme

Aim for at least three one-hour sessions a week, with 30 minutes of cardiovascular work and 25-30 minutes of resistance work and stretching.

Week one

Matt believes the most fundamental part of a burner programme is to work out the correct intensity for Martin to exercise.

'Aim to get your heart rate up to 70-80 per cent of its maximum during CV work,' says Matt. 'You can calculate this by taking your age away from 220 - so if you're 40, you get 180. Then find 70-80 per cent of that figure - in this case it would be 126-144. Take your pulse for 10 seconds. Count the beats for those 10 seconds and multiply by six. That figure should fall somewhere between the 70-80 per cent figure. In terms of weights, aim at a weight that lets you do two sets of 15-18 reps.'

Martin's diary: 'At my assessment my trainer, Simon, shows some surprise at how little I weigh. "That's not bad," he says, "you're just a funny shape." He means I have a belly from hell ... it has to go. I am quietly but firmly told to replace my morning bacon sandwich with an apple or banana and to drink a bottle of mineral water a day.'

Week two

Because he's working at a high intensity, Matt won't alter Martin's programme for the first three weeks. 'We're working on technique and breathing to make every move smooth and easy,' he explains. Physiologically, Martin's body is changing. 'He's growing more muscle fibres, making exercise easier and improving energy,' says Matt.

Martin's diary: 'I have three hourly sessions a week: half an hour of cardiovascular work (running, cycling, rowing machines) and half an hour of weights and floor exercises - I am phenomenally unsupple. I'm told that the mistake most people make is to expect to lose weight immediately. But most fat is converted to muscle. I repeat this as a mantra.'

Week three

The weight loss is starting to kick in. 'Martin has lost about three pounds,' says Matt - what he'd expect from most clients.

Martin's diary: 'It is clear by now just how unfit I am. There are no real visible results, but the combination of enforced exercise and a better diet is having a definite psychological effect. I feel more alert and find it marginally easier to get up in the morning. My stamina is slowly building.'

Week four

Things start speeding up now. 'Martin has reached a reasonable level of fitness, so it's time to crank things up a bit,' says Matt. 'We start bringing in interval training which takes his heartbeat up to 80-85% of its maximum and we start intensively weight training individual muscles - for example, doing three chest-toning exercises in one go.' This is when the results really start to happen.

Martin's diary: 'The remnants of flu mean a day's training is out. But a session of reflexology apparently reveals that I am still a physical wreck and not drinking enough water. The final two sessions of the week are tough, as Simon builds up the pressure. I hate the rowing machine, the best all-round exercise according to the experts, but torture for me. My breathing is more relaxed and I can feel my posture improving. I'm still a funny shape, but now I know what to do about it.'

THE TEAMSTER

This plan combines your own personal selection of daily activities like walking and cycling, and thrice-weekly exercise classes and team-based sports. Elesa Argent, from Holmes Place, Barbican, who helped us devise the programme, says, 'You can increase your health dramatically simply by doing 30 minutes' activity a day.'

In the teamster plan, you're aiming for a variety of different activities not only to keep your interest but also to ensure maximum fitness benefits. 'If you do the same workout too often, your fitness stops improving,' says Elesa. This is particularly prevalent in sports-based plans where you can't easily work faster or harder each session. By swapping exercises, you stop your body getting bored and prevent this.

The four-week programme

Variety is the key here. As well as 30 minutes' activity a day (in short bursts or one long session), Elesa recommends three sessions a week of team sports and exercise classes.

Week one

The most important thing when you start a programme to improve your fitness is to start slowly. Unlike gym-based programmes where you control the intensity of what you do, class- and team-based programmes mean you can get influenced by the fitness levels of others and, if they're more advanced than you, you could end up with injuries.

For week one, Elesa recommends that Vanessa concentrate on the activity-based part of the programme. 'She should be aiming to walk or cycle for half an hour a day - and during each session, she should aim to work harder.'

Vanessa's diary: 'This week seems to be about simply trying to motivate myself. I am concentrating on how it would feel to be fit, but my energy is so low and it is so cold. Elesa tells me that after a couple of sessions it will seem a lot easier.'

Week two

This is the week to add your first exercise class or sport session to those 30-minute activity sessions. Elesa recommends a low-impact, low-coordination class for Vanessa. 'There's no point going to a complex class yet; you'll just get disheartened if you can't keep up or don't know the moves.'

Vanessa's diary: 'She was right. Once you start to move your body about again, things do get better. Although I am still getting puffed very quickly, even from just walking a bit more, I find that my back aches less after a day at the computer and I am sleeping better. Also, happily, the desire to eat bad food diminishes as you start to treat yourself better. This was something I remember from fitter days.'

Week three

Now that you're feeling stronger, it's time to start your first sport. 'Which you choose depends on personal preference,' says Elesa, 'but Vanessa's choice of squash is a good one for beginners, as it's something in which she can control the intensity herself.'

Vanessa's diary: 'This is pure frustration. I am not noticing much of a change in my body shape or energy levels, and so it is hard not to fall into skipping planned visits to the gym. The time needed to arrange a regular squash partner is proving impossible on top of work and doing all the household stuff. I am drinking and eating less (but that might be because I'm getting flu).'

Week four

You can switch up to a more advanced exercise class or sport. As Vanessa is proving, not only will your fitness levels have improved, so will your motor skills, making trickier classes easier. You'll also find you're better at sports that need quick reaction times like squash or tennis.

Vanessa's diary: 'I am trying to start going to aerobics classes again. This, along with swimming, looks increasingly like the right way for me to get healthy because it is so hard to set up regular sessions for squash. Flu has knocked me out, so I feel a bit like I am starting from scratch. But I have more determination. I actually want to keep this going.'

THE TONER

This plan defines your muscles to create a lean, sculpted look which, in turn, improves strength and flexibility. Pilates uses a series of detailed movements that work the muscles deep inside the body.

'Over the years factors like poor posture or injuries alter these muscles. Some shorten and tighten, others become loose and less elastic, and both combined lead to a body that's out of balance,' says Pilates teacher Lynne Robinson. 'This leads to an un-toned figure, poor posture, problems like back pain and even dull skin as the taut muscles trap toxins. Pilates corrects these and reminds your body how to move naturally.' Many of the movements are very small but it takes intense concentration and focus, and it gets results.

The four-week programme

Lynne recommends that Tracy see her three times a week to start with. By week four, she can reduce this to once or twice, working on her own at home for at least another hour.

Week one

The first part of any Pilates programme is a postural assessment that looks for any muscle imbalances, postural problems and/or faulty movement patterns. A personal programme is then devised to correct these and, by the end of the first week, 'Tracy should be more aware of how she stands/sits, etc and recognise problems that need correcting,' says Lynne.

Tracy's diary: 'I've never been scrutinised so closely. Apparently, my centre of gravity is wrong, leading to problems with my back and knees. My first few sessions are spent doing some gentle moves to loosen and tone these areas.'

Week two

'Now that Tracy is aware of how to move correctly, we can start exercises that promote flexibility and strength in the spine. This helps create the "girdle of strength" - a set of strong muscles in the midsection of the body that support every part of it,' says Lynne.


Tracy's diary: 'Things are getting tougher. A lot of the work focuses on my back and abdominal muscles, and I haven't really used these before. The moves are subtle, but you really feel the muscles under your skin. I've been adjusting how I sit and stand outside sessions, trying to get my body into its "natural" position - which feels wrong, as I've been standing incorrectly for so long.'

Week three

As Tracy progresses, she can now use the Pilates machines - particularly the one called the Reformer. 'This really tones the buttocks, arms and legs,' says Lynne. 'Tracy's feeling muscles she never knew existed.'

Tracy's diary: 'Apparently, I'm doing really well. Lynne is already noticing stronger stomach and back muscles and an improvement in my body positioning. My reward is to get on the machines dotted around the studio. I loathe the Reformer. I have to lie legs splayed and lift weights with my thighs - I thought Pilates was supposed to be dignified and gentle.'

Week four

Exercises with weights and more complicated exercise sequences are added to Tracy's programme. 'It'll still be many months before she masters all Pilates has to offer. But everyone will already be noticing that she stands taller and looks leaner - yet she won't really have lost weight,' says Lynne, adding that Tracy will also feel stronger and more energised.

Tracy's diary: 'I'm lifting free weights. The variety of exercises is really surprising and has stopped me getting bored. While I haven't yet noticed a dramatic change in my shape, I'm feeling looser, my stomach and back feel firmer and I'm standing better. People in the studio all have great bodies, which is really motivating.'

THE SPIRITUALIST

The spiritualist programme uses exercise to calm the mind and body. What matters is the sense of relaxation you achieve and the physical benefits that come with this. 'Yoga combines held postures with breath work,' says our teacher Anton Michael Rocke. 'The aim is to help you relax mentally through the use of these held postures, tapping into the fact that each has its own physical, mental and energy benefits.'

The four-week programme

Anton recommends that Richard attend classes three times a week. 'The best class contains a mix of postures, breathing exercises and guided imagery for deep relaxation.'

Week one

Anton says the thing Richard finds hardest is low flexibility, which could make many of the postures seem impossible. However, over the next few sessions, the muscle fibres will lengthen. 'He'll first notice this in the area around the lower back, making positions like this Sitting Forward Bend much easier. Mentally, he'll find his thoughts are less scattered.'

Richard's diary: 'The session has more spirituality, and less stretching, than I expected. There's lots of relaxation and breathing exercises. I can't stretch any distance at all. But I feel good afterwards.'

Week two

'The muscle fibres are lengthening and Richard will notice he has an increased range of movement. He's also getting more accustomed to using his body strength and so even more positions will be within his grasp.'

Richard's diary: 'To my amazement, I am able to move my muscles a little bit more than before. Part of it is in the concentration, I think. Anton has to push and pull quite a bit because my back is hopeless. I am struggling with long stretches, but I am definitely more relaxed.'

Week three

Richard's breathing is getting noticeably deeper. The postures he's practised over the last few weeks have encouraged slower, deeper breathing. 'This will be helping to calm him in day-to-day life,' says Anton.

Richard's diary: 'I've got the breathing thing going much better, which has reduced my anxiety levels. I'm feeling better about my body (an achievement when I look at Anton's!) and am able to do more of the moves.'

Week four

Richard's flexibility is improving quite dramatically, particularly in his legs. 'Because we are so sedentary, the muscles in this area are very tight,' says Anton. 'For many people, this point brings relief from a lot of backaches. Richard should now be better at meditating on his own and finding it easy to switch off from day-to-day pressures.'

Richard's diary: 'I can put my fingers around my feet! My back feels stronger, and the exercises have improved my posture. I am breathing better, and am more relaxed.'

 Check you're up to it. You should always get a health check before you start an exercise programme. Most gyms will do a blood pressure check and ask you about any injuries, but if you're working on your own, you should get a general OK from your GP. This is particularly true if you have any heart or blood pressure problems and back or joint injuries.

 Know your baselines. Taking some simple measurements like resting heart rate, blood pressure, body fat or weight and flexibility before you start will allow you to see how you're progressing. You'll be amazed at how quickly things can change and knowing exact figures can be hugely motivating.

 Get yourself in the right mindset. 'The people who succeed on an exercise programme are those who know why they are doing it. They go into it thinking that they are going to succeed and, more importantly, that they want to do it,' says Professor Stuart Biddle. 'Think of all the things you can gain from exercise and how they're going to benefit your life.'

 Even if the plan fails, stick at it. 'Many novice exercisers think they'll achieve far more than they will and get disheartened when it doesn't happen,' says Professor Biddle. 'Set yourself mini-plans and goals.' Information on useful contacts and addresses will appear in issue three.

Then find 70-80 per cent of that figure - in this case it would be 126-144. Take your pulse for 10 seconds. Count the beats for those 10 seconds and multiply by six. Week three Now that you're feeling stronger, it's time to start your first sport. Flu has knocked me out, so I feel a bit like I am starting from scratch. But I have more determination. I actually want to keep this going.' fields.headline: Mr Straw, you are wrong
fields.trailText: The government deplores the forces of conservatism. It detests Old Labour. And now Home Secretary Jack Straw is a ferocious critic of 'woolly-minded' liberals. The only constituency and philosophy that draws its uncritical admiration is business.
fields.body:
The government deplores the forces of conservatism. It detests Old Labour. And now Home Secretary Jack Straw is a ferocious critic of 'woolly-minded' liberals. The only constituency and philosophy that draws its uncritical admiration is business. It was the fact that businesses in Manchester might make losses with the cancellation of the Tyson fight, explained Mr Straw last week, that had decisively influenced his decision to alter the law of the land and admit a convicted rapist.

Thus the Labour Party enters its centennial year: as the declared enemy of liberalism and of the use of the state to redistribute wealth; an uncertain custodian of public services, and the firm friend in every circumstance of business, entrepreneurship and profit. It is a breathtaking political repositioning, leaving liberal and social-democratic Britain with only the Liberal Democrats to champion its values and beliefs. Mr Straw and Mr Blair congratulate themselves on their courage and political nous. The Observer disagrees.

Mr Straw's hostility to woolly Hampstead liberals comes from his belief that they live in another world to those in British housing estates. For the latter, noisy neighbours, teenagers running amok and courts that side with the perpetrators of crime rather than the victims are the real enemies of the people. Mr Straw believes that he is on their side, and not that of the lofty idealists in privileged north London.

But Mr Straw is fundamentally wrong. Britain has no written constitution to embody its liberal political and social values. Rather its tolerant and liberal society has been built up over centuries by profound social forces calling for justice, fairness and moderation. The populist culture of repression and retribution expressed by Mr Straw has no echo in our literature or political philosophy. He will look hard to find any support in Shakespeare, Dickens, Locke or Russell for the views he now champions. The abysmal conditions on our housing estates cannot be solved by overthrowing the elements of liberalism in our criminal justice system. The British look to our Home Secretaries to sustain our liberalism, not use the power conferred on them by an unwritten constitution to bury it.

So Mr Straw is wrong to construct a two-tier justice system in which the right to trial is not available for a wide range of cases in magistrates' courts. He is wrong to champion a Freedom of Information Act which gives so much discretion to the Government over what will be 'freely available'. Wrong to overturn the rule of law in the Tyson case to protect commercial interests. Wrong to construct a system in which asylum seekers are reduced to poverty-stricken mendicants with no rights. And wrong to seek to associate himself with every populist cause, whatever its rights and wrongs.

For where the woolly-minded liberals are right is that liberalism - a respect for rights, for justice and for liberty on which not only free markets but just societies are built - is an indivisible set of political and moral propositions. This, though it might shock him, is a view that is deeply shared in Britain by rich and poor alike even if not openly articulated. It is part of our heritage and in our blood. Mr Straw holds those who take this view in contempt, a constituency which includes The Observer, its writers and many of its readers. We return the contempt - tolerantly - but with interest.

fields.headline: Eating for weight loss
fields.standfirst: Thinking about losing weight? Doing so isn't nearly as mysterious or difficult as most of the   slimming industry would have you believe
fields.trailText: Thinking about losing weight? Doing so isn't nearly as mysterious or difficult as most of the   slimming industry would have you believe
fields.body:
Sometimes I wish there was a quirky answer to the weight loss issue - 'eating grapefruit after every meal will extinguish all the calories consumed', or 'drinking a herbal tea at 6pm will cause body fat to disintegrate for ever'. I wish!

Despite the fact that hundreds of books profess to have found the answer in some unsubstantiated, wacky theory, the truth is that weight loss is based on a simple equation: eat fewer calories than you expend. For this reason, just getting more exercise will help you to lose weight if you already eat well. Calorie counting can be counter-productive, so the best way to plan your diet is to know what you're eating, and to eat well - but not overeat - within these guidelines.

One area that people neglect when they think about weight loss is the mouth. Because of food manufacturers' slimming campaigns, we resort to eating foods that have had all the taste and goodness removed. Diet and slimline foods are a con - they lead you to think that they're the only way to lose weight. Their poor taste does nothing more than make you feel that eating is something you get over and done with - the only pounds you'll lose are those from your purse, as often the fat and sugars have been replaced with other calorific substances to disguise the poor taste.

Eating in a way that sends plentiful signals back to your fullness centre (located in the brain, within the hypothalamus) should involve more than filling yourself up with low calorie or 'lite' foods - this is a negative and destructive mind-set. There's no difference between a large amount of a low-calorie dish, or a small amount of a high-calorie one. You can eat the foods you love, as your brain will receive copious signals to its fullness, rather than hunger centre, due to your body being satisfied sooner with the foods you actually enjoy eating. Hence you will devour fewer calories. A few simple tips can help you maximise satisfaction:

 Chew your food - don't gulp. Within the jaw are stretch receptors which respond when you chew. The more you chew, the greater the feeling of fullness.

 Try to include some fibre within each meal. Fibres (present in fruits, vegetables, grains, pulses etc) swell in the presence of water and trigger stretch receptors also present in the stomach lining, which send signals of fullness to the satiety centre in the brain.

 Keep your taste buds on their toes. Foods with the highest satiety value are those with several organoleptic qualities - they look, smell, feel and taste good; they even sound good. Juggle textures, tastes or temperatures within a meal, munch one mouthful of chicken and follow with grilled vegetables. This way, you'll be full more quickly than by eating all the chicken first and then moving on to the vegetables (as children often do); the brain will fail to recognise you're meant to be feeling full. Eating the same food, mouthful after mouthful, is rather like having sex in the same position all the time - boring and unsatisfying!

 Concentrate on your food; you'll feel more satisfied than eating while you're distracted.

 Practically everything you put in your mouth provides calories (units of energy). Gram for gram, carbohydrates and proteins provide less than half the calories of fat. Foods with a high percentage of water (such as fruit and vegetables) have fewer calories than those with a high percentage of fat (butter or cream).

Fat

We all need some fat in our diets to carry important fat-soluble vitamins, to help our bodies produce and regulate hormones, and to provide flavour. However, fats are concentrated sources of calories, so one of the best ways to reduce your calorie intake is to reduce your fat intake. A common mistake is to think that margarines and oils have fewer calories than butter; they don't. Unless you have a cholesterol problem, I think the best way to treat fat is to use one you like the taste of, be it butter or extra-virgin olive oil, but keep the quantity down. To cut fat intake:

 Choose the best quality fish, leanest meat and poultry (cut fat off), or vegetables, and cook simply. Grill a fillet steak or wrap a trout in foil and bake to seal in the flavour, rather than smothering them in creamy sauces. Chargrilling gives a tasty slant to vegetables, fish and lean meats and a little fat is needed to stop the food from sticking.

 Instead of cream, base sauces on tomato, or a reduction of wine, perhaps with yoghurt.

 Experiment with yoghurt in dishes where you would use cream. It can be added to soups, served with vegetables such as baked potatoes, and used in salad dressings. Serve it with fresh fruit salad or mix it with fruit compote to make a dessert sauce.

 Watch the pastries, fried and battered foods - they're loaded with fat.

 It's better to stick to normal-fat foods and just keep the quantity down.

Protein

Keep your protein intake balanced - most people should aim to eat a chicken breast-sized portion of lean protein (meat, fish, chicken etc) for their main meal and roughly half this with their lunch/snack. Vegetarians should make sure they're not loading up on the cheese, nuts and oils; these can change a normal protein-rich lentil dish into a high-calorie meal.

Sugars

Natural sugars are found in fruit and vegetables. Refined sugars (which include honey, white and brown sugar) are found in soft drinks, cakes, biscuits, jams and other preserves. All sugar has the same number of calories but refined sugars are the ones to avoid as far as possible, as they provide 'empty' calories - there's no positive nutritional benefit from eating them.

Fresh fruit and fruit desserts will satisfy your sweet tooth at the same time and they contribute valuable vitamins and minerals. Fruit also provides fibre, the weight-loser's ally. The reason why people are often confused when they look at food labels is that sometimes sugar is called carbohydrate. Sugar is one form of carbohydrate, the other is starch, both providing the same number of calories.

As with sugars, starches can be natural or refined. Foods containing refined starch - sugary breakfast cereals, biscuits and cakes, white bread and pasta, white rice - tend to be less satisfying because they have lost fibre in the refining process, resulting in your wanting to eat more of them, which is when you can easily put on weight.

But natural high-fibre starches are found in wholegrain, wholemeal and wholewheat breakfast cereals, flour, bread, pasta, brown rice, potatoes, lentils, chickpeas and beans, bananas, parsnips and other root vegetables. These high-fibre starches provide a good base for a weight-loss plan.

However, don't make the mistake of adding lots of fat or sugar to them - have just a little butter and a high-fibre fruit jam on your wholemeal toast in the morning. High-fibre starches also don't aggravate hunger and energy levels; they're processed by the body at a slow, steady pace, whereas sugary foods are digested and absorbed into the blood very quickly. Rapid changes in your blood sugar level can cause your body to go into 'overeat' mode - eating a chocolate bar may give you an energy lift, but its sugar content is dealt with by the body in a way that is followed by a drop in blood sugar level, and you will soon be ravenously hungry again.

This said, carbohydrates don't seem to work for everyone - some people find they lose weight or feel a lot slimmer if they keep the quantity of high-fibre starches down and get calories from proteins, fruits, vegetables and some dairy products. There is no physiological reason for this, but it's worth a try if your body's not changing - it may just give you the psychological boost you need.

Talking of fibre, incorporate plenty of vegetables and fruits - they're rich in fibre and relatively low in calories. Aim for six portions of fresh fruits or vegetables a day. There is generally no limit to the non-root vegetables (spinach, peas etc), as they have so few calories, but you need to watch fruits and roots; they can contain quite a lot of fructose (fruit sugar) and calories if eaten in too great a quantity. Make them tasty and interesting - use a small quantity of good quality olive oil to dress salads and grilled vegetables.

Don't forget the water - aim to drink around 2.5 litres a day. This enables your body to glean essential nutrients, helps fibre to swell, and refreshes the palate as you're eating, meaning your next mouthful will set those taste buds tingling.
