For this reason, just getting more exercise will help you to lose weight if you already eat well. Calorie counting can be counter-productive, so the best way to plan your diet is to know what you're eating, and to eat well - but not overeat - within these guidelines. One area that people neglect when they think about weight loss is the mouth. Because of food manufacturers' slimming campaigns, we resort to eating foods that have had all the taste and goodness removed. Diet and slimline foods are a con - they lead you to think that they're the only way to lose weight. Their poor taste does nothing more than make you feel that eating is something you get over and done with - the only pounds you'll lose are those from your purse, as often the fat and sugars have been replaced with other calorific substances to disguise the poor taste. Eating in a way that sends plentiful signals back to your fullness centre (located in the brain, within the hypothalamus) should involve more than filling yourself up with low calorie or 'lite' foods - this is a negative and destructive mind-set. There's no difference between a large amount of a low-calorie dish, or a small amount of a high-calorie one. You can eat the foods you love, as your brain will receive copious signals to its fullness, rather than hunger centre, due to your body being satisfied sooner with the foods you actually enjoy eating. Hence you will devour fewer calories. A few simple tips can help you maximise satisfaction:  Chew your food - don't gulp. Within the jaw are stretch receptors which respond when you chew. The more you chew, the greater the feeling of fullness.  Try to include some fibre within each meal. Fibres (present in fruits, vegetables, grains, pulses etc) swell in the presence of water and trigger stretch receptors also present in the stomach lining, which send signals of fullness to the satiety centre in the brain.  Keep your taste buds on their toes. Foods with the highest satiety value are those with several organoleptic qualities - they look, smell, feel and taste good; they even sound good. Juggle textures, tastes or temperatures within a meal, munch one mouthful of chicken and follow with grilled vegetables. This way, you'll be full more quickly than by eating all the chicken first and then moving on to the vegetables (as children often do); the brain will fail to recognise you're meant to be feeling full. Eating the same food, mouthful after mouthful, is rather like having sex in the same position all the time - boring and unsatisfying!  Concentrate on your food; you'll feel more satisfied than eating while you're distracted.  Practically everything you put in your mouth provides calories (units of energy). Gram for gram, carbohydrates and proteins provide less than half the calories of fat. Foods with a high percentage of water (such as fruit and vegetables) have fewer calories than those with a high percentage of fat (butter or cream). Fat We all need some fat in our diets to carry important fat-soluble vitamins, to help our bodies produce and regulate hormones, and to provide flavour. However, fats are concentrated sources of calories, so one of the best ways to reduce your calorie intake is to reduce your fat intake. A common mistake is to think that margarines and oils have fewer calories than butter; they don't. Unless you have a cholesterol problem, I think the best way to treat fat is to use one you like the taste of, be it butter or extra-virgin olive oil, but keep the quantity down. To cut fat intake:  Choose the best quality fish, leanest meat and poultry (cut fat off), or vegetables, and cook simply. Grill a fillet steak or wrap a trout in foil and bake to seal in the flavour, rather than smothering them in creamy sauces. Chargrilling gives a tasty slant to vegetables, fish and lean meats and a little fat is needed to stop the food from sticking.  Instead of cream, base sauces on tomato, or a reduction of wine, perhaps with yoghurt.  Experiment with yoghurt in dishes where you would use cream. It can be added to soups, served with vegetables such as baked potatoes, and used in salad dressings. Serve it with fresh fruit salad or mix it with fruit compote to make a dessert sauce.  Watch the pastries, fried and battered foods - they're loaded with fat.  It's better to stick to normal-fat foods and just keep the quantity down. Protein Keep your protein intake balanced - most people should aim to eat a chicken breast-sized portion of lean protein (meat, fish, chicken etc) for their main meal and roughly half this with their lunch/snack. Vegetarians should make sure they're not loading up on the cheese, nuts and oils; these can change a normal protein-rich lentil dish into a high-calorie meal. Sugars Natural sugars are found in fruit and vegetables. Refined sugars (which include honey, white and brown sugar) are found in soft drinks, cakes, biscuits, jams and other preserves. All sugar has the same number of calories but refined sugars are the ones to avoid as far as possible, as they provide 'empty' calories - there's no positive nutritional benefit from eating them. Fresh fruit and fruit desserts will satisfy your sweet tooth at the same time and they contribute valuable vitamins and minerals. Fruit also provides fibre, the weight-loser's ally. The reason why people are often confused when they look at food labels is that sometimes sugar is called carbohydrate. Sugar is one form of carbohydrate, the other is starch, both providing the same number of calories. As with sugars, starches can be natural or refined. Foods containing refined starch - sugary breakfast cereals, biscuits and cakes, white bread and pasta, white rice - tend to be less satisfying because they have lost fibre in the refining process, resulting in your wanting to eat more of them, which is when you can easily put on weight. But natural high-fibre starches are found in wholegrain, wholemeal and wholewheat breakfast cereals, flour, bread, pasta, brown rice, potatoes, lentils, chickpeas and beans, bananas, parsnips and other root vegetables. These high-fibre starches provide a good base for a weight-loss plan. However, don't make the mistake of adding lots of fat or sugar to them - have just a little butter and a high-fibre fruit jam on your wholemeal toast in the morning. High-fibre starches also don't aggravate hunger and energy levels; they're processed by the body at a slow, steady pace, whereas sugary foods are digested and absorbed into the blood very quickly. Rapid changes in your blood sugar level can cause your body to go into 'overeat' mode - eating a chocolate bar may give you an energy lift, but its sugar content is dealt with by the body in a way that is followed by a drop in blood sugar level, and you will soon be ravenously hungry again. This said, carbohydrates don't seem to work for everyone - some people find they lose weight or feel a lot slimmer if they keep the quantity of high-fibre starches down and get calories from proteins, fruits, vegetables and some dairy products. There is no physiological reason for this, but it's worth a try if your body's not changing - it may just give you the psychological boost you need. Talking of fibre, incorporate plenty of vegetables and fruits - they're rich in fibre and relatively low in calories. Aim for six portions of fresh fruits or vegetables a day. There is generally no limit to the non-root vegetables (spinach, peas etc), as they have so few calories, but you need to watch fruits and roots; they can contain quite a lot of fructose (fruit sugar) and calories if eaten in too great a quantity. Make them tasty and interesting - use a small quantity of good quality olive oil to dress salads and grilled vegetables. Don't forget the water - aim to drink around 2.5 litres a day. This enables your body to glean essential nutrients, helps fibre to swell, and refreshes the palate as you're eating, meaning your next mouthful will set those taste buds tingling.

webTitle: Masked men kill the butcher of Bosnia

fields.headline: Masked men kill the butcher of Bosnia
fields.standfirst: Serbian warlord Arkan shot dead
fields.trailText: Serbia's most notorious war criminal, Zeljko Raznatovic - infamous througout the Balkans under his  nom de guerre of Arkan - was shot and killed in a Belgrade hotel yesterday afternoon by masked assailants.
fields.body:
Serbia's most notorious war criminal, Zeljko Raznatovic - infamous througout the Balkans under his nom de guerre of Arkan - was shot and killed in a Belgrade hotel yesterday afternoon by masked assailants.

The Serb paramilitary leader, sought by the UN war crimes tribunal for alleged atrocities in Bosnia and Kosovo, was declared dead in hospital after being gunned down in the lobby of the Hotel Intercontinental in a volley of automatic weapons fire at just after 5pm. A doctor who attended Arkan said 'all vital functions had stopped'.

Later Serb authorities confirmed his death. Police at the scene said he was shot in the head and taken to hospital for emergency surgery. According to witnesses, Arkan, 47, a former ice cream parlour owner, was drinking with colleagues in the lobby when the men burst in and opened fire, hitting the paramilitary leader in the left eye.

One witness said Arkan's friend and bodyguard, Momcilo Mandic - known as 'Manda' - was shot dead, while another man and a woman - apparently the sister of Arkan's wife, Serbian folk singer 'Ceca', were wounded.

'Arkan was alive when he was taken to a car that drove him to a hospital,' the witness said.

A source said Arkan was hit in the head by at least one round from a Heckler and Koch sub-machine gun. Speculation over the motive was last night focusing on rivalries inside Belgrade's violent mafia underworld which controls drugs, smuggling and the lucrative market in cars stolen from western Europe.

Colonel Bob Stewart, former Nato commander in Bosnia, speculated last night that Arkan's attackers were 'mafia' and said he was widely known to have been involved in gangland activity. Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said: 'Arkan lived violently so it is no surprise that he died violently. I regret his death because it prevents us doing justice to the victims of his atrocities by seeing him in the dock.'

Arkan became infamous after overseeing the massacre of over 250 patients, medical staff and injured Croatian fighters from the city of Vukovar during the Croatian war in 1991. With his Tigers paramilitary group - drawn largely from Serb nationalist gangs and football supporters' clubs - he was also implicated in massacres in Dalj in Eastern Slavonia and ethnic cleansing in Bjilena. More recently Nato commanders insisted Arkan and his Tigers were active in Operation Horseshoe, the ethnic cleansing of Albanians from Kosovo last year, conducting massacres in the wake of attacks by Serb police and army. Arkan was finally indicted for war crimes in Bosnia in September 1997, but the indictment was kept secret until the Nato air cam paign in Kosovo began in March.

He always denied involvement in war crimes.

Reputedly one of Serbia's richest men, Arkan's long criminal record goes back to the 1970s and 1980s in connection with bank and gemstore robberies in Sweden, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. In 1981 he managed to escape police custody from a heavily guarded hospital room in Frankfurt. Interpol issued three arrest warrants against him.

In 1992 Arkan was briefly a deputy in the Serbian parliament. He later left politics and bought the Belgrade Obilic soccer club.

fields.headline: Vatican vultures circle Pope
fields.standfirst: The saga of the ailing John Paul II has taken a bizarre new twist  with claims that he is exaggerating his sickness
fields.trailText: A week of fevered plotting over the Pope's future has turned surreal with claims that John Paul II, a former actor, is faking his illness.
fields.body:
A week of fevered plotting over the Pope's future has turned surreal with claims that John Paul II, a former actor, is faking his illness.

Few doubt that his trembling, immobility and pain are genuine, but the hunt is on for who planted the story - and why.

The Pope, 79, has striven to orchestrate a successor in his own mould but claims that he is exaggerating his sickness to wrongfoot opponents have shocked Vatican officials. Cardinals jockeying to be the next pontiff have been thrown into disarray by the conflicting rumours sweeping Rome.

The timing of John Paul's death or retirement will be crucial to deciding who is chosen to lead the world's one billion Catholics. Suggestions that the Pope was exploiting skills acquired from treading the boards more than 50 years ago in his native Poland were scorned, but they fuelled suspicions of rival disinformation campaigns.

'It is total nonsense, the man is clearly very, very ill, but nothing in this place is said without a reason,' said one senior Vatican official. 'Even if it is just to kick up dust, it benefits the one who does it by confusing those who don't know where it comes from.'

Reports in the Italian newspapers La Repubblica and Il Giornale said the Pope, who was elected in 1978, planned to retire next year to a Polish monastery after jubilee year celebrations are completed.

Under canon law 322 a Pope can 'freely' renounce his office. The first to do it was Celestine V in 1294. Gregory XII tried in 1406 but botched it and ended up deposed.

The uproar caused by Karl Lehmann, the head of the German bishops, who suggested that John Paul could follow suit, has disrupted the discreet campaigns of those ambitious cardinals who dream of one day occupying St Peter's throne.

They cannot be seen to canvass, yet they must somehow woo the college of cardinal electors who will eventually form a conclave to vote for a leader when the throne becomes vacant. There are 156 cardinals but those aged over 80 are banned from voting, leaving 112.

John Paul's 21-year reign has put him on the verge of being the first pontiff to have appointed every cardinal elector. The most recent batch was in February 1998 when he created 20 new cardinals from 13 countries.

About 10 frontrunners have been identified as likely successors, but division over whether the next Pope should be black or white, liberal or conservative, young or transitional, means the winner could turn out to be a virtual unknown, as John Paul was when he entered the 1978 conclave as Cardinal Karol Wojtyla.

Contenders who are calibrating every statement and action in an effort to build up support know that the landscape will be transformed if the Pope calls a consistory, or assembly of cardinals, this year to appoint another batch of cardinals. Rumours swirled through Rome last week that the Pope plans to do that. 'Watch this space,' said one source.

Having stacked the college with like-minded conservatives, the Pope has a final way of influencing the choice of successor: resignation.

Unlike death, he can control the timing to suit his favourite. Despite last week's hype, however, that remains unlikely. A feasibility study he commissioned several years ago reportedly concluded that the Church, despite the provision in canon law, could not function with a reigning Pope looking over his shoulder at his predecessor.

John Paul's conviction that he was chosen by divine force to lead the Church into the third millennium will further fortify his resolve. Just in case anyone was in doubt, the pontiff's slurred voice last week declared that God 'never asks us something which is beyond our powers'.

The fading of his physical powers has been scrutinised since 1993, when surgeons removed an intestinal tumour. He has dizzy spells, which may explain at least five known falls during the Nineties.

But what gives his officials nightmares is his suspected Parkinson's disease, which the Vatican does not confirm but now no longer denies. At some stage it is likely to assail his mental faculties.

'And then what do we do?' said one former aide. 'What happens if he goes ga ga and wakes up one morning blaspheming, or starts pissing out the balcony?'

fields.headline: Bad habit-busters: Smoking
fields.standfirst: Luisa Dillner reviews the best ways to stop for good
fields.trailText: Luisa Dillner reviews the best ways to stop for good
fields.body:
Everyone knows why they shouldn't smoke. But there's no harm in a bit of revision for those who love sucking that smoke deep down into their lungs. Half of all smokers will die early from tobacco-related diseases and those who don't will spend money on an addiction that makes them smell, wrinkled and a social outcast. Never underestimate the addictive power of the fag. For every person who says they found giving up easy, there are 10 who struggled for months. Altogether about three per cent of smokers become non-smokers each year. Maybe the rest didn't know what works and what doesn't.

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)

Nicotine is an addictive drug that changes the chemistry of the brain so don't expect it to give up without a fight. Withdrawal symptoms are so unpleasant most people go back to smoking within 48 hours. NRT is available as gum, patches, nasal sprays and an inhaler - and it works. Trials of NRT show it doubles quit rates, especially if you smoked over five a day.

Gum

Gives your mouth something to do. Heavy smokers may still suffer a bit, as gum can't deliver the huge shots of nicotine but does make levels more stable. Heavier smokers do better on the 4mg as opposed to the 2mg gum. One 2mg gum equals one cigarette. Try weaning after two months.

 Patches

Eight weeks of wearing patches should be enough, and it makes no difference whether you stop abruptly or gradually taper off the patch. You can save money by not wearing it when you are asleep. Try 21mg rather than 14mg for better success rates if you smoke over 20 a day. Nasal sprays and inhaler are both by prescription and are a good bet for those who have failed with gum and patches because they deliver higher rates of nicotine.

 Bupropion (Zyban)

Much hyped in the US - understandably, because who wouldn't love to be cured of nicotine addiction by a pill? Bupropion is an antidepressant prescription drug, shown in trials to help people stop smoking, doubling success rates, especially when combined with NRT. Treatment, by prescription, is for nine weeks, starting a week before the day you plan to stop smoking. In a trial of over 600 smokers in the New England Journal of Medicine, nearly a quarter of those taking the drug were still non-smokers at the end of a year.

 Acupuncture

No real evidence, apart from the anecdotal, that it works. Some people, however, swear it worked for them (especially the needle in the ear area), so there may be individual differences between practitioners and smokers.

 Behavioural counselling

Available in some places on the NHS in groups or individually. De-programmes you from your addiction by explaining the mental processes behind smoking and getting you to change them. There are also techniques to help you avoid relapsing.

 Allen Carr method

An institution that comes in book form (The Easy Way to Stop Smoking), video, CD-ROM, cassette and group and private sessions. It also has a 24-hour helpline. A friend, a heavy smoker, who read the book, says it bored him into submission by relentlessly explaining why he smoked and the myths about its desirability. He is still a non-smoker 10 years later. John Dicey, the main therapist for London, says the group session (four to five hours - a one-off) has a success rate of more than 90 per cent. Smokers puff away through the session, ceremoniously throwing packets onto a pile at clearing-out time. More info on 020 8944 7761.

 Quitline

Offers professional help on freephone 0800 00 22 00 by trained counsellors. Helps when willpower is weak and you are uncertain of your strategies.

 ASH strategies

Worth getting from the Web, 15 top tips such as what to expect (irritability, insomnia and being accident prone) on www.ash.org.uk. Also has a list of why you want to give up smoking (can travel to the US by plane without hyperventilating with nicotine withdrawal) and how much money you will save. Avoid pubs for a while (that feeling there's no point in going if you don't smoke any more will pass) and any other triggers for a fag. Have a holiday in California, where anti-tobacco laws make most bars smoke free.

 Willpower

What all the experts say it boils down to. You have to want to give up, although you can still love smoking and miss it. Few people regret giving up, unlike the millions who regret taking it up in the first place.

Next week: Caffeine

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The New Deal Collection | Dark Star | Central Station | Ronin
fields.trailText: The New Deal Collection (1934-40, E, Academy, Retail/ Rental)
fields.body:
The New Deal Collection (1934-40, E, Academy, Retail/ Rental)

The first of a valuable video series of polemical pre-war US documentaries, made under the auspices of President Roosevelt's National Recovery Act, this compilation is essential viewing for students of cinema and social history. The Plow that Broke the Plains (1936), by Roosevelt's favourite director Pare Lorentz, is a powerful indictment of the ecological disaster that turned much of middle-America into a desert. The River (1937), his follow-up, leads from the exploitation of the Mississippi to its control by way of the Tennessee Valley Authority. In The Power and the Land (1940), the most enduringly revered Communist documentarist Joris Ivens argues the case for rural electrification as a federally sponsored collective enterprise. The fourth film, The New Frontier (1934), is about the creation of a self-help rural community in Texas. All four pictures are didactic, high-minded and openly propagandistic.

Dark Star (1973, PG, Fabulous, VHS/DVD Retail)

Witty, sophisticated shoestring SF movie, this cult classic, made for under $300,000 by director John Carpenter and co- writer Dan O'Bannon, sent up the solemnities of Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey and helped create independent American cinema. Carpenter went on to become a genre specialist with Assault on Precinct 13 , Halloween and The Thing , and O'Bannon scripted Alien and Total Recall.

Central Station (1998, 15, Buena Vista, VHS Rental/Retail)

Walter Salles' road movie gives Fernanda Montenegro, Brazil's greatest actress, a terrific role that brought her an Oscar nomination. She plays a retired primary schoolteacher whose empty, cynical life is changed when she takes an abandoned nine-year-old lad under her wing.

Ronin (1998, 18, MGM, VHS/DVD Retail)

John Frankenheimer was one of the key directors of the 1960s and has done little of real significance since. The Plow that Broke the Plains (1936), by Roosevelt's favourite director Pare Lorentz, is a powerful indictment of the ecological disaster that turned much of middle-America into a desert. The River (1937), his follow-up, leads from the exploitation of the Mississippi to its control by way of the Tennessee Valley Authority. webTitle: The NHS needs money, and much more

fields.headline: The NHS needs money, and much more
fields.trailText: It was refreshing to read a sensible article about the NHS (Leader Comment, last week). As a consultant surgeon, I spend every day of my working life struggling to cope with totally inadequate facilities. The NHS is a national disgrace.
fields.body:
It was refreshing to read a sensible article about the NHS (Leader Comment, last week). As a consultant surgeon, I spend every day of my working life struggling to cope with totally inadequate facilities. The NHS is a national disgrace. The public are only just waking up to this fact, partly because politicians are always telling them how good it is. The patients who use the service know otherwise. It is grossly underfunded and failing miserably. I have cancer patients queuing up at home waiting for surgery because of a lack of beds, overstretched resources, too few specialist surgeons and inadequate operating-room facilities. A flu epidemic may put the NHS in the spotlight briefly but it is up to the media to keep up the pressure on government and campaign for action. Money really is the answer, and lots of it.
Richard Hardwick MD FRCS
Heath, Cardiff

Most sensible and fair-minded people will agree with your leader, printed last Sunday, that the NHS has to be properly funded. They will also realise that this can only be done from income-related taxation. However, I would suggest that not only the NHS falls within this sphere but also education, transport and welfare, including the state pension. The Government must be honest and explain to the public that these four vital services are the responsibility of government, answerable to the people, and therefore have to be paid for by us all.

The role of government is not, as over the past 20 years, to pander to greed and short-term opportunism, thus resulting in the present difficul ties. The role of government is to lead, to inform, to educate and to gain public acceptance of the measures needed to maintain a civilised society, in both the short, and the long term. We did this after 1945, when the country was near bankrupt; surely we can do it again with today's increasing prosperity.
Clifford Fuller
Gloucester

fields.headline: Name-dropping
fields.standfirst: When is Chilean Merlot not Chilean Merlot? Maybe 80 per cent of the time
fields.trailText: When is Chilean Merlot not Chilean Merlot? Maybe 80 per cent of the time
fields.body:
Anyone who has travelled in Chile will know that it's the worst place in South America to buy coffee. The locals are addicted to Nescafé - known to gringos as 'No es café' - so finding an espresso that doesn't taste like macerated llama droppings is almost impossible. To distinguish between instant coffee and the stuff that caffeine-deprived Europeans want to drink, the Chileans have invented a new term: café café.

The use of repetition to distinguish between two very different things has rubbed off on winemakers. Not so long ago, there was only one kind of Merlot in Chile. Now there are two: Merlot and, you've guessed it, Merlot Merlot. (At least it's not called Marilyn Merlot, a 'voluptuous' wine brand currently on sale in California.) It is all very confusing for the befuddled consumer.

Chilean 'Merlot' has nothing to do with the famous and increasingly trendy grape of Bordeaux. Well, almost nothing. It probably came from the same region of south-west France, but there the resemblance ends. The Chilean version was brought to the Maipo Valley in the mid-19th century, 30 years before the variety was wiped off the map of Bordeaux by a vine louse called phylloxera. The descendants of those Chilean pioneers always assumed they had bona fide Merlot in their vineyards, but they were wrong. In the mid-1990s, two French ampelographers visited South America and discovered that - dios mio! - Chilean Merlot was something else entirely: Carmenère.

Carmenère and Merlot, or Merlot Merlot if you prefer, look very different in the vineyard. So much so that even a sozzled wine writer could tell them apart. So why has it taken the Chileans so long to wise up? Two reasons, essentially. First, they thought that Carmenère was a clone of Merlot rather than a different grape. And secondly, even after the Frenchmen cleared the matter up, they were not allowed to use the C-word on their labels. That all changed in 1998, when Carmenère was finally recognised as a grape in its own right by the Chilean authorities.

Confusion persists, however, and not all of it is accidental. One estimate is that more than 80 per cent of the Chilean wine sold as 'Merlot' is actually Carmenère, or a blend of the two varieties. Incidentally, this is part of the reason why Chilean Merlot has always been so good. Carmenère produces wines with plenty of colour and, in most years, lots of soft fruit and fleshy concentration - perfect for everyday drinking. It makes more powerful wines than Merlot, but lacks the class and refinement of the best examples from St Emilion and Pomerol. That's why the winemakers of Bordeaux chose not to replant it after the outbreak of phylloxera.

So far, there are very few 'own-up' Carmenères in Chile. Carmen, Santa Inés, Morandé and Mont Gras have led the way, but most Chilean wineries prefer to be economical with the facts. 'Why should I change the name Merlot to something nobody's heard of?' a top winemaker asked me. 'It doesn't make commercial sense.'

The man is not a fool. In a world where Merlot is a superstar, Carmenère is a struggling unknown. But it doesn't have to stay that way. It is not inconceivable that Carmenère could do for Chile what Pinotage has done for South Africa, Zinfandel for California, and Shiraz for Australia. Chile has lots of very good wines, but nothing that is unique. Carmenère, the grape with a split personality, could change all that. If only it could do something about the local coffee.

fields.headline: Piece meal
fields.standfirst: Whether it's grilled red peppers, salami or a simple bowl of olives, antipasti will whet your appitite
fields.trailText: Whether it's grilled red peppers, salami or a simple bowl of olives, antipasti will whet your appitite
fields.body:
The downside of fast food, or for that matter anything impromptu, is the absence of anticipation. Don't get me wrong - I am all for something spontaneous on the kitchen table from time to time, but equally, I like a bit of notice, something to say that supper is a sure thing. In my house, in culinary terms, this means a little bowl of olives, a few slices cut from a salami and, sometimes, a plate of crisp zucchini, lightly floured and chucked into hot oil, or some melon with prosciutto - what the Italians call antipasto, and meaning, literally, before the main meal.

The British have never been very good at this culinary foreplay, tending to either overachieve with fussy little canapés or taking the slob's route of emptying out a bag of Twiglets and saying, 'Help yourself.' The Italians do it in style, of course, and far more importantly, they understand that what you want at that point in the proceedings is something to stimulate and tempt, and to give you an appetite. Or as Marcella Hazan, the recently retired doyenne of Italian cookery writing, puts it so graphically: 'to set the gastric juices in motion'.

Antipasto is a restaurant thing, really, but I cannot think of eating dinner at home without something to nibble first. You know, that six-o'clock feeling when a bottle begs to be opened and you need something to nibble with it. To be honest, the whole thing is usually deeply informal in my house, with some thin, chewy salami and a dish of olives put on the table to be picked at as I get the rest of the meal ready. A great favourite is nothing more than some bread, admittedly very good bread, and a little dish of olive oil for dunking it in. The more fickle foodies have suddenly become very snooty about this particular antipasto and have started to grandly wave it aside. This sort of foodie one-upmanship drives me quite mad. Have none of their silliness - dunking good bread in deeply fruity olive oil is a delightful way to get those juices flowing.

If someone is coming over for supper, then I will do something hot, too, not to show off, but because hot antipasti such as suppli, the tiny deep-fried balls of rice and melting cheese, or mussels baked with breadcrumbs and garlic are as tempting as nibbles get. Unless you get carried away, no antipasti is a great deal of work - neither should it be - and anyway, who is to know that the suppli were made with yesterday's risotto? Bruscetta, its crunchy bread dripping with heady garlic and new season's olive oil, falls into this category, too. I should mention here that antipasto also allows you time to tinker with whatever is to follow.

Let me tempt you further. Involtini di melanzane are slices of aubergine that have been stuffed with olives, toasted breadcrumbs and pecorino cheese, then rolled and baked, to be eaten warm; oysters are often eaten at this point, too, baked with breadcrumbs and grated Parmesan; garnet-coloured figs can come with chopped mint and lemon juice, or you could end up with the thinnest slices of San Daniele ham with pieces of melon so ripe they weep sweet juice on the way to your mouth.

Then there is the seafood antipasti: the aforementioned baked mussels and oysters, but also clams steamed with white wine, garlic and parsley or gamberetti all'olio e limone, shrimps steamed and peeled and marinated with olive oil, lemon juice and black pepper, and anchovies, too, usually with crusty bread and sweet, unsalted butter.

Tempting though they are, I do think you shouldn't go overboard. The point is to tease the palate rather than to satiate it. This is why antipasto is so often laid out by the door in restaurants in Italy, so you get a hint of them on your way to the table. Too many at home would look silly and, as anyone who has tried to prepare Turkish mezze knows, lots of diminutive dishes can take forever to prepare.

If several people are due, by which I mean about six, then I think you can offer five or six little dishes, but it is essential that some of them are simple, both for the cook and the eater. Sweet and milky mozzarella di buffala drizzled with olive oil, some figs - there are still a few around - and the sweetest melon you can find. Do you sprinkle salt on yours? It really brings out the honeyed sweetness. Whatever, I do think that the majority of antipasti should be something that requires little or no work. These are only nibbles after all, albeit quietly stylish Italian ones.

Suppli
Those who have learned to read recipes through before they start to cook (a lot of us don't, apparently) will probably spot that you could easily use a bit of yesterday's risotto for this. And of course you can, the only proviso being that it must be thick enough to hold its shape. If you detest deep-frying, you may prefer to flatten the balls into patties and shallow-fry them. The effect is much the same, though they are somewhat inauthentic and, in a way, lose just a little of their charm. Either way, the magic lies in the way the cheese melts into long strings. Makes 12 to 15, which is enough for 6 as part of an antipasto

30g butter

1 small onion

5 tbsps risotto rice

500ml hot stock (bouillon powder or even a stock cube

is fine here)

30g Parmesan, grated

1 egg

1 ball of mozzarella (about 125g)

nutmeg

beaten egg and fresh breadcrumbs for coating

groundnut oil for deep frying

Melt the butter in a shallow-sided pan over a low heat. Peel and finely chop the onion and let it cook in the butter until it is tender and transparent, stirring it to keep it from sticking. Stir in the rice, then add a ladleful of stock, turning the heat up a bit so it starts to boil. As the rice absorbs the stock, add more, letting it almost but not quite disappear before adding the next ladleful. Go on until the rice is creamy and thick, but still has a bit of a bite to it. You may not need quite all of the stock. Stir in the grated Parmesan, then spread the risotto, for that is what it is, over a large plate so that it cools and sets.

Beat the egg briefly in a large bowl, then cut the mozzarella into small cubes and add it, along with the cooled rice. Season the mixture with salt, black pepper and a little very finely grated nutmeg. Scoop the mixture into balls. The size is up to you, but I think they should be a two-bite ball, about the size of a golf ball. Set them out on a baking sheet or plate to set a little, then get ready a plate each of beaten egg and fine fresh breadcrumbs.

The next bit is inevitably messy. Roll the balls gently in the beaten egg and then in the breadcrumbs, setting them aside on a plate. Warm the oil in a deep pan. I dislike deep-frying, so I tend to fry them in about 5cm of oil, three at a time, turning them once to cook the other side and keeping the finished ones hot in the oven.

To be really good, they must be eaten hot, so that the cheese forms long, hanging strings.

Insalata di peperoni arrostiti
Many cooks suggest grilling the peppers before skinning and dressing them. I rarely find this leaves them tender enough. If this dish is to be good, then the peppers must be meltingly soft and positively silky to the touch. There are two ways to do this. Either roast them until the skins are black, then peel and dress them, or grill them, tear away the charred skins, then cut them into wide strips and fry slowly in lots of good olive oil. Either way will give you peppers that are seriously tender. Enough for 4 as part of an antipasti

2 large, long red peppers

olive oil

6 anchovy fillets

1 tbsp capers

basil leaves - a small handful

Wipe the peppers and lay them in a shallow, ovenproof dish (you want to save any juices that escape as they cook) and put them under a hot grill, about 15cm away from the heat. Leave them until they are charred and black, turning them as each side blackens. Remove from the heat and cover the dish with a tea towel so the peppers steam briefly, making the skin easier to peel.

When they have cooled just enough to handle, peel off the blackened skin - it should tear away in crisp strips - and discard it. I don't rinse them under running water, as some people suggest. This can remove some of the sweet juices that help to make this dish so toothsome. Cut the peeled peppers into wide strips and set them aside.

Warm 2 tbsps of olive oil in a shallow pan and add the peppers. Let them soften in the warm oil, stewing slowly to tenderness. They should, I think, be on the verge of collapse. Meanwhile, rinse the anchovies and capers and gently pat them dry, then transfer the peppers to a serving dish, the simpler the better, and toss gently with a little new oil, the anchovies, capers and some torn basil leaves.

Fried artichokes with lemon and mint
There is nothing especially authentic about this. It is just something I make at home when I want some hot and almost effortless antipasti. Serves 4 as an antipasto

12 small artichokes in oil

extra-virgin olive oil

1 lemon

12 mint leaves, chopped

for the batter
50g plain flour

1 tbsp sunflower oil

80ml sparkling mineral water

1 egg white

groundnut oil for deep-frying

to serve
a little sea salt, finely chopped mint and some wedges of lemon

Cut the artichokes in half. Pour over just enough olive oil to cover them (you can use it again once you have drained them) and squeeze in the juice of half the lemon and the chopped mint leaves. Set aside overnight, if you can; if not, then for a good couple of hours.

Make the batter half an hour or so before you need it. Don't be tempted to skip this - the resting time is essential for a light batter. Sift the flour with a good pinch of salt, then beat in the oil and mineral water with a fork. Set aside.

Drain the artichokes. Beat the egg white until it is stiff and fluffy, then fold it into the batter. Get the frying oil hot. Submerge the artichokes in the batter, then slide them into the hot oil. Submerge them, holding them down with a draining spoon, until they are golden light and crisp. Drain them on kitchen paper and grind a little salt, scatter some chopped mint and serve in a little white dish with a wedge of lemon.

Meanwhile, rinse the anchovies and capers and gently pat them dry, then transfer the peppers to a serving dish, the simpler the better, and toss gently with a little new oil, the anchovies, capers and some torn basil leaves. Fried artichokes with lemon and mint There is nothing especially authentic about this. It is just something I make at home when I want some hot and almost effortless antipasti. Serves 4 as an antipasto 12 small artichokes in oil extra-virgin olive oil 1 lemon 12 mint leaves, chopped for the batter 50g plain flour 1 tbsp sunflower oil 80ml sparkling mineral water 1 egg white groundnut oil for deep-frying to serve a little sea salt, finely chopped mint and some wedges of lemon Cut the artichokes in half. Pour over just enough olive oil to cover them (you can use it again once you have drained them) and squeeze in the juice of half the lemon and the chopped mint leaves. Set aside overnight, if you can; if not, then for a good couple of hours. Make the batter half an hour or so before you need it. Don't be tempted to skip this - the resting time is essential for a light batter. Sift the flour with a good pinch of salt, then beat in the oil and mineral water with a fork. Set aside. Drain the artichokes. Beat the egg white until it is stiff and fluffy, then fold it into the batter. Get the frying oil hot. Submerge the artichokes in the batter, then slide them into the hot oil. Submerge them, holding them down with a draining spoon, until they are golden light and crisp. Drain them on kitchen paper and grind a little salt, scatter some chopped mint and serve in a little white dish with a wedge of lemon.

fields.headline: The worm turns
fields.standfirst: It's official: garden worms turn paper into perfect compost. Now there's an idea for this page...
fields.trailText: It's official: garden worms turn paper into perfect compost. Now there's an idea for this page...
fields.body:
Making usable compost is at the heart of all good gardening. It is certainly essential for any organic garden, as it embodies the principle of organics, recycling waste in any form and returning it to the soil to enrich future plant growth, which, in turn, will provide the raw material for future compost. The organic garden can never have too much waste or too much compost.

The process of making compost has the same magic as breadmaking. Both rely on experience, performance and natural function and are satisfyingly poised between success and failure. It is also an important element in reducing landfill sites. A staggering half of all household waste is easily compostable in the garden.

I know that, to the unconverted, compost has all the allure of filling in a tax return. Somehow one feels that composting is not, and never will be, the new sex. I think the answer lies in the compost itself. For, according to a recent survey made by the Centre for Alternative Technology (CAT), most gardeners go through the motions of making compost but fail to make it in any acceptable form. People bang on about the importance and beauty of sweet-smelling, rich, crumbly stuff that looks, smells and feels like exceptionally rich soil, yet it seems that the most common experience is of an unpleasant-smelling sludge occupied by the odd rat.

The CAT survey found that, while everyone knew what 'good' compost was, no one was able to agree on exactly how to make it. Some said there should be holes in the container, others said you must use an activator and others still that you should make aerating holes in the heap. And these were just the experts.

They did, however, agree on the need to turn the compost, ideally every three weeks.

But the one certainty that came from CAT's investigations was that almost no one turns their compost at all, let alone every three weeks. This was partly due to human frailty and partly because it is horribly hard work if the compost heap reaches any size - which it must do if it is to generate enough heat. So, advising people to turn their compost every month is a waste of time. CAT tested tumbler-type compost makers and found them to be useless. They simply inverted the waste rather than mixing it up.

So they did some experiments and found that composting works best if the initial ratio of the ingredients is about 30 parts carbon to one part nitrogen. More carbon, and the process will be slower; more nitrogen, and the result will be too slimy and undecomposed. Conventional advice is that you layer your compost material, mixing up the drier carbon with the wetter green stuff. But in real life, it all gets chucked on as and when. Kitchen waste is always high in nitrogen, and the smaller the household, the less carbon there is likely to be. Grass clippings - the most common component of compost heaps - have half the carbon-to-nitrogen ratio that is needed. Conscientious householders who liberally lace their compost heap with an activator - also high in nitrogen - just compound the problem. The result is not compost but said sludge.

However, there is a solution: add more carbon. Straw is ideal for this. If garden centres sold straw in small bales for composting, that would solve the problem at a stroke. Mix grass clippings with an equal volume of straw and they rot down beautifully. But it is hard enough getting straw in the countryside, as most of it is made into huge bales, let alone in a town.

CAT went back to the drawing board and had a brainwave. Paper - wastepaper - is the solution. It is biochemically similar to straw, being essentially partly digested cellulose, and available to every household. We fill our bin bags with huge quantities of paper and cardboard packaging every week - as much as 40 per cent of all landfill matter - from cereal packets to kitchen towels. Put it all on the compost heap, and not only will it rot down to provide good compost, but it will also dramatically reduce the amount of landfill. That way you get to save your garden, your soul and the planet in one fell swoop.

Aspects of this method seemed to confound all previous conventions. For one, it hardly heated up, as most of the compost was generated by invertebrate activity - mainly from brandling worms, which love wet paper, and also from woodlice and slugs, nematodes, beetles and centipedes. They all ate the compost and then excreted it politely at the bottom of the heap. After about a year, only the 'worm compost' (invertebrate dung by any other name) remained. Perfect. There was no evidence that turning was required, although it might have speeded up the process. It was necessary to keep the compost moist, but the best heaps were open ones kept damp by rainfall. They also found that the bigger the surface area, the better (the minimum being a square metre) and that it should not be too high. A wide, low pile decomposes faster because most activity is from the bottom up.

I have been experimenting with this for the past six months, and it works like a dream. It is astonishing how much invertebrate activity is created by the presence of a few bits of cardboard and paper. Crumple up smaller stuff and tear up cardboard boxes. You want as large a surface area as possible exposed to other compost material. Paper should be mixed in with vegetable waste rather than in lasagne-like layers, and it is better to cover cardboard or paper with nitrogenous stuff such as grass clippings. The system works. No more turning, a lot less household waste and a lot more good garden compost.

fields.headline: Last battle of Hitler's historians
fields.standfirst: Neal Ascherson, chronicler of the great events in postwar Europe, spent the past week in court assessing a case that goes to the heart of the last century's worst crime
fields.trailText: Neal Ascherson, chronicler of the great events in postwar Europe, spent the past week in court assessing a case that goes to the heart of the last century's worst crime
fields.body:
Armageddon in Courtroom 37? Some older people on the public benches hope for that. As David Irving begins his libel action against Penguin Books and Deborah Lipstadt, author of Denying the Holocaust, they sit there with faces stiffened by the memory of pain.

Some of them hope this trial will be a sort of Last Judgment, the breaking of the Seventh Seal to reward the righteous and drown the wicked, and flood the Earth with truth too blinding to deny.

But there is nothing apocalyptic about the old Queen's Bench Division, off the Strand in London. Last Tues day, it was just another libel case that began. The usher carefully writes out COURT FULL on a scrap of paper and hangs it on the door. The wind moans and wails in the double-glazing. The scholar with the appalling cough is barking to death on a diet of Strepsils; the ginger-haired lad who stenotypes the record glares at him without sympathy. And three upper-class Englishmen - a judge, a barrister and David Irving - are having a civilised conversation about the darkness at the end of the world.

All the same, there are invisible last chances in the room. The first is about handing on truth. It is 55 years this month since Soviet troops entered what was left of Auschwitz: the Nazis had dynamited the gas chambers and the Russians now set fire to the typhus-infested huts. Those who saw what happened there and elsewhere, to Jews and to the other human categories redefined as vermin, are today few and near the end of their lives.

Idealists, like some of those vigilant old people on the public benches, dream that this trial will culminate in a mighty rite of transmission. It will lay out one last time the evidence about what was done in the Holocaust (to how many, by whom, in what manner and why). The young generations will lose the voice of the witnesses. But they will be armed instead with a judgment.

The other last chance, more convincing, is Irving's. For something like 40 years, this strange figure - historian or chronicler or propagandist - has laboured at a single gigantic project which could be called (begging some questions) the rehabilitation of Adolf Hitler. Book after book, lecture after lecture and libel action after libel action, Irving has slogged on with the world's most unpopular historical enterprise. His skill at sniffing out unknown Third Reich documents is a legend. But the way he chooses to interpret them has so far condemned him to failure.

This trial may be his last throw, although he has a similar action pending against this paper. Last week in Court 37, Irving hurled himself at those he regards as his real foes. In the person of Professor Deborah Lipstadt, he is trying to defeat a new generation of Jewish-American intellectuals, who have spread their own version of 'Holocaust Studies' and defined 'Holocaust Denial' as an offence - in some places, as a crime.

The declared purpose of Irving's libel suit is to punish them for calling him a 'Holocaust Denier', and thereby allegedly wrecking his career. Irving accepts that an enormous slaughter of European Jews took place. What he disputes is its scale, circumstances and authorship. He will bring witnesses to 'prove' the Auschwitz gas chambers were mostly mythical. He refuses to accept the killing as 'systematic'. And he insists Hitler didn't know and wouldn't have approved.

But if Irving were to win this case, the impact would be far greater than damages. At the last possible moment, his reputation as a credible historian would be salvaged. His version of Hitler and the Holocaust would be given a degree of plausibility.

A last chance for David Irving in Court 37 - that can be argued. But a last chance for truth and history? Watching last week, I remembered the saying that for establishing what really happened in history an English libel court is the worst place in the world.

That saying emerged, as far as I remember, from one of the most famous, spectacular and (for once) really important libel suits of the last century, the 'Cossacks Trial' of 1989 in which Lord Aldington sued Count Tolstoy. Tolstoy had blamed him for the handover of 70,000 anti-Soviet Russian soldiers to Stalin's vengeance at the end of the last war.

Aldington won: the jury awarded him £1.5 million damages. But in the process the trial churned the business of historical inquiry into a sort of Passchendaele of fear and confusion. The jury found that Aldington was not to blame but the trial actually made it far harder to find out who was really responsible for the only serious war crime committed by the British Army in World War II.

The judge lopes in with a sort of athletic impatience, and as we rise I recognise in Mr Justice Gray that Charles Gray QC who was Aldington's barrister 11 years ago. And here - ironic, relentless - comes Richard Rampton QC, counsel for Lipstadt and Penguin Books. He fits his wig on, and reveals himself as the man who was Count Tolstoy's advocate and Charles Gray's duelling opponent.

Well, there. Both men did their best for their clients, and neither is to blame for the way that trial reduced history to toxic sludge. But the tale of the Jewish Holocaust, the worst deliberate act in modern European history, is like the Cossack tragedy in two ways: it is neither entirely simple nor entirely known.

There are areas piled high with documentation - passenger lists, death lists, crematorium blueprints. But there are also huge gaps. How many died? We are less certain about that than 20 years ago. Did Hitler know, did he order it? I am certain he did. But the signed directive, even the secondary letter or phone note confirming this, has never been found. What chance is there that this trial in London will clear up mysteries and bring clarity rather than thicken the fog?

It's unfair to say an English libel trial is not about truth. It has something to do with proof, after all. But above all it is about people. It is about the personalities of libel litigants, the way they can be made to seem liars and cheats or selfless victims, their breaking-strain under interrogation, their motives for suing. This trial is unusual. Given the wall-stacks of documents, largely in German, the parties agreed that a jury would be overwhelmed, So Mr Justice Gray will decide verdict, costs and any damages on his own, without even a pair of lay judges or assessors to help him.

And David Irving has no lawyer. He is conducting his own case. This is impressive, but it means the judge has to make allowances for any amateurism and make sure Irving knows his rights. As for Lipstadt, she has decided not to testify. She sits quietly in the front row, busy with her laptop, looking unhappy.

All week, Irving has been defending his reputation, while Richard Rampton seeks to prove he is a liar and distorter. Irving, at bay, hunches giant blue-suited shoulders around his ears, his eyes glittering like a badger's. Fragments of history are snatched out of context, dried, treated and used as firelighters to scorch an adversary.

We spend hours on the timing of a scribbled Himmler phone-note about how a transport of Berlin Jews should be treated in Riga, on a bugged conversation between captured SS men in London about whether somebody said he had an order from Hitler to kill Latvian Jews, on the meanings of words such as Vernichtung (destruction) or Judentum (Jewry).

The civilised voices fence on. But they drop names too, and the shadows of human beings flit across Court 37: SS monsters from the pit such as Odilo Globocnik and Dieter Wisliceny. Or the unnamed human reality of that Judentransport steaming from Berlin towards death in Riga (whose grandfathers, whose maiden aunts?).

Once, in a bout with Rampton over whether the Führer had ordered the extermination of the Jews, David Irving reminded him that no signed order had been found. That, said Rampton, was just negative evidence. Noisily, Irving retorted: 'I have to remind you of the basic principle of English law that a man is innocent until he is proved guilty: am I right?'

And at that second there was a tiny stillness in Court 37. We were talking about Adolf Hitler.

fields.headline: Tony Blair catches a cold
fields.standfirst:
The voters are ready to hear the truth about funding the health service, but the politicians dare not tell it.
New Labour in power: special report
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Head spinning? Body aches in every joint? Feverishly crawling into bed to splutter under the duvet? It doesn't have to be the flu. You may be trying to follow the argument about the funding of the health service. The correct diagnosis is not to be obtained by ringing NHS Direct.
fields.body:
Head spinning? Body aches in every joint? Feverishly crawling into bed to splutter under the duvet? It doesn't have to be the flu. You may be trying to follow the argument about the funding of the health service. The correct diagnosis is not to be obtained by ringing NHS Direct.

After nearly three years of caring, sharing, modernising, twenty-first-century New Labour Government, our health service is less well provided for than that of dirt-poor, ex-communist, basket-case Poland. So opines Robert Winston, distinguished fertility expert, celebrity TV documentary-maker, peer of the Labour realm, and a man on such intimate terms with the First Couple that he can tell us how Cherie plans to have the Blair babe delivered. The good Lord tells us that the NHS is in intensive care, for want of money.

Au contraire, as they say in Geordie, insists Alan Milburn. The head spinologist at the Department of Health maintains that the Government has given the NHS 'the biggest cash injection' of all time. And the sum endlessly recited by the Health Secretary - £21 billion - does indeed sound like a lot of stethoscopes.

The trouble is that it only magnifies the Government's difficulty explaining why patients are being rattled hundreds of miles around the country in search of a hospital that can care for them. If they are really spending so much more than those slash-and-burn Conservatives, why is the health service in no better shape to cope with a predictable outbreak of winter influenza? The answer must be that New Labour is hopelessly inefficient at spending taxpayers' money, which is surely not a conclusion that Ministers want us to reach. If that's not the case, then the Government is hoist by its own hype.

That £21bn is funny money. Stretch it over three years, strip out the triple-accounting, take away inflation, allow for the ever-increasing demand for more sophisticated and expensive health care from a longer-living and more affluent society, and take into account the spending clamp over the first two years of the Government's life. Then, those billions shrivel into small change. Labour is not only spending much less on health as a proportion of national wealth than our European neighbours. On current spending plans, this Government will spend no more real money, perhaps even less, over the lifetime of this parliament than that appalling Major regime which they toppled on the promise that things could only get better.

No one knows this more acutely than Mr Milburn. Touring the television and radio studios, he is professionally compelled to argue that the health service is 'coping', as if she were an elderly aunt with a terminal illness who, all things considered, is remarkably cheerful in the face of so many adversities. Pacing the dark corridors of Whitehall, he is trying to squeeze an immediate cash salve from the fist of Gordon Brown. The whisper is that the Department of Health is bidding for an additional £30bn over three years in the new round of spending negotiations with the Treasury.

This points to the golden lining to this winter crisis for the Health Secretary. It has pushed him to the head of the queue of spending Ministers desperate for attention from Dr Brown. An Education Minister I spoke to in recent days mournfully observed that if his department was not to be a loser to health, then what David Blunkett badly needs is some sort of crisis in schools. Similar thinking will be going on at the Home Office. Jack Straw is not a man easily shamed, but the Home Secretary is increasingly uncomfortable trying to explain away the fall in police numbers. John Prescott will probably not have to manufacture a transport emergency to bolster his bid for extra billions. Accidents have a way of finding him.

At the heart of New Labour's spending problem is that it won the last election on the basis of a big fib. The fib is that we can have world-envied public services without having to pay what they cost. The fib was told - and by Tories, too - because it is what all politicians continue to assume that Middle Britain wants to hear. Tony Blair pleads that there 'will always be capacity constraints', accountant-speak which will be of little comfort to anyone whose gran will die of cancer for want of an intensive-care bed.

'We said there would be two tight years,' insists the Prime Minister. I expect that Downing Street could rustle up an old speech in which, if you read the small print, Mr Blair mumbled something along those lines. What I can't bring to mind is when he told us that the NHS would continue to be as overstretched and under-staffed as under those terrible Tories. What most of us remember rather more vividly is his headline claim that only Labour could be trusted to save the health service which it had founded.

The Government is in this hole for understandable reasons. One was the history of previous Labour governments, which oversplurged on public spending early in their life. Transfixed by the need to establish the confidence of the markets, the Prime Minister and Chancellor strapped themselves into an iron corset. They also felt they had to prove to the public that they could spend money wisely and efficiently, which is why there is such relentless emphasis on modernisation. And determined to shed forever Labour's reputation as the party of high taxation, they resolved that what additional resources were raised would be done so by stealth.

It seems to me that this strategy is exhausted. The voters, no longer so beguiled by cuts in income tax, are alive to the fact that they will pay for them either in other, sneakier imposts or at the expense of vital public services. In the United States, George W. Bush, the man most likely to be come the Republican candidate for President, is on the back foot trying to justify his tax-slashing agenda. Even allowing for the propensity of people to tell porkies about their willingness to shell out for improved public services, an astonishingly high proportion of Britons now say they'd forsake the income tax cut the Chancellor has planned for them for improvements to the health service.

The electorate is sophisticated enough to know that they will pay one way or another. It could be in new charges for visiting the GP and staying in hospital. This idea was secretly toyed with when the Government first came to power. It was rapidly dropped when Ministers realised that not only would it ignite vast controversy, but there would have to be so many exemptions for the young, the elderly and the poor that the charges would probably raise little more than the cost of collecting them.

Another route - the road down which the Tories are pressing - is to reduce demand for state provision. The expansion of private insurance, either by deliberate design or by letting the health service become so rotten that anyone who can afford to opt out does so, would certainly take some strain off the system. It would also undermine any commitment the better off had to funding the NHS. The prospect of it becoming an American-style safety-net sink service is one which rightly terrifies Ministers.

The alternative is finally to confront the people with the truth that if they want a health service that is a beacon to the world, then it can only be paid for from taxation. I think the people are ready to hear it. What I doubt is whether most of the politicians are brave enough to say it. Pass the paracetamol.

webTitle: Hell on wheels, but still  the jokes keep coming

fields.headline: Hell on wheels, but still  the jokes keep coming
fields.standfirst: Observer journalist  John Sweeney  last week went undercover as a hospital porter as the NHS reached crisis point. His story is one of chaos on the wards, but also one of heroic forbearance and unfailing humour among patients and staff
fields.trailText: Observer journalist John Sweeney last week went undercover as a hospital porter as the NHS reached crisis point. His story is one of chaos on the wards, but also one of heroic forbearance and unfailing humour among patients and staff
fields.body:
My first patient was as frail as a porcelain teapot but, though in her nineties with thin wisps of hair plaited over her head, she was oddly girlish. As the newest hospital porter at St Thomas Hospital, I was to take her from 'transport', where the non-emergency ambulances and taxis come in, to the eye department, in a cumbersome wheelchair.

As we pushed off, she said in the poshest rah-rah voice: 'Is this a BMW?' I played Q to her 007: 'All the usual accessories, 007...'

And off we went. We got ten yards. To get from the lower ground floor on the Lambeth wing to the eye ward on the ground floor of the north wing is an easy run. If the lifts work. But they don't. A growing throng of walking patients, relatives and the wheelchair-bound waited. And waited.

The lift came, we jammed in and spun round to the eye ward. En route, the old lady declared that for the Millennium she had drunk champagne washed down by mulled claret. They have fun, these old biddies.

I went back to the lodge to get the next job, to be told: 'Find a wheelchair.' There weren't any. Half an hour later I decanted one old codger from a wheelchair into a normal chair - passing on the problem of moving him to some other poor soul - so that I could whizz back to transport. And wait for the lift going down. And then pick up, and wait for the lift.

At 'Tommy's' none of the lift shafts are numbered for easy identification. None of them have a telephone number clearly marked on them, to report faults immediately. The non-medical side of the hospital doesn't just lack money, it lacks confidence, nous, imagination. New lifts are planned, and will happen in two years' time, but somehow that has meant they have almost given up repairing the old ones.

Moving patients around is like walking through glue. The computer in the porter's lodge logs in red patients who have had to wait an especially long time. During the day the reds grew and grew, not because the porters were lazy or incompetent, but because the simplest things - getting a lift, finding a wheelchair - didn't work.

That first morning another porter showed me around. We picked up an elderly Asian man. He was desperate to get back to his ward on the north wing, but when the lift came it was crowded out with a patient in a bed being moved by another porter. So we waited for the next lift. And waited. The porter and I did a bit of banter, making it easier to switch off the humanity in thewheelchair. Our patient was weeping, silently. The lift had taken so long, he had wet himself.

When we got to the ward, the other porter didn't want to have to wipe off the urine, so he dumped the wheelchair by the patient's bed. A nurse ran after us: 'We're really busy, you've got to take that away.' We left it in the corridor, seat still covered in urine. 'You never clean up,' said the porter, 'unless it's a removal' (taking a dead body to the mortuary).

Had it not been my first morning - I was new, unsure - I would have argued the point, and cleared it up myself. By the time another porter came along, the urine could have dried and the next patient would have had to sit in another man's piss. This was the only time I saw a porter - or anyone in the hospital - act without humanity.

Back at transport... chaos. The controller, a poor wretch of a woman, had a room full of elderly and infirm patients staring miserably into space and, outside, a car park jammed with minicab drivers and non-emergency ambulances, all waiting to move the patients home. And the machine that made sense of it all had switched itself off. Five patients were queueing for her attention. The phone rang, and she barked: 'I've got a complete computer close-down. I've got a wait of at least two hours.'

I was dispatched, along with a woman porter who had only been at the hospital four days, to move a patient from an intensive care unit to an ambulance, picking up the ambulance wheel-stretcher first. Neither of us knew where to go. As we traipsed around Accident and Emergency, a stretcher case came in, howling with pain, shoulder dislocated. His girlfriend followed him, carrying tell-tale roller blades. He howled again, a wolf in Lambeth.

We found the stretcher, a complicated affair of folding metal struts and the other porter declared: 'I'm crash-trained.' But from her lack of confidence I was worried she didn't know how to work it. She wanted the ambulancemen to come with us, but they wanted a break, so we went to the ward on our own. The patient turned out to be a huge man. 'I'm crash-trained,' my companion told the ward doctor, then started wrestling with the stretcher as if it was some great aluminium crocodile. There was a huge crash as it collapsed to its flat state. So that was what 'crash-trained' meant.

The patient lowered himself on to the flat stretcher, and we tried to heave it up. We couldn't do it. The patient got up, and then we had another go. This time it worked, and the patient made it to his ambulance, mysteriously still alive.

Another day, another heroic patient. She was beautiful, dark-haired, in her mid-thirties, pale and frail, with an oxygen tube leading to her nostrils, and sitting in her wheelchair reading a fat novel by Vikram Seth. We talked books - her backing Seth, me plumping for Harry Potter - as we headed for the eleventh floor on the north wing.

The lift was packed. The press of people was too much for her: 'I'm going to be sick.' Everyone decanted on the tenth, and she started coughing into her hands. The lift treacled up to the eleventh. I almost sprinted with her to the ward, but not fast enough. The nurses wiped her clean, but she was so apologetic and grateful for my efforts that I hurried off, on the edge of tears.

As the days ground on, the patients blurred into each other, but moments of their ordinary yet extraordinary heroism still stand out, and the hospital's wit, and the gentle humanity of the nurses.

One of the sweetest things about being a porter was wheeling patients out on their way home. The nurses would pause from taking notes or checking drips or washing someone and look up and say: 'Goodbye, Joe', 'Take care, Joe', and they'd go on so much that poor oldJoe would be choking back the tears with pride and pleasure at having made so many friends.

The nurses weren't saps, mind. I turned up at one ward without a wheelchair and the staff nurse snapped: 'Going to carry the patient on your back, are you?' Another nurse sneezed on me and I said: 'It's all right, I'll change my shirt.' She came back: 'It wasn't ironed, anyway, was it?'

The NHS wards were packed solid but had an earthy companionship about them. 'Kinship is healing; we are physicians to each other,' Oliver Sacks wrote, and in that phrase he summed up the wonderful democratic spirit of the NHS.

The private wards, on the twelfth floor of the north wing, were a little Switzerland: quieter, cleaner, much better decorated but colder, emptier. And the private patients locked away in their private rooms seemed lonelier and more miserable than the NHS ones. I can't recall a single joke heard in the private wards.

And in the public? There are too many. I brought a 92-year-old back from X-ray. He could walk, just, and crept to the loo. I looked at his bedside table and saw a jug of Ribena and a copy of Loaded . Another patient, an 85-year-old, saw the magazine too. We both looked at the randy devil, tottering towards the loo: 'You would have thought, at his age ...'

The lady, originally from County Cavan, had been waiting for an hour-and-a-half when I found her - and I had only been looking for a wheelchair. The nurses had called for a porter three times, and even the doctor had called down. A sweet Irishwoman, she wasn't the complaining type. I took her down to the lift and across to X-ray, but she was late. At the end of the day I found her again in transport, waiting some more. She leaned over to me and whispered, quietly: 'I've never had such a horrible day.'

Through no fault of her own, she had missed some of her appointments and would have to come back.It was half past four, and she had been picked up at nine in the morning. Patients don't understand hi-tech medicine, but they do understand and resent hanging about. For nearly every patient I spoke to, the pointless waiting was the worst. But you could tell that no one with power in the hospital - still less the NHS - has addressed the simple, boring complaints: how long does a patient have to wait for a porter, the patient and porter for a lift, the patient to queue for the right doctor. For the doctors who run the hospitals, what matters is good medicine for the patients. For the patients who pay for the health service what matters is subtly different: not good medicine butgood treatment. They don't like being treated like cattle.

I suspect that most patients, particularly the elderly, would rather die earlier than be kept waiting for hours while they are alive. In that simple but fundamental way, the NHS is misdirecting huge amounts of resources and money.

The lack of money impacts on care and dignity in the wards. I turned up at a ward to wheel an old man down to X-ray in his bed. He was out of his bed, upright, saying: 'I'm all sticky.' He had soiled himself. To deal with that, the nurse would have had to stop doing her drugs round and wash his bottom - and that would knock on to his X-ray appointment, which he might miss completely. So she compromised: 'You'll be all right.'

He made the journey in silence. That night, dog tired from walking around the hospital all day, I overheard the staff nurse talk to a younger one, called Sarah O'Connor: 'Can you do a double shift tomorrow?' She nodded, but made no attempt to conceal the look of exhaustion on her face.

He was a very sick old man, his body covered in tubes and surrounded by bleeping machines, lost to consciousness. Two nurses and two doctors unhooked some of the tubes, plugged in others and we were off. In getting out of the door, the bed became trapped and a saline drip was punctured, causing a small fountain of clear fluid to erupt and shower the patient and us.

The bed stopped, and the nurses and doctors plugged the leak. Then we were off again, this time with the porter at the front, steering the bed while walking backwards. It was a long journey, and a terrifying one. I didn't want him to die while I was steering his bed.

We made it to the scanner. Half an hour later I pushed the bed back. The lift button for 'going up' on the first floor of east wing had not been working since Christmas, one of the porters had said. It still wasn't. So the patient, his tube and bleeps, the doctor, the two nurses and I had to go down to the ground floor, and then ping ourselves up again.

For a full week being a porter I would have earned £151.74. At six on Friday night I handed out the X-rays to the wards. At the intensive care unit, the lights were down, conversation subdued. The sister was talking to a staff nurse: 'Have you asked any of them on tonight whether they can work tomorrow?' Oh, I've asked them all.' The sister looked up, and the staff nurse shook her head and said: 'Definitely not.'

The best health service in the world?

 Britain has about the lowest number of doctors in the developed world, with one for every 625 people. In the US it's one for every 384, and in France one for every 344.

 Britain spends less on health care than virtually any other developed country. In 1997, we spent £869 per head on health, compared with £1,245 in the Netherlands, £1,490 in Germany and £2,559 in the US.

 Over the last 10 years, the number of acute beds in Britain has fallen by 25,000.

 Men with lung cancer have only a 7 per cent likelihood of living five years in Britain, half the survival rate of France, Spain and the Netherlands.

 Women with breast cancer have a 67 per cent chance of living more than five years, compared to 80 per cent in France, Sweden or Switzerland.

 Every year, 314 of every 100,000 men in Britain die from heart disease, compared with 202 in Australia, 233 in the US and 251 in Germany.

 Britain carries out fewer heart operations of almost all types than nearly any other developed country in the world. * The amount spent on food per patient per day by the NHS: £1.70.
