fields.headline: Confidence in a tarnished age
fields.trailText: Confidence is at the heart of economic policy. Once forfeited, it is hard to regain. The Labour Party took almost 20 years to recover from its travails of the 1970s; and the Conservatives finally lost the confidence of a sorely tried nation on Black Wednesday 16 September 1992.
fields.body:
Confidence is at the heart of economic policy. Once forfeited, it is hard to regain. The Labour Party took almost 20 years to recover from its travails of the 1970s; and the Conservatives finally lost the confidence of a sorely tried nation on Black Wednesday 16 September 1992.

The economics of Roosevelt and Keynes were essentially aimed at restoring the confidence and 'animal spirits' of businessmen whose nerves had been badly shattered by the post-1929 Depression (when output in the US fell by a third).

During the golden age of the 1950s, there was a lot of confidence around in the competence of economic policy-makers; and more and more analysts are now writing as if we have returned, via low inflation and the technological revolution associated with computers and the Internet, to that golden age.

Someone who has reflected as much as anyone on the precise significance in economic history of the revolution in information technology is Alan Greenspan, chairman of US Federal Reserve. Although Greenspan's speeches are usually reported for their relevance to interest rate policy, his collected works are more those of a pragmatic economic historian who was taught in his youth to beware the four words: 'This time it's different'.

In his more recent speeches, Greenspan has given more weight to the view that the US has indeed been experiencing some kind of productivity miracle.

But last week, against a background of the US valuing high-technology stocks at on average 200 times their annual earnings, Greenspan said it was not yet clear whether we were witnessing 'a once in a century acceleration of innovation', or 'one of the many euphoric speculative bubbles that have dotted human history' - or elements of both.

There is no lack of confidence in Greenspan. Indeed, if anything, the US adminis tration and the financial markets are over-confident, imbuing him with magical powers. People may have forgotten, but a number of Greenspan's predecessors, including Paul Volcker, were also regarded as so important to business, consumer and market confidence as to be irreplaceable. President Clinton has decided that Greenspan will be replaced by Greenspan.

One of the great things about Greenspan is that, unlike US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers, he does not radiate over-confidence. He is cautious. He listens, and he studies every available statistic. This darling of a Democratic administration is in fact very right wing, even by US standards. He comes from a school that would not have been as generous as he in erring on the side of employment rather than deflation.

Of course, he and his committee are obliged by law to aim at maximum employment. This is unlike the brief of the European Central Bank or the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee. If the Fed had been subject to the MPC's 2.5 per cent inflation target, it would have missed that target in 10 of the past 12 years.

There is plenty of scope in the Fed's brief for encouraging growth, and Greenspan has taken full advantage of that. But all the best aspects of the American economic system have contributed to its recent strong performance. To read some of his adulators, you would think Greenspan was personally responsible for the innovation associated with the Internet and e-commerce.

Nevertheless, his growth-orientated policies, and his correct reading of the disinflationary effect of technology and global competition, have certainly helped. The Fed was also quicker than other central banks to spot the disinflationary effect of the Asian crisis.

The question in the US is how long confidence can last before it becomes over-confidence, and pride is followed by a fall. Even in the golden age of the 1950s, policymakers had to beware of macro-economic imbalances. It is not just the stock market that is issuing warnings in the US. The country's trade and current account deficit is spiralling out of control, and at some stage there is likely to be a classic reaction.

John Llewellyn of Lehman Brothers asked last week: 'What does it take to slow down a large, fast-growing, confident economy?' His answer: 'Intervention from outside will be necessary.'

In other words, if confidence in Greenspan is to be retained, the great man may have to stop talking and start acting.

By contrast, the European Central Bank is still trying to gain a reputation for competence, and to build up the kind of public confidence the Fed enjoys. Relatively low European interest rates are helping a Euroland economy that still lags some years behind the US in the Grand Recovery Stakes.

There is something for everyone in the latest musings from the ECB - for the hawks, for the doves and for the sparrows sitting on the fence. The president of the ECB, Wim Duisenberg, has recently been interpreted as 'talking tough' about interest rates. But Duisenberg could learn a few lessons from Greenspan's recent years. Confidence in the recovery of the core German economy is still fragile, and does not need to be knocked on the head.

Which brings us, last but not least, to that non-Euroland known as the UK. Here Chancellor Gordon Brown, for all the carpings from his friendly critics, has gained a reputation for great competence. Stocks in 'G Brown plc' have been rising and rising. The public seems to have enormous confidence in him.

There is also a lot of confidence in the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee, despite the recent little local difficulty between the 'insiders' and 'outsiders'.

But I wonder how long this confidence will last. 'We were popular when rates went down. But you watch what happens as they go up,' said one Bank man not long ago.

The general expectation is that, following last week's widely expected quarter-point rise (to 5.75 per cent), UK rates are going to go up and up. The pound is already at absurdly high levels, and it is a fantasy to believe that the British economy has happily adjusted to this high exchange rate. Last time markets knew rates were going to go up and up, they drove the pound up and up. I wonder how long confidence in current policies will last if the markets do the same again.

webTitle: US stars of all stripe join race

fields.headline: US stars of all stripe join race
fields.trailText: There was no laser light show, only glow-in-the-dark letters on black posterboard. But the pulsating music as Bill Bradley loped towards the school auditorium was the same beat that sends the New York Knicks charging into Madison Square Garden.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy in New York  and Sandra Sobieraj  in Johnston, Iowa
fields.body:
There was no laser light show, only glow-in-the-dark letters on black posterboard. But the pulsating music as Bill Bradley loped towards the school auditorium was the same beat that sends the New York Knicks charging into Madison Square Garden.

That beat had 71-year-old Bob Kusy dancing in his seat. Long before he started following Bradley's Democratic presidential campaign, Kusy followed his pro basketball career. 'I knew all the guys back then, but Bill more than most because he was so good,' he said before Bradley's appearance at Johnston High School.

Hardly squeamish about being seen more as a jock than a President, Bradley encourages fascination with his old career. He regales every crowd with at least one tale from his years with the Princeton Tigers, the United States' 1964 Olympic gold-medal team, and the Knicks. His first political ads showed footage from the Olympics and he sometimes brings old team-mates such as Dave DeBusschere along on the stump.

The presidential campaign is plodding into its first primary. And the reality of the presidential race is that its map is being defined not by the political issues, but by the latitudes and longitudes of celebrity.

On the Democratic side, Harrison Ford and Jack Nicholson are backing Bradley. The Knicks themselves, past and present team members, played a celebrity gala game for him at Madison Square Garden. Bradley has bagged Calvin Klein, and even Alice Cooper - the heavy metal star whose shows used to feature mock executions..

On Al Gore's side, Kevin Costner and Barbra Streisand have turned out, along with Quincy Jones and Don Henley of the Eagles.

For the Republicans, George Bush may, like Gore, have all the charisma of a Dallas traffic jam but he has managed to sign up Jerry Seinfeld and the country and western crooner Pat Boone.

Bush has also recruited Disney top dog Michael Eisner and martial arts star Chuck Norris. John McCain last week added a new name to his bandwagon, claiming the mantle of Ronald Reagan - cowboy and right-wing rebel. McCain also picked up a couple of useful endorsements from the land of the living: David Geffen of Dreamworks, the rock band Pearl Jam and the veteran TV producer Norman Lear.

On the frozen cornfields of Iowa, birthplace of John Wayne, voting takes place in eight days. The primary is expected to be an uninteresting one, though not unimportant for frontrunners Bush and Gore, who must both win if they are to retain a shred of credibility, and probably will - in the run up to the real prize of 'Super Tuesday' - the 12-state primary on 7 March.

Bradley has spent money but little energy in Iowa, McCain little of either.

In New Hampshire, where the primary will be held on 1 February, the picture is radically different, the voltage higher, the place where outsider Bill Clinton first became a contender.

New Hampshire will be a test for those who have established themselves as contenders, but not as winners. McCain leads the Bush juggernaut by a few lengths in some polls, though the media's love-affair with him is ebbing. Bradley, meanwhile, is spending like a madman to steal a march on Gore. But New Hampshire could end it all for both of them.

If not, there will follow a rivetting couple of months of compressed primaries, through 'Southern Tuesday' - when Gore will stand or fall - and finally 'Super Tuesday'.

The need to package and propel the candidates is especially urgent this time for two principal reasons. First, they all face a more formidable enemy than each other - apathy. Harvard University's 'Vanishing Voter Project' finds that 74 per cent of the electorate do not support any candidate. Voters say they are dismayed by the partisanship of Washington, and spending of so much time, money and effort on the Lewinsky affair.

The second reason is that all candidates are playing a game on Clinton's field, and by his rules - those of non-politics at a time when the economy is strong. For all the flying sparks, the leading candidates (with the possible exception of McCain) have to sound more or less like Clinton, leaving ideology to the no-hopers in the wings. The President even provides a negative model to unite the field, that of character. The message is: do not, whatever you do, appear like him.

Hence the need to pack a good life story, as seen in the proliferation of political books that force even potboilers off the shelves. Hence the need to get a personality that is anything unlike Clinton's. Words such as 'vision' and 'character' poll well.

And hence the need to raise cash. Lots of cash; more of it than has ever blessed, or sullied, any election in any country.

webTitle: Swaggering style of the hard-eyed killer we knew

fields.headline: Swaggering style of the hard-eyed killer we knew
fields.standfirst: Maggie O'Kane  recalls her encounters with the hard man who wanted to be admired
fields.trailText: The black four-wheeled drives would usually draw up after midnight at the Intercontinental Hotel in Belgrade. The porters would bow deferentially at Arkan and his entourage as they swept through the revolving doors and turned left across the marble lobby into the coffee shop.
fields.body:
The black four-wheeled drives would usually draw up after midnight at the Intercontinental Hotel in Belgrade. The porters would bow deferentially at Arkan and his entourage as they swept through the revolving doors and turned left across the marble lobby into the coffee shop.

Usually it was Arkan with the lads - one with a particular liking for loud green suits. Arkan himself, however, was always expensive and stylish, if considerably beefier than the killer who started his 'cleansing' career in a village called Bijlena, where an enduring image of the Bosnia war is one of his boys kicking the dead body of a Muslim on the pavement.

They would walk through the dining room to order a table in the corner of the coffee shop and then wait for a journalist - usually somebody new in town - to grovel up and ask for an interview. Arkan would make the appointed hack sit down at the table so he could show off his considerable language skills. Later, as the nights of the Kosovo war dragged on and the press was confined to Belgrade and the Intercontinental, journalists stopped paying him any attention and he would have a slightly offended look in his handsome face when people stopped looking on from their late dinner to draw breath at his presence. Arkan was getting fat and becoming old hat.

He was, however, a brilliant and charming TV performer who left interviewers struggling with his articulate defence of himself as a 'nationalist and servant of the moth erland.' I've met him twice. First on the Field of the Blackbirds, the heartland of Serbian nationalism. It was 1993 and he was running for a seat in the Serbian parliament. He lost it the next year. Even then he liked entrances, arriving with a sweep of black jeeps and expensive sunglasses.

That afternoon I had to ask him about his connection with Milosevic. He, as expected, denied the truth. Milosevic had been the political mentor who turned him from a full-time gangster into a political hero in the name of Serbian nationalism. Milosevic was Arkan's puppet master - although his ego would never have admitted to that. But I will always remember the steely denial, the long hard stare and the look that dared me go on asking. I hadn't the nerve, and an urgent kick from a colleague encouraged me to shut up. Truth is, we were all afraid of him.

But like gangsters, criminals and servants of the motherland everywhere, he was desperate to be admired. His Spanish hacienda-style home, with Grecian pillars and an outside glass lift was a monument to crassness, but he wanted to impress. He tried crime, then he bought football teams and then he became a murderer.

In March and April of last year, with the war still lingering on in Kosovo, I stopped being afraid of him. And I couldn't bring myself to go through the disgusting process of interviewing him. So it was on one of his pathetic jaunts to the Intercontinental that he was finally finished off, on the duck-egg speckled marble tiles that stretch from the shining revolving door of the hotel. My only sadness is that The Hague was deprived of his presence and the world of his trial, but perhaps, some day, his puppet master Milosevic may still take his seat.

Maggie O'Kane's documentary on Milosevic and Arkan- the Puppet Master of the Balkans, won the Royal Television Society Award for the Best Documentary of the Year in 1994.

First on the Field of the Blackbirds, the heartland of Serbian nationalism. It was 1993 and he was running for a seat in the Serbian parliament. He lost it the next year. Even then he liked entrances, arriving with a sweep of black jeeps and expensive sunglasses. That afternoon I had to ask him about his connection with Milosevic. He, as expected, denied the truth. Milosevic had been the political mentor who turned him from a full-time gangster into a political hero in the name of Serbian nationalism. Milosevic was Arkan's puppet master - although his ego would never have admitted to that. But I will always remember the steely denial, the long hard stare and the look that dared me go on asking. I hadn't the nerve, and an urgent kick from a colleague encouraged me to shut up. Truth is, we were all afraid of him. But like gangsters, criminals and servants of the motherland everywhere, he was desperate to be admired. His Spanish hacienda-style home, with Grecian pillars and an outside glass lift was a monument to crassness, but he wanted to impress. He tried crime, then he bought football teams and then he became a murderer. In March and April of last year, with the war still lingering on in Kosovo, I stopped being afraid of him. And I couldn't bring myself to go through the disgusting process of interviewing him. So it was on one of his pathetic jaunts to the Intercontinental that he was finally finished off, on the duck-egg speckled marble tiles that stretch from the shining revolving door of the hotel. My only sadness is that The Hague was deprived of his presence and the world of his trial, but perhaps, some day, his puppet master Milosevic may still take his seat. Maggie O'Kane's documentary on Milosevic and Arkan- the Puppet Master of the Balkans, won the Royal Television Society Award for the Best Documentary of the Year in 1994.

webTitle: Why the thug turned into a war criminal

fields.headline: Why the thug turned into a war criminal
fields.standfirst: Commentary by Henry Porter
fields.trailText: There is possibly no death among the indicted war criminals of the Bosnian civil war more heartily desired than that of Arkan. With the Serb General Ratko Mladic, Zeljko Raznatovic - as he was baptised - was responsible for untold misery among the muslims of Bosnia and a cruelty even Mladic would have found hard to stomach.
fields.body:
There is possibly no death among the indicted war criminals of the Bosnian civil war more heartily desired than that of Arkan. With the Serb General Ratko Mladic, Zeljko Raznatovic - as he was baptised - was responsible for untold misery among the muslims of Bosnia and a cruelty even Mladic would have found hard to stomach.

The barbarity of the paramilitaries known as the Tigers achieved a special notoriety. The mass rapes, executions and torture that he and his men practised will be remembered for generations.

It was the pointless extremes of his violence which were so striking. Eric Stover's book on the mass graves constantly refers to Arkan. 'In the village of Bieljina,' he writes, 'they left an old woman with her eyes gouged out and her hands tied behind her back, in the street for all to see. When asked to explain what he was doing in Eastern Bosnia, Arkan told Serbian television: "These muslims are wild dogs. This is war: us against the wild dogs".'

Although an intelligent man who spoke four languages, Arkan was apparently utterly without pity or remorse, which made his continued freedom in Belgrade the more hard to bear. He lived high on the hog with multiple sources of illegal revenue. He was wanted in Belgium, Finland, Italy, Sweden and Croatia. Yet he was able to exist in Belgrade, living with his pop star wife and two children in a smart suburb, not far from Slobodan Milosevic's home. He owned a football club and numerous night club interests and was involved in smuggling every possible commodity. He was the archetype of the post-communist hustler turned war criminal - dishonest to the core, vain and cowardly.

What transformed a common thug into the war criminal will remain a mystery, but some part of his personality catalysed in the circumstances of the war. There was never any doubt that he loved what he did and by the end of the three years of butchery there had grown in him a significant force for evil.

Stories of his personal cruelty are told over and over by muslims who survived, as if they are trying to convince themselves that they actually witnessed a human being committing such acts.

Yet he lived - until yesterday - with apparent immunity, laughing at The Hague's claims that he would be taken and tried.

With his contacts, wealth and cunning, Arkan might never have been caught. Only Milosevic, Mladic and the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, presented a greater challenge to the guile of the UN security forces.

But they wanted Arkan most desperately, if only because of the blood he shed with such relish. His death will be greeted with bleak satisfaction throughout Europe. But whatever the grim toasts made to his killer this weekend, there will be a lingering sense that Arkan cheated justice.

fields.headline: Bloody handiwork of Arkan
fields.trailText: 'They dragged the husband out of the house first, across the street from the mosque. The local butcher. The soldiers were telling me not to take photographs. Then the wife was dragged out. She was screaming - shots rang out and the husband went down. The wife reached down and took his hand in hers, then they shot her, and she went down.
fields.byline: by Ed Vulliamy in Moscow and Stacy Sullivan
fields.body:
'They dragged the husband out of the house first, across the street from the mosque. The local butcher. The soldiers were telling me not to take photographs. Then the wife was dragged out. She was screaming - shots rang out and the husband went down. The wife reached down and took his hand in hers, then they shot her, and she went down.

'Then they dragged out the sister-in-law. I walked back towards some other soldiers who had just taken a kid on the lawn of the mosque. He broke free and tried to escape but couldn't - there was a wall. They shot him in the back. Over the road, they shot the butcher's sister-in-law before the order came to move to another part of town.'

Ron Haviv, an American photographer, described yesterday the handiwork of the Serb whose name chilled the hearts of Croatia and Bosnia during the bloodiest carnage to blight Europe since the Third Reich. The man whose name was synonymous with cruelty without pity, and mass murder: Captain Arkan - aka Zeljko Raznatovic.

'Arkan's Tigers', his paramilitary unit was called, and these were the first Muslims to be killed in Bosnia. Haviv was the only international eye to witness them - four murders out of hundreds of the hundreds of thousands that followed, on the day the Tigers came to the town of Bieljina in north-west Bosnia in March 1992.

The bloodlust of Arkan's Tigers made them the most feared, brutal unit in the Serbian murder machine. The Tigers were the arrowhead of 'ethnic cleansing', the systematic killing first of Croatians and then Bosnia's Muslims.

'He was charming, extremely smart and deceptively evil,' says Haviv. 'Egotistical, baby-faced, and he considered himself the saviour of the Serbian people. He was a likeable guy, except that he was a pathological killer. He liked pretty women.'

Arkan was wanted in six European countries for robbery when war broke out in Yugoslavia - and for murder in Germany. He had shot his way out of a Swedish court, escaped from prison in Belgium and lived in London for two years.

He was one of the very few Serbs trusted by the indicted tyrant and architect of the pogroms, Slobodan Milosevic. He was a member of the Yugoslav security service, with a brief to dispose of Croatian nationalist dissidents.

Arkan recruited his thugs in jails and from among soccer hooligans supporting Red Star Belgrade, a team he owned. Their military presence in the war was first located in the Serb-dominated Krajina region of Croatia, where some of the first shots of the Yugoslav carnage were fired.

But the Tigers first left the savagery of their calling card in the eastern zone of the fledging rebel nation, Slavonia. In the indictment for crimes against humanity issued secretly in 1997 by the tribunal in the Hague, Arkan is accused of the massacre of 250 patients and staff in the hospital in the beseiged and battered town of Vukovar.

The unit's most heinous crimes were committed as the hurricane of Serbian violence crossed into eastern Bosnia - to Bieljina, Foce and Visegrad. The Tigers swept into unsuspecting towns, villages and communities - raping, beating torturing, killing. Arkan's name became a calling card for atrocity.

During the bloobath, Arkan, wearing designer suits, would take rest and refreshment in Belgrade, where people hailed him as a hero.

His wedding to Serbian rock diva 'Ceca' was a festive national occasion, shown live on television.He finally met his match against the Muslims of Bihac, where the Bosnian Army, on the offensive for the first time, drove the Tigers back.

But Arkan reappeared in Kosovo, his Tigers sweeping through Albanian communities as they had in Bosnia. Villagers in Velika Krusha, where the remains of 20 incinerated civilians were found, insist that the massacre was the mark of the Tigers.

As in Bosnia, Arkan was encouraged by the Serbian government. It was at this point during the Kosovo onslaught that the Hague tribunal elected to make the sealed indictment public.

But throughout the carnage, Arkan would entertain and boast to international journalists at the luxury Hyatt Hotel in Belgrade.

Much of the intelligence on Arkan was picked up by the British GCHQ in Cheltenham - but when the War Crimes Tribunal in the Hague asked for it, they were refused.

Ed Vulliamy won various awards for his coverage of the Bosnian war. Stacy Sullivan covered the war for Newsweek.

webTitle: Tories turn their backs on safe seats

fields.headline: Tories turn their backs on safe seats
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Tory party chiefs are facing a desperate struggle to find suitable candidates to fight the next election, even in winnable seats.
fields.body:
Tory party chiefs are facing a desperate struggle to find suitable candidates to fight the next election, even in winnable seats.

Vice-chairman Roger Freeman is trying to counter the image that the party is run by faceless men with no experience of the world outside politics. He is hoping to fill the small number of plum seats with experienced men and women with a good chance of rising rapidly to the Shadow Cabinet.

This would allow William Hague - or his successor - to purge the front bench of the 'invisible men' who have made almost no impact as the Government comes under fire over the crisis in the NHS and the controversy surrounding the Dome. There are no black or Asian Tory MPs, and just 13 women.

But with the party 26 points behind Labour in the latest Gallup poll, the sort of people Freeman wants are not interested in becoming Tory MPs, according to insiders.

'Too many are deciding to sit it out for five years, earn some money, and see whether there is a better chance next time,' said one former Central Office official.

It is feared that most of the 'new' Tory faces in the next Parliament will actually be old faces who lost their seats in 1997, and have not been able to find regular work, or full-time political activists with little direct experience outside Westminster.

One exception is Mark Field, a 35-year-old City headhunter, who has been chosen to fight the safe City of London seat. He says tougher rules on MPs' earnings introduced after the sleaze scandals of the Major years have put off other high earners.

'If you're earning several hundred thousand a year in the City, are you going to give it up for £47,000 a year in the Commons? I'm a rarity, because I'm a small businessman and I will be able to continue to run a business after I'm elected.'

One of the most prominent unsuccessful Tory candidates last time around was journalist Boris Johnson, an experienced television performer who is thought to have a good chance of securing a safe seat if he wants it. But friends say he cannot make up his mind whether to go into politics or stick to his job editing the Spectator magazine.

David Cameron, a former special adviser to the Major administration, was tipped as a candidate in the Kensington by-election, but turned down the chance because he preferred his new job at Carlton TV. However, Cameron has kept his name on the list of possible Tory candidates.

Daniel Hannam, a former adviser to Michael Howard and Daily Telegraph leader writer, was expected to make a bid to oust Esher MP Ian Taylor, an outspoken critic of William Hague's policy on Europe. Hannam insisted he did not want a Commons seat this time, preferring to stay in the European parliament, where the right is stronger.

The first candidate chosen in a seat the Tories are confident of winning was George Osborne, who will fight Tatton, where the independent MP Martin Bell has said he will quit. Osborne, 28, works as Hague's speechwriter.

fields.headline: Ashcroft's Lotus position
fields.standfirst:
Andy McSmith and Ben Laurance raise new questions over the business dealings of the man who bankrolls the Conservative party
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Conservative party treasurer Michael Ashcroft faces new questions about the business dealings that helped him build the £1 billion-plus fortune now being used to bankroll the Tories.
fields.body:
Conservative party treasurer Michael Ashcroft faces new questions about the business dealings that helped him build the £1 billion-plus fortune now being used to bankroll the Tories.

Just one month after the Times withdrew false suggestions that Ashcroft had been suspected of involvement in laundering drugs money, fresh evidence has emerged about his business activities during the most active phase of building his empire.

It raises the issue of how closely Ashcroft was involved in a deal led by his long-time associate David Wickins to rescue sports car maker Lotus.

The rescue was being finalised just as the two men were trying publicly to distance themselves from one another. Investigations show that:

 A large shareholding in Lotus acquired by Ashcroft was originally built up through Benor, a company registered in Bermuda.

 After Ashcroft eventually announced that he had acquired a stake in Lotus, the shares in question remained registered in the name of the Bermuda company.

While the Lotus shares were being bought through the offshore company, no one had any reason to make any connection with Ashcroft. Hence no one asked whether he was working in tandem with Wickins, who was putting together a package to rescue Lotus in 1983. Indeed, there is no evidence showing Ashcroft had any link to Benor before he declared that he had bought the Lotus stake.

Any disclosure that Wickins and Ashcroft were both investors in Lotus would have sparked intense interest: the closeness of the duo was at the time already being examined by the City watchdog overseeing mergers and takeovers. The share dealings now under scrutiny date back to 1982 and 1983 - early in a period of frenetic corporate activity when Ashcroft was one of the most high-profile dealmakers in British business building up his main company, Hawley. During this period, Ashcroft was frequently linked to Wickins, who was then head of British Car Auctions. Their association was well-known and completely open, but at that stage they rarely formally teamed up for deals.

Under the Companies Act, large investors working together must tell any company where they are investors of any mutual interests they have - if they are in a 'concert party'.

The rules aim to stop companies being taken over by stealth. If a single investor builds up a holding of 30 per cent or more of a company, it must formally bid for the whole concern. Similarly, two investors acting in concert will have their shareholdings added together: if these exceed 30 per cent, they will be normally have to bid.

In the summer of 1983, just as Wickins' rescue of Lotus was coming to a climax, the question of the closeness of Ashcroft and Wickins' ties was the subject of vigorous debate. The men had to persuade the City's takeover panel that they were not working in concert in building up stakes in Cope Allman, a company making packaging and fruit machines.

Wickins' British Car Auctions owned 13.6 per cent of Cope Allman. Had Ashcroft been judged to be working in concert with Wickins, he would have been limited to holding little more than 16 per cent of Cope: otherwise, they would have breached the 30 per cent ceiling.

But the City's takeover panel found that that they were operating independently, so Ashcroft was able to increase his holding to 29.9 per cent. His shareholding, plus Wickins', amounted to 43.5 per cent of Cope Allman, giving them the power to introduce sweeping changes without launching a full bid.

The panel's ruling was bitterly contested by Cope Allman, which argued unsuccessfully that Wickins and Ashcroft were clearly acting in concert and should there fore have their joint holding capped at below 30 per cent.

What was not known at the time was that even as the Cope Allman dispute was being fought out, a large shareholding being built up in Lotus would eventually be acquired by an Ashcroft company.

Official records show that Benor Investments of Bermuda began building up its Lotus holding on 19 December 1982, just three days after the death of Lotus founder Colin Chapman.

Benor bought further tranches of shares until early September 1983. Over this period, Wickins emerged as the saviour of Lotus, with British Car Auctions buying new shares in the car group, underwriting the issue of further shares and securing bank loan facilities.

In July, as the Wickins-led rescue deal was being finalised, there was intense speculation that Ashcroft would also become involved. He flatly denied this.

But on 7 September 1983, the day that the takeover panel announced it was clearing Ashcroft and Wickins of being in a concert party in buying Cope Allman shares, an Ashcroft company announced that it had taken a 14 per cent stake in Lotus. That day, Wickins formally announced that BCA had 25 per cent of Lotus shares. So between them, the two men's companies had nearly 40 per cent of Lotus - but they were not obliged to bid.

Analysis of the Lotus shareholders' register shows that Ashcroft's stake must have been the same as the one that had been built up over the previous nine months by Bermuda-based Benor.

An Ashcroft spokesman said last week that he could find out nothing about Benor.

Lotus's annual report for 1983, submitted to Companies House only in August 1984, was apparently a draft version with hand-written corrections made before it was finally printed for distribution to shareholders.

Benor's name is printed as the holder of 14 per cent of Lotus. But this has been crossed out, and the name of the holder has been changed in handwriting to Midepsa - a company that, by then, Wickins and Ashcroft had publicly said they were using to hold their joint investments.

Even as late as September 1984, the Lotus shareholders' register shows Benor as the holder of the stake - a stake that Ashcroft's Hawley had by now said it owned .

In the late summer of 1983, the dispute over whether Wickins and Ashcroft were acting in concert over Cope Allman was at its height.

So if any connection between Ashcroft and Benor's Lotus shareholding had been made, the two men would undoubtedly have faced further questioning over the closeness of their ties.On the day that Ashcroft's investment in Lotus was announced, only one person raised the issue of whether Ashcroft and Wickins had acted together or independently in building up their stakes - together amounting to nearly 40 per cent of the company.

Lotus chairman Fred Bushell said: 'I find this all rather surprising. I believe Guinness Mahon [Lotus' merchant bank] made inquiries and was advised that there is no concert party involved.' Although the combined Ashcroft/Wickins stake was so large, they were not obliged to bid for Lotus.

Conservative party accounts show Ashcroft as not only the Tories' biggest backer but possibly the most lavish donor the party has ever had, giving £1 million a year in cash plus other valuable benefits.

Labour MP Peter Bradley said: '[William] Hague has had to choose between financial and political bankruptcy. He clearly believes that a party without principles has better prospects than a party without cash.

'If this is the case, he has yet again shown an extraordinary lack of judgment, for which the Conservatives will pay heavily.'

Over this period, Wickins emerged as the saviour of Lotus, with British Car Auctions buying new shares in the car group, underwriting the issue of further shares and securing bank loan facilities. In July, as the Wickins-led rescue deal was being finalised, there was intense speculation that Ashcroft would also become involved. He flatly denied this. But on 7 September 1983, the day that the takeover panel announced it was clearing Ashcroft and Wickins of being in a concert party in buying Cope Allman shares, an Ashcroft company announced that it had taken a 14 per cent stake in Lotus. That day, Wickins formally announced that BCA had 25 per cent of Lotus shares. So between them, the two men's companies had nearly 40 per cent of Lotus - but they were not obliged to bid. Analysis of the Lotus shareholders' register shows that Ashcroft's stake must have been the same as the one that had been built up over the previous nine months by Bermuda-based Benor. An Ashcroft spokesman said last week that he could find out nothing about Benor. Lotus's annual report for 1983, submitted to Companies House only in August 1984, was apparently a draft version with hand-written corrections made before it was finally printed for distribution to shareholders. Benor's name is printed as the holder of 14 per cent of Lotus. But this has been crossed out, and the name of the holder has been changed in handwriting to Midepsa - a company that, by then, Wickins and Ashcroft had publicly said they were using to hold their joint investments. Even as late as September 1984, the Lotus shareholders' register shows Benor as the holder of the stake - a stake that Ashcroft's Hawley had by now said it owned . In the late summer of 1983, the dispute over whether Wickins and Ashcroft were acting in concert over Cope Allman was at its height. So if any connection between Ashcroft and Benor's Lotus shareholding had been made, the two men would undoubtedly have faced further questioning over the closeness of their ties.On the day that Ashcroft's investment in Lotus was announced, only one person raised the issue of whether Ashcroft and Wickins had acted together or independently in building up their stakes - together amounting to nearly 40 per cent of the company. Lotus chairman Fred Bushell said: 'I find this all rather surprising. I believe Guinness Mahon [Lotus' merchant bank] made inquiries and was advised that there is no concert party involved.' Although the combined Ashcroft/Wickins stake was so large, they were not obliged to bid for Lotus. Conservative party accounts show Ashcroft as not only the Tories' biggest backer but possibly the most lavish donor the party has ever had, giving £1 million a year in cash plus other valuable benefits. Labour MP Peter Bradley said: '[William] Hague has had to choose between financial and political bankruptcy. He clearly believes that a party without principles has better prospects than a party without cash. 'If this is the case, he has yet again shown an extraordinary lack of judgment, for which the Conservatives will pay heavily.'

fields.headline: Alps face disaster over warming
fields.trailText: Researchers have discovered that Europe's permafrost - the frozen bedrock on which the Alps rest - is melting.
fields.body:
Researchers have discovered that Europe's permafrost - the frozen bedrock on which the Alps rest - is melting.

Underground ice temperatures rose by more than a degree in the Nineties, threatening widespread devastation within the next two decades. Foundations of cable car stations face collapse; mountain slopes, held together by frozen soil, are likely to be swept down valleys; and rock faces will disintegrate.

Already several recent Alpine disasters, including the avalanches which killed more than 50 people at the Austrian resort of Galtur last year, are being blamed on the melting of permafrost, say scientists. And all agree about the culprit: global warming.

'It is now clear that rises in atmospheric temperatures are producing significant changes in permafrost levels,' said geologist Dr Charles Har ris of Cardiff University. 'Global warming is changing the nature of weather systems and this is having disproportionate effects on temperatures underground.'

Atmospheric temperatures round the world rose about 0.2 degrees Celsius last decade, producing a spate of observations about the effects of warming, including signs that Europe's glaciers are shrinking.

But now engineers and geologists have discovered a new, alarming effect: air temperature increases are being magnified fivefold underground. A test borehole, dug in Murtel in southern Switzerland, has revealed that frozen sub-surface soils warmed by 1.2 degrees since 1990.

'We are getting earlier falls of snow which provide blankets of insulation that keep the soil warm,' said Harris. 'Summers are also warmer and are heating up the ground more.'

To try to predict the worst effects, scientists backed by European Union funds have launched a programme, Permafrost and Climate in Europe (Pace), to provide a continent-wide survey of threatened permafrost, which is concentrated in Scandinavia, the Alps, the Pyrenees and the Sierra Nevada in Spain.

A series of boreholes are being drilled in these areas, and scientists are developing techniques for predicting the effects of permafrost loss on slopes and valleys. And a key, and unexpected, instrument in this work will be the centrifuge.

'When you spin things round and round very quickly, you create very powerful gravitational fields, and when you place objects in these fields the effects of gravity are speeded up,' said another Pace researcher, civil engineer Professor Michael Davies of Dundee University. 'We are now building model valleys, and will put them in centrifuges to study what happens when soil is warmed up and the permafrost, which holds the ground together, is destroyed. We will simulate landslides and avalanches.'

The aim is to find out how to spot early signs of the imminent collapse of buildings and valleys, he said. 'Cracks and strains, the first evidence that cable stations and other buildings are under threat, may be easy to spot. This gives engineers an opportunity to put things right.'

On the other hand, the recent wave of avalanches in the Alps suggests it will be a trickier job to spot valley walls and rock faces that are about to crumble and disintegrate, and destroy communities underneath them.

'There is no doubt that there is a real danger to human life, thanks to permafrost warming,' said Harris. 'We want to minimise the destruction.'

webTitle: Long march from mean streets to clean streets

fields.headline: Long march from mean streets to clean streets
fields.trailText: 'Go Where The Burger Is King!' The poster stares down boldly from the side of a listed Georgian building alongside Dublin's Four Courts, overlooking the River Liffey.
fields.body:
'Go Where The Burger Is King!' The poster stares down boldly from the side of a listed Georgian building alongside Dublin's Four Courts, overlooking the River Liffey.

It points hungry Dubliners towards O'Connell Street where the fast food chain, Burger King, has one of a number of outlets in the city. Last week Dublin Corporation went to the High Court to have the poster removed. The legal argument is that the hoarding had been erected without planning permission - which had been refused in 1998.

Many Irish people see the case as another episode in the continuing battle to clean up Dublin's image. This stretch of the Liffey is one of the capital's most historic areas. In recent years serious attempts have been made to preserve the best of the old, while allowing development of hotels and bars. Last month a footbridge was opened across the river, as part of Dublin's millennium celebrations.

The main emphasis of this campaign to restore Dublin to its former eighteenth century grandeur focuses on O'Connell Street. The main street of the capital was once a broad and gracious thoroughfare with elegant stores, attractive restaurants and hotels.

It was badly damaged during the struggle for Irish independence and the subsequent civil war. Yet one of the first acts of the leaders of the impoverished newly independent state was to restore O'Connell Street. Today the General Post Office, where the leaders of the 1916 Easter Rising proclaimed independence, remains an historic shrine.

The street's glory days were long ago. Today it is dirty and sometimes dangerous. A proliferation of fast food joints, slot-machine arcades and cheap 'convenience' shops accounts for much of the litter. But there are other reasons for the dingy and menacing atmosphere. Just off O'Connell Street lie some of the most deprived areas of Dublin.

The scourge of heroin has led to open drug dealing, and a growth in petty crime - handbag snatching, shoplifting - deters Dubliners and tourists alike from visiting O'Connell Street, particularly at night.

There is a growing demand that Dublin's main street should provide a more seemly focus point for the country's new booming economy. In l998 an integrated plan for the redevelopment of O'Connell Street was published. It envisaged broad footpaths, pavement cafes, a civic park in front of the Post Office, a glittering spire to mark the new millennium and to replace Nelson's Pillar which was blown up by the IRA.

The hope has been that the refurbishment would have a wider effect in improving the aesthetic appeal of Dublin. The success of the economy, combined with generous grants from the EU, has brought a dramatic increase in the building of offices and hotels.

But, so far there has been little visible improvement in O'Connell Street. A fairly typical row erupted in June when the Ann Summers chain of sex shops opened its first retail outlet in Ireland, directly opposite the GPO. The view most widely expressed was that it was inappropriate to have a shop selling seductive lingerie within yards of the spot where patriots fought and died. But Dubliners accepted the shop with aplomb, even enthusiasm. On the weekend after it opened 9,000 people, mainly women, visited it.

Now an American photographer, Spencer Tunick, wants to get 100 Dubliners to pose naked in front of the GPO. The city fathers have yet to give their reaction to his plan for a 'Naked City'. However, most Dubliners want them to get on with the job of making O'Connell a safe and attractive place.

webTitle: Scourge of Middle England signs off

fields.headline: Scourge of Middle England signs off
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: James Boyle, the Radio 4 boss who became the man Middle England loved to hate when he gave the station a populist makeover, is to quit.
fields.body:
James Boyle, the Radio 4 boss who became the man Middle England loved to hate when he gave the station a populist makeover, is to quit.

BBC insiders say the tough Glaswegian has had 'a personality clash' with the head of BBC Radio, Jenny Abramsky. He will announce his departure today.

Boyle, who became the scourge of the chattering classes, leaves the £100,000-a-year post after 25 years at the corporation. He is tipped to take over as head of the British Library.

The 53-year-old revamped Radio 4's schedules two years ago. Listeners who regard Radio 4 as a treasured institution switched off in droves as he moved old favourites such as The Archers, Woman's Hour, The Moral Maze and Loose Ends, and axed the arts magazine Kaleidoscope.

MPs and journalists railed against his decision to shorten the World At One and shift political coverage to long wave or late-night slots.

The number of listeners plunged. At one point the year-on-year decline was some 600,000, taking Radio 4 well below the important eight million mark to 7.68 million. Boyle admitted the figures were 'very disappointing'.

Speculation mounted that he would head back north of the border but he defied Middle England and made more changes. And after a year of turmoil new figures emerged showing a sharp rise in the number of listeners.

His strategy was vindicated at the end of last year when it was revealed that more than nine million listeners tune in every week for 90 minutes more than they used to. 'The listener sulk has gone. Radio 4 is settling down extraordinarily well now. It's great fun to work in Radio 4,' Boyle said.

The reasons for Boyle's sudden departure are unclear but BBC insiders say his rela tionship with Abramsky has gone sour. They claim Boyle - who applied for the job of head of BBC Radio - was furious when he was passed over.

At his Edinburgh home yesterday Boyle was tight-lipped. 'I have heard all sorts of rumours since I was appointed. I am getting divorced. I am leaving. You name it,' he said.

But friends confirmed he was stepping down. 'He has commissioned some really ambitious programming and the network is in good health. He has attracted record audiences. He has done his job and he has always said he would move on when the job was done,' one said.

Boyle is tipped to take over from Brian Lang, who steps down in May as chief executive of the British Library, which moved to a controversial £510 million home in St Pancras two years ago. BBC insiders say there is no clear front-runner to replace him.

webTitle: Grief that will last a generation. And a mystery as deep as the sea

fields.headline: Grief that will last a generation. And a mystery as deep as the sea
fields.standfirst: In the pubs of Whithorn, relatives of the seven dead fishermen sit in near silence, reports Euan Ferguson.  All that can be said, or guessed at, has already been grimly discussed
fields.trailText: It's the Cairngorms of the sea. Just as the mountain plateau is notorious for the speed at which conditions can alter, claiming the lives of experienced, well-prepared climbers every year, the Irish Sea has a reputation for swift, vicious change.
fields.body:
It's the Cairngorms of the sea. Just as the mountain plateau is notorious for the speed at which conditions can alter, claiming the lives of experienced, well-prepared climbers every year, the Irish Sea has a reputation for swift, vicious change.

Within half an hour, the seas will grow a cold grey and climb, and climb, then just as swiftly drop, leaving a world chilled but tranquil, as unthreatening as the big, quiet sky that came with yesterday's dawn to the village of Whithorn.

It grew on Tuesday, from a Force Six, as forecasted and confidently expected to persist, to a Force Nine, within the hours of the Solway Harvester's leaving Kirkcudbright and starting her doomed run for shelter in the Isle of Man's Ramsay Bay.

There would have been some desultory conversation about the forecast on the way, probably even in the cars as Craig Mills and his six colleagues headed from the Machars of Whithorn to the boat's berth at Kirkcudbright. There always is. Fishermen talk of the weather in precisely the same fashion as Londoners talk of their trans port system, with a rather bored mix of rumour and grumbling. The weather is just there and they have to get through it. Even a Force Nine.

For, although the Harvester's crew would have been surprised by the sudden, severe change, even in the Irish Sea, even in this stormy season, they would not have been terrified by it.

The difference between Six and Nine is one of degree, not character. It's not the difference between flat calm and storm; it's the difference between a big sea and a bloody big, bloody scary sea.

But it's not unknown, certainly not in that part of our treacherous coastline. Some (if not all) of the seven would have sailed Nines easily before, and the Harvester, six years old and, according to the Whithorn people on Friday night, the safest in the fleet, was more than ready for such seas. She would have been heaved and battered and sometimes become awash, but they would have had the hatches down and the engine gunning before the storm. No, something else went wrong.

The Harvester could have hit something. There was a burst of speculation last week that it had hit a floating container, one of hundreds seemingly lost from the decks of Atlantic cargo carriers recently; a number of the lifeboats and rescue vessels that struggled to the scene on Tuesday night reported seeing vats of mayonnaise bobbing about, which could have come from a stricken container ship, but until a Manx team with their submersibles arrive 11 miles east of Douglas, sometime within the next few days, this is only speculation, and not carrying much weight.

In any case, even if holed, it's thought she would have had a few minutes; the fact that both lifeboats were found unopened suggests that she went down suddenly, as does the fact that she managed to get off only one burst from the emergency beacon, picked up by satellite. The last heard of her on this earth was heard not on earth but in space.

They call it a lump of water, or a wall of water. After days of speculation, shocked hours spent discussing it before the fires in the Queen's Head and the Steam Packet, there is a feeling at the moment that a freak wave is about the only thing that could have beaten Craig Mills and his colleagues.

They have them more commonly in the Roaring Forties, where they arrive in the middle of a White Squall, a sudden banshee of a storm that whips seas into shapes they've never known before.

But they have them round this coast, too. I've spoken in the past to East Coast fisher men, to riggers and to coastguards, who have seen them. I remember talking to a Shetlander after the Braer disaster who told me about the seas in that broiling beeftub of a channel that night, and of his own experience in them.

He spoke of a wall: 'Suddenly, the seas just rose up and started walking towards us. This big bloody lump of sea. Never have I been so frightened.'

He survived. The Mills boys and their colleagues did not, if the theory is correct. The skipper was way too experienced to have made any of the fatal mistakes novices can make in high seas - to batter the waves head-on, or to stop the boat, both mistakes made by the captain of the Estonia, the ferry which toppled and sank in 1993. He would have been running off the waves, and running hard.

But a lump would have got him. With the currents in that area, and converging storms and wave patterns, a freak could have formed, ridden up and started walking towards them, and come down like a hand, from a hundred feet above, and battered them below.

Why do they do it? Well, it's a hard life, but it's not an awful one. The money's good, comparatively. There is camaraderie, and there's the fulfilment of a job well done, and there's getting home.

Clean, it's not. Stand on a quayside and look at the trawlers and you won't see the dirt, long washed away. But out there, hauling up from the sea, it's filthy. Silt and mire from fathoms below cover the decks and the oilskins. Trawlermen wade, as they sift through the detritus of the bottom of the sea. Their boots squash flatfish and flounders; eyeballs pop out and roll along the deck, swimming in blood and salt and grit.

But the rewards can be rich, and there's always home in a few days; home, with a shower, and a shave, and some ironed clothes and a rendezvous in the pub. And someone has to do it, and they do it well; and we are, silently, grateful as we eat, even if we remember them only at times like these.

One writer last week drew elegant attention to the surreal experience of driving to Whithorn while listening to a radio discussion with one Charles Leadbeater, author of the book Living On Thin Air , which argues that we now live in a world where old-fashioned physical work is no longer needed and we can survive in a 'knowledge economy'.

The absurdity of the argument can be clear in no other place than Whithorn. They're kind here, and they would want to be friendly, but the scar in this tiny community is one that will never heal until a whole new generation comes along.

They moved aside, silently, for us on Friday night, the relatives gathered with whisky in the Queen's Head, and they would not speak, and we did not really want them to speak. All has been said.

We left them at dawn yesterday to find what peace they can.

One writer last week drew elegant attention to the surreal experience of driving to Whithorn while listening to a radio discussion with one Charles Leadbeater, author of the book Living On Thin Air , which argues that we now live in a world where old-fashioned physical work is no longer needed and we can survive in a 'knowledge economy'. The absurdity of the argument can be clear in no other place than Whithorn. They're kind here, and they would want to be friendly, but the scar in this tiny community is one that will never heal until a whole new generation comes along. They moved aside, silently, for us on Friday night, the relatives gathered with whisky in the Queen's Head, and they would not speak, and we did not really want them to speak. All has been said. We left them at dawn yesterday to find what peace they can.

webTitle: Sick Biggs: let me come home

fields.headline: Sick Biggs: let me come home
fields.standfirst: Train robber wants to quit his Rio haven... and return at last to his Leytonstone roots
fields.trailText: His food is liquidised and fed to him through a tube. He is unable to speak and is paralysed down one side. His few outings are in a wheelchair accompanied by a nurse.Ronnie Biggs, the Great Train Robber who has been living in Rio de Janeiro for 30 years, is facing the battle of his life as friends become increasingly concerned over his deteriorating health.
fields.body:
His food is liquidised and fed to him through a tube. He is unable to speak and is paralysed down one side. His few outings are in a wheelchair accompanied by a nurse.Ronnie Biggs, the Great Train Robber who has been living in Rio de Janeiro for 30 years, is facing the battle of his life as friends become increasingly concerned over his deteriorating health.

Fearing he may never recover from two crippling strokes in recent months, his family, with supporters from the criminal underworld, are launching an emotional appeal on the fugitive's behalf, saying that he should be pardoned on compassionate grounds and allowed to see out his remaining days in Britain.

Michael Biggs, the 70-year-old's son, last week told The Observer: 'He talks about it (returning to Britain) a lot. He misses home and his old friends. He's always talking about the London in which he grew up and the friends he had. Not all of them can afford to come out here and visit him.'

'I'm sure he wants to come back to the UK,' says John Pickston, a neighbour and long-time friend. A part-time actor in Brazilian horror movies, Pickston is a close friend of Ronnie Biggs.

Pickston's wife, Maria Imelia, was awarded guar-dianship of Michael Biggs when Ronnie was kidnapped in 1981. Her account of the ordeal was published in Brazil as Child Of Freedom .

'He is not looking very well these days,' says Pickston. 'He can't talk, has problems eating solid food. Ronnie - in his quieter moments - always says that he'd like to get back to the UK. But the initial problem remains: he is a fugitive living abroad. He would be arrested almost as soon as he landed in the UK.'

Biggs's immediate friends and associates from his Great Train Robbery past have noted the deterioration of his condition in recent months. 'He has hardly been in touch,' says Nick Reynolds, whose father, Bruce, is credited as having organised the notorious railway heist.

The younger Reynolds last summer flew out to document Biggs' reunion with his friends for a television documentary. 'He is very ill,' said Reynolds. 'And there seem to be few signs that his condition will get any better. Does he want to come back to the UK? He always talks about it.'

Biggs is currently unable to speak - two strokes have effectively reduced him to silence. He communicates mainly through hand signals and inquisitive sounds.

Biggs was jailed for his part in the £2.6 million Great Train Robbery, but escaped in 1965 after serving only 15 months of a 30-year sentence. He has lived in Brazil, under threat of extradition, since then. In 1997, the Brazilian government announced he could stay indefinitely since his crime was committed more than 30 years previously.

Biggs now lives in a peeling apartment in Santa Teresa, on the outskirts of Brazil. The suburb is on hills adjacent to the city, and the neighbourhood is overrun by petty crime.

Until his strokes, Biggs spent his days regaling visitors with narratives of his escape. For this, he charged willing listeners, mainly holidaying Americans and visiting Brits, £25 each. His story is accompanied by a free meal in his back garden - one that overlooks the depressed and crime-ridden streets which surround it.

T-shirts and photographs advertising his career as a famous criminal help supplement his income. The money is used by Biggs to finance his already lacklustre lifestyle; he has little savings of his own to draw from. The royalties from his recording with Malcom McLaren's Sex Pistols are long gone.

But his hopes of returning appeared to be forlorn, with police unwilling to forgive, far less forget.

A Metropolitan Police spokesman said last night that Biggs would almost certainly be arrested upon his return to the UK, should he decide to risk it.

'He would be arrested as soon as he tried to gain entry into the country,' said the spokesman. 'Even in the case of his ill health and worsening condition, Biggs remains a fugitive. Nothing changes that.'

webTitle: Schoolgirls in rush for plastic surgery

fields.headline: Schoolgirls in rush for plastic surgery
fields.standfirst: Starstruck youngsters of 12 are being tempted by facelifts and breast reduction, reports  Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: She has a pretty face and a sweet smile, but Anna hates her looks so much she consulted a plastic surgeon. That's no surprise these days - but Anna is 11 years old.
fields.body:
She has a pretty face and a sweet smile, but Anna hates her looks so much she consulted a plastic surgeon. That's no surprise these days - but Anna is 11 years old.

Image-conscious British youngsters are electing to go under the knife in growing numbers. There is no legal minimum age and in most cases no counselling is sought or given. It is a trend one plas tic surgeon described as 'extremely frivolous and sad'.

The Observer found clinic after clinic admitting to having given breast implants to girls of 15, 16 and 17. Girls as young as 12 have had breast reduction operations, while nose jobs and liposuction are being carried out on youngsters whose bodies have not yet matured. As pubescent stars such as Britney Spears dominate the charts and 14-year-olds strut the catwalks, children now want beauty at any cost, and teenage angst is being exploited by unregulated private clinics.

Sandra's story is typical. At 17, she cannot yet marry without parents' consent, buy alcohol or vote. But she boasts silicone-enhanced C-cup breasts. 'All my friends are jealous,' she giggles. 'I had really little ones and I felt embarrassed. I'm more confident now and wear low tops.'

The operation cost her father £2,450. She thinks he paid it to annoy her mother, from whom he is estranged.

Sandra is among an estimated 65,000 Britons who have cosmetic surgery each year. More and more are teenagers and at least 20 per cent will need corrective surgery later. In the US, 3 per cent of patients are under 18. American surgeon Michael Niccole has operated on hundreds. 'We are seeing a huge influx of younger people,' he says. 'Half have mothers who had operations.'

Dr Eileen Bradbury, a psychologist from London's Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, said: 'One mustn't demonise cosmetic surgery - it can be an enormous help to those who would otherwise be deeply unhappy. But there is a huge amount of money to be made and therefore a huge amount of exploitation. Children today face a sense of competition in looking as good as possible. Even the boys - you can't just be a great footballer, you have to look like Beckham too.'

There are risks in adolescents having surgery before they have stopped growing. A surgically reduced nose, for example, may deform as it grows. That was one reason why Professor David Sharpe turned Anna away from his Bedford clinic. A former president of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons, he knows that when he turns away a patient nothing prevents them going elsewhere, and work being done quite legally by a doctor with no plastic surgery training at all. The surgeon may even have been sued in the past for malpractice.

'I have sent four patients to a psychologist this morning alone,' said Sharpe. 'I turn down 50 per cent of cases because I'm not happy. But cowboy clinics who have to pay high malpractice premiums can't afford to turn patients away. I'm not comfortable doing breast implants in anyone under 21, although I have done. Plastic surgery is worthwhile, but often it is used in a way that is extremely frivolous and sad.

'Breast augmentation for fashion is foolish. But a girl who is miserable because her breasts are significantly uneven should be helped.'

Abigail Stevenage, 19 from Kidderminster, was miserable about her breast size. She had surgery in December 1998. A week after the operation her weight had risen by a quarter. She died from toxic shock due to an infection contracted through surgery. The surgeon told the inquest: 'The operation was not a serious surgical procedure, and the infection she developed was not a typical infection.'

Her devastated mother, Christine, 45, said Abigail insisted on having the operation. 'It was always her decision,' she said.

The Observer sent two women to five London cosmetic surgery clinics, posing as 16- and 17-year-olds. Both self-assured, slim and attractive, neither could have been mistaken for girls suffering a physical deformity or lack of confidence. The five clinics offered free consultations. Potential risks were not discussed, although credit arrangements were. They also offered discounts for two procedures done at once.

Farrah Esmail went to two of the several clinics in Harley Street and asked for breast implants and a nose job. At the Harley Medical Group clinic she said she wanted to be 'good-looking' for a career in television. 'I asked if my age, 17, would be a problem,' said Farrah. 'They said "no", they do lots of girls my age and younger, and I could get a reduction - £800 off a total of £6,200 - if I went ahead with both procedures.'

At the Cosmetic Surgery Clinic, Farrah, claiming to be 16, was told she would need parental consent, but was assured surgery was not dangerous. She was seen by a nurse who discussed different types of implants.

'She told me silicone were the most natural-looking, and that men like them best too.

'I asked about the whole silicone scare and she said the only reason silicone was banned in some countries was because everybody just jumped on the "bandwagon" not because they were dangerous. I finally asked her if I should go ahead with the procedure. She said that she was supposed to give unbiased opinions, but if getting surgery would give me confidence in myself then I should do it.'

At the Transform Clinic in nearby Wimpole Street, Lorna Fletcher was told she would have to wait until she was 18, but was offered credit terms. 'The woman said I could start paying now and have it done on my eighteenth birthday,' said Lorna.

The stories did not surprise Labour MP Ann Clywd, a long-time campaigner for clinic regulation. 'Young girls are particularly vulnerable to sales techniques, and a lower age limit should be set.'

Additional reporting by Lorna Fletcher and Farrah Esmail

fields.headline: Dating game turns ugly
fields.standfirst: The 'art' of enticing a woman into bed is at the centre of  a bitter court case
fields.trailText: Can an unattractive man seduce an attractive woman in 20 minutes flat just by using secret phrases with hidden meanings? Can a middle-aged man win the heart of a woman half his age by having a good shave and following a handy 10-point formula?
fields.body:
Can an unattractive man seduce an attractive woman in 20 minutes flat just by using secret phrases with hidden meanings? Can a middle-aged man win the heart of a woman half his age by having a good shave and following a handy 10-point formula?

These and other questions vital to the future of the species will form the basis of a legal case set to start in Los Angeles next month, when two men who sell seduction and dating manuals face each in court. It has been called 'The Battle of the Babe-Hounds' and, whatever their competing guides and videos have to say about the gentle art of seduction, the case promises to be a vicious grapple with each side accusing the other of being a fraud.

In one corner is Paul Ross - aka Ross Jeffries - author of How to Get the Women You Desire into Bed , developer of the 'speed seduction' and organiser of $3,000-a-head seminars on how to seduce beautiful women no matter how unattractive you are.

In the other corner is John White - aka Don Steele - author of How to Date Young Women for Men over 35 and publisher of Steel Balls Press. At stake is the highly profitable business of advising America's army of bashful or unsightly men on surefire techniques to make women fall madly for their hidden charms.

Steele, 60, thrice married and living in Whittier, California, he had been a technical write when a woman friend suggested he write a how-to book on attracting women. How To Date Young Women, published in 1987, sold 75,000 copies and took Steele on to the talk-show circuit. He has since run dating seminars and published similar books on body language. Among his tips are that men should shave off all facial hair.

According to Steele, he first came across Jeffries when the latter phoned him in the early 1990s for advice about approaching women. Jeffries, now 41, from Culver City in Los Angeles, had had an unsuccessful career as a stand-up comedian, scriptwriter and para-legal worker before he went into the seduction publishing game with How to Get the Women You Desire into Bed in 1989. He went on to develop what he calls the 'speed seduction' technique using 'neuro-linguistic programming' in which the would-be seducer uses key words and phrases with hidden suggestive meanings, such as 'below me' (meaning 'blow me'). Thus, suggests Jeffries, a man can turn himself from geek to Greek god in 20 minutes.

This technique, which is at the heart of the row, is the basis of home study courses now offered in seven languages, including Serbo-Croat, and Jeffries' $3,000-a-head seminars.

All this has brought Jeffries fame in the form of interviews in Playboy, Rolling Stone and on late- night television. His website lists testimonials from grateful men who have met highly responsive 'HBs' (Jeffries slang for 'hard bodies') by using the techniques of the self-styled Chairman of the Broads. Jeffries, who says he only had sex twice in four years at UCLA because of his own awkwardness, promises clients: 'You don't get laid, I don't get paid.'

Anyone studying the lonely hearts' column in any big American city will know that there is a massive market of men who would happily pay for this advice. There was certainly room in the market for both Steele and Jeffries and, for a while, all was well. But Steele, who had been slow to spot the potential of the Internet in spreading his gospel, says that he gradually realised that Jeffries was using it to peddle what he believed was a load of nonsense. He started belittling him as a fraud. A vicious e-mail war erupted between the two men.

Finally, Jeffries launched a legal suit alleging invasion of privacy, business interference, slander and libel. The case has been listed, appropriately enough, for 14 February. 'Steele's a loser big time, and has been since way back,' said Yates Canipe, Jeffries' partner. 'He's throwing shit and hoping some sticks against the wall. He is so clueless.'

Steele, who says that the legal action has affected his work, accused Jeffries of being a 'snake-oil salesman'. He said that neuro-linguistics was a 'ridiculous concept in the hands of amateurs. He's a failed stand-up comedian, a clown, and women don't want a clown. He is the most disgusting human being I've ever met. He is genuinely sleazy and cheesy. I want to win this damn thing.'

Steele says that he does not have the money to pay for a lawyer. He has approached New Times, an LA magazine, to write about the case in the hope that an attorney might offer his services free. He has argued that he has no case to answer, but a superior court judge has ruled that he does. He is appealing this decision, which may delay the moment when both men appear in front of a jury. Then 12 women and men will have a chance to see exactly how seductive their opposing claims are.

Try it on your date

Steele's top 10 steps to dating

1 Get informed on subjects young women care about. Leave Cosmopolitan on your coffee table.

2 Trade the Pontiac wagon for something that does not reek of middle age. No big or tiny cars.

3 Don't comb your hair in an intricate attempt to disguise the lack of it. She secretly ridicules you.

4 Shave off all facial hair. To her you're outta it: cop, leftover hippy or compensating for thinner hair.

5 Stop dressing like a dork.

6 Don't wear more than $200 of jewellery.

7 Never look in a bar. Go to any and every wedding. She'll be there.

8 Join a spa. Hang out. Be yourself.

9 Six million are co-eds. Get your ass into classes.

10 Decide. Do you want to keep on dating fat, complaining divorcees with three kids?

fields.headline: Couch potatoes find true love
fields.standfirst: British experts claim, there is only one secretto seduction: you need to be a scruffy slob
fields.trailText: Dress scruffily, cancel the gym membership, don't shave or wash, eat chips and drink Irn Bru - and you will fall in love, get married and find true happiness.
fields.body:
Dress scruffily, cancel the gym membership, don't shave or wash, eat chips and drink Irn Bru - and you will fall in love, get married and find true happiness.

Researchers at Essex University have applied economic theory to the sex and marriage 'market' and found 'low pizazz couch potatoes' who attract 'low pizazz' partners make the happiest couples. The more people try to 'self-improve' the worse off everyone is.

Economists Professor Ken Burdett and Professor Melvyn Coles say slobs achieve 'equilibrium' while obsessive self-improvers chasing the 'surgically enhanced Californian ideal' disrupt the delicate balance of the marriage marketplace. Rab C Nesbitt and his wife Mary Doll - not Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston - are the ideal couple.

The study, to be published in the academic journal the International Economic Review later this year, warns that, if too many people spruce themselves up, the 'top end' of the singles market becomes overcrowded with perfect tans and teeth.'Some people who pizazz themselves up may find a little increased happiness by finding a glamorous partner, but both people will have spent vast sums for what may turn out to be little gain. If they had been happy with the way they were, the gym owner, designer, life coach, dietician and plastic surgeon would be poorer but they would have been richer, and, we argue, happier.'

What's more, as people 'trade up' the balance of the marriage market-place is disrupted. Low-pizazz types are left on the shelf because the pool of potential low-pizazz partners has shrunk.

The paper, Transplants and Implants: the Economics of Self-Improvement, concludes that there is too much social pressure on singles to self-improve. 'By encouraging everybody to self-improve we create a situation where everybody is forced to trade up to remain "acceptable". A preferred equilibrium may be that there is no costly self-improvement.'

The two academics say the compromises people make when they are looking for a partner are 'pure economics'. 'Think of it like a car. You might lust after a Rolls-Royce or a Ferrari, but you end up with a Ford Fiesta or a Skoda because you know that is what you can afford. Most people would like to get together with the best woman or man in the world but know they would probably not have them, so they compromise.'

The academics picked as their ideal types the stars of the BBC series Rab C Nesbitt . 'Rab's family seem to be pretty unimproved. And their friends are rough, too. But the Nesbitts seem happy.' Pure dead brilliant, as Rab would say.
