webTitle: Dyke defies calls for BBC to axe News 24

fields.headline: Dyke defies calls for BBC to axe News 24
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the incoming boss of the BBC, is to defy William Hague, a Commons Select Committee and critics in commercial television by rejecting calls to pull the plug on the troubled rolling news service, News 24.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the incoming boss of the BBC, is to defy William Hague, a Commons Select Committee and critics in commercial television by rejecting calls to pull the plug on the troubled rolling news service, News 24.

BBC insiders say that after a shaky start the channel will be transformed into 'the CNN of the future'. One source said: 'Greg has made it clear he is a fan of News 24. The BBC ain't going to bow to pressure.'

The move, which has the backing of BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland, will infuriate Hague, who labelled News 24 a £77 million flop last week. Writing in the Sun - whose proprietor Rupert Murdoch owns the successful News 24 rival Sky - the Tory leader said News 24 cost 'tens of millions of pounds more to run every year than the equivalent news service on Sky'.

MPs on the Culture Select Committee will also be dismayed. Last month the committee's chairman, Labour MP Gerald Kaufman, accused the BBC of frittering away public money. 'We find it difficult to discern the justification for News 24 in view of its huge cost and small audience,' he said.

Although Dyke, who takes over from John Birt as director-general next week, is committed to the controversial news service, he is thought likely to order a management shake-up and cost savings. The first signs came last week when corporation chiefs axed an entire layer of news and current affairs management

When the round-the-clock news service was launched in 1997 it was hailed as an up-to-the minute rival to CNN and Sky but it has failed to win audience share. MPs on the Select Committee claimed that at times it reached fewer than 10,000 viewers.

Senior journalists, including newsreader John Humphrys, claimed that the corporation's commitment to a rolling news service had adversely affected its journalistic output because it made 'insatiable demands' on correspondents. The service was revamped last October.

BBC bosses have remained tight-lipped about the channel's future but Tony Hall, chief executive of news and current affairs, told The Observer News 24 would be at the heart of the BBC brand.

'If you are in the news business and you cannot give people news when they want it, you are dead. This is a reality that it seems to have taken people years to come to terms with but it is the truth. Our critics have to face up to it.

'News is at the core of the BBC. All the research shows how important it is. We have it in our power to be the place where people go to get their news wherever they happen to be and that's what I want to get to. If we are not there when people want us, we will gradually wither away. People will look at us and say, gosh weren't they wonderful once.

'We will be wherever people want to have their news in the future. Wherever you are, whenever, you will have the choice of pushing the BBC button.'

Hall admitted that News 24 had had a lacklustre start and had 'a perception problem' but he pointed out it had taken Sky and CNN almost a decade to establish themselves. New presenters such as Sue MacGregor and James Naughtie would attract new viewers and bring News 24 'into the BBC family'.

He also questioned the Sun's decision to publish Hague's criticism and to use its editorial column to accuse the BBC of 'tipping your money down the drain'. 'Murdoch owns Sky,' he said. 'Should Murdoch have a monopoly on 24-hour news in this country? No. You have a choice of going to the BBC.'

The service that the BBC provides is the subject of intense debate because Culture Secretary Chris Smith is due to announce next week whether he agrees with the recommendation of Gavyn Davies, the leading economist appointed by the Government to examine BBC funding, that licence-payers should pay a £24-a-year levy to fund digital services.

The plans have been bitterly criticised by commercial broadcasters who fear the charge will discourage people from going digital.

John.Arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: IRA men offhook as guncase collapses

fields.headline: IRA men offhook as guncase collapses
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Senior IRA figures from Belfast and Co Cavan will not now be identified in court because of the withdrawal of charges against a Co Galway woman implicated in the IRA Florida arms case.
fields.body:
Senior IRA figures from Belfast and Co Cavan will not now be identified in court because of the withdrawal of charges against a Co Galway woman implicated in the IRA Florida arms case.

Leading IRA names were identified by gardai as being involved in the gun-running from the United States. Documents obtained by the garda investigation identified one Belfast man close to the IRA and Sinn Fein leadership. These details would have emerged during a court case in Ireland at a time when the peace process enters a critical phase.

Among those named in statements to the gardai was the man who replaced Michael McKevitt - now the reputed leader of the Real IRA - as the so-called quartermaster-general of the Provisionals. The man, based in Co Cavan, is in charge of the IRA's entire arsenal.

The revelation that the IRA was smuggling further arms into Ireland last summer angered Unionists and put pressure on First Minister David Trimble to pull out of talks with Sinn Fein.

The release of Jacqueline McIntyre has prompted opposition parties in the Dail to demand a full statement from Justice Minister John O'Donahue about why the case against her collapsed.

Garda sources questioned the validity of an anonymous letter sent to the Republic's Director of Public Prosecutions that contained serious allegations about the way officers handled the case. Sources close to the investigation said the allegations were false and could never be used in court to dismiss charges against McIntyre.

The Observer has learnt that the shipment of eight guns to a house in Connemara, where McIntyre was arrested, was the second sent there from the US. The earlier shipment was under surveillance from the time it left the United States, but contact was lost when it arrived in Ireland. More than 100 guns have since found their way to the IRA.

The weapons were sent by an IRA unit in Florida which had been buying guns and ammunition, including bullets for a sniper rifle used by the IRA to kill nine members of the security forces along the border. Her common-law husband is one of four people in custody in the US facing charges connected to the gunrunning case.

It is understood the IRA leadership was intent on re-arming with new weapons from the US before decom missioning some of its old guns.

A spokesman for the Department of Justice said there was 'bewilderment' over why the McIntyre case collapsed. 'We have not got a reason as to why the DPP dropped the charges. The DPP in Ireland is totally independent and does not have to give a reason as to why the charges were dropped,' he said.

The Justice spokesman added that the Minister would be making a statement in the Dail about the case. He said if the garda were found to have acted properly then the DPP could decide to state why the charges were withdrawn.

Fine Gael's Justice spokesman, Jim Higgins, said the withdrawal of the charges was 'extremely serious'.

'I will be raising the issue by way of a special notice question to Minister O'Donahue in the Dail when it resumes on Wednesday week. He must give a full statement outlining all the circumstances surrounding the case, and in particular the gardai's version of events,' Higgins said.

An internal garda inquiry is likely to conclude there were no irregularities into the criminal investigation in Galway and clear the investigating team of any wrongdoing. According to federal sources in the United States two of the defendants are expected to plead guilty to giving false information to gun dealers when they go on trial at the end of this month. If convicted they are likely to spend between two and five years in a US prison.

fields.headline: Violent crime soars in cities
fields.trailText: Muggings and violent crime have risen sharply over a year in urban areas, according to new crime statistics to be published on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Muggings and violent crime have risen sharply over a yearin urban areas, according to new crime statistics to be published on Tuesday. The figures, for the 12 months to last September, will fuel the debate about police use of stop-and-search powers, but will also show falls in car crime and domestic burglary.

Ministers recognise the statistics for urban areas such as the West Midlands and London are worrying, and may reflect a long-term trend of crime being concentrated in cities.

In a bid to show his concern about violent crime, Tony Blair will meet the new Metropolitan Police Commissioner, John Stevens, on Tuesday and reassure him that his force should continue to use its powers to stop and search suspects.

The Macpherson report, produced in the wake of the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence, called for a more careful use of such powers, widely seen as harassing the black community.

Use of stop-and-search in London has fallen from 337,309 in 1997-98 to 296,072 in 1998-99, of whom 74,000 were black. The fall coincided with a rise in crime, although the Home Office claims there is no proven causal link. Nationwide, black people are six times more likely than white people to be stopped and searched by the police.

Downing Street is expected to tell Stevens that stop-and- search is a very effective part of the police armoury; in London 13 per cent of all arrests of black people arose from searches. This week's figures will show a decline in some forms of crime. Previous figures showed theft from vehicles fell by 2 per cent in the 12 months to March 1999, while domestic burglary fell by 6 per cent.

But the Home Office knows it may face a long-term rise in recorded crime after several years when the figures have stabilised. Home Office reseach shows property crime to be closely related to economic growth and the number of young males aged 15 to 20 in the population.

fields.headline: Executive 'on road to collapse'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A senior ally of David Trimble, Northern Ireland's First Minister, has predicted that the power-sharing Executive will collapse by the end of next month.
fields.body:
A senior ally of David Trimble, Northern Ireland's First Minister, has predicted that the power-sharing Executive will collapse by the end of next month.

Trimble's aide told The Observer he believes the Ulster Unionist leader will resign his post and precipitate the Executive's fall because the IRA will not decommission by the middle of February.

The UUP's 860-strong ruling council meets on 12 February to review participation in the new government. Trimble is under obligation to resign as First Minister if the IRA has not started to decommission arms by then. The critical UUP council vote was originally scheduled for 5 February but party officers postponed it for a week at a meeting in Belfast on Friday to allow the IRA more time to start decommissioning.

'We are in a very dangerous situation, because I have no doubt that David is ready to resign if there is no progress. There is a real feeling within the entire unionist community that, if there is no decommissioning by then, we should pull out.'

He added that the Ulster Unionist delegation which visited Downing Street last Thursday warned the Prime Minister that the UUP council would probably vote to pull out of the executive in the absence of decommissioning. Tony Blair was understood to have been taken aback.

Trimble's aide went on: 'The executive will be suspended for a few months until people are brought to their senses and we reach the final decommissioning deadline at the end of May.'

Although Irish and British government sources believe the IRA will eventually start to decommission, there is growing doubt that the Provisionals will do so before the Ulster Unionist Council meeting. The IRA does not want to create the perception it has bent to unionist pressure.

webTitle: Police hold spiky-haired man in Downing St crash

fields.headline: Police hold spiky-haired man in Downing St crash
fields.trailText: Police were last night holding a 35-year-old spiky-haired man after a car ploughed into the gates outside Tony Blair's Downing Street home.
fields.body:
Police were last night holding a 35-year-old spiky-haired man after a car ploughed into the gates outside Tony Blair's Downing Street home.

A woman tourist and her eight-year-old daughter were injured. Eyewitnesses said the woman, who was standing outside the gates with her two young children, managed to push one child out of the way shortly before the red Vauxhall Astra crashed into the heavy security barrier at around 12.30pm.

The driver was taken to Charing Cross police station on suspicion of causing crim inal damage. Officers were questioning him to find out whether he deliberately attempted to smash down the barrier which protects the Blair's residence, or had simply lost control of the vehicle.

Sertac Bahri, who was in a Turkish protest opposite Downing Street, witnessed the incident. 'I saw the woman push one of her children out of the way to save them from getting hit, but the car went into the woman instead.'

The Blairs were not at home and Scotland Yard said: 'There is no question of security being breached.'

fields.headline: Nelson death suspect faces deportation
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The chief suspect in the Rosemary Nelson murder inquiry now faces deportation from the United States.
fields.body:
The chief suspect in the Rosemary Nelson murder inquiry now faces deportation from the United States.

Drugs and firearms offences against the former Loyalist Volunteer Force member were dropped last Monday after a preliminary hearing at a court in Riverview County, southern California.

But the ex-LVF man and two associates from Portadown were immediately handed over to the FBI because their visas had expired. They now face the prospect of being put on a plane back to Britain within the next few days because they are living in the United States illegally, according to loyalist sources in the Co Armagh town.

The trio were arrested in the southern Californian town of Murrieta following complaints from neighbours about guns being discharged in the garden of the house where they were staying. Police officers were called and raided the loyalist's home. They found guns, ammunition and drugs during their search.

An inquiry team back in Northern Ireland headed by Colin Port, the Deputy Chief Constable of Norfolk, wants to question the loyalist about Rosemary Nelson's murder near her home in Lurgan last year.

They believe he was involved in placing the bomb under the solicitor's car moments after she drove away from her house. Rosemary Nelson's murder prompted allegations of security force collusion in the killing.

The murder was carried out by an alliance of LVF members in Portadown, the dissident Red Hand Defenders group and members of the Ulster Defence Association from west Belfast - who made the bomb.

Relatives of the murdered solicitor yesterday accused the authorities of undermining the 'principles of justice' in the handling of her case.

Nelson's parents, sisters and brothers have written to the Director of Public Prosecutions in Northern Ireland and Irish Secretary Peter Mandelson to condemn the decision that no RUC officers - who were alleged to have threatened the solicitor - will be prosecuted. An inquiry into claims that RUC officers threatened Nelson ended before her murder last year.

The letter from the Magee family reads: 'We the parents, brothers and sisters of Rosemary Nelson would like to express our deep sense of annoyance and disillusionment at the recent decision by the DPP not to prosecute.

'This fundamentally disassembles the principles of justice for which Rosemary worked so hard to uphold. We would expect that full details as to how this decision was arrived at would be made available.'

Meanwhile, relatives of Richard Jameson, the Ulster Volunteer Force commander murdered outside Portadown last Monday night, painted over LVF murals in the town in a gesture of defiance yesterday.

A 37-year-old man has also appeared at Cookstown magistrates' court charged with possessing a handgun with intent to endanger life. He was arrested last week following inquiries into the murder of Richard Jameson.

A 37-year-old man has also appeared at Cookstown magistrates' court charged with possessing a handgun with intent to endanger life. He was arrested last week following inquiries into the murder of Richard Jameson.

fields.headline: We want to be alone
fields.standfirst: They're the New Singletons - happy, affluent and free - and they are transforming our culture.  Jay Rayner predicts the shape of things to come in post-couple Britain :  'The most obvious result of New Singleton's rise will be the youthing of society'
fields.trailText: They're the New Singletons - happy, affluent and free - and they are transforming our culture.  Jay Rayner predicts the shape of things to come in post-couple Britain :  'The most obvious result of New Singleton's rise will be the youthing of society'
fields.body:
Meet single woman. She lives in an airy loft apartment of blond wood floors and bright white walls on the fringes of the City. She has two large marble-clad bathrooms but uses only one. Her bed is a mattress on the floor because she moved in just a few months ago and hasn't had time to build the frame. She has a tidy spare bedroom for visiting friends, a wardrobe full of power suits and a bottle of extra virgin olive oil by the hob. She is oh so very now.

Single Woman is not an imaginary composite, cobbled together from the dubious findings of hack consumer surveys. She is a real person and I am in her £500,000 flat checking out the contents of her fridge - although she doesn't know it. Being single and unencumbered, she has decided to sell up and take a new banking job abroad, even though she only just started living here. The estate agent overseeing the sale suggested we meet in her flat to discuss the impact of people like Single Woman upon his business and I am taking the opportunity to do some research. Or snoop, as it's more commonly known.

Because Single Woman is not just some cultural oddity. She is our future. In 1961 the proportion of households occupied by just one person was 10 per cent. Today that figure is 30 per cent. The Department of the Environment estimates that by 2010 it will have reached 40 per cent. In short, there will be more single-person households than any other kind. The cause, according to a report from the Henley Centre for Forecasting, is the triple whammy of 'increased affluence, the break-up of relationships and lower rates of marriage'. The second of those causes is a given: people become single because they are no longer part of a couple. It is reasons one and three which are more interesting. They suggest that major personal decisions are being made. 'Singledom is no longer something that only happens to you solely because of a relationship breakdown,' says Helen Wilkinson, a director of the think tank Demos, who has researched the subject. 'It may actually be a positive choice.'

There is, it seems, a growing tribe: the New Singletons. They are marrying less and divorcing more. They are steering clear of emotional commitments. They are avoiding parenthood. The only ambition many of us now have is not to be an 'us' at all. It is to be an 'I'. The New Singleton wants to be alone.

The impact of this vast social change will be felt everywhere, not just in the banal arithmetic of the housing market but in our cultural lives: in the books we read, the television programmes we watch and the films we go out to see. The publication in 1996 of Helen Fielding's book Bridget Jones's Diary , has long been credited with giving a voice to a particular kind of desperate thirty-something woman for whom being single is an affliction or disease. It sold over a million copies and was followed by myriad imitators. Already, however, it seems an outmoded model.

The shift in attitudes that has taken place can now be traced most acutely not on the page but on the screen, in the career of one Hugh Grant, who went from Sad Singleton to New Singleton in the space of just two movies. In the 1994 film Four Weddings and a Funeral he played Charles, a pathologically single man, incapable of commitment, uncertain of what he wanted and no happier for that; the kind of man, in fact, who would have made Bridget Jones's life a misery. Five years later, in last year's Notting Hill , he played William. He too was single but there was nothing particularly desperate about it. His singleness was just the state in which he found himself after a failed marriage, in a world where so many marriages do. He wanted a new relationship but not just so that he was no longer alone. He specifically wanted a relationship with Julia Roberts.

That unremarkable shifting between the coupled and the uncoupled state is also a feature of the New Singleton's lifestyle. 'There is this assumption that there are these two groups, the singles and the smug marrieds,' says Wilkinson. 'But it's not like that any more. Actually they interchange all the time.' Wilkinson knows what she's talking about. Her last co-habiting relationship finished four years ago. 'For me being single is neither a positive nor a negative state,' she says. 'It's just what I happen to be. I thoroughly expect at some time to meet someone else but I am very aware now of what I would be giving up if I went into a relationship. I love my own space.' She lives in a development of 2000 flats in London's East End which she describes as 'a self-created community' with its own bars, restaurants and a gym. 'They are people with shared values. In that sense you don't feel alone.'

Ian Murray, a 29-year-old senior research executive at the polling organisation Mori, which has conducted surveys on singledom, agrees. 'Most of the people I know in London are single. We live in our own flats doing our own thing. It's a lot more acceptable now. People don't look at you with pity in supermarkets because of the ready meals in your basket.' Would he like a relationship? He's really not sure. 'You get used to being single and you come to like it. And that makes it more and more difficult to compromise. I get into relationships and find I can't make that compromise.'

In the area where our Single Woman lives on the edge of the City a whole social infrastructure has developed to support her lifestyle. Bars and restaurants, their facades gilded with neon, have sprung up all over the district, usually in the ground-floor units of new residential blocks converted from unused office space.

'Fifteen thousand new homes have been created within a mile and a half of here in the past three years,' says David Salvi of Hurford Salvi Carr Estate Agents. 'Of those, at least 50 per cent have been bought by single people. As a result the bars are alive in the evenings. The social life is good but it's definitely for unencumbered living.' I ask him if he had ever thought of buying one? 'I have two kids and I couldn't imagine family life here. External space is in short supply so there are no gardens, and of course roof terraces aren't ideal for children.'

I examine the contents of Single Woman's fridge: a few blocks of cheese, some cooked chicken, a bag of fresh pasta and a jar of pesto. 'Definitely not a family fridge,' the estate agent says. In the freezer there are three tubs of ice cream, a bag of ice cubes and a frozen leg of lamb, presumably for when she entertains which, statistically, single people do far more regularly than couples. The rest of the time food will be bought according to the demands of convenience. 'For many of my clients the Marks & Spencer food shop at Moorgate is a godsend,' Salvi says.

I take a trip to this M&S food hall, an inner-city temple to single living. Young men and women float up and down the ready-meal aisles alone, filling their baskets with single servings of chicken risotto and prawn rogan josh, tagliatelle with chicken, tomato and basil and even ready-made mash (yours for £1.99.) At present, M&S has the local market to itself. Four years ago both Tesco and Sainsbury's considered building a new store near here but decided against it because they perceived a lack of future consumer demand. Now they are fighting over the only available site.

It's not surprising they should be desperate to move into an area highly populated by New Singletons. Over the past year Tesco has seen a 63 per cent increase in the sales of its meals for one. Likewise Sainsbury's has discovered a market for single servings of bagged salad. They sold five million in 1999. Some of this is the result of fractured family eating habits but, equally, a lot of it is down to the rise in the number of people living and eating alone.

There is little doubt that this 'ready-meal and white wine' lifestyle has so far been reflected most extensively in books - in the novels of Jane Green and Marian Keyes, Isabel Wolff and Freya North - though it seems now that the appetite for the single thirtysomething book is all but sated. 'Offer a publisher a book about being single and a woman and looking for love and they'll groan,' says literary agent Jo Frank. 'They'll say the trend has come and gone even though there may be more and more single people in society.'

Carolyn Mays, editorial director of Hodder which publishes Arabella Weir's Does My Bum Look Big In This? and Mike Gayle's My Legendary Girlfriend, concurs. 'We are still being offered lots of novels about single life,' she says. 'But the books that we're most interested in now are the ones where the issues of being single and trying to find a mate are dealt with in a different way. There's one going round now where the protagonist has to choose between two men and there are two endings. The reader gets to decide which one she should end up with. In the end I think the single character will just become an accepted part of the fictional landscape.'

For the novelist William Sutcliffe, whose latest book, The Love Hexagon , deals with relationships between twentysomethings, the problem with the novels published so far has been their over-obsession with gender difference. 'In my experience personality traits like an inability to commit have nothing to do with gender. Gender differences are shrinking and now non-sexual friendships across the divide are becoming easier and easier.'

Ironically, he says, this is one of the reasons people are staying single for longer. 'Romance becomes harder because traditional romantic gestures seem cheesy. A proffered red rose looks naff. It's easier to woo someone in a world where men are men and women are women.' In any case, he says, it's deeply old-fashioned to equate singleness with bleakness. 'Maybe we're staying single because we're getting more out of our friendships so the need for pair bonds reduces. In my latest book the only couple who get married are the least pleasant. Marriage is their punishment, not their reward. It's what they deserve.' It is, Sutcliffe says, his revenge on Jane Austen.

Television drama has lagged a little behind fiction, though only because so many of their ideas come from the pages of novels, sometimes bought for adaptation. At the forefront of TV drama's assault on the subject was, of course, This Life , the shambling story of young lawyers on the make and their Byzantine couplings. It's been followed by the likes of Big Bad World, Lucy Sullivan is Getting Married and Wonderful You .

According to Jane Tranter, head of serials at the BBC, this rash of dramas self-consciously dealing with the lives of single people has probably run its course, just as it has in books. 'We're going to have to look in a slightly different way at the issue and be rather more truthful about it,' she says. She accepts that in future scriptwriters may simply have to make a point of including characters who are single. 'Every so often in the past there's been an effort to put representatives of ethnic minorities into ensemble pieces without making a fuss about it. Maybe representatives of the single lifestyle should start appearing in the same way. Perhaps we should have a happy single character pop up in EastEnders without their single state being an issue.'

Notting Hill aside, the eventual impact of the New Singletons on the movies may be harder to define. It's not that the issue has been ignored. Already we've had British movies like This Year's Love and Martha Meet Frank Daniel and Lawrence which happily dwelt on the single lifestyle. But inevitably they tumbled towards a paired-off ending (as, indeed, did both Four Weddings and Notting Hill ). 'It's perceived that movies need that kind of conclusion,' said one script development executive. 'I have yet to see a script in which the lead character starts off single and decides to stay that way for the next 90 minutes.' That said, the movies have a good record of reflecting changing social mores. Changing attitudes to sex outside marriage in Britain, for example, were first most acutely reflected in the 1960 movie Saturday Night Sunday Morning ; it seems unlikely that British film will miss such an obvious trend as the rise of the New Singleton.

As to popular music the impact will simply be economic. The classic pop song is, and always has been, about falling in love and falling out of love, very much the meat and potatoes of the singleton's lifestyle. That will not change. 'But more people will be buying the records,' says songwriter and producer Pete Waterman. 'Single people always buy more music and it remains a social part of their lives for much longer.' They also tend to have younger tastes than their married contemporaries, he says. 'He may be into the Propellerheads while his married friend is listening to Clapton.'

Inevitably that will be the most obvious result of the New Singleton's rise: the youthing of society. Consumer trend analysts are already talking about a further boom in health and fitness clubs for singles concerned about their appearance as they slip, unencumbered and randy, into young middle-age. With no commitments their expendable income will be high and their spending - on clothes and music, eating out and holidaying - will be equally so. The retail industry will have to adapt to meet their needs.

Meanwhile the smug marrieds sitting out in the suburbs with their gardens for the kids and their two-car drives and their regimented bedtimes - the people who for so long have represented some socially desirable norm - may find that they are the ones who are now the excluded minority, their lifestyle less and less represented on screen and in books. As they watch their increasingly youthful New Singleton contemporaries out there playing the scene, living how they want where they want, answering to no one and loving it, they may suddenly start asking themselves what it is exactly that they have to feel so damn smug about.

webTitle: How can I make my depressed husband seek help?

fields.headline: How can I make my depressed husband seek help?
fields.trailText: Moral muse
fields.body:
My husband has suffered from chronic clinical depression for many years. I have always sympathised with him and learned to live with his bleak moods. Recently he has got worse. Although he knows he has a problem, he will not seek medical advice and thinks his depression would instantly lift if certain problems were sorted out. I know this is not the case. He needs medical help but will not recognise this or seek help. What can I do?

Anon of Dorset

Psychiatrists make the distinction between endogenous depression, which is regarded as an illness, and reactive depression, which is a more or less appropriate and natural response to life's vicissitudes. There seems to be a continuum of mood disturbance. For instance, after bereavement it is accepted that a person grieves and is sorrowful; but such a process can turn into an abnormal and protracted grief reaction, especially in a predisposed personality.

The duration of your husband's dark moods would tend to suggest an endogenous problem. Do I understand that throughout this time he has never had any medical attention? If not, this is very sad, because help is available to improve his quality of life and yours. Somehow you really do have to connect him up with his doctor, who will probably want to involve a specialist. You may have to take this by degrees. Even the word 'psychiatrist' carries overtones of 'being put away' to some people, and the American term 'analyst' may be a preferable euphemism.

Depression may be an accompaniment of other conditions. People of high attainments, drive, and workaholic tendencies are prone to depression in later life as their abilities fade or if their expectations do not match reality. Also, insidious conditions such as an underactive thyroid can sometimes be the root cause, so your husband needs a complete physical overhaul. Regular medication needs to be critically assessed, as depression can be a side-effect of some drugs. Does he have an alcohol problem? This can be a cause of mood disorder, and must be addressed in tandem.

The chances are that none of these things is relevant, and his depression is a primary condition. Your continuing sympathy is vital. It is difficult to imagine the despair which is the unremitting atmosphere for the sufferer, who may be obsessed with thoughts of doom, guilt, punishment and nihilism; and who may drop progressively out of his employment and recreational pursuits and become a prisoner of his own morbid state of mind. The resistance to taking advice is a symptom, so must be overcome. You must be aware that suicide is a risk, and if he is getting worse and has articulated such thoughts, there may be some urgency.

I suggest you make a point of seeing your doctor and discussing your anxieties. He should visit your husband at home or arrange for a psychiatric domiciliary consultation. There are a number of treatments , and effective anti-depressant medication is available. Electro-convulsive therapy (ECT) is occasionally used in an emergency; though controversial and unaesthetic, it produces rapid results and is remarkably free from side effects. Possibly his treatment may begin as a hospital in-patient. You should see a significant improvement, with a progressive willingness to co-operate.

Readers' responses
As someone who works with men and boys in education, business and sport, this dilemma is all too common. I urge this man to seek help as soon as possible and to assure him that he is not the only man to suffer in this way. Depression is no respecter of status and he may be surprised at the help available, whether via sdrug or therapy or a combination. Do not let the macho fear of feeling a failure put him off. Richard O'Neill, Performance in Motivation Consultants.
mensbox@aol.com

My father suffered from depression (untreated) and I am about to start attending a psychiatric out-patients' clinic. It may be that this man is simply very apprehensive about the treatment he is likely to receive. The mention of 'chronic clinical depression' suggests that he has been diagnosed in the past and understands more than she does about what is in store for him and the stigma attached to mental illness.

When you are so vulnerable it is daunting to put yourself in the care of strangers. Someone who is very depressed can sometimes be self-indulgent and controlling: 'If I'm going to be miserable, so are you.' Maybe if she threatens to leave him, it may shock him into seeking help.
A.W. of Greenford

Next week's dilemma is from I.R. of Newcastle Upon Tyne
I've started dreaming about my boss. The dreams are very vivid and filled with emotional longing and sexual desire, although I have never felt anything like this towards him in real life. In fact, a lot of the time he drives me mad.

He is really elusive when you need him, and a complete control freak. Recently, though, the dreams have become so powerful and disturbing they are starting to affect my relationship with my husband. They stay in my head all day and I feel as though I'm keeping a huge secret from him. Is it possible to be unfaithful in your dreamlife? And would it help if I told my husband what's been going on?

 Write to The Observer Review at the usual addresss or e-mail kim.bunce@observer.co.uk
Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday.

 Margaret Cook writes a column for Woman's Journal.

The duration of your husband's dark moods would tend to suggest an endogenous problem. Do I understand that throughout this time he has never had any medical attention? If not, this is very sad, because help is available to improve his quality of life and yours. Somehow you really do have to connect him up with his doctor, who will probably want to involve a specialist. You may have to take this by degrees. Even the word 'psychiatrist' carries overtones of 'being put away' to some people, and the American term 'analyst' may be a preferable euphemism. Depression may be an accompaniment of other conditions. People of high attainments, drive, and workaholic tendencies are prone to depression in later life as their abilities fade or if their expectations do not match reality. Also, insidious conditions such as an underactive thyroid can sometimes be the root cause, so your husband needs a complete physical overhaul. Regular medication needs to be critically assessed, as depression can be a side-effect of some drugs. Does he have an alcohol problem? This can be a cause of mood disorder, and must be addressed in tandem. The chances are that none of these things is relevant, and his depression is a primary condition. Your continuing sympathy is vital. It is difficult to imagine the despair which is the unremitting atmosphere for the sufferer, who may be obsessed with thoughts of doom, guilt, punishment and nihilism; and who may drop progressively out of his employment and recreational pursuits and become a prisoner of his own morbid state of mind. The resistance to taking advice is a symptom, so must be overcome. You must be aware that suicide is a risk, and if he is getting worse and has articulated such thoughts, there may be some urgency. I suggest you make a point of seeing your doctor and discussing your anxieties. He should visit your husband at home or arrange for a psychiatric domiciliary consultation. There are a number of treatments , and effective anti-depressant medication is available. Electro-convulsive therapy (ECT) is occasionally used in an emergency; though controversial and unaesthetic, it produces rapid results and is remarkably free from side effects. Possibly his treatment may begin as a hospital in-patient. You should see a significant improvement, with a progressive willingness to co-operate. Readers' responses As someone who works with men and boys in education, business and sport, this dilemma is all too common. I urge this man to seek help as soon as possible and to assure him that he is not the only man to suffer in this way. Depression is no respecter of status and he may be surprised at the help available, whether via sdrug or therapy or a combination. Do not let the macho fear of feeling a failure put him off. Richard O'Neill, Performance in Motivation Consultants. mensbox@aol.com My father suffered from depression (untreated) and I am about to start attending a psychiatric out-patients' clinic. It may be that this man is simply very apprehensive about the treatment he is likely to receive. The mention of 'chronic clinical depression' suggests that he has been diagnosed in the past and understands more than she does about what is in store for him and the stigma attached to mental illness. When you are so vulnerable it is daunting to put yourself in the care of strangers. Someone who is very depressed can sometimes be self-indulgent and controlling: 'If I'm going to be miserable, so are you.' Maybe if she threatens to leave him, it may shock him into seeking help. A.W. of Greenford Next week's dilemma is from I.R. of Newcastle Upon Tyne I've started dreaming about my boss. The dreams are very vivid and filled with emotional longing and sexual desire, although I have never felt anything like this towards him in real life. In fact, a lot of the time he drives me mad. He is really elusive when you need him, and a complete control freak. Recently, though, the dreams have become so powerful and disturbing they are starting to affect my relationship with my husband. They stay in my head all day and I feel as though I'm keeping a huge secret from him. Is it possible to be unfaithful in your dreamlife? And would it help if I told my husband what's been going on?  Write to The Observer Review at the usual addresss or e-mail kim.bunce@observer.co.uk Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday.  Margaret Cook writes a column for Woman's Journal.

webTitle: Two cheers for Mr West End

fields.headline: Two cheers for Mr West End
fields.standfirst: Susannah Clapp holds out a cautious optimism for theatre after the Lloyd Webber takeover
fields.trailText: Susannah Clapp holds out a cautious optimism for theatre after the Lloyd Webber takeover
fields.body:
The West End is to theatre what Fleet Street is to newspapers: emblematic and largely inert. It's time to stop talking as if what happened in a small pocket of streets in London were a litmus test of the artistic wellbeing of the English theatre - let alone the Irish, Scottish or Welsh. It's time to stop using that cutely heritage term 'theatreland' to refer to this patch. It's time to stop behaving as if lamplighters were going to come whistling down Drury Lane in the dusk. Much of the dynamism of the theatre has for a long time been generated elsewhere.

This isn't to deny that Andrew Lloyd Webber's purchase of a clutch of theatres in and around Shaftesbury Avenue is significant. In buying for £87.5 million the group of theatres formerly owned by Stoll Moss, he has acquired, along with his City backer, 10 of London's most celebrated houses, among them the London Palladium, the Gielgud and the Theatre Royal Drury Lane. He is already owner or part-owner of three other theatres.

This makes Lloyd Webber the largest West End theatre owner. The potential revenue and the effect not only on the capital but on the country are huge. The Phantom of the Opera has taken £2 billion worldwide - nudging it just ahead of the box-office take for the film Titanic. The West End is estimated to bring more than £1bn a year into the British economy. Meanwhile most backers of productions stand to lose: Tess, with a budget of £1.5m, has closed after only eight weeks.

With one bound Lloyd Webber has become Mr West End, but this doesn't make him Mr Theatre. Looking back over the pieces I've written for The Observer over the past few years, I've been struck by how comparatively seldom these have featured the West End. In the last six columns of 1999, I reviewed 18 shows: only three of these were premiered in the West End. This may serve as some comment on the disappointing nature of West End shows: but it can also be interpreted as one sign of a healthy off-West End theatre.

An Almeida or a Royal Court opening is pretty much a guarantee not necessarily of a perfect play or production, but of vitality. On the South Bank, the National seems set on a path of recovery, and at Bankside the much-derided Globe is transmitting Shakespeare to packed houses.

In Kilburn the Tricycle created a vital piece of political theatre with its dramatisation of the Lawrence Inquiry. In Shepherd's Bush the tiny Bush flies the flag for sharp-edged realistic plays. Meanwhile the most original show of the past three years - Improbable Theatre's Shockheaded Peter - started at West Yorkshire Playhouse.

So, who, you might think, needs the West End? Well obviously big shows do. And while there's still life there, it would be a shame to lose it - and a shame not to make it better. Lloyd Webber's hands may be an improvement on those of the most recent owners or other prospective buyers. He is a theatre enthusiast and not an asset-stripper.

While curious about his latest venture - a musical about football to be written with Ben Elton - I am not a fan of his music: watching Whistle Down the Wind was one of my more disagreeable recent experiences. But there's no evidence to suggest the West End is going to be flooded with his musicals - 'My God, I hope not,' he says - or with imitations. He's cannier than that; he must want to expand his profile.

He has given one encouraging signal, enthusing about Bollywood, in particular about Indian composer and musician A.R. Rahman, who writes about four musicals a year. He has said he would like to commission Rahman. If he does so, he will bring new sounds, sights and dances into the theatre. With these would come a sensibility quite distinct from that of any musical currently on the London stage.

So far, Lloyd Webber's pronouncements about his aims have been vague: he has said he hopes he'll take risks and promote challenging work. Unfortunately, he went on to cite as an example of risk-taking the staging of his own Cats . The challenge will be to go outside his habitual orbit, and to promote work which argues and unsettles; to give space, alongside musicals and revivals, to non-cajoling new plays. He should take his cue from the work of those theatres mentioned above: together, they supply the ingredients for a revivified West End. Which would be really useful theatre.

webTitle: MI5 to open its files to MPs

fields.headline: MI5 to open its files to MPs
fields.trailText: British Intelligence is to allow unprecedented parliamentary scrutiny of its files in a bid to convince MPs that it did not mislead Ministers over the Mitrokhin Archive - papers smuggled out of Russia in the early Nineties which revealed the extent of KGB penetration of Western security.
fields.body:
British Intelligence is to allow unprecedented parliamentary scrutiny of its files in a bid to convince MPs that it did not mislead Ministers over the Mitrokhin Archive - papers smuggled out of Russia in the early Nineties which revealed the extent of KGB penetration of Western security.

The opening of the files, including advice to Ministers, has been agreed by MI5 director-general Stephen Lambert and the Intelligence and Security Committee chaired by Tom King.

The files relate to the security services' handling of the archive and are being examined in a secure room in the Cabinet Office. Lambert has stressed that access to original papers, usually denied to a parliamentary select committee, is unique to this inquiry and reflects the importance of the issues being examined.

The security services appear to have admitted to the committee that they mishandled the Mitrokhin Archive, in believing it would emerge as 'a good news story' showing that, in comparison with the US, Britain's MI5 and MI6 had not suffered much infiltration by the Russians.

Instead, the Times serialisation of a book written by Cambridge academic Christopher Andrew led to a frenzied attempt to expose Britain's Cold War spies. The security services have admitted it was unfortunate that MI5 co-operated with Andrew and the Times, while MI6 liaised with the BBC. Competition between the rival media outlets led to a battle to expose spies, including 87-year-old Melita Norwood.

MI5 has also acknowledged in private that it erred in failing to inform Ministers that it had decided there was no point in trying to prosecute Norwood. The Intelligence and Security Committee is certain to criticise MI5 over this lapse, but MI5 will insist Norwood's importance to the Russians has been exaggerated.

In a further bid to open its operations, the services are pressing ahead with plans to release some of their post-war files to the Public Record Office (PRO) this year. As a priority the security services have released First and Second World War files, including files kept by the Cabinet Office setting out the strategic thinking on the postwar threat posed to Britain by communism.

The security services have agreed that files earmarked for destruction should be subject to independent scrutiny by PRO staff with security clearance. The Home Secretary revealed nearly 18 months ago that MI5 retains 440,000 files, of which 290,000 relate to individuals who have been subject to investigation or inquiry. Some 20,000 files were classified as green or active.

The security services will strenuously oppose any such right of access.

webTitle: Fast Forward: The Loafer's Guide To Popular Culture

fields.headline: Fast Forward: The Loafer's Guide To Popular Culture
fields.standfirst: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week:  Trigger Happy TV
fields.trailText: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week:  Trigger Happy TV
fields.body:
So what are all these ads on TV and bill posters around town, showing a picture of a traffic warden, and saying 'Do not trust this man'? Ah, I see you fall prey too easily to modern marketing ruses. The ads are there to promote Trigger Happy TV, a new series on Channel 4 on Fridays at 9.30pm, featuring Dom Jolly, the man pictured driving the scooter - the one you're not supposed to trust.

I never trust traffic wardens anyway. But why does this one have his own show? Dom Jolly is not actually a traffic warden. His job's not any way near as dignified as that. In this series, he spends his time in a variety of guises, either messing about or trying to trick unsuspecting members of the public, and celebrities - including Ian Botham, Ken Livingstone, Tamara Beckwith, Tim Rice, Terry Gilliam, Alice Cooper, Jason Donovan - into making fools of themselves. Oddly enough, it proves to be quite an easy task.

Oh, the tike. What else does he get up to? He dresses up as a park warden and asks pensioners out on a quiet stroll not to let off fireworks; dressed as a traffic warden, he tells a road sweeper, who's parked on a double yellow line while he empties the bins, to move along, as he doesn't want 'any grief on his patch'; as a TV reporter, he tries to interview Bill Wyman, but a young lad keeps drifting into shot and won't go away. So he beats him soundly.

Bet Bill was appalled? Absolutely. 'That was a bit vicious,' he said. But interestingly, during the series' 142 hours of footage, shot over 13 months in seven countries, only one member of the public has complained so far, and this was 'settled amicably'.

I'll suppose the rest haven't seen it yet. What else has this man been up to? He used to work behind the scenes with comic spoofer Mark Thomas on his Channel 4 programme Comedy Product. You might have seen him on the front page of the Evening Standard , as the 'mystery protester' stood behind Mohamed Al Fayed or Neil Hamilton during their libel trial, dressed as a gorilla or a bear, waving a placard.

One shameless self-publicist after another's camera-time? Absolutely. But at least Jolly is intentionally funny.

fields.headline: Dotted history
fields.standfirst: Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama's 40-year obsession with dots, mirrors and pattern has inspired American pop artists and BritArtists alike. But her painting's joyous resonance belies the artist's troubles, as she tells long-term admirer Damien Hirst
fields.trailText: Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama's 40-year obsession with dots, mirrors and pattern has inspired American pop artists and BritArtists alike. But her painting's joyous resonance belies the artist's troubles, as she tells long-term admirer Damien Hirst
fields.body:
Damien Hirst: Do you feel that your work is optimistic?

Yayoi Kusama: No. Each piece is a condensation of my life.

H: There seems to be so much happiness in your work.

K: I don't think my work projects happiness. I have been able somehow to live to this day without committing suicide simply because I have used my art as a shield against my illness.

H: Does your illness have a name?

K: It is obsessional neurosis. I have been suffering from this for more than 50 years. Painting pictures has been therapy for me to overcome the illness.

H: Art is about life, and the art world is about money. How have you separated the two?

K: I think of fame and money like shoes and umbrellas. How one uses his or her money reflects that person's character. I try to incorporate myself into my work as a means to break out of my illness.

H: What are you doing now?

K: I have been in a hospital for more than 20 years because of my mental disorder caused by traumatic experiences I had in my childhood. I am certain I will die a 'death while doing art' in this hospital. Every day I create sculptures and other formative art pieces, write novels and poems and compose music as well.

H: Do you feel lonely being an artist?

K: I am very lonely. It is almost unbearable, especially when I hear the sound of tree leaves trembling in a windstorm. When I go up to the roof of a high-rise building, I feel an urge to die by jumping from it. My passion for art has prevented me from doing that.

H: Do you feel famous? How do you deal with it?

K: Yes, I feel famous. There is a Kusama boom in both Japan and New York. My 'One Thousand Boat Show' held at the Gertrude Stein Gallery in 1963 caused a great sensation in New York. The show featured one boat with 999 posters of the boat pasted on the ceiling and walls. In 1965, Andy Warhol made 'Cow Wallpapers' using the same concept. When I was a child, one day I was walking in the field, when the sky became bright over the mountains, and I saw clearly the very image I was about to paint appear. I also saw violets which I was painting multiply to cover the doors, windows and even my body. It was then I learned the idea of self-obliteration.

 A Yayoi Kusama retrospective opens at the Serpentine Gallery on 26 January until 19 March. An accompanying book, Yayoi Kusama , is published by Phaidon Press at £19.95

webTitle: Mayor Ken would let radicals rule

fields.headline: Mayor Ken would let radicals rule
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has promised jobs in the Mayor of London's office for black radicals and other left-wing activists rejected by the official Labour leadership if he wins the election in May.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has promised jobs in the Mayor of London's office for black radicals and other left-wing activists rejected by the official Labour leadership if he wins the election in May.

He says he will need them because Labour's candidates for the Greater London Assembly - elected on the same day as the Mayor - are 'not inspiring'. He told The Observer : 'They're definitely not our First Eleven.'

His remarks will horrify the Labour leadership, reviving memories of how the Livingstone-led Greater London Council created dozens of jobs for political sympathisers, and could also undermine efforts to get official Labour candidates into the new Assembly. All Labour's candidates have declared their support for Livingstone's rival, Frank Dobson.

Livingstone delivered his attack at a party meeting in Islington last week, and repeated it to The Observer yesterday. 'I will make certain that people who represent London's black community are in the team,' he said. 'You cannot have these people ruled out for all time simply because they weren't supporting Frank Dobson.'

He named four black party members who he says were unfairly prevented from running in the May election, including Lee Jasper, the outspoken secretary of the National Association Against Racism. Jasper said yesterday: 'I'll be very interested in the Metropolitan Police portfolio. Flag that up, and you'll have them running round in circles in Scotland Yard, tearing out their hair.'

Others named by Livingstone as victims of an alleged 'stitch up' included Tower Hamlets councillors Christine Shawcroft and Kumar Murshid, and Geoff Martin, London regional organiser of the public sector union, Unison.

Livingstone was boosted yesterday by support from actor Richard Wilson, who played Victor Meldrew in the BBC's One Foot in the Grave . In a foreword to a mini-manifesto which Livingstone is mailing to London party members, Meldrew hails him as a man who 'clearly cares about London'.

The Dobson camp admits it is trailing Livingstone by around 35 per cent to 41 per cent among the 62,000 London members eligible to vote in next month's postal ballot. But they insist Dobson can close the gap, and believe Livingstone's Achilles heel will be his repeated attacks on the economic policy of Chancellor Gordon Brown.

Brown will share a platform with Tony Blair on Wednesday to win over wavering voters. Nearly 20,000 members have been telephone-canvassed by Dobson's team, who say a fifth of the London membership has yet to make a decision.

Dobson will also be trading on his own left-wing credentials by campaigning with Mo Mowlam, Ian McCartney, Clare Short, David Blunklett and Paul Boateng. But he may not be helped by a statement of support from Labour's newest MP, Shaun Woodward, who is not forgiven by many party members for his past as a Tory MP.

The Dobson team has had to scotch rumours among Livingstone supporters that Dobson will pull out to give former Transport Minister Glenda Jackson a chance to beat Livingstone.

Steve Norris is expected to emerge tomorrow as the clear winner in a ballot to choose the new Tory candidate. Norris is expected to deliver a warning to his party against Tory spin doctors who have been hinting that a Livingstone victory would be the best outcome for the Tories. Norris spokesman Ceri Evans said: 'Certain people are saying Livingstone for Mayor would be a win-win situation, because he'd kick Blair and have unpopular policies. I say "get a life". We can fight this to win.'

In a foreword to a mini-manifesto which Livingstone is mailing to London party members, Meldrew hails him as a man who 'clearly cares about London'. The Dobson camp admits it is trailing Livingstone by around 35 per cent to 41 per cent among the 62,000 London members eligible to vote in next month's postal ballot. But they insist Dobson can close the gap, and believe Livingstone's Achilles heel will be his repeated attacks on the economic policy of Chancellor Gordon Brown. Brown will share a platform with Tony Blair on Wednesday to win over wavering voters. Nearly 20,000 members have been telephone-canvassed by Dobson's team, who say a fifth of the London membership has yet to make a decision. Dobson will also be trading on his own left-wing credentials by campaigning with Mo Mowlam, Ian McCartney, Clare Short, David Blunklett and Paul Boateng. But he may not be helped by a statement of support from Labour's newest MP, Shaun Woodward, who is not forgiven by many party members for his past as a Tory MP. The Dobson team has had to scotch rumours among Livingstone supporters that Dobson will pull out to give former Transport Minister Glenda Jackson a chance to beat Livingstone. Steve Norris is expected to emerge tomorrow as the clear winner in a ballot to choose the new Tory candidate. Norris is expected to deliver a warning to his party against Tory spin doctors who have been hinting that a Livingstone victory would be the best outcome for the Tories. Norris spokesman Ceri Evans said: 'Certain people are saying Livingstone for Mayor would be a win-win situation, because he'd kick Blair and have unpopular policies. I say "get a life". We can fight this to win.'

fields.headline: Health report: On the cheap
fields.standfirst: The price is right, but how's the quality? Helen Foster had the experts test six cut-price cosmetics
fields.trailText: The price is right, but how's the quality? Helen Foster had the experts test six cut-price cosmetics
fields.body:
A recent survey by Mintel revealed that, when it comes to cosmetics and skincare, 73 per cent of women believe that the pricier the product, the better it performs. But are we right to be so sceptical about the cheaper end of the market?

The £3.30 foundation
No17 Perfect Cover Foundation

This foundation claims to offer good coverage, UVA and UVB protection and contain light diffusers, which are often used in more expensive foundations to help disguise wrinkles.

The expert: dermatologist Dr Elisabeth Dancey, a specialist in skin ageing
'Despite the fact that the No17 range is aimed at younger women, this would be a brilliant product for any age skin. It has a moisturising formula and is high in pigment, so it covers well. It is also quite possible that it will make the face look younger - it contains titanium dioxide, which as well as being a sunblock (hence the UV protection) also bounces light off the skin and so softens the look of fine lines and wrinkles. An additional benefit is that it is also very low on allergens. My only criticism is that although it says it protects against UV light, it doesn't give an SPF and it warns against wearing while sunbathing, which makes me think protection is probably low. The labelling should be clearer. Eighty per cent of skin ageing is caused by the sun, and people should choose products with an SPF of 15 or over. Still, for use at night, this is an exceptionally good product.'

The £1.69 mascara
Collection 2000 Longer-Lash Mascara

This product uses a mix of keratin, silicone and other ingredients to give longer, thicker lashes, and also contains vitamin B5 for conditioning.

The expert: optometrist Christopher Kerr, adviser to the Association of Contact Lens Manufacturers and the Eyecare Information Service
'My staff tested this and said it's one of the best mascaras they have ever used in terms of lash-lengthening effect. It also comes off easily and leaves lashes soft. However, from an opthalmological point of view, this product does contain two preservatives - methylparaben and propylparaben. These are known eye allergens which also have an anaesthetic effect on the eye. This means that if any mascara gets into the eye (ie, if the fibres flake), this anaesthetic effect could prevent the wearer from feeling discomfort and so lead to damage or infection. But the product contains a high level of beeswax, which reduces risk of flaking anyway. It's a bargain - but do not use it if you've got very sensitive eyes.'

The £2.09 moisturiser
Boots Traditional Skin Care Moisturising Lotion with Vitamins A and E

Vitamins have taken over from AHAs (alpha-hydroxy acids) as the anti-ageing skincare ingredient of choice, but not many of the products that have flooded the market come at this price.

The expert: consultant dermatologist Dr Ravi Ratnavel from Thames Valley Nuffield Hospital
'In terms of moisturising, this product contains the necessary mix of water and glycerine to hydrate skin. It is also well absorbed, but its watery formulation may not be suitable for older or extremely sun-damaged skins, which often respond better to thicker or greasier formulations. However, if you are buying it because of the vitamin content, don't be fooled. For starters, when applied topically, vitamin E has never been proven scientifically to have any anti-ageing benefits on the skin. Vitamin A has, but only in certain forms: tretonoin - which is only available on prescription - and retinol, which is often included in pricier brands. This lotion contains neither of these. So it is a good basic moisturiser but not a bargain anti-ageing product.'

The £2.49 shampoo and conditioner
Pantene 2-in-1 Shampoo Plus Conditioner for Dry or Damaged Hair

This one-application product claims to cleanse and condition even the trickiest hair in minutes.

The expert: leading trichologist Philip Kingsley
'The most important thing to look for when you buy any hair product is that it is suitable for your hair type, and as far as I'm concerned no '2-in-1' is suitable for dry and damaged hair. The problem with 2-in-1 products is that they condition the hair evenly - generally the roots of the hair need very little moisture and the ends a lot. Also, the main conditioner in this product is dimethicone, which is a silicone, and while silicones are great conditioners, they do weigh down fine hair. In terms of cleansing, I had to use a lot of the product to get a lather, but it did clean the hair well. I found it quite difficult to comb the hair through afterwards though, which means despite the silicone, its conditioning power is probably low. All things considered, for regular use, I'd say you would be better spending a bit more and buying two separate products.'

The £2 nail varnish
Spectacular Nail Polish

This nail varnish claims to be free of formaldehyde (a common allergen) and toluene, which has been linked to cancer risk. It also claims to be long-lasting and hardwearing.

The expert: top manicurist Iris Chapple
'When it comes to nail varnish, high price certainly doesn't guarantee a good product. I really liked this polish and was surprised by how long it lasted on the nail; formaldehyde and toluene are normally used to stop products chipping, so I expected this to chip quickly. In fact, it lasted three days. It also covers the nail very well, although the brush is dreadful. It's too wide at the bottom, which makes for blobbing and streaking. My only other reservation is that the colour on the outside of the bottle is quite different from the result you get from two thin coats - you would need four thin coats to get anywhere near the right shade. Still, all things considered, this is a bargain.'

The £1.09 shower gel and body lotion
Superdrug Purité 2-in-1 Shower & Lotion

This 2-in-1 product claims to cleanse and moisturise the skin, reducing the need for a body lotion. It is fragrance-free and suitable for sensitive skins.

The expert: cosmetic pharmacist and skincare researcher Dr Colette Haydon
'According to the label, this contains both cleansing and moisturising ingredients, so it will do what it says. However, this is a soap-free formula and so uses a detergent (sodium laryl sulphate or SLS) to cleanse the skin. This is significant because if a product is made up of more than 40 per cent SLS, it can be exceptionally drying. The SLS here contains much less than 40 per cent. What's more, there is a lot of water in the product, and this combined with the oil-based humectants means that it will hydrate the skin very effectively - you could certainly get away without using a body lotion if you have normal or oily skin. If you have dry skin, give it a try and see how you feel. For its cleansing properties alone, £1.09 is definitely a bargain. And it would be good for sensitive skins.'

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: A combination of design and business skills has enabled James Dyson, with the help of fellow RCA-trained     Mark Bickerstaffe, to transform a £1m overdraft into sales of 1.4 million vacuum cleaners a year
fields.trailText: James Dyson |  Mark Bickerstaffe
fields.body:
James Dyson: Mark and I have an innate love of design in common. Mark's enthusiasm for it pervades everything. He drives a Ducatti, the ultimate design motorbike, and zooms out of the car park at 90 mph every night. I discovered design at the Royal College of Art (RCA) in the mid-Sixties. I helped to design the Sea Truck [military boat] as part of my degree course. I then organised the manufacturing and selling of them for five years. In a sense, I was an arms salesman; many of them were sold for military use. Scottish lairds also went crazy for it. The Sea Truck's ability to land on beaches meant that they could ferry sheep and provisions from island to island without the need for a jetty. I wanted to do something on my own and had the idea for the Ballbarrow [a wheelbarrow with a ball instead of a wheel]. I made every type of mistake, but it did capture a large chunk of the market, which gave me the confidence to do vacuum cleaners.

After 12 years cleaning my house, I got fed up with vacuum cleaners. I put in a new bag and was amazed to discover that while it worked well for a couple of rooms, by the third it wasn't picking up dust. The bag was empty, but the first dust that went into it blocked the bag and clogged the pores. That is what spurred me to think of the dual cyclone, which spins the dust out of the air by a non-clogging technique.

In the beginning, it was just me. I had a coach house across the yard at my old house near Bath. I started employing engineer/designers in 1987. In the mid-Eighties, we started getting licenses to make vacuums for Japanese and US companies. We lurched from one financial crisis to another, but we just about managed to keep our heads above water.

In the early 1990s, we decided to make our own product, the DC01. Mark joined us in 1992. I needed engineers with training in design and it was natural for me to go back to the RCA to recruit.

Suddenly, Mark was involved in things he had no experience of, such as going to Taiwan to find and supervise toolmakers during a civil unrest. You can give people from college total authority from the word go and they respond brilliantly. Mark is an absolute shining example of that.

I react more emotionally to things than him, and he's a much better people manager. I don't think he has any weak points, which is why he's head of Research and Development and a group board director at a very young age (31).

I wouldn't want Mark to become a competitor. I'm aware that people may well want to leave and do their own thing.

That's fine by me. I did the same. However, I wouldn't say I'd encourage it.

I'm not extravagant; I have about two outfits. I have the odd holiday, a week off in January somewhere hot, and two weeks in the summer at our house in Provence.

I truthfully like vacuuming. I learn a lot from housework; things that are inefficient give me ideas. It isn't the money - coming up with products that work better is my motivation. People will buy something if it works better, even if it's more expensive. I don't want to get big, either. We're not empire building.

Mark Bickerstaffe: The company has grown so fast and achieved so much. It was very risky in the early days, but we felt it was up to us to make it work. We'd be working in the coach house overnight, slaving away, with matchsticks propping open our eyes, and the light in James' house would click on. Ten minutes later, he would wander over with coffee and hot cross buns. James is very good at motivating people.

James is incredibly shrewd and bright. You can have an in-depth technical discussion for hours, consult James, and at the drop of a hat he's got your answer. James is not just a designer - he has a business mind. It's that combination that I respect. Because he's so motivated, he wants to get involved with everything, and with a business this size, it's a bit difficult. We do have some fairly heated debates sometimes.

James is an open, frank human being who I would classify as a friend. There's a lot of interchange: he came to my wedding; I've been round to his house for meals; I go fishing on his water, sometimes with his son Jacob. James and his wife Deirdre live in an old mill house near Malmesbury - where the Dyson Head Office is situated - that they bought from Lord Puttnam. It has 38 acres, with a river running pretty much past the house.

We've seen James' family grow with the business. When I started, his youngest son Sam was at school and his older son Jacob was just off to university. Now Sam works as a designer at Dyson, and Jacob and his daughter Emily have their own businesses - Jacob designing products and interiors, Emily, bed linen and nightwear.

Each new employee goes on the production line, builds a vacuum cleaner, buys it and takes it home. I must have about seven or eight. I do use them, but I also have a cleaning lady. My favourite upright is the DC03. It's lightweight and the design is fantastic. There are other domestic appliances in development but I can't talk about them yet. We might be five years away from bringing a product out - but it's all top secret, I don't even talk about it to my wife.

If you're up to the job, then age or experience are fairly irrelevant at Dyson. What matters most is your ability. There's a lot of very young senior management for a company of this size. James lets you run with it and make mistakes. He's the first to say as long as we've learned something, it's not disastrous. He gives people vision, the capability to do anything.

The next five to 10 years won't see me needing to move anywhere for another challenge. A lot of people would have to say that if they came up with a good idea, they'd love to do a Dyson, do it themselves. Yes, I would like to set up my own business. You go so far, and then you want to have the success that James has had.

fields.headline: Learning swerve
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams, whom I worship just this side of idolatry, is sadly out-of-date in drawing our attention to David Blunkett's recent pronouncement that schools are there principally to meet the needs of employers (Diary, last week).
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams, whom I worship just this side of idolatry, is sadly out-of-date in drawing our attention to David Blunkett's recent pronouncement that schools are there principally to meet the needs of employers (Diary, last week).

Way back in 1976, then Labour Prime Minister James Callaghan said in a speech at Ruskin College: 'The educational system is out of touch with the fundamental need for Britain to survive in a highly competitive world through the efficiency of its industry and commerce.'

A year later, there was Shirley Williams' Green Paper Education in Schools and, since then, the idea has become politically powerful that state schools are to be little more than training departments for employers who are too mean, too stupid or too lazy to train their own work-force.
Peter Sampson
Woodbridge, Suffolk

fields.headline: Dome puffery
fields.body:
Much though I am an admirer of Lord Roger's works, isn't the huffery and puffery around the Dome (Focus, last week) an example of South-East cultural over-heating? Multicolumania about a 'permanent' tent at Greenwich. Meanwhile, not a word about the Don Valley stadium Sheffield, where Tensile1 - the world's largest portable tent, a four-acre PVC cathedral by a brillant young British designer, had it first commercial outing - 30,000 people paid £110 each for a sell-out New Year's Eve party in it. Perhaps just as remarkable and relevant for this point in history, a week later, it's gone.
Denis Postle
London W4

webTitle: Let's hear it for the suburbs?

fields.headline: Let's hear it for the suburbs?
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr's timely article (Comment, last week), strikes just the right note about suburban Britain, and sets out the challenge. There now needs to be a serious and sustained response.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr's timely article (Comment, last week), strikes just the right note about suburban Britain, and sets out the challenge. There now needs to be a serious and sustained response.

In our report for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, Sustainable Suburbs , we drew attention to the critical importance of community involvement. We suggested the need for more local forms of participation in government. Not just the occasional focus group, but a role for urban parishes or neighbourhood councils as a continual basis for community consultation and debate. They could perhaps also run a few simple services, for which they could raise a few pence in the pound, like rural parishes.

By their nature they would have to be very accountable to local people. The legislative frame is already partly in place, but it needs strengthening and it needs leadership from the Government. As well as the 'Minister for the Suburbs', which Andrew Marr suggests, how about a campaign for the suburbs.
Michael Gwilliam, Director of the Civic Trust
London SW1

There now needs to be a serious and sustained response. In our report for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, Sustainable Suburbs , we drew attention to the critical importance of community involvement. We suggested the need for more local forms of participation in government. Not just the occasional focus group, but a role for urban parishes or neighbourhood councils as a continual basis for community consultation and debate. They could perhaps also run a few simple services, for which they could raise a few pence in the pound, like rural parishes. By their nature they would have to be very accountable to local people. The legislative frame is already partly in place, but it needs strengthening and it needs leadership from the Government. As well as the 'Minister for the Suburbs', which Andrew Marr suggests, how about a campaign for the suburbs. Michael Gwilliam, Director of the Civic Trust London SW1

fields.headline: Girls on top
fields.trailText: The men have been behaving badly in the contest to be Mayor of London. Frank Dobson has been struggling to suppress the impression that he never really wanted the job. Ken Livingstone certainly lusts for the title, but Labour MPs of every complexion fear he would indulge his ego at the expense of the capital.
fields.body:
The men have been behaving badly in the contest to be Mayor of London. Frank Dobson has been struggling to suppress the impression that he never really wanted the job. Ken Livingstone certainly lusts for the title, but Labour MPs of every complexion fear he would indulge his ego at the expense of the capital. Steve Norris, who will surely be picked as the Tory candidate, is a cheerful card, but it is easier to list his mistresses than to name anything he did for London when he was Minister for the metropolis in the last government.

It is the women in the contest who have emerged most handsomely. Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat, has a sane approach to addressing the capital's problems. The same can be said of Glenda Jackson. Labour selectors should think hard before they dismiss her as bound to lose. Glum Glenda of the early days appears to have been liberated by the knuckle-headed attempts of Labour central command to edge her out of the contest. To her credit, she has not taken the Livingstone course of responding to dirty trickery by mud-slinging at her opponents.

She wants the job and she seems to want it for the right reasons. While realistic about the constraints imposed on the Mayor, she talks passionately about the challenges facing the capital. Given the limited powers of the office, one of the most important roles to be performed by the Mayor will be as an ambassador to the rest of the world for Britain's capital. She may not enjoy the notoriety of the blokes at home, but it is a fair bet that she is better known around the rest of the globe.

All things considered, Ms Mayor begins to look a great deal more attractive than any of the Mr Mayors.
