fields.headline: Drink drive
fields.trailText: So I should avoid binges of five or more units of alcohol (Life, last week). Fine.
fields.body:
So I should avoid binges of five or more units of alcohol (Life, last week). Fine. But I'm also cautioned against drinking on consecutive days. I can therefore only have a maximum of four units on, say, four evenings a week - 16 units in all. The recommended weekly limit for a man is 27 units. Despairing of getting my consumption up to government-approved levels, I've taken to drinking at lunchtime too.
Adrian F. Lacey
London SW17

fields.headline: The AWE's 'gold' performance
fields.trailText: It is difficult to believe that a responsible newspaper such as  The Observer should publish such a one-sided account, giving details of allegations [of alleged accidents, breakdowns in safety procedures and environmental contamination, (News, 24 October 1999)], and an alarmist misinterpretation of events, without including any explanation by AWE [the Atomic Weapons Establishment].
fields.body:
It is difficult to believe that a responsible newspaper such as The Observer should publish such a one-sided account, giving details of allegations [of alleged accidents, breakdowns in safety procedures and environmental contamination, (News, 24 October 1999)], and an alarmist misinterpretation of events, without including any explanation by AWE [the Atomic Weapons Establishment].

All of industry has incidents, some important and some unimportant. At AWE we try very hard to be open about them all. Although we are sometimes constrained by the country's obligations under the non-proliferation treaty, I believe it is right that we should strive to be as open as possible.

This does make us a target for irresponsible speculation by those who would place misinformed or mischievous interpretations upon our activities. It appears this is something that, regrettably, we may have to live with. However, I am anxious that our staff should not be discouraged from reporting incidents or 'near misses', or that we should suppress making them publicly available.

I should like to reiterate assurances your reporter was given that AWE is safe. Over the last seven years we have made tremendous progress with safety management and in dealing with environmental legacy issues, and we have received two 'gold' safety awards from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents. We can still improve but that should not be allowed to detract from the fact that many people at AWE have worked extremely hard to achieve great success. Both the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate and the Ministry of Defence, who both audit our performance, agree with this.

Your article gave only one side of the story. Your lack of balance does not serve democracy well. However, this will not deter me from continuing to work with the media to achieve a better understanding of the true situation prevailing at AWE and to ensure that the public can be properly informed about our activities.
R.A. Bradley, Chief Executive, AWE
Reading

fields.headline: Cup of woe
fields.trailText: The first FIFA Club World Championship was meant to promote the club game under the sport's global authority, which was fearful that the Manchester Uniteds of this world were becoming bigger than its own World Cup. Was it a genuine tournament? A goodwill exercise? Good PR for England's 2006 World Cup bid? The answer to all is 'yes', yet it failed to deliver.
fields.body:
The first FIFA Club World Championship was meant to promote the club game under the sport's global authority, which was fearful that the Manchester Uniteds of this world were becoming bigger than its own World Cup. Was it a genuine tournament? A goodwill exercise? Good PR for England's 2006 World Cup bid? The answer to all is 'yes', yet it failed to deliver.

Man Utd against South Melbourne was never going to convince us of the competition's pedigree. Goodwill was absent when United adopted their 'them and us' approach to PR. England's World Cup hopes arguably benefited, but not from David Beckham's sending off.

The tournament ended with Vasco da Gama against Corinthians, a truly awful advertisement for Brazilian football. So welcome back, United - you may have been poor but you were in good company.

fields.headline: Detector will spot 'invisible' mines
fields.trailText: British scientists have developed a detector that pinpoints 'invisible' landmines. It uses powerful pulses of electromagnetic energy that last less than a billionth of a second to create radar pictures of buried objects.
fields.body:
British scientists have developed a detector that pinpoints 'invisible' landmines. It uses powerful pulses of electromagnetic energy that last less than a billionth of a second to create radar pictures of buried objects.

The first versions of the device, being built at the Defence Ministry's Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (Dera) at Malvern, Worcestershire, will be used in trials to detect anti-personnel mines that contain no metallic parts and defy detection by other methods.

It is hoped to use the detector to find mines laid during wars such as those in Angola, Bosnia, Cambodia and the Falklands.

There are more than 100 million landmines, laid in more than 60 countries, mostly in the Third World, causing at least 25,000 casualties a year.

In other words, somewhere in the world a landmine explodes and kills or maims a person every 20 minutes. Clearing these objects from fields and from the outskirts of African and Asian cities has become a major political concern and has triggered considerable interest in the British project.

'At present the only really effective way of clearing mines is to try to dig them up, or detonate them with some kind of robot vehicle,' said Dundee University mathematician Dr Paul Smith, a researcher involved in the new detector's development. 'It's a slow and dangerous business.'

The device designed by Dr Smith and his collaborators at Dera gets around such risks by exploiting a technique known as ultra-wideband synthetic aperture radar.

At the heart of the machine, a specially designed generator is used to emit powerful but very brief bursts of electrical energy, every thousandth of a second. These pulses consist of energy that covers a very wide part of the electromagnetic spectrum, and this is bounced back from objects in ways that differ according to their wavelength.

The device's detector then builds up a series of images created by these different reflected pulses and combines them to create a picture of nearby objects.

'Essentially, we can create images of any object that has been buried or hidden and from its shape tell whether it is man-made or not, and therefore whether it is potentially lethal or harmless,' says Smith.

'We have already completed successful preliminary tests, and hope to complete full trials in the near future. Hopefully we can then begin landmine clearing in earnest after that.'

webTitle: Czech prisoners treated worse than dogs - and made to pay £8 a day

fields.headline: Czech prisoners treated worse than dogs - and made to pay £8 a day
fields.trailText: Riots that broke out in prisons across the Czech Republic last week were provoked by chronic overcrowding and new laws forcing prisoners to pay for their stay behind bars.
fields.body:
Riots that broke out in prisons across the Czech Republic last week were provoked by chronic overcrowding and new laws forcing prisoners to pay for their stay behind bars.

Thousands of inmates in more than half of the country's cash-starved jails went on hunger strike and lit fires in protest at the law, which makes prison stricter but fails to tackle appalling conditions which have steadily declined since communism's collapse 10 years ago.

The protests, which opinion polls show are supported by 30 per cent of Czechs, started at the high-security Vinarice prison west of Prague, dubbed the 'Czech Alcatraz', on Tuesday, when the 1,500 inmates demanded the resignation of its director.

Riots spread quickly throughout the country. Prisoners burned their mattresses, bedding and furniture, threw dishes out of their windows and banged on pots and pans to ensure they were heard. They hung banners stating: 'We're not animals.'

International penal experts and the European Commission have warned for years of overcrowding in Czech jails. Crisis point came last year with record overcrowding. Just under 24,000 prisoners are crammed into 33 jails with capacity for only 19,500.

The Czech Republic's prison population is more than 220 per 100,000 people, compared to an EU average of 100. More than half of the convicts are Roma or Gypsy, according to expert sources.

The new prison law, which came into force last week, requires prisoners to pay for their stay (up to £8 a day), to pay compensation to their victims, and restricts them to only two parcels a year in order to cut drug smuggling. Prisoners have demanded the scrapping of the law as well as the right to watch TV, have more than one roll of lavatory paper a month, improved food and sanitary conditions.

Prison chiefs readily admit shortcomings. 'Food rations aren't sufficient, clothing is inadequate and there are other serious shortfalls,' said Eduard Vacek, a prison administration spokesman.

Authorities have said they will make concessions, including increasing the daily food allowance from 35 crowns (60p) to 45 crowns (76p), still below the allowance for Czech police dogs. They will also increase tenfold the monthly pocket money allowance, which is now 100 crowns (£1.70).

Prison Authority chief Kamila Meclova said she had asked parliament to invest one billion crowns (almost £17 million) in the prison service as a priority. By law each Czech prisoner should have 3.5 square metres of cell space. Most have half that. First offenders are placed with dangerous criminals.

'There are 14 of us crammed into a cell meant for just eight,' said Roman Cmunt, from Rynovice prison in northern Bohemia. 'There are only 10 cold water taps for 90 people. We're only allowed to take a shower once a week. One roll of lavatory paper is meant to last a whole month.'

President Vaclav Havel, a prisoner under the Communist regime, is under pressure from some quarters to grant amnesty to less serious criminals, to relieve the problem.

Such unrest has not been seen in Czech prisons since 1989 when prisoners went on hunger strike calling for a general amnesty after the collapse of communism. One prisoner died and many more were injured in riots.

Justice Minister Otakar Motejl said he was considering a special commission to evaluate prisoners' demands.

Deputy Minister for Justice Josef Baxa blamed recidivism as one of the main reasons for overcrowding. 'Two-thirds of prisoners return,' he said. He admitted judges were failing to look at alternative punishment. 'It's true it would help if judges looked at punishment options other than prison, but they are turning to these more and more,' he said.

Prisoners at Pankrac prison in Prague also joined the riots. One of its inmates is Chris Denning, 58, the former Radio 1 DJ who has spent more than two years in jail on trial for paedophile activities. Last week he attacked the prison system as he told a Prague court of the 'appalling conditions' he has endured since 1997.

'I've been subject to degrading treatment ... For three months I was held in isolation in a maniac's cell with two doors and gates and everything bolted to the floor or made of plastic,' he said.

'I was allowed no contact with human beings, and was naked except for underpants.'

webTitle: Heroic rebel town rises from deep

fields.headline: Heroic rebel town rises from deep
fields.standfirst: A century after 'the war at the end of the world', drought uncovers Brazil's tragic 'Troy of mud huts'
fields.trailText: It is the town that no one could suppress. A century after Brazil's most serious civil war was fought at Canudos, the buildings that sheltered thousands of religious rebels are rising again - from the bottom of a dried-out reservoir.
fields.body:
It is the town that no one could suppress. A century after Brazil's most serious civil war was fought at Canudos, the buildings that sheltered thousands of religious rebels are rising again - from the bottom of a dried-out reservoir.

Immortalised in two classics of Latin American literature, The War At The End Of The World by Mario Vargas Llosa and Rebellion in the Backlands by Euclides da Cunha, Canudos was the 'Troy of mud huts' that humiliated the newly formed Brazilian republic at the end of the nineteenth century.

For 30 years the remnants have been submerged under 15 metres of water, because of a dam that aimed to irrigate a region consistently plagued by savage droughts. But one of the worst droughts in the area's history has evaporated most of the reservoir and Canudos, like a ghostly Atlantis emerging from the sea, has gradually reappeared from beneath the water.

'The drought has been difficult for the local population but it has been great for archaeology,' says Paulo Zanettini, who led the first excavation team late last year. For the first time, the site of one of the most important and tragic events in Brazilian history can be investigated. 'We need to take advantage of it before the rains come back and cover it up again,' he says.

While most of the town was built with mud and sticks, the central square had two stone churches and a cross on a stone pedestal. These constructions are now clearly visible, especially the semi-circular steps on the pedestal that are recognisable from old photographs taken during the war.

Founded by a black mystic called Antonio Conselheiro in remote scrubland 1,300 miles north of Rio de Janeiro, Canudos attracted liberated slaves and poor farm workers who created a religious commune. It was a poor commu nity in a distant and inhospitable area but attracted thousands of people until it was second only in size to Salvador, the state capital.

Conselheiro's messianic pull terrified the Brazilian government and the Church, possibly exacerbated by an end-of-century malaise. The army was dispatched to destroy it. But against all the odds Canudos's ill-equipped men managed to defeat the army three times in the bush before eventually, in 1897, they were massacred by a battalion of 5,000 soldiers and heavy artillery.

The battle - which left at least 1,500 dead - was one of the defining events in Brazil's 500-year history, uniting the issues of race, religion, slavery and regionalism, and the fallout still haunts the Brazilian North East.

Erika Robrahn-González, one of the co-ordinators of the research, supervised by Bahia State University, believes the site contains at least 600 skeletons of soldiers and possibly a larger number of Conselheiro's men. She has excavated one soldier's body and sent it for X-ray, DNA and ultrasound tests to discover the racial type and the diseases it was afflicted with.

Zanettini is aware of how controversial the Canudos episode still is for Brazil, and is cautious about drawing conclusions from his preliminary research. However, he believes he can prove the population was no more than 8,000. This compares to a figure as high as 25,000 spread by the military to justify the heavy artillery used.

'Canudos is a very complex issue, but hopefully archaeology can open some new doors. We have touched an enormous iceberg,' he says.

As no research was done before the dam was built, there are a huge number of historical objects still there. This means that looting is easy. Daniel Ernesto Joaquim, aged 12, found 100 bullets lying on the ground. He now sells them for £1 each to tourists. The cemetery had seven headstones. Now there are two left.

'When everything was covered in water, at least this stopped people picking around,' says Zanettini, who has had money for only one short excavation - 30 people for six weeks. 'We won't start a new excavation until we have money to do it properly. If we only do it by half-measures, then other people will finish off the work and take things home as souvenirs.'

In the past fortnight, rain has started to fall and the site is covering up again with water, although this is thought to be temporary. A drought is predicted for another five years.

In the villages nearby, there are people who used to live in Canudos before the dam. Madalena Antonia Santos Oliveira, aged 50, remembers, however, that the local politicians banned people from visiting the relics. For her the influence of Conselheiro is still strong. The mystic was her uncle's godfather. 'He was a very good man,' she said. 'My grandparents told me about him. He built this whole town. It was terrible what the government did.'

'When everything was covered in water, at least this stopped people picking around,' says Zanettini, who has had money for only one short excavation - 30 people for six weeks. 'We won't start a new excavation until we have money to do it properly. If we only do it by half-measures, then other people will finish off the work and take things home as souvenirs.' In the past fortnight, rain has started to fall and the site is covering up again with water, although this is thought to be temporary. A drought is predicted for another five years. In the villages nearby, there are people who used to live in Canudos before the dam. Madalena Antonia Santos Oliveira, aged 50, remembers, however, that the local politicians banned people from visiting the relics. For her the influence of Conselheiro is still strong. The mystic was her uncle's godfather. 'He was a very good man,' she said. 'My grandparents told me about him. He built this whole town. It was terrible what the government did.'
fields.bylineHtml: Alex Bellos in Canudos, Brazil

webTitle: Forces of weevil trump World Bank

fields.headline: Forces of weevil trump World Bank
fields.trailText: A multi-million pound World Bank scheme to combat giant weeds clogging Lake Victoria has been beaten by bugs.
fields.body:
A multi-million pound World Bank scheme to combat giant weeds clogging Lake Victoria has been beaten by bugs.

The release of weevils into Africa's largest lake has reversed the spread of the water hyacinth, dubbed the 'Aids of the Water' in Uganda and Kenya because it destroyed fishing and wrecked local economies.

Despite this success, the World Bank is still funding giant mechanical harvesters to shred the weeds against the advice of experts.

Scientists and environmentalists say the dredgers are not only a waste of £5 million of World Bank money because of the weevils, but carry their own dangers. One group, Environmental Economics for Eastern and Southern Africa, said harvesters dump weed on the lake bed which could damage the eco-system.

The hyacinth Eichornia crassipes is believed to have been brought to Rwanda by Belgian colonists, and until months ago seemed unstoppable. Plants drifted across Lake Victoria and cut off villages from fishing grounds.

Farmers could not get crops to market. Uganda's hydro-electric dam was clogged and shut down.

Traffic stopped at the Kenyan lake port of Kisumu, stranding railway wagons destined for Tanzania. Many port workers lost jobs.

The first hundred weevils, reared by the Kenya Agricultural Research Insitute, were let loose three years ago. Since then 100,000 have been released.

'The reduction has been significant,' said Tom Moorhouse, head of Aquatics International in Uganda, an American firm monitoring the hyacinths as part of a US aid project. 'The weevils grazed on the leaf and laid eggs on the stem and the pupae bore into the stem.'

Uganda and Kenya brought in harvesters, but weevils have left five of the machines redundant.

The World Bank paid for two harvesters as part of its £50m World Bank project to clean up Lake Victoria,

The World Bank dispatched an Australian expert, Michael Julien, to assess the impact of the weevils last year. He said the bugs had made the machines almost obsolete.

Now, Kenyan fishermen whose livelihoods were nearly wrecked by the hyacinth are pleading to save it. They say it provided the perfect habitat for a type of catfish which had almost disappeared and for which there is a lucrative market.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText:
Letterman heart bypass American TV host David Letterman, 53, fresh from an interview with Hillary Clinton, is recovering in a New York hospital from a successful quintuple bypass heart operation.

Six of the best

Maria Grazia Berenate, 28, gave birth to four boys and two girls by Caesarean section in the Sicilian city Perugia, a conception aided by fertility treatments.

Letterman heart bypass American TV host David Letterman, 53, fresh from an interview with Hillary Clinton, is recovering in a New York hospital from a successful quintuple bypass heart operation.

Six of the best

Maria Grazia Berenate, 28, gave birth to four boys and two girls by Caesarean section in the Sicilian city Perugia, a conception aided by fertility treatments.

Doctors said all appeared healthy and likely to survive. Natural sextuplet births are extremely rare, though hormone-assisted fertility treatments made them comparatively more common.

Arrest request

India asked Pakistan to arrest and extradite five hijackers of an Indian Airlines plane who fled in Afghanistan after a hostage exchange last month.

Porn ban

Poland's senate passed a Bill banning all pornography as part of a new penal code, pending a vote by the lower house.

Congo massacre warning

Escalating massacres in remote eastern Congo could swell into a humanitarian catastrophe, a Christian aid group has warned.

Up to 5,000 people have been killed since the Lendu tribe erected roadblocks near the town of Bunia in June and attacked the Wahema tribe, said David McAllister, for Christian Blind Mission.

Thousands more have been wounded with machetes and driven from homes.

Papon back in jail

Convicted Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon, 89, returned to jail in Paris after surgery to implant a heart pacemaker.

Car ambush

Four Namibians were killed in a car ambush by the Angolan border, where three French children were killed on 3 January. Unita rebels were blamed.

Banker killed

The owner of London Broker, the troubled Hungarian brokerage suspended last year, was shot dead in a car in Budapest.

webTitle: Gates still in the hot seat?

fields.headline: Gates still in the hot seat?
fields.trailText: Every empire crumbles in the end, and every King or Queen knows that what they built contains the seed of its own destruction. But unless they are mad, like Nero or Lear, few would willingly accelerate the process. And Bill Gates is not mad. No way.
fields.body:
Every empire crumbles in the end, and every King or Queen knows that what they built contains the seed of its own destruction. But unless they are mad, like Nero or Lear, few would willingly accelerate the process. And Bill Gates is not mad. No way.

Just as the Internet is the first truly global colony, Gates rules the planet's first truly global empire - and an illegal monopoly to boot. Planet Microsoft, planet of the digital smile: 'Hi-howz-it-going?' An imperial capital where young millionaires work in jeans, sneakers and sweatshirts bearing the corporate logo. A Huxleyesque bubble in which the loyal drones can be treated, give birth and die at the Microsoft hospital and play football on the Microsoft soccer pitch.

But it's an empire based on the new science of thin air, on cyber-space, where nothing is tangible, nothing has mass or volume. The Newtonian dynamics of cause and effect do not apply. A manufacturing science in which the product costs nothing to make, but the thinking behind it can create incalculable zillions and - until a US court drew the line last November - apparently unlimited power.

And so there is a certain quantum logic to the mystery of why Gates - with the world's eyes fixed on the historic merger of AOL and Time Warner - chose suddenly to hand over his crown to his lieutenant, Steve Ballmer. But only a cyber-logic. It utterly fails to convince in the real world of market physics.

The announcement had that familiar Gatesish, childish minimalism. He reiterated his puerile mantra: 'Steve's promotion will allow me to dedicate myself full time to my passion - building soft ware and strategising for the future.' He just wants to be a geek again.

People started looking for an ulterior motive. There is, after all, that baby at home whom Gates apparently loves and who has occasionally, in the past, caused him to approximate human behaviour. Some said Gates was too close to burn-out. Others thought the adjudication by the Federal court that he ruled an illegal monopoly hit a raw nerve. 'He has made it to the apex of the apex,' one employee told The Observer last Friday, 'and to have to spend time and effort doing anything other than climbing was something he had forgotten how to do.'

There is one tempting rumour - that Gates has it in mind to set up a subsidiary which has its eyes on a takeover of Disney, thereby metamorphosising it into a multi-multimedia behemoth - Mickey Microsoft. Now that would be something.

There are a few realities that Gates was asked to grasp in the light of the court decision. That the empire could not go on for ever. That a combination of economics and laws governing the digital industry would intervene.

In conversations with The Observer, Microsoft employees and Microsoft rivals paint a picture that is more subtle - which can weave a middle course between the court's ruling, Washington's intentions and the status quo. And preserve an omnipotent, almighty Microsoft.

Whatever the truth or otherwise of the Disney rumour, the notion that it makes sense from Microsoft's point of view to break up the company is not without temptation. A sort of model is there in the fate of the last victim of anti-trust legislation, US phone giant AT&T.

Once AT&T had reorganised itself, it became a self-procreating creature, spawning 'Baby Bell' subsidiaries which it could sell off and then attach itself to as a lucrative long-distance carrier.

Sources at sworn rival IBM and from within Microsoft say that a strategy of voluntarily fragmenting the empire for its own sake has been hotly debated. Lawyers and corporate strategists have gone into conclave to try to find a formula.

But the premise was never allowed to be other than that this would in fact be a way of rebuilding the empire and re-capturing what market share - if any - was lost to challengers such as IBM or Steve Case at AOL.

But Gates and Bullmer - according to sources outside and inside the company - knocked back any idea of a voluntary break-up, 'and did so pretty ruthlessly', says one lawyer. Indeed, a sense of urgency has been injected into the air. 'Don't let the legal problems dull your edge,' said an employee.

But how does all this explain Gates's resignation? One thing is for sure, as made clear in an internal memo: 'If some of you are wondering if today's announcement means I'll spend less time at Microsoft - that couldn't be further from the truth.'

webTitle: Teen rapist with the cruel mind of a child

fields.headline: Teen rapist with the cruel mind of a child
fields.trailText: As they marked off the days on the calendar leading to 13 January 2000, anxiety grew at police headquarters in Lille, where detectives kept a 24-hour telephone listening watch on friends of the suspected three-time killer, Sid Ahmed Rezala.
fields.body:
As they marked off the days on the calendar leading to 13 January 2000, anxiety grew at police headquarters in Lille, where detectives kept a 24-hour telephone listening watch on friends of the suspected three-time killer, Sid Ahmed Rezala.

Two of the murders linked to his name, including that of British student Isabel Peake, were committed on the thirteenth day of the month and his birthday was 13 May 1979. Profilers had told police to expect another murder for 13 January.

Within 48 hours of the fateful date, the breakthrough came when Rezala briefly phoned the mother of his young daughter in the northern city of Amiens, using a false name, but giving a Portuguese number.

Unaware that the public telephone in a run-down Lisbon suburb had been traced, Rezala, 20, walked up to the phonebox at the corner of the Avenue of Freedom at midday on 12 January and was flung against a wall and handcuffed by plainclothes Portuguese police. 'I am Hassan,' he screamed in protest until he recognised two detectives from his home city of Marseilles. 'But they know who I really am,' he mumbled before bursting into tears.

His identity may have been clear, but after a few hours of questioning police were less sure they knew the true character of a good-looking young man who allegedly flung a British girl out of a train at 90mph, killed a mother with 14 knife wounds in a night sleeper and strangled a French student, hiding her naked body under the coal in a cellar.

Orlando Romano, assistant head of the Lisbon CID, said that if the French police had not been there the Portuguese might not have recognised Rezala, whose hair had been cut so short he barely resembled the photo-fit posted in railway stations throughout Europe. What might have thrown police fur ther off the track was that Rezala, feared for his alleged sexual attacks on women, had been protected on the run by a homosexual network that fed, lodged and slept with him.

A rich Spanish businessman, Armando Sánchez, is being questioned about his friendship with Rezala (love at first sight, according to one detective) which began soon after Rezala slipped across the border on 15 December. When police raided Rezala's hideout, his bag was packed and he was carrying a train ticket to Madrid, from where he was due to fly to the Canary Islands with his lover.

Rezala's homosexual past, which included the rape of a 13-year-old boy in Marseilles railway station, is part of one of the most complex criminal person alities to be linked with serial murders in recent years. The man known as the 'night train killer' had so many sides to his character his motives might remain obscure for ever. For the moment, police believe that hatred, after he was ditched by the mother of his daughter in October, triggered off lust for revenge on women in general.

His violent side lived unsuspected under a seductive, smiling presence. He charmed other people, including probation officers and policemen, in a life of crime that started almost as soon as he arrived from his native Algeria at the age of 15 with his parents, three brothers and a sister.

Within weeks of registering at a Marseilles high school, Rezala began playing truant and mixing with petty criminals and drug dealers around the Gare Saint-Charles. His parents asked for him to be sent to a special school, but by autumn he was associating with boy prostitutes. During 18 months in prison for rape he cut his wrists and wrecked his cell in fits of rage. Psychiatrists became alarmed, welfare officer Sylvie Vázquez revealed after the Lisbon arrest. 'He suffered a lot,' she said, and said Rezala 'had kept the violence and cruelty of a child'.

Rezala's interminable journeys by train began in 1997 after another arrest, for stabbing. Ticket inspectors, who fined him 42 times for refusing to pay his fare, became familiar with the introverted traveller in a baseball cap with a supply of cannabis in his backpack and a preference for half-empty, long-distance night trains.

He visited relatives all over France before stopping for a time in Amiens, where he met a young woman called Nadia, who gave birth to his daughter, Sarah Yasmina. But before she was born, Rezala had been arrested again, for robbery with a knife at Marseilles station, and was in jail until June 1999. When he returned to Amiens, Nadia was living with another man. After a brief reconciliation during which neighbours said he looked after his daughter 'like a real father', Nadia suddenly quit him for good.

'That was in October 1999, the month Isabel Peake was murdered,' a Lille detective recalled. 'The break-up with Nadia and the violence that followed are probably not coincidences.'

If that is proved, two other women, Emilie Bazin and Corinne Caillaux, also paid a fatal price for his rejection. And if Rezala had not been so attached to Nadia, he would never have gone to a Lisbon phonebox on the eve of 13 January and stepped into the arms of detectives.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Woman in trunk arrest
fields.body:
Woman in trunk arrest

A man has been arrested by detectives investigating the murder of a woman whose body was found in a luggage trunk by the side of the A343, north of Andover, on Wednesday.

Fire disrupts Virgin trains

Virgin train services on the West Coast line were suspended after a fire, thought to have started in cabling in a bridge near Harlesden, north London.

Killer has 'emotion problems'

Kevan Roberts, 52, sentenced to life last month for murdering Norfolk schoolboy Thomas Marshall, was being treated in Norwich prison hospital for 'emotional problems'.

Virtually sacreligious

A stone mason from Worcestershire has been criticised by church leaders for creating a 'virtual cemetery' on the Internet.

Lunar eclipse this week

Astronomers hope for no clouds on Friday as the first full lunar eclipse this century sees Earth aligned with Sun and Moon.

Stuart Bell MP

On 21 November 1999, in 'Church Commissioners drawn into GM crop dispute', we said that Stuart Bell, MP, the Second Church Estates Commissioner, was a paid consultant for Bell Pottinger, whose client list includes Monsanto. We did not intend to suggest that there was a conflict of interest on the part of Mr Bell.

We also said that Monsanto paid for an overseas visit to France. This was wrong. Mr Bell has never accepted free travel to France or anywhere else for Monsanto or any other company involved in the GM industry. We apologise to Mr Bell for any embarrassment caused.

webTitle: Freeze-fry clue to life on Earth

fields.headline: Freeze-fry clue to life on Earth
fields.standfirst: New scientific discoveries show the evolution of the world has been shaped by extreme climate changes
fields.trailText: Our planet has been plunged through a recent cycle of icy climatic catastrophes, scientists have discovered. On each occasion the world was turned into a cosmic snowball coated in ice sheets half a mile thick. The last Ice Age would have looked like a mild winter in Bournemouth.
fields.body:
Our planet has been plunged through a recent cycle of icy climatic catastrophes, scientists have discovered. On each occasion the world was turned into a cosmic snowball coated in ice sheets half a mile thick. The last Ice Age would have looked like a mild winter in Bournemouth.

The finales of these massive, icy disruptions were also dramatic, for each was followed by an abrupt climatic reversal that triggered a period of brutal greenhouse warming. The effect of this rapid jump from freezing to boiling extremes was profound, for the whole course of evolution was changed, say Harvard University scientists Paul Hoffman and Daniel Schrag in the current issue of Scientific American.

'As improbable as it may sound, we see clear evidence that striking climatic reversal - the most extreme imaginable on this planet - happened as many as four times between 750 million and 580 million years ago,' say Hoffman and Schrag. 'These extreme glaciations occurred just before a rapid diversification of multicellular life, culminating in the so-called Cambrian explosion between 575 and 525 million years ago.'

It was during this period that simple one-celled organisms - bacteria-like entities that were Earth's only lifeforms - evolved into the first complex creatures, a develop ment that was to pave the way for the appearance of animal life today.

'Ironically, the long periods of isolation and extreme environments on a snowball Earth would most likely have spurred on genetic change and could help account for this evolutionary burst,' state Hoffman, a geologist, and Schrag, an oceanographer.

The pair say the development of their snowball Earth theory was ignited by studies - along the Skeleton Coast of Namibia - which revealed the presence of 600-million-year-old geological remains of glaciers that had mysteriously melted. At this time, the land that formed the continents was entirely straddled along the Equator, yet it showed signs of being covered in glaciers for much of this time.

The idea that the tropics had frozen over seemed impossible until climate simulations were carried out by Mikhail Bukyko of the Leningrad Geophysical Observatory. These showed that when ice sheets stretch far enough down from the poles they start to reflect dangerous amounts of sunlight back into space. 'The more radiation the planet reflects, the cooler the temperature,' say Hoffman and Schrag.

In other words, Earth suffered a runaway freeze in which a severe Ice Age triggered a far more awesome event, an entire planetary glaciation. 'Imagine the Earth hurtling through space like a cosmic snowball for 10 mil lion years or more,' the pair say. fields.headline: Gay riddle of Isabel's killer
fields.standfirst: Forensic teams bungle dummy runs
fields.trailText: The bungled French police investigation into the death of British student Isabel Peake and two other women became a grotesque charade yesterday, involving a stuntman, an investigating magistrate, 80 policemen, a dummy and a speeding train.
fields.byline: by Anna McQueen in Chabenet and Paul Webster in Paris
fields.body:
The bungled French police investigation into the death of British student Isabel Peake and two other women became a grotesque charade yesterday, involving a stuntman, an investigating magistrate, 80 policemen, a dummy and a speeding train.

For the quiet village of Chabenet, set in the flat countryside of central France, the reconstruction of her death should have been the most gripping event since Michael Jackson tried to buy the the local chateau.

But at 9.06am, when sirens announced the impending arrival of the test train, few locals were up. Later, a few families arrived with children and dogs. Afterwards the local bar, taken by surprise, struggled to cope with the demands of the international press for drinks and phones.

As the reconstruction began of a crime - one in a series of train killings that has thrown the French criminal justice system into disarray - a hush fell on the waiting crowd.

The noise of the approaching express became deafening. As it thundered into view in a gloomy cutting, a life-sized dummy, dressed in a white top, black trousers and trainers - similar to those worn by Peake on the day of her death in October - appeared at a window cradled in the arms of an obscure figure on board.

The dummy was forced from the window. It bounced head first off the track and flicked up, hitting the side of the train. It was decapitated, smashed against a post and scattered in pieces in the dirt just yards from where Peake's corpse was found.

White powder dusted on the side of the track enabled investigating police to analyse how the body fell. The position of the mutilated dummy was carefully recorded on film before it was gathered up for analysis.

Detectives from Peake's home county of Staffordshire, Peter Sharratt-Freeman and Diane Marne, joined investigating magistrates and gendarmes on the express to witness the reconstruction.

The operation was coordinated by Remy Julienne, a stunt adviser engaged by the French Transport Ministry to assist police with the reconstruction, repeated four times during the day.

Julienne, 69, has worked on almost 50 films including James Bond features For Your Eyes Only, Octopussy, The Living Daylights, Licence To Kill and Goldeneye . He also co-ordinated car stunt scenes in the 1969 classic The Italian Job .

Early shortcomings in the investigation into Peake's death could lead to an unsuccessful prosecution of chief murder suspect Sid Ahmed Rezala, 20, detained in Portugal last week. His extradition to France could take three months. In France itself, magistrates and police are competing to be the first to interview him about the three crimes of which he is suspected in what the Paris newspaper Libération last week called a judicial 'free-for-all'.

It took police nine days to open the Peake inquiry during which time the Brive-Paris train was left in service and cleaned at least twice, destroying any potential forensic evidence.

If, during the course of their investigation, French police prove that Peake could have fallen from the train without assistance, they would be spared the embarrassment of a murder prosecution against Rezala proving unsuccessful through lack of evidence.

But Jean-Paul Thibault, lawyer for the Peake family, expressed his confidence in the investigations. 'I am satisfied Rezala has been arrested but it remains for his guilt to be proved in this atrocious crime.'

The extradition from Portugal of Rezala was originally expected to take only 48 hours. But his lawyers are taking advantage of Portuguese laws which forbid the extradition of suspects who risk a higher sentence than the maximum 25 years in jail in Portugal. Rezala faces a life sentence - the limit to be set by a judge - in France if he is found guilty of killing Peake, Corinne Caillaux, 36, and Emilie Bazin, 20.

Rezala's defence is being paid for by a Spanish businessman whom he met in Madrid's gay quarter while on the run from French police in December.

The two men were said to have had a 'passionate relationship'. Rezala was due to leave with his Spanish lover for the Canaries only hours before he was arrested in a Lisbon suburb.

Unless a special dispensation is granted by the Portuguese authorities under the Schengen agreement, which covers emergency extradition procedures in the EU, Rezala will have to be released from custody during the run up to a court hearing.

So far, French detectives in Lisbon have not been allowed to question him about Peake or the deaths of Caillaux, murdered in the Calais-Riviera night train on December 13, and Bazin, who disappeared in Amiens in October after a meeting with Rezala.

From the start, the hunt for Rezala was one of the most bungled investigations in French police history and may lead to a complete overhaul of the judicial system.

Poor collaboration between police forces and local examining magistrates was evident from the day Peake's body was found on 13 October.

Despite her parents' concern, a murder investigation was not started for 10 days.

A communications breakdown between police and the state railways meant that the link between a known rapist and a man answering his description who had been caught travelling without a ticket to Limoges went unnoticed.

By the time Emilie Bazin's body was discovered on 17 December, five examining magistrates, the national police, the gendarmerie and the police judiciaire (CID) were working on separate inquiries.

webTitle: Scientists' claims that rape is about sex not violence outrages feminists

fields.headline: Scientists' claims that rape is about sex not violence outrages feminists
fields.trailText: A bitter dispute between feminists, social scientists and evolutionary biologists has been started by two US academics who say the belief that rape is a violent, rather than a sexual, crime is 'erroneous, even mythological'.
fields.byline: by Robin McKie and Tracy McVeigh
fields.body:
A bitter dispute between feminists, social scientists and evolutionary biologists has been started by two US academics who say the belief that rape is a violent, rather than a sexual, crime is 'erroneous, even mythological'.

The two scientists claim that rape conferred an evolutionary advantage on its perpetrators, a notion that has outraged many groups.

Evolutionary biologists Professor Randy Thornhill, of New Mexico University, and Craig Palmer, of Colorado University, have also provoked fury by suggesting that young women be advised that 'the way they dress can put them at risk' while young men should receive instruction so they do not 'mistake a woman's friendly comment, or tight blouse, as an invitation to sex'.

These claims are outlined in Thornhill and Palmer's book, A Natural History of Rape: Biological Bases of Sexual Coercion (to be published in April by MIT Press), extracts of which have recently been published in the journal The Sciences. Social scientists and feminist scholars - who believe rape is a crime of violence, not sex - have reacted with fury.

Rape expert Mary Koss, of Arizona University, dismissed the notion that young men should be educated about the evolutionary origins of rape. Thornhill and Palmer, she said, 'have obviously never stood up before a group and given a rape prevention talk'. She called their advice about dressing attractively ' unacceptable'.

Reports about the book have also infuriated British feminists.

'These are outrageous assertions,' said Sandra Horley, of Refuge, the United Kingdom charity which helps the victims of domestic violence. 'Rape is about power and control, not about sex. Rape is violence, and nothing to do with sex. And if it is about evolution, then what does what women wear have to do with anything?'

But anthropologist Donald Symons, of the University of California at Santa Barbara, backed the two scientists. 'This is an argument for a particular view of male sexuality and it's a view I think is correct.' Thornhill and Palmer say rape - although inexcusable - must be viewed as a 'natural biological phenomenon'. They say young women at the peak of their childbearing years are over-represented among rape victims - suggesting that reproduction is the prime motivation. But Koss added that a surprisingly large number of rape victims are children.

Thornhill and Palmer's use of violent sexual acts committed by other species to buttress their arguments has also caused anger.

'We can't ask a female fish whether she appears to resist because she doesn't want to copulate or because she is testing males for their fitness,' Dr Jerry Coyne, of Chicago University, said.

fields.headline: Downing Street's lapdogs?
fields.standfirst: Political editors were last week accused of being Labour puppets. But partisan does not mean biased, argues  Julia Langdon, who has written for newspapers on both the left and right
fields.trailText: Political editors were last week accused of being Labour puppets. But partisan does not mean biased, argues  Julia Langdon, who has written for newspapers on both the left and right
fields.body:
'I have to tell you,' a Cabinet Minister confided over lunch last week, 'that I despise them. I have no respect for them. I think they are a disgrace.' The subject that produced this comment was political journalists and it was really quite a curious thing to say to me - not least because I am one. I took it as an inverted compliment, assuming I was excluded from the collective disgrace; besides, I wasn't buying.

The reason for this anecdote is an extraordinary piece of journalism in the current issue of The Spectator magazine. It purports to expose 'why New Labour scandals go unreported' and names those of my newspaper colleagues working at Westminster on whom Downing Street is alleged to be able to rely. The thesis put forward by Peter Oborne of The Express is posited on the supposition that the present Government has the press in its pocket.

I feel justified in engaging in this debate because I am a partisan journalist. But I also believe that it is possible to be a member of a political party and an objective journalist. I have been political editor of both the Daily Mirror and the Sunday Telegraph and I have also in my time chaired the parliamentary lobby. I have been a member of the Labour Party for 30 years and relish the fact that I am regarded with the utmost suspicion by the Downing Street thought police - and yet Ministers still trust me.

It makes me feel I must be doing something right. It is also not a new experience. Shortly after I started work at the Sunday Telegraph I was informed by my proprietor, Conrad Black, that he received two complaints about my appointment. One was from Lord McAlpine, the former Tory Treasurer and a close friend who I knew would, most likely, have said something about me being a leftie. So it proved. The other, more significantly, was Margaret Thatcher's then foreign affairs adviser, Charles Powell - although when I bearded him, it turned out to have been his wife, Carla, who spoke to Conrad Black on the steps of the Brompton Oratory after morning service. That is the way in which influence is wielded in the British Establishment. As it happens, I have since become friends with Carla, too.

The point I seek to make is that the Tory Establishment, during those years of Tory government, was careful to maintain its important friends in the press and was wary of those who were not of the Conservative faith. 'It's not that we don't lurrve you for yourself,' drawled Alan Clark with his ability to mix flattery with a political point, 'It's just that you're not one of us.' I didn't mind that; it didn't prevent me from doing my job.

Oborne's article is a swingeing attack upon the current practice of political journalism, but it begs questions. For example, does not partisan journalism (as distinct from propaganda as practised by Alastair Campbell) have a place? I would have thought so. Haven't the Conservatives, including Oborne, been busy at this for years? Isn't the point that reporting should be fair? Why, for example, did the late Lord Whitelaw pick Ian Aitken (another leftie) as his biographer ? It was because, as he once said, Aitken was a political opponent - but a fair man.

And there are other puzzling suppositions within Oborne's polemic. Are scandals really going unreported under this Government? It doesn't seem like it. Scandals have been breaking thick and fast. Indeed one of the criticisms I would make of the younger generation of journalists today is that they are more interested in scandal than in anything else - certainly more than in politics itself, in political issues or in policy. That may be the real reason why much political reporting is so poor, as bewailed by my Cabinet friend. Far from being under-reported, the most minor indiscretions are happily inflated into 'scandals'. If there are really journalists working at Westminster who are sitting on scandals in the hope of keeping on the right side of Alastair Campbell, or in the expectation of being rewarded with the next prime ministerial interview, I would be truly astonished. Scandalmongering is well paid too.

Another suggestion from Oborne is that had it been a Conservative Chancellor, Norman Lamont, rather than Gordon Brown, who bought a flat from the receivers of the Maxwell empire, he would have been flayed alive. Putting aside the fact that Brown has had his own problems with the press in the course of this Government's tenure, it was precisely the question of the purchase of a flat under unusual circumstances which did lead to the resignation of a Cabinet Minister, just over a year ago.

And, come to that, when he was Chancellor, Lamont was flayed alive anyway. And while we are on the subject - and having worked for Robert Maxwell for five years without perjuring myself - I don't recall the Tory newspapers lambasting two former Tory Cabinet Ministers, the late Geoffrey Rippon and the late Michael Havers, who took the Maxwell shilling after they left government. Maxwell revelled in it, incidentally. He used them for their names. They were his 'useful idiots'.

Oborne also suggests that Peter Mandelson's return to office 'simply would not have been possible had he been a Tory Minister', implying that the press would have prevented his rehabilitation. But that is nonsense. The resurrection of Mandelson was strongly criticised in many newspapers and it is the political judgment to reinstate him which is in question here. It is worth pointing out that several previously disgraced Tory Ministers did later return to office as well.

His most bitter criticism, however, is reserved for a number of individual journalists - including the political editor of this newspaper, Patrick Wintour, soon to join The Guardian's political team: 'now Downing Street has its man in The Guardian' is how Oborne describes it. I scarcely know Wintour and I have not been asked to defend him here; nor is that the purpose of this piece. But it is ludicrous to criticise a political journalist for having good contacts within the Government - if that is his crime. Surely that is part of the object of the journalistic exercise. I boasted above of my own exclusion from the favours of Alastair Campbell, but I do not have a staff job to defend. If I did, I would need some sort of relationship with the machine, however much I disliked its methods.

And that is the real criticism that should be aimed at the management of the media as practised by this Government. What I find really astonishing is that Downing Street's desire to control the press and public opinion is so overriding, and political principle is regarded so little, that those who run the show are prepared to smile upon those Tory newspapers which piled one calumny upon another to keep the Labour Party out of government for a generation. That is a scandal.

Peter Oborne on...

Mirror political editor Peter MacMahon:
'[His] arrival has coincided with a series of glowing profiles of or first person pieces from senior Labour figures. So prostrate is the Mirror's coverage that Downing Street sources claim even Mirror campaigns...are carefully cleared with Campbell first.'

His Express colleague, political editor Tony Bevins:
'Bevins's friendship with the Prime Minister's press secretary [Alastair Campbell] has not prevented him from running a series of damaging stories about Gordon Brown's ally Geoffrey Robinson.'

The Times:
'[Its] political team has been ethnically cleansed of Tories and is perceived in the lobby as a subsidiary branch of the Downing Street press office.'

The Evening Standard and the Daily Mail:
'New Labour to the core. Only the Daily Mail, perhaps open to the charge of being dogmatically anti-government, is there no New Labour presence.'

I boasted above of my own exclusion from the favours of Alastair Campbell, but I do not have a staff job to defend. If I did, I would need some sort of relationship with the machine, however much I disliked its methods. So prostrate is the Mirror's coverage that Downing Street sources claim even Mirror campaigns...are carefully cleared with Campbell first.' His Express colleague, political editor Tony Bevins: 'Bevins's friendship with the Prime Minister's press secretary [Alastair Campbell] has not prevented him from running a series of damaging stories about Gordon Brown's ally Geoffrey Robinson.' The Times: '[Its] political team has been ethnically cleansed of Tories and is perceived in the lobby as a subsidiary branch of the Downing Street press office.' The Evening Standard and the Daily Mail: 'New Labour to the core. Only the Daily Mail, perhaps open to the charge of being dogmatically anti-government, is there no New Labour presence.'

fields.headline: Making up for lost time
fields.standfirst: His work is elitist and meditative, but a new film has brought Marcel Proust fresh fame.   Andrew Marr revisits the great French author's home to celebrate his comeback
fields.trailText: His work is elitist and meditative, but a new film has brought Marcel Proust fresh fame. Andrew Marr revisits the great French author's home to celebrate his comeback
fields.body:
Marcel Proust, one of France's greatest writers, had a sharp - some would say nasty - sense of humour. What he would have made of the news that his novel, a massive and elaborate meditation set among the French aristocracy from the 1870s to the 1920s, was enjoying a revival in 2000, is hard to imagine. Proud, no doubt - but he would also, surely, have found it very, very funny.

What has a highly strung, gay, culturally elitist Frenchman, whose mental world was fed by a rigid caste system he described as Hindu, a life of seaside holidays in grand hotels, glittering and interminable dinners, Parisian balls and provincial gossip, got to say to the world of the Internet and of Euro-federalism?

Quite a lot, it seems. The growth in book sales since the release of a new French film of the final part of A la recherche du temps perdu (or Remembrance of Things Past as it is generally known in English) has been modest - hundreds, not thousands, of extra copies - but enough to surprise booksellers in the UK. In France, the film has been a hit and Proust is enjoying a major revival.

Certainly Raúl Ruiz's film of Time Regained is the best of several stabs at translating Proust's allusive and reflective tale for the cinema. But this is not saying much. Filming Proust is a little like painting a late Beethoven quartet, or trying to make Westminster Cathedral into a ballet: heroic, but also silly. Proust, poor man, worked in the days before the book, the film, the novelisation of the film of the book, the CD of the soundtrack and the Playstation game were all released together. He thought words - some 1.3 million of them - were enough.

Yet the film was rapturously received in France, where Proust has seemed to be less revered than he is among British intellectuals. There, they have tended to regard him as a brilliant social humorist, rather than as the philosophical and aesthetic guru hailed by Bloomsbury and later generations of thick-tweeded and flannel-shirted Proustiens anglais. Perhaps, belatedly, the profound, pessimistic patriotism of Proust and his placing of a little agricultural town near Chartres as the emblem of old France, la France profonde, has struck a chord.

Illers was where Proust spent childhood holidays, and which he used to create his famous 'Combray'. It is not a pretentious place, still a hard-working farmers' town in the middle of a vast and featureless plain, with small factories clustered around it. The bars are rough, thick with smoke and guttural voices, the people amused by the fuss. Once, Illiers was a stopping-place for Catholic pilgrims - hence the scallop-shaped madeleine cakes that so famously began Proust's search for lost time. Now it is a shrine to Proust and the pilgrims still come, somewhat to the locals' bemusement.

'The film? No, I have not seen it, and I have not read the book either. But if the English want to come here and spend their money, that's fine by me,' said a laughing stallholder at the Friday market. The tourist officer hadn't seen the film either, but she was selling a formidable array of Proust-related souvenirs, biographies and even the new comic-strip book of his first volume, which she recommended vigorously.

Illiers is like France in having an ambiguous relationship with Proust. Some of the most sacred places to Proust-addicts have vanished from the town. The road he loved most, the Rue de L'Oiseau Flesche, named after an ancient inn where medieval archers met to shoot birds tied to poles, has been renamed and the inn has vanished. After a lot of tramping up and down, I decided the inn was probably what is now a garage. The old church with its famous spire still looks the same, though its ancient stained glass, which he loved, has gone, bombed in 1940.

But the house where he stayed, his Aunt Léonie's, is still there, a Proust museum, with the garden bell that Swann rang when he came to visit in the 1880s, and you can still walk along the little River Loir - Proust's Vivonne - which is an unearthly bright blue-green colour, just as he described it. The town still looks, from the fields by the river, very like the medieval cluster he knew, with 'the woolly grey backs of its huddled houses'. On a raw January afternoon it smells, satisfyingly, of cabbages and wet mud and the river.

And above all, whatever its inhabitants think of their local hero, they know a good thing when they see it, going so far as to rename the place Illiers-Combray to attract visitors - rather as if Lichfield had decided to call itself Middlemarch, or Scotland's major city decided to lure Alasdair Gray readers by calling itself Glasgow-Unthank.

But it is a tricky business, coaxing a living from such a lively, unpredictable book. One of the most resonant names in the Combray volume is 'Montjouvain', a country house based on a real one, about 20 minutes' walk from the town, called Mirougrain. There, as one hoped, stands the extraordinary rocky house, above a little blue-green lake. When I arrived, a caretaker, with a shotgun and a very large black dog, was contemplating trees that had been ripped up by the recent storm. What did he think of the new interest in Proust? He looked at me stolidly, then turned and very deliberately spat. His dog snarled. Mirougrain says 'non'.

And yet, up the road, the civic camping ground has been named 'Montjouvain', presumably in homage. Did the authorities, trying to get the right atmosphere for holidaymakers, know that Mont-jouvain is famous because that was where the young narrator spies on two sadistic lesbians? Probably not. He remains, everywhere, more talked about than actually read, no doubt because of the daunting size of his great work. But could it be that, in France and Britain, because of our 30-second-soundbite culture and our slim, slight novels, the prospect of something completely different is beginning to appeal? Because it isn't only the film. In the New Year round-up of millennial 'greatest writer ever' lists, Proust was chosen with surprising regularity.

In recent years, there have been Proust cook-books, that French comic-strip version, three films and two revised translations, pruning back the more purple prose and the many inaccuracies in Scott Moncrieff's version. Alain de Botton produced a short volume, posing as a kind of impossibly intellectual self-help book called How Proust Can Change Your Life. The collected letters are being published - the last volume will be reviewed this month in The Observer. Penguin is bringing out a new biography, by Jean-Yves Tadie, professor of French literature at the Sorbonne, in the spring.

And, above all, a complete new translation, with seven separate translators, one for each volume, is being prepared, also by Penguin, and will be published next year. It will be a shock to traditionalist British Proustians, offer ing a harder, more authentic version. The traditional English title will be replaced by the more accurate In Search of Lost Time. The series editor, Christopher Prendergast, now teaching in Copenhagen, says it will be 'a bloody good read' and an antidote to the 'recipe-book Proust' of de Botton and others.

One of the translators, John Sturrock of the London Review of Books , argues that Scott Moncrieff's Edwardian prose 'is exactly what Proust himself abandoned with some shame when he was quite young ... this is a very cruel book. It is a comic book, but the comedy is not always very funny.'

If this radical brushing-down of Proust brings new readers, it can only be a good thing. For, to declare my hand, In Search of Lost Time is one of the two or three greatest novels of all time, anywhere. Tolstoy is perhaps the only obvious rival. Hence the passion.

The idea of a literary 'pilgrimage' to Illiers - a place the novelist has recast and reshaped - is inherently absurd. 'Illiers-Combray' reminded me of lots of other small agricultural towns. Yet it is quite a power to draw people from all over to one little place, merely because, more than a century ago, a very clever small boy walked here, happened to sit in these pews, to walk past that butcher's shop, or listen to those church bells. Proust inspires a cult-like enthusiasm, a fervent adulation among his readers which can border on the embarrassing. His new translators' argument with the old school is essentially that he's a story-teller, not a religion.

Yet there are good reasons for the emotion he inspires. Reading Proust can be almost hallucinatory, sharpening the reader's sense of smell, colour and character for some time afterwards. And, for all the elaborate prose and setting, there is a simple and universal message from the book - the agonising realisation that time really does pass, and all our lives are lost, and can be regained in art but nowhere else. Behind the obscure duchesses and gossipy writers, this is the story of the modern, irreligious Everyman.

In the end, the best answer to the question, 'why should I read Proust?' sounds almost offensive - because Proust had a better brain than the rest of us. But readers who doubt this have only one solution - to go out and lift A la recherche du temps perdu from number 544 to a little higher in the fiction bestseller list.

fields.headline: The right scheme
fields.trailText: A look at all the options
fields.body:
What about an ISA ?

If you save through an Isa, there will be no tax to pay on the interest you earn or, if you invest in a stock market-based scheme, on dividends and any capital growth.

You can invest up to £7,000 in an Isa before 5 April this year. Next year the limit drops to £5,000.

You can have three mini Isas, putting £3,000 in cash deposits, £1,000 in an insurance-linked savings scheme and £3,000 in shares. Alternatively, you can buy one maxi Isa where you can invest the whole £7,000 in shares. You cannot have a maxi and mini Isa in one year. A mini cash Isa would be suitable for someone trying to build up emergency cash savings.

You can withdraw money and then reinvest, and still have your interest paid tax-free as long as total deposits in the year do not exceed the £3,000. If you are moving a rung up the savings ladder you can choose a stocks and shares Isa.

I already have a pension. Do I need to save as well?

Yes. Although a pension is an essential part of saving for the very long term - retirement - you cannot gain access to your money before you stop work.

You need other savings for emergencies and also to give you flexibility. Increasingly, because of the low returns on annuities - which you must buy when you cash in a personal pension or 'money purchase' employers' scheme - financial advisers think it is worth diversifying into other stock market-based investments.

You won't necessarily get a better return from your money, but you won't be compelled to buy an annuity with it.

I often get mailshots from insurance companies about savings schemes. Are these a good bet?

Usually these are endowment-style schemes. The ultimate destination for your money will be the stock market, or a stock market-linked investment such as a with-profits fund, and you will also receive a small amount of life insurance with the contract.

These schemes may provide discipline, but the disadvantages are that you will usually not be able to break the contract without suffering early surrender penalties and in the early years you are unlikely to get back as much as you put in. If you choose a unit trust or investment trust savings scheme, you can stop and start your contributions whenever you like with no penalty. The insurance companies promote the policies' tax-free status, but you need to invest for 10 years regularly to receive the proceeds tax-free.

If you invest in a unit trust or investment trust scheme through an Isa, you will have no tax to pay on dividends or profits. Most small investors can invest for years in the stock market without running into a capital gains tax bill anyway because the annual capital gains tax exemption - £7,100 this year - allows for substantial profit before tax becomes an issue.

It is also worth noting that the returns on with-profits endowment savings schemes are falling because bonuses on the policies are being cut by many insurers. Despite their disadvantages, however, Alan Dickinson at Massow Financial Services says these schemes can be suitable for people who find it extremely difficult to discipline themselves. 'Some say that if the money is in an Isa they can get at it.'

Dickinson prefers to see people saving elsewhere, and cautions that these schemes are not suitable for savings that may be needed within a 10-year period - for the deposit for a home, for example - but for some they may be the only way to build up a capital sum.

What's the difference between saving and investment?

The Penguin English Dictionary defines saving as 'money accumulated by economising' while investment is defined as 'laying out money for a return'.

In the investment business, saving tends to be used to describe money held in bank or building society accounts; cash deposits where there is no risk to capital.

Investments are generally deemed to be savings that carry a greater risk, in return for a higher return in the long term.

But many of the companies that run stock market funds also offer savings schemes, particularly the investment trust companies. For the novice, the important point to grasp is the difference between money put into a cash deposit account and that saved in a higher-risk scheme. Don't take it for granted that the description 'savings scheme' means no risk.

What about schemes such as Virgin One that seem to offer the best of all worlds, saving and borrowing?

These are billed as the new way to manage your money and are likely to become more popular. Such schemes are already well established in Australia and New Zealand.

They work on the basis that it does not make sense to keep money languishing in a deposit account, where it would earn 5 or 6 per cent, when spare cash from your monthly budget could be used to reduce the mortgage, where interest may be charged at 6 or 7 per cent.

All finances, including your current account, are operated from the same pot and each time a credit comes in it instantly goes towards the mortgage. You pay bills from the account but any monthly surplus reduces your mortgage debt, beyond the minimum needed to repay it.

If you need to borrow for a new car, for example, you simply draw on the equity in your home.

The theory is sound but you need to be disciplined to make it work. If you don't keep a close eye on the account you will not pay off enough of the home loan to make it worthwhile.

Another option is a flexible mortgage, repaying more than you need to in order to get the total interest bill down and saving elsewhere.

webTitle: Why was my insurance at a premium?

fields.headline: Why was my insurance at a premium?
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
For many years I thought my Halifax home insurance premiums, some £700, were excessive, but have been unsuccessful in reducing the cost despite annual attempts at negotiating a discount. I was discouraged from seeking insurance elsewhere as I had claimed for extensive underpinning work following subsidence damage. However, this year, being required to deal with Halifax Insurance Service direct rather than my own branch, I was offered insurance at under £300 - less than half the premium the Halifax quoted in its renewal notice. I questioned the difference but the reasons seem somewhat obscure.

WH, Ashford

Banks and building societies used to push their borrowers into house and contents insurance policies for which they earned millions of pounds in commission from insurance companies. Last August, the Halifax stopped selling new customers combined policies like yours and substituted its own separate house and contents policies which are cheaper.

It is ingenuous for Halifax to say that your premiums have gone down because you can now fine-tune your requirements to avoid paying for unwanted insurance. Competition has forced prices down.

But Halifax does admit it was wrong to say you were stuck because of your subsidence claim; you could have moved to a different insurer at any time without penalty. For this, and because you are a long-standing customer, it has agreed to pay the whole of this year's premium, around £300, for you as a gesture of goodwill.

Auction bill: I was hammered

Is there a watchdog body to which I could appeal concerning a complaint against an auctioneer? In this case Spinks deducted a staggering 42 per cent of the hammer price from a lot I recently sold in one of its sales. I have written to Spinks but had no reply.

PC, London

There is no ombudsman scheme but several trade associations for dealers, auctioneers and valuers. You can ask them to help in a dispute but only if the auctioneer is a member.

One, of which Spinks is not a member, is the Society of Fine Art Auctioneers. The chairman, Robin Barlow, says he acts as a mediator in complaints and will answer general enquiries. The telephone number is 01392 204470.

webTitle: Small changes that can yield big savings

fields.headline: Small changes that can yield big savings
fields.trailText: If you really want to get serious about saving, you will save surprisingly large sums by taking sandwiches to work and never going out. But, like a diet that's too severe, this sort of regime is likely to end in failure.
fields.body:
If you really want to get serious about saving, you will save surprisingly large sums by taking sandwiches to work and never going out. But, like a diet that's too severe, this sort of regime is likely to end in failure.

Small sums can still add up and you may find savings by making a few adjustments to your spending patterns. Check for subscriptions to services you no longer use, such as gym membership.

Then look at spending: at a typical London cafe price for cappuccino, you will spend £1.50 on a coffee. Assuming you go without one cup a day, five days a week, this works out at £390 a year. A glass of wine is likely to cost at least £2.50. Three a week, every week of the year costs £390. A packet of cigarettes costs about £3.80. One pack less a week will save you just under £200. Add them together and you could find nearly £1,000 a year to save, or £80 a month.

fields.headline: Farewell to the rabbit hutch
fields.standfirst: Far from characterless boxes, new-build homes are the high-quality choice of buyers young and old, says  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Far from characterless boxes, new-build homes are the high-quality choice of buyers young and old, says Jill Insley
fields.body:
Demand for newly built homes is at an all-time high. Developers and estate agents report properties selling up to nine months in advance of a single brick being laid, and government inspectors have recommended that another 1.1 million homes be built by 2016 in the South East alone.

Just before Christmas, 20 out of 25 apartments in a Galliard Homes development in Clapham, south London, were sold within two weeks of the plans going on display, although the new owners will not be able to move in until autumn. This demand is largely driven by the shortage of property - any property - in southern England. But this does not explain the 10-12 per cent premium builders are able to charge for new homes compared with second-hand properties.

During the housing market slump of the late Eighties and early Nineties, developers were tempting prospective buyers with offers to pay legal fees, shared ownership deals, low-cost mortgages, holidays in exotic destinations and, in certain cases, a free Porsche. Everyone wanted a home that was at least 100 years old, with all the period features. Edwardian homes were just about acceptable, provided they had coloured glass windows and verandahs. New-builds were bought by people with no taste or those who couldn't afford anything else.

But now a second market has developed among people who like the clean lines and low maintenance requirements of a new property.

Guy Foster of Friend & Falcke Estate Agents in Clapham says: 'Although period homes are still sought after - particularly by families - some people are now moving towards a more contemporary way of living.'

Such buyers are not swayed by gimmicks. Foster says: 'Buyers of today have a lot more savvy. They would rather have the quality in finish than a free holiday. As a result there's a lot more character being put in now, and more care and attention than in the late 80s, when new developments were basically rabbit hutches.'

New developments are also a good option for first-time buyers. They offer the advantage of no chain, straightforward leasing arrangements and no wrangles over management bills. In most cases the price of the property will include cooker, fridge/freezer and even dishwasher.

Buyers who can afford to spend a little more get a lot of say in the way their property is designed and finished. David Marsh of Bradford & Bingley estate agents says people can specify what they want in terms of decoration, and changes can be made to the positioning of partitions since the advent of concrete ceilings. This means people who prefer space to a large quantity of rooms can, for example, convert five bedrooms into three with en suite bathrooms and a dressing room.

But the prime attraction, as far as Marsh is concerned, is low maintenance. Many new properties have small - or no - gardens, and the structure should be in a pristine state. Any problems that do crop up, such as cracks between walls and ceilings, should be covered by the 10-year Buildmark Cover, a warranty backed by the National House Building Council (NHBC), provided the builder is registered.

This has made the new-build very popular with empty nesters, who want to be able to lock up their UK home for several months at a time while they travel abroad.

Adrian Barrick, editor of weekly construction magazine Building, says that not all development problems have been ironed out. 'We still come across a lot of cases where new owners feel their homes haven't been finished off properly, or in some cases, not built by the completion date.' He cites two recent cases where homeowners had to move into unfinished properties.

But Barrick agrees that most developers are now keenly aware of the need to protect and improve their reputation for quality work. Reputable builders will, he says, check on properties to make sure the owner is happy, even outside the terms of the guarantee.

Barrick has lived in both a newly built flat and a period house in the recent past, so has experienced the advantages and disadvantages of both types of property. He says: 'Aesthetically I prefer a character property, and live in an Edwardian house now. But a really modern, architect-designed home with lots of space would be blissful.'

To find out more about the NHBC and Buildmark Cover, visit www.nhbc.co.uk.
