webTitle: Fearless on the front line - but cautious with cash

fields.headline: Fearless on the front line - but cautious with cash
fields.standfirst: Ex-newsreader Gerald Seymour has investigated the Mafia but it's the Inland Revenue he fears, says Neasa MacEarlean
fields.trailText: Ex-newsreader Gerald Seymour has investigated the Mafia but it's the Inland Revenue he fears, says Neasa MacEarlean
fields.body:
You won't find many greater contrasts within one personality than in novelist and former ITN newsreader Gerald Seymour. One extreme of his character is expressed in his deeply cautious attitude to money while another is expressed in his work - on-the-ground investigation of terrorism and organised crime.

His nineteenth novel comes out on Thursday. Holding the Zero is about an English expert marksman drawn into the 'savage, forgotten war between Kurdish guerrillas and Saddam Hussein's military strength'.

Seymour, now 58 and living in the West Country, was a Kate Adie prototype - reporting on the ground from South Vietnam, Aden, Pakistan, Northern Ireland and other centres of conflict during his 15 years as an ITN reporter and newsreader. During this period - from 1961 to 1976 - he became a specialist in terrorism, reporting on the Basque campaign in northern Spain, the Red Brigades in Italy and the IRA in Belfast. It was this last experience that made his name as a novelist with his first thriller - Harry's Game, which became a best-seller and was made into a TV series.

Like many other journalists at that time, Seymour was encouraged to write taut thrillers by Frederick's Forsyth's great success with The Day of the Jackal. But he had no ambitions for his first novel, which he wrote in his spare time and left to lie in a drawer for three months before he showed it to an agent. The success of the book gave him the financial freedom to give up his day job.

Since then, he has 'gone to ground' to research each new book, investigating the Mafia in Italy, for example. Before a book is written, he bears the research costs himself. 'There is no advance contract,' he says. 'I value that freedom hugely. You cannot write by committee.'

But, as the son of a bank manager from Guildford, he was brought up to be extremely careful with his financial affairs. 'I was brought up to believe that money was going to be in short supply. You have in huge letters the word careful.'

What frightens him in his life is not so much that the Cosa Nostra will resent his curiosity about them but that his cheque to the Inland Revenue will arrive late. So with a payment due at the end of this month - as with millions of other self-employed workers - Seymour sent the cheque off before Christmas: 'I always send my Inland Revenue cheques in a month early. The idea of the cheque arriving at the last minute and earning me another four pence in interest would just not be worth the stress.'

For eight years, Seymour was a tax exile, fleeing the 83 per cent tax rate on earned income in the mid-1970s to write from Italy and Ireland. But, when the rates came down to 60 per cent, he was glad to stop being a member of a foreign literary elite and to return to England.

He has never taken a close interest in the management of his wealth which he cannot quite believe is there. He has lunch with his financial advisers once a year. They, of course, despite his travels to the war-torn Middle East and other hot spots of the world, classify him as a cautious investor.

 'Holding the Zero', £9.99, is published by Bantam Press

 Next week: writer and ex-model Frankie Park.

webTitle: A new recipe for secure retirement

fields.headline: A new recipe for secure retirement
fields.standfirst: Helen Pridham on putting together the ingredients for a cookery teacher's future
fields.trailText: Helen Pridham on putting together the ingredients for a cookery teacher's future
fields.body:
Barbara Green
Age: 64
Lives in: Ruislip
Occupation: Retired teacher
Income: Pension
Mortgage: £15,000 endowment mortgage
Debts: None
Investments: Peps, Premium Bonds, building society bonds, instant access account
Pension: State pension £90 a week,personal pension £42 a week, two further pension
policies maturing shortly
Aims: To get the most out of her private pensions when they mature and maximise income from other investments

Until recently, Barbara Green was a teacher of home economics. For most of her career she worked part-time, teaching adults or people with learning difficulties. But she has decided to call it a day and now wants to maximise her retirement income.

She already receives a state pension of £90 a week. She was never in an occupational pension scheme, but did take out a personal pension with Norwich Union about 15 years ago. When she reached 60 she started drawing a pension from that policy, purchasing the annuity from Norwich Union. It pays her a fixed £42 a week.

When she reaches 65 in May, two further personal pension policies, with NPI and Scottish Widows, in which she invested lump sums, will mature. Both are invested in a combination of with-profits and equity funds, and will be worth around £20,000 each, though she believes there will also be demutualisation windfalls.

Barbara feels rather confused: 'I am in a real quandary about what type of annuity to buy, and whether to amalgamate the two policies or not.' She wants to take the tax-free cash from her pension, but is also wondering how to invest that money.

Her other investments include £10,000 in premium bonds. She started to buy them three or four years ago and has received prizes equivalent to between 3 and 9 per cent each year since. She also has two Peps - one linked to the NPI Global Care fund, now worth just over £5,000, the other with Jupiter European. She invested £6,000 in the latter two years ago, but it was recently worth a disappointing £6,300.

Other savings consist of two fixed-rate bonds, one for £7,000 maturing in February and the other for £5,000 coming to an end later in the year. Barbara also has about £1,000 in an instant access account.

She owns some shares left her by her mother, which are now worth around £4,000, but wants to hang on to them: 'They pay a dividend on my birthday. It's as though my mother is giving me a present from beyond the grave.'

Barbara's husband is still working and paying the mortgage, but she likes to be financially independent.

Adviser 1: Gillian Cardy

One point Barbara may like to consider is whether to move the portion of her funds that are invested in equities into safer havens, such as cash or gilts, as protection against a drop in the stock market just before they pay out.

She then needs to get annuity quotations from her existing pension companies and from others that may offer a more competitive rate. Ironically, Norwich Union may well be one of those that give her a better deal. It is also worth investigating an impaired life annuity, which would produce an enhanced income. You don't have to be at death's door - a smoker or someone with high blood pressure or diabetes can qualify.

A with-profits annuity is another possibility. This would give Barbara some potential for a rising income, but there is also the risk that it could fall. This risk can be minimised by selecting a low anticipated bonus rate, say 3 per cent. It is unlikely that actual bonus rates will fall below that, but this will mean a lower level of income to start with. However, she could use just one of her policies for this type of annuity and the other for a level annuity.

Her tax-free cash is likely to be around £10,000, and she would probably be well advised to use this money to buy Isas to generate a tax-free income. In the meantime, she could take up this year's £7,000 Isa allowance with the money from her maturing Nationwide bond. I would suggest the corporate bond type, possibly a 50/50 split between M&Gs Corporate Bond fund and its Higher Yield fund.

I have no objection to Premium Bonds as a holding fund, but would point out that they provide no capital growth.

 Gillian Cardy works for financial adviser Professional Partnerships.

Adviser 2: Amanda Davidson

Annuity rates vary from day to day, so Barbara will need to look at the open market at the time she is retiring to find the best rates. An independent financial adviser can undertake this. She also needs to check the precise terms and conditions of the payouts from Scottish Widows and NPI to ensure she does not lose out.

Barbara will need to decide between a level annuity and one that increases. She also needs to consider whether to include her husband, though he is probably self-sufficient. She would get a higher income if she takes a level annuity. This works quite well with the tax-free lump sum from her pension, which can be invested for capital growth and used to generate more income.

She says she is a cautious investor, so she could consider investing the tax-free lump sum in with-profits bonds, which are not as risky as equities. Alternatively she could use a corporate bond Isa. Another option is to repay some of the mortgage. Her husband can then continue to pay the same amounts but effectively pay her an income rather than the building society.

Barbara should be aware that the overall return on Premium Bonds has fallen to 3.5 per cent (increasing to 3.75 per cent in March). She has been particularly lucky in the returns she has received so far.

She is right that Jupiter European has been disappointing compared with other European funds. She could consider a Pep transfer to a better-performing ­fund, such as Gartmore European or Fidelity European Opportunities. Or she could switch within Jupiter to the Income fund.

 Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan.

 Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Ski holidays  poles apart
fields.standfirst: Shop around and you'll get more runs    for your money, advises  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Shop around and you'll get more runs for your money, advises Jill Insley
fields.body:
One of the first things a skiing addict is likely to worry about is how he or she is going to afford a winter holiday. You may fret for weeks about the choice of runs, the quality of powder and the distance from your chalet front door to the ski lift, but the price of a beer, hiring boots or a childminder in the resort are just as important.

Research by travel agent Thomas Cook shows that careful selection of your resort could save you hundreds of pounds - possibly even enough to pay for another skiing holiday. The travel agent's annual Cost of holiday living index compares the cost of all the vital ingredients of a winter sports holiday, including ski hire, lift passes and ski school, in 10 resorts around the world. And for those who recognise that life does exist off the slopes, the index also surveys the cost of pleasurable extras, such as a glass of schnapps or coffee in the local café, a stick of sun block or a three-course set meal.

The table shows that for the basics - ski and boot hire, an area lift pass and five or six days' ski school - Breckenridge in the US is by far the most expensive at £621, followed by Banff in Canada at £312.10. The Romanian resort of Poiana Brasov is the cheapest, with the same basics costing £119.50.

The price of après-ski also varies widely, with the high cost of alcohol in Norway making the resort of Lillehammer the most expensive. A bottle of house wine will set you back £19, a glass of schnapps £4 and beer £2.80. However, the resort may still appeal to parents with young children because it offers the cheapest kindergarten at £4.75 a day. In contrast, parents in Breckenridge could face charges of up to £36.90 a day.

The figures for the survey were collected by ski reps in each resort. However, Vicki Burwell, a spokeswoman for Thomas Cook, warns that the prices for optional purchases will not be precise: 'When it comes to the cost of food, drink and things like sun block, the prices will depend on exactly where you shop. The survey is intended simply as a guide for people who are skiing on a budget so they know roughly how much money they will need to take.'

How to get the best value

 Avoid the peak seasons of New Year, Easter and other school holidays. Before Christmas, resorts tend to be quiet - but the snow may be absent as well, particularly below 1800m. If you can book last minute, you should be able to take advantage of good snow reports and cheap prices. Good deals and better snow are more likely after New Year until the second week in February.

 Self-catering is a false economy unless you are prepared to lug all the food to the resort in your suitcase. Although a self-catering holiday may seem the cheapest, buying food in a ski resort is usually heinously expensive. And after a hard day on the slopes, do you really want to slave over a hot stove?

 Buying all your ski gear will be expensive - and a bit of a gamble if you haven't skiied before. Borrow as much as possible from friends, and rent the rest. Mountain Bike & Ski Company in Victoria, London (0207 435 0124) charges £14.95 per jacket or trousers and £10 for ski boots for 12 days hire (plus a deposit of £50 per person). To buy the same gear could cost you more than £200.

 It's generally considered better to hire skis and poles in the resort so you don't have to haul them with you, and so you can switch them if necessary. But more experienced skiiers who know the type of skis they need may prefer to rent in the UK in advance rather than wasting the first morning on holiday.

 Consider joining the Ski Club of Great Britain. The annual membership of £66 for a family, £45 for an individual, or £10 for someone under the age of 24, provides access to discounts of up to 15 per cent off holidays with more than 100 tour operators, 20 per cent of equipment hire in ski resorts, and 15 per cent at UK dry ski slopes, plus extensive advice and snow reports, and free guiding in 35 resorts. Call 0208 410 2000 or www.skiclub.co.uk.

 'Learn to ski' weeks, sold by most of the larger tour operators, are a good value way for beginners to sample the joys of skiing for the first time. The weeks are generally in low season periods (mainly January) and usually include the cost of equipment, liftpass and ski school.

 Buy an insurance policy that covers you for all potential activities. Although you may not intend to go off-piste, you could lose your way and end up having an accident, so make sure this is included in the terms of your policy. Either consult an insurance broker or check out prices with a direct insurer, such as Columbus (policy includes unguided off-piste skiing, snowboarding and hele-skiing but not tobogganing. Call 020 7375 0011).

webTitle: Beat the deadline or face that £100 fine

fields.headline: Beat the deadline or face that £100 fine
fields.trailText: More than 3 million people are involved in an eleventh-hour dash to complete their tax return and avoid a £100 fine. People who do not return the eight-page form to the Inland Revenue by the end of this month are on line for an automatic fine.
fields.body:
More than 3 million people are involved in an eleventh-hour dash to complete their tax return and avoid a £100 fine. People who do not return the eight-page form to the Inland Revenue by the end of this month are on line for an automatic fine.

Most of those taxpayers, however, are thought to have employed a professional tax adviser to sort out the paperwork. Individuals who fill in the returns themselves are encouraged to get them back four months before the 31 January deadline so that they can ask the Revenue to work out the tax owed on their behalf. Taxpayers who opt for the January deadline, however, have to calculate their own liability - a complicated and time-consuming process for most people.

Tax advisers expect the system to work more smoothly this year than it did in the last couple of years, when there were sometimes long delays and surprising errors as the Revenue got used to this new system of self-assessment.

Richard Murphy of accountant Murphy Deeks Nolan says: 'I really can't gripe about the Inland Revenue end of things. We are not seeing as many stupid mistakes or stupid letters.' Even the Independent Adjudicator, the Revenue's independent complaints arbitrator, says that self-assessment 'isn't a big issue'. And Frank Akers-Douglas of accountant Smith & Williamson says: 'The accountancy profession is considerably better organised than the last-minute scrums of two years ago.'

So, the bad news is probably that if you miss the deadline you will find it hard to blame anyone but yourself.

Many people have a problem paying the tax that falls due on 31 January and 31 July. But the Revenue is used to this and will, in most cases, accept sensible offers of late payments. Murphy adds: 'Write a clear letter, making a proposal for how and when you will pay. If the offer is over a short period - a few months - then the Revenue won't even bother to argue in most cases.'

Tax is due in January for the final payment for the tax year 1998-99. If this is unpaid at the end of February, an automatic surcharge of 5 per cent of the sum outstanding is levied - so pay this debt first if you are short of cash. Tax is also due as the first payment on account for the tax year 1999-2000. A late payment of this sum will attract interest charges, but not the 5 per cent surcharge at the end of February.

Some people are confused about how much they are due to pay. 'A lot of people are waiting to get a letter saying please pay,' says Akers-Douglas. 'But if it doesn't arrive on time that isn't an excuse not to pay.' Finally, not everyone who misses the January deadline will get a £100 fine. The most common exemption will be for those who have no tax to pay.

 Inland Revenue helpline: 0845 9000 444. TaxAid (free advisory service for people who cannot afford to pay): 0207 624 3768 between 10am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays. The Independent Adjudicator (complaints or if you are just confused): 0207 930 2292, office hours.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Victorian values
fields.body:
Victorian values

It would be wrong to let Victoria's Secrets - Posh Spice on Posh C4 - pass without comment. A fine piece of TV, in which Posh revealed that she thought Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror , 'literally controls people's minds' and proved that if you are both v rich and v thin you can walk round Tower Records with a piece of flex stuck to the back of your jacket and no one will point or laugh. We can banish the Morgan rumour immediately because, apparently, if Piers had extra-sensory powers he would 'make people think I'm a genius'. We also hear that the original programme, presented as straight Posh interviews, was so astoundingly bad that only a bit of post-modern ironic re-editing saved it for the erudite C4 audience. Quote of the programme came from hubby D Beckham who, when asked what was good about being famous, replied: 'You get lots of free clothes.' What's wrecked privacy compared with a gratis Gucci thong?

Naked japes

Talking to Kelvin reminded us of the wistful days of Live TV and its own sports feature, Topless Darts. We hear that Bravo, the cable and satellite TV channel, is about to trump this with a new sport - nude football. Few details are available as yet, particularly on the important question of gender. Is this men, or women, or both? I think we should be told, as what might bobble around in a goalmouth incident is surely of key importance in determining the sort of audience you might attract.

Nation unto nation

What a week for The Nation. The newspaper whose editor, Michael Eboda, describes it as a 'kind of black Mirror', has broken a couple of corkers. First of all the survey that revealed that a number of black comedians thought Ali G was racist - picked up and run with all over Fleet Street - and then the scoop that Mike Tyson was to be banned from entering Britain, which as we know resulted in questions in the House. Well, stand by your beds because Eboda says the paper is about to make it a hat trick with a third big story breaking on Monday. Eboda would give away few clues, apart from saying that it is 'a Posh Spice story'. We're particularly proud of Eboda's achievements as on a Saturday he can be found beavering away putting together the Observer's sports pages.

Zero degrees Kelvin

Kelvin MacKenzie goes straight to the back of the queue for the Dome this week, on account of the fact that when approached by Media Diary three weeks before Christmas and asked whether he was contemplating changing his Talk Radio licence to turn it into a sports-only station, his response was 'that's not at all true' - or a similar form of words. So when we reminded Big Mac last week of this economy with the vérit&eacute:, and described him as a 'cad', or similar form of words, he quite reasonably stated: 'I couldn't tell you then - and I thought you'd print it, anyway,' Next time we'll know better...

webTitle: Land of the free and home of the brave class action suit

fields.headline: Land of the free and home of the brave class action suit
fields.trailText: There are 2 million guns in civilian hands in the US. That works out at 200 per lawyer. Wade through the foaming web sites of the anti-Semites, weekend militiamen and Republicans and it becomes clear that many among America's well-armed citizenry have performed the same calculation. Because if there is any hope of the ceasefire that they fear, it will come out of the barrel of a law suit.
fields.body:
There are 2 million guns in civilian hands in the US. That works out at 200 per lawyer. Wade through the foaming web sites of the anti-Semites, weekend militiamen and Republicans and it becomes clear that many among America's well-armed citizenry have performed the same calculation. Because if there is any hope of the ceasefire that they fear, it will come out of the barrel of a law suit.

First, the score. Gunshot deaths in the States are way down - to only 88 a day. Eighty-seven thousand lucky Americans were treated for bullet wounds last year; another 32,436 unlucky ones died, including a dozen policemen by their own weapons. In one typical case, a young man, Steven Fox, described feeling pieces of his brain fly from his skull after a mugger shot him. Fox is permanently paralysed.

But, hey, that's business for you. And what a business it is. Guns, ammo and accessories are a $6 billion-a-year honey pot for several corporations: Browning, Smith & Wesson, Colt and others.

Britain loves stories of gun lust in the US. It is an opportunity for snooty comparisons with America's crude and lawless society. This drives Elisa Barnes crazy.

Barnes is the lawyer who recently brought a groundbreaking law suit against handgun manufacturers, which were found negligent in the shooting of Fox. 'You EC guys are so smug. Glock, Browning, Beretta have these refined European owners. Smith and Wesson is the number one seller of killer guns and it's owned by Tomkins plc, of England.'

Armed crime is traditionally viewed as a social problem, but Barnes thought it was too convenient for gun makers to blame the criminal alone. Through investigation and statistical analysis she concluded that sales to criminals are a much-valued - if unpublicised - market segment sought out and provisioned by these upstanding manufacturers.

Her calculations are compelling. Gun companies dumped several million weapons into outlets in states with few curbs on purchases, super-saturating the legal market so that excess would flow up the so-called 'Iron Pipeline' to meet black market demand in New York and other big cities.

Like the company that sells cigarette rolling papers in quantities far outstripping sales of legal tobacco leaf, gun manufacturers have a wink-and-nod understanding of where their products end up. Their own market models cannot account for half the gun sales in loose-law states such as Georgia.

Nor can industry executives fail to have noticed the requests - more than 800,000 of them - to manufacturers from the Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agency (the Untouchables of movie fame) to trace guns captured by police after use in crimes .

The Fox case jury found a dozen gun makers guilty of negligent distribution. The shooter's gun was never found. Unable to determine which company made the gun that fired the bullet into Fox's head, the jury ordered all the maker of .25 calibre weapons in the case to pony up altogether $5 million for Fox's care and pain.

Fox's victory burst the dam. Several hundred lawyers - including the Costanza group, the combine of firms that mangled the tobacco industry - filed suits to make sure the gun industry feels our pain. The City of New Orleans is the first of dozens of cities in court demanding that gun purveyors pay the cost of gathering the wounded off the streets, and the cost of arming the municipal police force in self-defence. The legal profession may finally accomplish what a cowering Congress dare not consider: shutting down firearms sales at source.

Civil rights group NAACP has weighed in with a massive class-action suit on behalf of thousands of the wounded and dead, based on yet another theory: product liability. I spoke with one of their counsel, Mike Hausfeld, just after he returned from licking Hitler in a US courtroom. Fifty years after the war, Hausfeld's firm brought a suit against Mercedes-Benz, Siemens, BASF and others who used slave labour from concentration and prison camps under the Nazi regime. The defendants have agreed to create a $1.2 billion compensation fund .

Hausfeld concedes that the companies were acting under orders of the Reich, but points out: 'Contemporary industrial empires were made from those profits. In 1938, Henry Ford received a medal from the Führer, and his German plants continued to provide Ford income through 1942. Those profits belong to the victims.'

I took you into this column at gunpoint, but my real topic is America, Home of the Brave Lawsuit. The open courthouse is the best of US democracy, where Davids may sling their rocks at corporate Goliaths. That is sufficient reason for the powers that be to malign the US system of civil justice with frightful images of OJ Simpson and Louise Woodward where - they imply - juries ran amok.

Corporate Europe has good reason to fear American law. Consider other Hausfeld cases. His firm took part in securing $1bn from Hoffman LaRoche and other pharmaceuticals giants to compensate victims of their worldwide conspiracy to fix the price of vitamins.

The action, brought in the States, has so far benefited US victims only. European governments can collect fines, but victims of the cartel are effectively out of luck under EU and UK law, even under the supposedly tough new rules.

Hausfeld was also one of the legion of lawyers who whacked Exxon for $5bn in punitive damages for the Exxon Valdez spill. While the Wall Street Journal excoriated the courts for vacuuming Exxon's deep pockets, the $5bn hit seems to have focused the oil shipper's attention. Grudgingly, Exxon-Mobil now spends billions on double-hulled tankers, escort vessels and new safety equipment when operating in the lawyer-infested waters of Alaska.

By contrast, the French are still picking dead birds out of the crude oil from the TotalFina oil slick. I can't help thinking that disaster, whatever its technical cause, was a product of the Civil Liability Convention (which Britain joined after the Valdez disaster), limiting shippers' responsibility for spill damage in European waters to roughly £78 million. At that price, as far as shippers are concerned, an oil spill is a bargain compared with the cost of prevention.

That brings us to Hausfeld's suit against Monsanto, filed this month. Europe's Greens flatter themselves that they forced the company to retreat from its aggressive promotion of genetically modified grains. But it is difficult to imagine Monsanto CEO Robert Shapiro frightened by a salvo of well-drafted leaflets. Rumblings of a lawsuit, however, had to disturb his repose, and added to the pressure to seek a haven through merger.

After all, every US chemical company executive is schooled in the story of how half the asbestos industry was forced into bankruptcy court to settle several hundred thousand lawsuits which found companies culpable because they claimed the mineral was harmless.

Labour MP Alan Simpson (Nottingham South) has drafted a law that would make GM food and seed sellers liable to legal action for any medical or environmental damage they may cause, more in line with US law. Simpson suspects Monsanto, AstraZeneca and their ilk would be less cavalier about seeds with tweaked DNA if the companies knew they would reap what they sow.

Where will America's lawsuit-crazed lawyers strike next? General Pinochet has shopped at Harrod's in London, but has never been to Macy's in New York. In fact, since the coup, the general has not set foot in the US. Of course not, says Hausfeld, 'We'd sue him.'

Europe's Greens flatter themselves that they forced the company to retreat from its aggressive promotion of genetically modified grains. But it is difficult to imagine Monsanto CEO Robert Shapiro frightened by a salvo of well-drafted leaflets. Rumblings of a lawsuit, however, had to disturb his repose, and added to the pressure to seek a haven through merger. After all, every US chemical company executive is schooled in the story of how half the asbestos industry was forced into bankruptcy court to settle several hundred thousand lawsuits which found companies culpable because they claimed the mineral was harmless. Labour MP Alan Simpson (Nottingham South) has drafted a law that would make GM food and seed sellers liable to legal action for any medical or environmental damage they may cause, more in line with US law. Simpson suspects Monsanto, AstraZeneca and their ilk would be less cavalier about seeds with tweaked DNA if the companies knew they would reap what they sow. Where will America's lawsuit-crazed lawyers strike next? General Pinochet has shopped at Harrod's in London, but has never been to Macy's in New York. In fact, since the coup, the general has not set foot in the US. Of course not, says Hausfeld, 'We'd sue him.'

webTitle: BA cabin crews face job losses

fields.headline: BA cabin crews face job losses
fields.trailText: British Airways plans to shed at least 2,500 customer service staff - including 1,200 stewards and stewardesses - as it slashes costs in an effort to halt the profits nosedive.
fields.body:
British Airways plans to shed at least 2,500 customer service staff - including 1,200 stewards and stewardesses - as it slashes costs in an effort to halt the profits nosedive.

The airline is cutting 12 per cent of economy class seats in the next three years and will need fewer cabin crew, check-in and sales staff and baggage handlers as capacity shrinks. Earlier reports from the airline said 'front-line' staff were not threatened; most cuts would be in up to 8,000 redundancies among management and administration. Pilots will not lose their jobs, but a senior source told The Observer last week that with 12 per cent less capacity, 'we need correspondingly fewer cabin crew'.

Talks are due this week between BA management and union representatives to discuss 'productivity improvement' targets, to be finalised by March. The airline is dealing with cost-cutting department by department and treading carefully on cabin crew redundancies to avoid the kind of industrial unrest that sparked a strike in 1997. A City analyst said a repeat would be 'catastrophic' for BA's finances - it expects to lose £200 million this financial year - and for chief executive Bob Ayling's career.

fields.headline: Old hand for new job
fields.standfirst: Ben Laurance details how Davis was lured to Sainsbury - and the tough challenge ahead of him
fields.trailText: It was teatime when Sir George Bull stepped out of the lift on the seventh floor of the Prudential's building on Holborn in central London. He had telephoned earlier to ask Sir Peter Davis, chairman of the Pru, if he might drop round. There was something they needed to discuss, said Bull. It had to do with the Marketing Council, in which both men were involved.
fields.body:
It was teatime when Sir George Bull stepped out of the lift on the seventh floor of the Prudential's building on Holborn in central London. He had telephoned earlier to ask Sir Peter Davis, chairman of the Pru, if he might drop round. There was something they needed to discuss, said Bull. It had to do with the Marketing Council, in which both men were involved.

There was no reason for Davis to expect anything out of the ordinary. In any case, he had his mind on other things - he was contemplating his 58th birthday, and Christmas was days away. In fact, Bull's suggestion that he and Davis needed to discuss Marketing Council business was a bind. He had a much more important agenda: Bull was visiting the Pru in his capacity as chairman of Sainsbury.

The retailer was struggling: that was no secret. Two months earlier, when Bull had done the rounds of institutional investors to discuss plans for the appointment of David Bremner as chief executive of the company's UK supermarkets, with Dino Adriano as chief executive of the whole group, his attempts to explain the move had been greeted by less than rapturous acclaim. Since then, Sainsbury had delivered lacklustre figures. Competition in the food retailing industry had intensified. Bull was aware that there was appetite for a more fundamental change at the top of the company. In Bull's words, 'We needed now to have more pace, more power upfront.'

So, early in December, non-executives of Sainsbury had held a discreet meeting at the City offices of Warburgs, the retailer's financial advisers. They knew that they had to fill a vacancy on the board, as Sir David Scholey had announced he was to quit. But as they talked, the directors agreed that it was time to consider something much more fundamental - the replacement of Dino Adriano as chief executive. Hence Bull now found himself in Davis's office at the Pru: would Davis consider becoming chief executive of Sainsbury? It was one of Britain's best-loved high street names, but a company that had lost its former glory.

'Peter didn't actually throw George out of that first meeting,' said one insider. 'But neither did he offer many olive branches.' Bull's spoof about the Marketing Council was easily forgiven: the two men's relationship went back decades, from when the young Bull, selling drinks for Grand Metropolitan, had had to pitch to Davis, then working in Sainsbury's marketing department. Davis agreed to think it over. Bull said he needed to talk to his fellow directors. The non-executives agreed that although there were perhaps three or four people they would consider to replace Adriano, Davis came first.

Davis was torn. Since leaving Sainsbury 14 years before, as assistant managing director, he had headed publisher Reed and subsequently the Pru. He was looking forward to winding down his responsibilities with the insurer, aiming initially to devote three days a week to chairing the company, then cutting back to two days. But Davis had retained an affection for the retailer. He had been saddened to see it being steadily eclipsed over the past six years. And Davis, as much as Sainsbury's leading rivals, recognised that turning around the operation was one of the great opportunities in British business.

Bull and Davis met just once more at the Pru. But over the Christmas break there was a stream of telephone calls and faxes between Bull's home in Essex and Davis's in Hertfordshire. Eventually, a deal was done. Davis would join on a basic salary of £750,000 a year plus bonus - and the potential for becoming seriously rich if he could push Sainsbury's earnings faster than inflation, and if the share price rose.

By 4 January, Bull felt certain that his agreement with Davis would hold. So that day he broke the news to Adriano: he was to be replaced as chief executive. Adriano cannot have been completely surprised. Some of Sainsbury's leading shareholders had been voicing their dissatisfaction with him for a year or more, and much of the press had been vicious in criticism of his failure to lift Sainsbury's fortunes. Judging by the stock market's reaction on Friday, investors approved the appointment of Davis. Sainsbury shares rose 5 per cent. And Bull was able to point out that the team which will be running the company is now very different from the one that has been charge for much of the past few years. David Sainsbury has been out of the picture for nearly 18 months. And Davis is new - at least in the sense that he hasn't worked at Sainsbury since the company's glory days. Kevin McCarten, who will forever be associated with the chain's disastrous 'Value to Shout About' advertising campaign, is being shifted into the position of stores director. His former position - marketing director - is being filled by an outsider, Sara Weller, who has been retail marketing director at Abbey National.

After news of his appointment last week, Davis said he aimed to 'give the business some clear direction and self-confidence ... When I worked there before, people said with some pride that they worked for Sainsbury. 'I'd like to see that restored. I get the feeling that recently, people have had their tails down.' It is now his job to provide Sainsbury's staff with good reason to feel proud once more. It is a mammoth task - and very different from the part-time chairmanship Davis was contemplating just four weeks ago.

webTitle: BNFL threatened by loss of ISO quality guarantee

fields.headline: BNFL threatened by loss of ISO quality guarantee
fields.trailText: Nuclear reprocessor and generator British Nuclear Fuels this week faces being stripped of a vital international quality assurance standard after admitting that it had falsified safety records on monitoring the production of highly dangerous mixed oxide nuclear fuel (MOX) at its Sellafield plant in Cumbria.
fields.body:
Nuclear reprocessor and generator British Nuclear Fuels this week faces being stripped of a vital international quality assurance standard after admitting that it had falsified safety records on monitoring the production of highly dangerous mixed oxide nuclear fuel (MOX) at its Sellafield plant in Cumbria.

Loss of the standard - known as ISO 9002 - which assures BNFL customers that it has high management and quality control processes and 'is in control of the way it does things', would be a severe blow to the company.

BNFL is waiting for ministerial clearance to open a £300 million MOX plant at Sellafield, an important element in government plans for a partial privatisation of the company.

The extent of international demand for MOX fuel is unclear; government figures indicate that just under 7 per cent of the Sellafield plant's capacity is accounted for in future contracts.

Since the falsifications came to light in September, key future customers have indicated unhappiness with the fuel and the quality assurance processes at BNFL. Last week Japanese utility Kansai Electric said it would return the first MOX consignment which arrived there in December.

In the same month Swiss nuclear safety authorities said they had discovered faults with BNFL's MOX.

A three-month investigation into BNFL's management processes by inspectors at Lloyd's Register Quality Assurance, which monitors the ISO 9002, was concluded last week. BNFL has submitted an exhaustive report detailing measures to be introduced to prevent the falsification happening again.

Ian Hodgkinson, managing director of LRQA, said that withdrawal of the stan dard was clearly an option: 'When a system is found to be non- compliant with the requirements of the standard, we will withdraw the standard. Withdrawal of the standard is always an option.'

More than 20,000 organisations worldwide were covered by the standard; 22 were withdrawn last year.

Greenpeace Nuclear campaigner Helen Wallace said: 'It is a joke for BNFL to have a quality standards award, given the fiasco that has occurred at Sellafield in relation to Japanese fuel.'

BNFL said that it was confident that it would retain its ISO 9002.

fields.headline: BOC £700m sale means total break-up
fields.trailText: BOC is to spin off its world-beating vacuum pumps business and its UK freight operation for up to £700 million following a US-French bid for the company.
fields.body:
BOC is to spin off its world-beating vacuum pumps business and its UK freight operation for up to £700 million following a US-French bid for the company.

The deals mean a total break-up for the 114-year-old group after Pennsylvania-based Air Products and Paris-headquartered Air Liquide's planned carve-up of BOC's worldwide gas operations.

The £7.2 billion joint bid was announced last July, but has yet to clear all the regulatory hoops. On Tuesday, the European Commission will approve the merger, but impose stringent conditions, including disposal of UK plants in Runcorn, Cardiff and Kent. The US Federal Trade Commission is also set to make its decision shortly.

Merchant bank advisers are, however, already working on plans for a flotation worth up to £450m of BOC Edwards, the vacuum pumps business. BOC's UK distribu tion arm, the leading lorry fleet serving Marks & Spencer, will also be sold for £200m or more.

BOC Edwards is the world's top supplier of vacuum pumps to the chemical and semi-conductor industries, with two-thirds of the entire market. The business employs 3,000 people in 13 countries and made a profit of £30m last year.

Its dominant industry position would pose competition problems for would-be buyers, but French electronics and engineering group Alcatel may be interested, as may US and Japanese groups.

BOC's lorry fleet contributed profits of £29m last year on sales of £252m, and employs 4,500 people in the UK and continental Europe. The group is one of the UK's biggest logistics contractors and will be attractive to most of the big distribution firms.

About 500 shareholders gathered at London's Dorchester Hotel on Friday for BOC's last agm; most voiced sadness at the carve-up.

webTitle: I came, I saw, my rifle jammed

fields.headline: I came, I saw, my rifle jammed
fields.standfirst: Late delivery, spiralling costs and unreliability are perennial problems with military equipment. Oliver Morgan asks if 'Smart Procurement' at the MoD can cure them
fields.trailText: Late delivery, spiralling costs and unreliability are perennial problems with military equipment. Can 'Smart Procurement' at the MoD cure them
fields.body:
In 55 BC, as most schoolchildren know, Julius Caesar took the underprepared ancient Britons by surprise and invaded their country. Eight centuries later, the Vikings tested our sea defences with their longboats and found them wanting.

A millennium on our force in the Crimea was so badly provisioned that even the coffee beans were not roasted. And as Germany built panzers and stukas in the 1930s, Britain's armchair generals were still fighting the previous war.

So when it emerged that our men in Kosovo last year had SA80 rifles that jammed and obsolete Clansman radios that broadcast their intentions to the enemy, it rounded off two millennia of military logistical failure.

It was also embarrassing for a government that last year included the armed forces among the institutions it was making 'fit for the new millennium' and launched an overhaul of the system for buying military equipment called Smart Procurement.

This will, it claims, shake up the stuffy corridors of the Ministry of Defence (MoD) and establish a clear relationship between the civil servants and army officers who have traditionally spent years dithering over which radio/ tank/ship they want the forces to use and which companies are to be instructed to make them. Costs and delays will, ministers hope, fall.

There is much work to be done. Cost overruns on the biggest projects totalled £2.8 billion last year, according to the National Audit Office, which has tracked the top 25 since 1993. Between then and 1996 overruns increased from 2.6 per cent of original approval price to 8.7 per cent. The figure has subsequently dropped to 5.9 per cent, thanks largely to exchange rate effects.

Delays are simply getting worse. The 1998 NAO report found average delays increasing from 32 months in 1993 to 43 months in 1998, and stated: 'There is no sign of the trend in the department's performance stabilising or improving.' Smart Procurement is intended to change all this.

But we have been here before. Brigadier Bill Kincaid is a former soldier and director of operational requirements at the MoD. This, in the old system, meant the man who tried to work out in advance what the army needed. 'People have tried to make changes in the past. But the problem is, reliability of equipment has traditionally been low. In the Falklands, for example, Rapier surface-to-air missiles simply did not work.'

It is a similar story with tanks. Major-General Alan Sharman, who now heads the Defence Manufacturers Association, is a former MoD official who was involved in vehicle procurement. He points to the Chieftain, the army's main battle tank in the 1970s. 'The Chieftain's Achilles heel was its automotive system. The L60 engine, produced by the government-owned Leyland, was unreliable, going only 1,500 km between services. The engine never lasted long, and there were never enough spares.'

The last shake-up of defence procurement was launched to deal with such problems. Its architect, chief of defence procurement Peter Levene, imposed a Thatcherite framework on the arms business, breaking up the government-industrial complex. There was to be a clear division of responsibilities between the MoD and privatised defence companies. There were to be prime contractors, who managed projects and assumed risk, and competition among British and foreign firms.

But problems continued: attempts by GEC Marconi to devise an early warning radar system for the RAF's Nimrod failed, at a cost of £1 billion; the American Awac system was bought instead.

The tank programme floundered on. Challenger 1, originally built for the Shah of Iran, was intended to upgrade the Chieftain. 'The new armaments systems were not well-integrated,' says Sharman. But the real problems for Challenger came in 1991, in the Gulf War, when tanks had to be cannibalised for spares.

'This was back to one of the problems with Chieftain,' Sharman says. 'The man who orders the equipment wants money upfront. He doesn't worry about spares and support in the field.' That's someone else's problem.

Even as late as last September only two-thirds of new Challenger 2 tanks were operational. A mere 39 per cent of Challenger 1 tanks were fully operational. Both figures had declined from the year before.

British defence companies claim most British equipment is good. They say the problems are organisational - the delays and cost overruns reflect the bureaucratic culture of the MoD.

The NAO identifies several causes of cost inflation and delay, including project definition, technical difficulties and budgetary constraints - which covers just about everything.

Take the air-launched anti-armour weapon, Brimstone. It was commissioned in 1982, when feasibility studies indicated readiness by December 1991. Problems have pushed this back to October 2001. The result is that the army has been using the less effective BL-755 for a decade longer than planned, and the Government has spent £10 million upgrading it. Similar difficulties accompanied one of the most notorious procurement delays of all: the yet-to-be delivered Bowman radio.

Not only did the Kosovo force have its Clansman calls monitored, but spares were not easily to hand, and roughly a third were not working during the crisis. In addition, says Kincaid, the Bowman delay is holding up the introduction of digital command and control systems. In short, he says, delay affects quality.

And delay is linked to cost. The MoD procurement budget has fallen 16 per cent in real terms from £9.9bn in 1990-91. Sharman says: 'The MoD does not have the money to meet its aspirations, so it consistently has to delay projects.' He cites as an example the two-year delay in the introduction of Challenger 2. The MoD blames the builder, Vickers. The NAO similarly blames budgetary constraints for 24 months of the 92-month delay in introducing anti- tank MR Trigat missile.

But can it simply be the MoD's fault? Military systems are complex, as is managing such a massive budget. There are security considerations that do not exist in other areas, and the MoD is subject to often extreme political interference.

Smart Procurement is intended to ease these problems. Instead of competition, Labour has emphasised 'partnership' - getting the MoD and companies to work together to minimise problems. In addition, the convoluted procurement process has been simplified, with a clear main decision point. A single 'central MoD customer' has been created, and the Defence Procurement Agency will act for it. A Defence Logistics Organisation will add accountability between procurement and support. Some 145 Integrated Project Teams (IPTs) with MoD and industry members will steer 1,200 projects. Chief of Defense Staff Sir Robert Walmsley said: 'The idea is to set our targets hard and fast at the main decision point in procurement rather than it creeping along with no expenditure and delays increasing.' Walmsley added that he was negotiating with the NAO to write off past delays and rebase future reports to reflect this.

Some welcome the moves. Rolls-Royce, for example, says recent contracts - bidding for the Future Strategic Tanker Aircraft and the £350m upgrade of the RAF's GR7 Harrier engines - as models of Smart Procurement. But there are sceptics. One defence contractor says: 'This is a cultural problem and it is going to take years to change.' Another said: 'There are already problems with the IPTs. Some are better than others, and only two are led by people from industry.'

Sharman believes the split between procurement and logistics is likely to create problems: 'I would like to see one man in charge of the lot, otherwise you still have lack of accountability.'

Digby Waller, defence economist at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, points to deeper problems: 'These are demanding technical programmes, and there is high technical risk. This converts into financial risk, which the industry is reluctant to take.' It is not clear if Smart Procurement can make up for this.

And there is a classic economic dilemma underlying the whole process. 'There is a fundamental moral hazard problem here,' says Waller. 'The Government interferes because it knows if things go wrong it will have no national defence companies - and no defence. The companies know this.' Waller cites Rolls-Royce, which bankrupted itself trying to produce the RB211 aero-engine in the early 1970s. The Government rescued the company by nationalising it.

The Strategic Defence review and Smart Procurement may be buzzwords for streamlining procurement. But will they alter the millennia-old attitude that the forces get what they say they need, whatever the cost?

He points to the Chieftain, the army's main battle tank in the 1970s. 'The Chieftain's Achilles heel was its automotive system. The L60 engine, produced by the government-owned Leyland, was unreliable, going only 1,500 km between services. The engine never lasted long, and there were never enough spares.' The last shake-up of defence procurement was launched to deal with such problems. Its architect, chief of defence procurement Peter Levene, imposed a Thatcherite framework on the arms business, breaking up the government-industrial complex. There was to be a clear division of responsibilities between the MoD and privatised defence companies. There were to be prime contractors, who managed projects and assumed risk, and competition among British and foreign firms. But problems continued: attempts by GEC Marconi to devise an early warning radar system for the RAF's Nimrod failed, at a cost of £1 billion; the American Awac system was bought instead. The tank programme floundered on. Challenger 1, originally built for the Shah of Iran, was intended to upgrade the Chieftain. 'The new armaments systems were not well-integrated,' says Sharman. But the real problems for Challenger came in 1991, in the Gulf War, when tanks had to be cannibalised for spares. 'This was back to one of the problems with Chieftain,' Sharman says. 'The man who orders the equipment wants money upfront. He doesn't worry about spares and support in the field.' That's someone else's problem. Even as late as last September only two-thirds of new Challenger 2 tanks were operational. A mere 39 per cent of Challenger 1 tanks were fully operational. Both figures had declined from the year before. British defence companies claim most British equipment is good. They say the problems are organisational - the delays and cost overruns reflect the bureaucratic culture of the MoD. The NAO identifies several causes of cost inflation and delay, including project definition, technical difficulties and budgetary constraints - which covers just about everything. Take the air-launched anti-armour weapon, Brimstone. It was commissioned in 1982, when feasibility studies indicated readiness by December 1991. Problems have pushed this back to October 2001. The result is that the army has been using the less effective BL-755 for a decade longer than planned, and the Government has spent £10 million upgrading it. Similar difficulties accompanied one of the most notorious procurement delays of all: the yet-to-be delivered Bowman radio. Not only did the Kosovo force have its Clansman calls monitored, but spares were not easily to hand, and roughly a third were not working during the crisis. In addition, says Kincaid, the Bowman delay is holding up the introduction of digital command and control systems. In short, he says, delay affects quality. And delay is linked to cost. The MoD procurement budget has fallen 16 per cent in real terms from £9.9bn in 1990-91. Sharman says: 'The MoD does not have the money to meet its aspirations, so it consistently has to delay projects.' He cites as an example the two-year delay in the introduction of Challenger 2. The MoD blames the builder, Vickers. The NAO similarly blames budgetary constraints for 24 months of the 92-month delay in introducing anti- tank MR Trigat missile. But can it simply be the MoD's fault? Military systems are complex, as is managing such a massive budget. There are security considerations that do not exist in other areas, and the MoD is subject to often extreme political interference. Smart Procurement is intended to ease these problems. Instead of competition, Labour has emphasised 'partnership' - getting the MoD and companies to work together to minimise problems. In addition, the convoluted procurement process has been simplified, with a clear main decision point. A single 'central MoD customer' has been created, and the Defence Procurement Agency will act for it. A Defence Logistics Organisation will add accountability between procurement and support. Some 145 Integrated Project Teams (IPTs) with MoD and industry members will steer 1,200 projects. Chief of Defense Staff Sir Robert Walmsley said: 'The idea is to set our targets hard and fast at the main decision point in procurement rather than it creeping along with no expenditure and delays increasing.' Walmsley added that he was negotiating with the NAO to write off past delays and rebase future reports to reflect this. Some welcome the moves. Rolls-Royce, for example, says recent contracts - bidding for the Future Strategic Tanker Aircraft and the £350m upgrade of the RAF's GR7 Harrier engines - as models of Smart Procurement. But there are sceptics. One defence contractor says: 'This is a cultural problem and it is going to take years to change.' Another said: 'There are already problems with the IPTs. Some are better than others, and only two are led by people from industry.' Sharman believes the split between procurement and logistics is likely to create problems: 'I would like to see one man in charge of the lot, otherwise you still have lack of accountability.' Digby Waller, defence economist at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, points to deeper problems: 'These are demanding technical programmes, and there is high technical risk. This converts into financial risk, which the industry is reluctant to take.' It is not clear if Smart Procurement can make up for this. And there is a classic economic dilemma underlying the whole process. 'There is a fundamental moral hazard problem here,' says Waller. 'The Government interferes because it knows if things go wrong it will have no national defence companies - and no defence. The companies know this.' Waller cites Rolls-Royce, which bankrupted itself trying to produce the RB211 aero-engine in the early 1970s. The Government rescued the company by nationalising it. The Strategic Defence review and Smart Procurement may be buzzwords for streamlining procurement. But will they alter the millennia-old attitude that the forces get what they say they need, whatever the cost?

fields.headline: Archie tops Knutsford
fields.trailText: Michael Edelson, dubbed the 'shellmeister' in the City for his practice of reversing businesses into floated shell vehicles, ensuring they gain a stock market listing, is believed to be on the point of standing down as chairman of Knutsford. The company made news last November when its share price soared from 9p to 240p in a few days.
fields.body:
Michael Edelson, dubbed the 'shellmeister' in the City for his practice of reversing businesses into floated shell vehicles, ensuring they gain a stock market listing, is believed to be on the point of standing down as chairman of Knutsford. The company made news last November when its share price soared from 9p to 240p in a few days.

His replacement will be fellow director Archie Norman, former chairman of Asda and Tory MP for Tunbridge Wells.

The dramatic rise in the company's share price came after four high-profile entrepreneurs - Norman, retailer Julian Richer and property developers Nigel Wray and Nick Leslau - bought a 90 per cent stake in the firm with a view to using it as a takeover vehicle for ailing retailers.

Edelson's stepping down suggests they may be close to identifying a target. The team, dubbed the 'awesome foursome' in the City, has said it expects to have found a suitable company by March.

Possible targets mooted in the City include Sainsbury, Storehouse and Marks & Spencer, although Knutsford, currently valued at around £700 million, is believed to be looking at a smaller acquisition to start with.

Edelson, a Manchester United director, hit the headlines when he masterminded the reversal of Pharmacy restaurant into a shell company in 1998. A string of other reversals have followed.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Merger medicine | Boom time rats | A head of smoke
fields.body:
Merger medicine

Merger activity notwithstanding, 1999 was a rotten year for pharmaceuticals, with European drugs shares falling 20 per cent relative to markets as a whole.

Among the laggards, our own Glaxo Wellcome performed worst of all, slipping a relative 38 per cent. And, according to many estimates, there looks to be more downside to come, with US drugs growth slowing appreciably.

The only upside this year looks to be from further deal-making. And right on cue, following renewed market talk, Glaxo and Smith-Kline Beecham hve confirmd they are back in £100 billion merger talks.

With SmithKline chief Jan Leschly retiring in April, and the world changing fast, the odds on a deal happening are higher than last time. Both firms' powerful non-executive directors will see to that.

Arguably, given the sector's prospects and Friday's rise in both shares, much of the upside is already in the price. That, however, won't stop further euphoria if a deal is finally announced. So, with Glaxo at 1818p and SmithKline at 850p, investors should hold on.

Boom time rats

So what's it to be in 2000 - boom, or US interest rate-inspired bust? Broker Salomon Smith Barney is firmly in the growth camp , setting a year-end target of 7200 for the FTSE index.

Watch out, though, for some switching back to unloved industrial and consumer stocks in the first half, triggered by possible weakness in the US bond markets as inflation fears bite.

Salomon recommends staying overweight in telecoms and financial shares on growth and consolidation prospects. It includes Vodafone Airtouch, Cable & Wireless, insurer CGU and Lloyds TSB in its top 10 shares.

A head of smoke

If there is a swing back to value stocks, tobacco shares - with their superb cashflow characteristics - will surely be first in line to benefit.

After doing well for us in previous years, 1999 was the year to avoid the sneaky fag. Shares in our preferred two of the big UK three really let us down. Gallaher, recommended at 380p last March, slumped to 260p by the year-end. BAT, highlighted at 527p in May, also dropped a third to around 350p.

Both, as well as Imperial Tobacco at 560p, are undervalued on any rational yardstick. Forecasts from broker Charles Stanley give a target price for BAT of 720p. Buy on the exaggerated pessimism.

Pack animals

Packaging was a dull but worthy sector that underwent major consolidation in 1999, with six UK plcs worth £1.3bn succumbing to bids or buyouts. Trading prospects still look tough, even if the pound does finally weaken against the euro. So, with rising raw material prices and increasing retail buying power, the environment looks favourable for more deals - especially as shares remain low.

At 274p.5, Rexam has appreciated strongly since we recommended the shares at 246p in September. The firm is still well-positioned to benefit from industry rationalisation, however, so don't take profits just yet.

House tops

Best known as a venture capital firm, Apax Partners now has a securities arm producing broking research. First note across our desk this year is a buy recommendation on housebuilding and hire firm Allen. Since we recommended them a month ago, the shares have already risen nicely, from 280p to 342.5p. Like broker Beeson Gregory, however, Apax believes the stock to be undervalued, as it is still trading at less than 8 times upgraded forecast earnings. Hold on.

webTitle: Utility fat cats face pay curb

fields.headline: Utility fat cats face pay curb
fields.trailText: Government pressure on the bosses of privatised utilities to link their pay to the performance of their companies will be stepped up next week with the publication of the Utilities Bill.
fields.body:
Government pressure on the bosses of privatised utilities to link their pay to the performance of their companies will be stepped up next week with the publication of the Utilities Bill.

Measures in the legislation, to be unveiled on Thursday, require directors of regulated electricity and water companies to spell out in their annual reports how their salary and bonus packages reflect specific customer service standards. If directors refuse to link their pay to these standards, they will be required to say so.

The measures are part of the Government's attempts to bolster the interests of consumers, and are linked to Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers's determination that all directors' earnings reflect their performance.

Company performance will be measured against the number of customer complaints to the regulator and set standards, including how quickly they respond to complaints or faults and what happens when electricity supplies are disrupted or water pipes burst.

Ministers are concerned about the levels of complaints. Last year there were 24,300 against electricity companies, compared with about 6,000 in 1998 and 8,000 in 1995. Complaints against gas companies rose from 3,300 in 1995 to 62,000 in 1998, dropping to 40,300 in 1999.

A DTI source said: 'This will enable the public to measure consumer performance and compare it with directors' pay. There will be pressure to make sure there is a link between the two, and if there is not they can expect some fairly adverse publicity.' The regulator would also take consumer service into account when setting future price caps.

The Government has already passed measures requiring utilities regulators to pass on information on company performance to remuneration committees.

webTitle: Tomkins' dough unlikely to rise too much higher

fields.headline: Tomkins' dough unlikely to rise too much higher
fields.trailText: It may seem churlish of the City to complain about Tomkins' interim results, when the only bad performances came from the food manufacturing and leisure divisions, which the group intends to sell. Surely that just vindicates Tomkins' strategy?
fields.body:
It may seem churlish of the City to complain about Tomkins' interim results, when the only bad performances came from the food manufacturing and leisure divisions, which the group intends to sell. Surely that just vindicates Tomkins' strategy?

'Yes, but,' is the City's reply. And the big but for Tomkins is what will these sales achieve? A full-scale auction of the food business is in progress following the cancellation of plans for a demerger, and Tomkins advisers are indicating that it could fetch as much as £1.75 billion.

That would be excellent news. Ian Rennardson, analyst at broker Merrill Lynch, estimates that it has spent around £1.5bn on the business, including the cost of acquiring Ranks Hovis McDougall in 1992, as well as restructuring costs and capital spending. To sell it for anything less would be an admission that the critics, who have shunned Tomkins' shares almost since the RHM deal was concluded, were right.

But how realistic are Tomkins' hopes for £1.75bn? On the face of it, food businesses are commanding fancy prices - after all, Nabisco and Danone, the US and French food groups, have been slugging it out to buy United Biscuits. But UB has a collection of well-established brands and a valuable position as Britain's best-known biscuit maker, albeit in a mature and fiercely competitive market.

RHM may be Britain's biggest breadmaker, but there the similarities end. There is no baking equivalent of Nabisco, keen to create an international bread empire. While Hovis may be the strongest bread brand, it does not carry the weight of McVities. Others, such as Mr Kipling, or Bisto, are niche markets rather than mainstream brands.

Rather than making comparisons with the battle for UB, it may be more appropriate to look at the value of RHM's baking rival, Associated British Foods. Merrill's Rennardson estimates that its baking business stands on a multiple of 10 times earnings. Applied to RHM, that would give a price tag of just £860 million, plus whatever debt Tomkins attaches to it.

A few months ago, ABF was trading on 13 times earnings but, even at that multiple, RHM would still fetch just £1.1bn - some way short of the target. The decline in ABF's rating reflects the fierceness with which the big supermarket groups are squeezing prices, and therefore bakers' profits. RHM will not be immune to that.

Such price pressures were clear in the interim figures. Sales declined by 4 per cent, operating profit was down 12.7 per cent and margins dipped from 7.5 to 6.8 per cent. True, about half of the fall was due to one-off restructuring costs but it is easier to command fancy prices when profits are rising.

Elsewhere at Tomkins, that was the case - overall, operating profit was 3 per cent higher, and earnings per share, courtesy of last year's share buy-back, were 13 per cent ahead. Chairman Greg Hutchings could not resist another moan about the City's refusal to recognise Tomkins' value creation: earnings and dividends have grown by at least 15 per cent every year since 1983.

The question is, can that be sustained? Tomkins' two main markets after food has gone are construction and automotive in the US, both vulnerable to a slowdown. Its businesses are not high-tech enough to command fancy prices, so it is at the mercy of cost-conscious customers. If the food business does raise £1.75bn, Hutchings still has to find somewhere to put it - and many of its targets face the same problems as its existing business. A prospective multiple of less than 10 looks mean for the growth record but, barring a dramatic shift in City priorities, it is unlikely to go any higher.

Play safe

Safeway calls it the Carlos effect but, in truth, it is far too early to give the new chief executive full credit for the 6.1 per cent rise in like-for-like sales at the supermarket group in the 12 weeks to 8 January. It is also far too early to say whether such rises can be sustained for long enough to get Safeway back into a credible position in the supermarket wars.

Certainly, initiatives such as making huge cuts in the price of some products - and making sure they were on the shelves when customers got there - has been attracting shoppers. Nor does it seem to be just a case of taking advantage of the weak - Safeway says that it has been winning market share from all its rivals, not just the beleaguered Sainsbury's.

The figures suggest that Safeway is at last starting to turn the corner. But Asda (with Wal-Mart behind it) and Tesco are formidable competitors and, following its shake-up, Sainsbury may become one again. Take advantage of the bargains to be had on Safeway's shelves, but stay away from its shares.

In concrete

A flurry of positive trading statements from building materials companies proves that the recent recovery in prices in the sector, after a bleak autumn, was justified. It does look as if volumes of aggregates, cement and concrete will rise in Britain this year, albeit modestly; Goldilocks has yet to be frightened away by the bears in the US, and even Germany seems at last to be on an upward trend.

It is this latter market that makes RMC, Britain's biggest concrete producer, look interesting. Finance director Bob Lambourne is anxious that no one get too excited about Teutonic prospects, warning that the East is likely to fall still further and that the recovery in the West is not that well established. But, given how pessimistic analysts were, anything vaguely positive is good news.

Add in the potential from integrating Rugby Group, the acquisition of which was completed last Monday, and RMC looks more attractive still. Much has been made of the fact that the deal will make RMC the first company in Britain to own major suppliers of cement and of concrete, the latter being the biggest user of cement. But, given the inherent conservatism of RMC, it would be rash to predict that it will do anything to exploit its position, at least in the short term. It certainly would not want to upset the market before it is clear what Anglo American, which has just bought aggregates group Tarmac, will do with its existing small cement interest.

RMC should find plenty in Rugby to boost its profits without fiddling with the markets - including £20m of cost savings by the end of next year. That should be enough to keep RMC's shares moving. Buy.

fields.headline: Books in advance
fields.trailText: Do you really need to buy a guidebook for every holiday? It entirely depends where you're going. A trip to the US can be planned largely in advance (or on the road, if you stop at cybercafés) if you make judicious use of the web. But more remote destinations still demand a trip to the bookshop.
fields.body:
Do you really need to buy a guidebook for every holiday? It entirely depends where you're going. A trip to the US can be planned largely in advance (or on the road, if you stop at cybercafés) if you make judicious use of the web. But more remote destinations still demand a trip to the bookshop.

The Rough Guides series republishes the contents of their guides on the web, but at a fairly basic level. Unless you're inter-railing - in which case you probably haven't planned your trip in great detail, and might as well buy the book - the Rough Guide to Europe is often cursory, and that's the extent of the European information you'll find on the site ( http://www.roughguides. co.uk/ ). North America and Thailand are better covered.

Lonely Planet ( http:// www.lonelyplanet.co.uk ) allows you to update your existing guidebooks for free. More radically, it offers downloadable city guides - San Francisco, Las Vegas and Sydney are the only cities available at the moment, and the downloads aren't free, but it's a commendable initiative.

French guides Michelin ( http://www.michelin-travel .com ) are still much more protective of their paper business. Their recommendations are available online, but you'll have to pay for a subscription first. Time Out's restaurant and hotel listings ( http://www.timeout.com ) for major cities are free but less comprehensive than in the paperback format.

The undoubted and somewhat surprising winner is Fodors ( http://www.fodors. com ). The site lets you create a "customisable miniguide" for 110 destinations, and its coverage of US national parks and restaurants is exemplary. Fodors has also provided an online talking phrasebook in French, Spanish, German and Italian - clicking on a phrase enables you to hear it spoken. The Insiders' Guides ( http: //www. insiders.com ) are not well known in Britain but are an excellent guide to US nightlife and restaurants. Try Cityspin ( http://www. cityspin.com ), too.

fields.bodyText: Do you really need to buy a guidebook for every holiday? It entirely depends where you're going. A trip to the US can be planned largely in advance (or on the road, if you stop at cybercafés) if you make judicious use of the web. But more remote destinations still demand a trip to the bookshop. The Rough Guides series republishes the contents of their guides on the web, but at a fairly basic level. Unless you're inter-railing - in which case you probably haven't planned your trip in great detail, and might as well buy the book - the Rough Guide to Europe is often cursory, and that's the extent of the European information you'll find on the site ( http://www.roughguides. co.uk/ ). fields.headline: Tyson faces legal fight
fields.trailText: Anti-rape campaigners and women's groups will go to the High Court tomorrow in an attempt to stop boxer Mike Tyson fighting in Britain.
fields.body:
Anti-rape campaigners and women's groups will go to the High Court tomorrow in an attempt to stop boxer Mike Tyson fighting in Britain.

The activists are determined to overturn Home Secretary Jack Straw's decision to allow Tyson, who was jailed for raping a teenager, to enter the country and take part in a bout in Manchester later this month.

The former world heavyweight champion, who has numerous convictions and once bit off an opponent's ear during a boxing match, will arrive at Heathrow airport this afternoon amid unprecedented security.

Justice for Women, a group which campaigns against domestic violence and sexual assault, will seek an urgent judicial review of Straw's use of exceptional powers to override immigration rules which ban foreign criminals convicted of crimes which would carry more than a year's prison sentence in Britain.

The group has instructed lawyers Fisher Meredith to challenge the decision on the grounds that Straw was acting beyond his powers. Julie Bindel from Justice for Women said: 'We believe that the Home Secretary acted illegally. We already have enough rapists in this country without Tyson too.'

Tyson will be protected during his two-week stay by uniformed police officers and private security guards.

The High Court scrutiny of Straw's decision could be highly embarrassing for the Home Secretary, who justified his stance by claiming that businesses in Manchester would have been badly hit.

If successful, the challenge by the women's group would force the cancellation of the 29 January encounter with British fighter Julius Francis. All 21,000 tickets have already been sold. Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB television network has begun charging viewers £11.95 to watch the bout.
