fields.headline: Turn resolutions into reality
fields.trailText: There is no point in starting a savings programme if you have debts on credit cards. You will not earn as much interest on savings as you will pay on debt tied up in a credit card, so it makes sense to pay off debt before getting serious about saving. This sounds tedious, but you can look at the debt repayment as a form of saving.
fields.body:
There is no point in starting a savings programme if you have debts on credit cards. You will not earn as much interest on savings as you will pay on debt tied up in a credit card, so it makes sense to pay off debt before getting serious about saving. This sounds tedious, but you can look at the debt repayment as a form of saving.

Alan Dickinson, a client liaison manager with independent adviser Massow Financial Services, says: 'Some people have money on their credit cards and money in the building society. You wonder why they bother.'

Once you have got debt under control, work out a budget and decide how much you can put away each month. You will probably already have a reasonable idea, from the amount you have been putting towards debt repayment.

Start with an instant access savings account. The best rates at present come from the Internet-based accounts - Egg pays 6.30 per cent on as little as £1 and First-e pays 6.31 per cent. If you are a reluctant saver but a keen Internet user, this type of account may appeal.If you do not have access to the Internet, Legal & General Bank is paying 6.26 per cent on its Easy Access Tracker account.

Nationwide building society has a postal account that can be accessed with a cash card; Investdirect pays 5.15 per cent on a minimum of £1. Rates of interest on accounts offered by high street banks tend to be poor; building societies offer better deals. Some have regular savings accounts: Nationwide is paying 6.4 per cent on its Bonus Saver account, requiring a minimum monthly commitment of just £20.

Some building societies make such accounts available to local residents only, but they can be a good deal for those who are eligible. Monmouthshire, for example, is paying 6.55 per cent on its scheme and Saffron Walden 6.4 per cent.

A point to watch with regular savings accounts is that they may require that you save a set amount for a certain time, and there may be penalties for making withdrawals.

There is rarely any sense nowadays in taking out an account that operates a notice period: it is possible to get the same rates, and possibly better ones, from instant access accounts.

Independent financial adviser Christine Ross says one of the secrets of successful saving is to set up a standing order from your current account to a deposit account.

'Don't trust yourself to physically put money into an account each month,' she says. 'Put a mandate in place. The greatest discipline is a standing order.'

The aim when starting a savings programme should be to first set aside a fund of money to call on in emergencies. After that you should concentrate on short-term goals, such as holidays, cars and special events. Once the emergency fund and short-term goals are sorted out you can begin to think longer term.

Bank and building society accounts do not offer any growth in capital. To get this you need to look to the stock market.

Figures from the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds show that £50 a month saved in a building society instant access account over 10 years would have produced £7,172, after tax, in the 10 years to last April. The same sum in a tax-free personal equity plan would have grown to £12,229.

webTitle: Valuing shares in dot.coms is a virtual impossibility

fields.headline: Valuing shares in dot.coms is a virtual impossibility
fields.standfirst:
Heather Connon asks how you put a price on Internet firms with low profitability but high ideas
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Internet frenzy has been in full swing for more than a year now, but what is Internet paper worth as a currency?
fields.body:
Internet frenzy has been in full swing for more than a year now, but what is Internet paper worth as a currency?

Its value was put to the test last week both in the US, with the AOL acquisition of Time Warner, and in the UK, with a £46 million bid by Internet start-up freecom.net for the Pegasus software company.

Both involve bidders with large ambitions and small - or no - profits, which are using their shares to buy real assets: in AOL's case a portfolio of entertainment assets; in freecom's case, a respected accounting software package.

Both bids suggest that there is some doubt in investment bankers' minds about how investors will react to swapping an actual business for a virtual one. AOL offered a massive 70 per cent premium to Time's share price, freecom.net almost 50 per cent more than a rival cash offer for Pegasus. In normal bids, a 20 per cent premium would be seen as generous.

The market's reaction suggests that the doubts were justified. Time's shares are now about 20 per cent below the peak they reached when the deal was announced, while AOL's have fallen by almost 12 per cent.

But at least AOL has an established business, with 20 million subscribers, revenue of $4.8 billion, and earnings of $1bn. (Though Time, of course, earns more than five times as much).

One investor summed up the paradox of the freecom deal: 'Freecom.net has 200 customers, £600,000 of revenues and has been going for less than a year. Pegasus has 50,000 customers, 30,000 of whom pay an annual fee. It owns its software; freecom doesn't. It is absurd. It's madness.'

Shares in Pegasus have jumped by more than 10 per cent since the bid, and freecom's have held their value, but that probably reflects the fact that Solution 6, the Australian rival offering 430p a share for Pegasus, will be forced to increase its bid.

Solution 6 seems, for the moment, happy to wait - after all, who knows what will happen to Internet shares during the 60-day course of the bid? As one of those involved in the deal said: 'Freecom could just as easily be worth 228p as 338p.'

That is the key issue with Internet currency: who can say what it is worth? Freecom's shares have trebled since it floated on the alternative investment market and its business plan, to offer an Internet service to small companies, looks sensible. But no one can gauge how successful it will be.

Talks between the two companies started last summer, when freecom approached Pegasus with a view to selling itself to the software group. Under those proposals, Pegasus shareholders would have ended up with around 75 per cent of the enlarged group. Freecom decided demand for Internet shares was so high that it should list instead. It was right: its offer would give Pegasus shareholders less than 30 per cent of the enlarged group.

It is easy to see why freecom is keen on Pegasus - if nothing else, it should offer some protection from any shake-out in Internet shares. But Pegasus' shareholders may care to remember the fable of the emperor's new clothes. The emperor may have managed to get his citizens to admire his new suit but would any of them have bought the trousers?

So who will be the nest Steve Case?

STEVE BALLMER, 42, was late last week appointed Microsoft chief executive officer, replacing the company's founder Bill Gates. Described as brilliant and energetic, Ballmer, Microsoft's former marketing guru, has a degree from Harvard in maths and economics, and started out at Procter & Gamble before taking a course at the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

JEFF BEZOS, 35, founder and chief executive of Amazon.com, is a computer genius. Soon after graduating from Princeton, he redesigned computer systems for Bankers Trust, and became the company's youngest vice-president. Amazon, which he founded in 1994, is being transformed into an online mall, and will probably soon offer services such as video- on-demand and music.

JAMES MURDOCH, 27, son of Rupert and the man charged with developing News Corporation's new media strategy. Murdoch dropped out of college to set up his own record company, Rawkus Entertainment, and is keen to develop News Corp's music interests as well as its content library.

JERRY YANG, 30, founded Yahoo!, the Internet search engine and portal site, in April 1994 with fellow Stanford engineering student David Filo. The pair initially designed Yahoo! to help find their way around the Internet. Yang and Filo hold stakes worth around $3bn each in the company, which they are keen to keep independent.

fields.headline: SmithKline lands Glaxo merger
fields.standfirst: £130bn deal expected 'in days'  15,000 jobs at risk  Horlicks and Lucozade to be sold off
fields.trailText: Drugs giants Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are to unveil a £130 billion merger this week - far sooner than expected - creating Britain's largest company and the biggest force in world pharmaceuticals.
fields.body:
Drugs giants Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are to unveil a £130 billion merger this week - far sooner than expected - creating Britain's largest company and the biggest force in world pharmaceuticals.

According to advisers, an announcement may come as early as Monday morning, with the pace of the deal surprising the City. Up to 15,000 job losses are feared from a worldwide staff of 110,000.

The white collar Manufacturing Science and Finance Union has requested a meetings with company chief executives and Trade and Industry Minister Lord Sainsbury on 26 February to outline the likely impact on jobs.

The all-share merger is expected to give Glaxo around 58 per cent of the new group. In negotiations this weekend, however, SmithKline advisers were pressing for better terms, to reflect SmithKline's superior growth prospects through Avandia, its diabetes wonder drug. After the deal SmithKline's non-medical brands, including Horlicks, Lucozade and Macleans toothpaste, are tipped to be sold, sources say.

The merger will make Glaxo SmithKline the industry leader with combined sales of £17bn and a 7.4 per cent market share. Regulators, however, are likely to force the sale of at least two of SKB's best-selling drugs - herpes treatment Famvir and Kyrtril, for nausea. The two are worth up to £2bn.

The talks, confirmed on Friday, mark the second time Britain's two top drugs companies have sought to merge. Two years ago - when Glaxo barged in on SKB's attempted merger with American Home Products - it failed in a clash of egos between Glaxo chief executive Sir Richard Sykes and his counterpart Jan Leschly.

This time, Sykes will be chairman only briefly before he retires, with Leschly's number two, Jean-Pierre Garnier, becoming chief executive. Leschly steps down in April. That, plus Garnier's confirmation as Leschly's successor and US rival Pfizer's £45bn hostile bid for Warner Lambert in November, prompted resumption of merger talks late last year. It was Garnier's initiative, but Leschly was closely involved.

'I would be surprised if there was not an announcement early next week,' said one close source. 'There is too much value at stake for this to fall apart a second time,' said another. 'Shareholders and non-executive directors will not allow it. If Sykes is not happy with his role, Glaxo chairman Roger Hurn may fit the bill instead.' Glaxo finance director John Coombe is tipped to fill the role in the combined group.

In 1998 shareholders, led by Carol Galley at Mercury Asset Management, which owns 4.6 per cent of SKB, were furious at the merger failure and have been pressing ever since for talks to reopen, sources say.

Friday's confirmation was forced by the Stock Exchange and the Takeover Panel after press leaks led the City to conclude negotiations were at an early stage. Glaxo, however, had already asked bankers Goldman Sachs to negotiate with Morgan Stanley, SKB's US advisers.

webTitle: What's up, doc? The end of the Net as we know it

fields.headline: What's up, doc? The end of the Net as we know it
fields.standfirst: Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
fields.trailText: The advent of whatsupdoc.com (as the new AOL-Time Warner amalgam is known on the Net) is great news for investment bankers. For the rest of humanity, however, it is an unqualified disaster.
fields.body:
The advent of whatsupdoc.com (as the new AOL-Time Warner amalgam is known on the Net) is great news for investment bankers. For the rest of humanity, however, it is an unqualified disaster. Just when the Internet looked like offering a way of escaping from the ideological arteriosclerosis of the huge multi-media corporations that control film, television and publishing, one of them lumbers into the clutches of the world's biggest Internet service provider and sets off another wave of media consolidation. The corporate world's campaign to dumb down the Net has just received its most powerful boost since Walt Disney went online.

The growth and growth of AOL is one of the wonders of the age. From humble beginnings it has come to provide 20 million subscribers with a pipe to the Internet. It achieved this position by a relentless determination to be the lowest common denominator of the online world.

Steve Case, the company's boss, was once a pizza marketer, and he has never lost sight of the fact that mainstream America doesn't like surprises. He recognised early that cyberspace red in tooth and claw would not play in Des Moines, and designed an online service which was bland, sanitised and safe - the kind of virtual space Disney might have constructed if its executives had had the foresight to spot the business opportunity.

Thus AOL led the way in providing painless installation software, so you didn't need a PhD in computer science to set up an email account. It targeted families by offering multiple email addresses and parental controls. It signed deals with news providers and retailers to create online malls. It adapted browser software to provide its own branded window onto cyberspace. In the process, it created a simulacrum of the Net that mainstream USA mistook for the real thing, but which techies recognised as 'the Internet with training wheels'.

But what do techies know about business? Case's strategy worked, and he brought more people online than anyone else in history. As the subscribers rolled in, however, it became clear that AOL could not create branded content fast enough to keep pace. And without branded content there was no way of preventing sub scribers from - shock, horror! - venturing out into areas of the Net not controlled by AOL. The thing to do, therefore, was to acquire a company with a serious capacity to create content - and, if possible, major assets in cable TV. Enter, stage left, Time Warner. Cue trumpets.

The choreographed scenes surrounding the announcement of the deal were little short of nauseating. Case wore a tie, to show the corporate suits that he was a regular guy. Gerald Levin, Time Warner's boss, didn't wear a tie, to show the Internet boys that he was cool. Ted Turner, Time Warner's vice-president, said he was as excited by the deal as he had been by his first experience of sex, 42 years ago. What this says about his relationship with Jane Fonda is perhaps better left unexplored.

What the corporate testosterone cannot obscure, however, is that the old system where an ISP rents you a pipe to the Net and you go where you like for content is now under threat. In its new role, AOL owns both the pipe and the content, and the temptation to discriminate against other people's content will be hard to resist. And if it does turn out to be irresistible, there is the question of how assiduously journalists at Time , Fortune or CNN (prop: S. Case) will be permitted to investigate such abuses. What is good for America Online is not good for America. Or for anyone else.

But what do techies know about business? Case's strategy worked, and he brought more people online than anyone else in history. As the subscribers rolled in, however, it became clear that AOL could not create branded content fast enough to keep pace. And without branded content there was no way of preventing sub scribers from - shock, horror! - venturing out into areas of the Net not controlled by AOL. The thing to do, therefore, was to acquire a company with a serious capacity to create content - and, if possible, major assets in cable TV. Enter, stage left, Time Warner. Cue trumpets. The choreographed scenes surrounding the announcement of the deal were little short of nauseating. Case wore a tie, to show the corporate suits that he was a regular guy. Gerald Levin, Time Warner's boss, didn't wear a tie, to show the Internet boys that he was cool. Ted Turner, Time Warner's vice-president, said he was as excited by the deal as he had been by his first experience of sex, 42 years ago. What this says about his relationship with Jane Fonda is perhaps better left unexplored. What the corporate testosterone cannot obscure, however, is that the old system where an ISP rents you a pipe to the Net and you go where you like for content is now under threat. In its new role, AOL owns both the pipe and the content, and the temptation to discriminate against other people's content will be hard to resist. And if it does turn out to be irresistible, there is the question of how assiduously journalists at Time , Fortune or CNN (prop: S. Case) will be permitted to investigate such abuses. What is good for America Online is not good for America. Or for anyone else.

webTitle: Blessed are the wealthy in spirit...

fields.headline: Blessed are the wealthy in spirit...
fields.standfirst: ... for they shall have much better careers.  Neasa MacErlean on spiritual intelligence
fields.trailText: First we had IQ tests, then we talked about Emotional Intelligence (EQ), and now we are on the verge of discussing Spiritual Intelligence (SQ). Sceptics dismiss such concepts as ways for management consultants to make large fees. But the ideas will not go away - and demand for training courses, workshops and other offerings will continue to rise during 2000.
fields.body:
First we had IQ tests, then we talked about Emotional Intelligence (EQ), and now we are on the verge of discussing Spiritual Intelligence (SQ). Sceptics dismiss such concepts as ways for management consultants to make large fees. But the ideas will not go away - and demand for training courses, workshops and other offerings will continue to rise during 2000.

The development of ideas such as EQ and SQ offers clues to the ways in which we are using different parts of our selves in the workplace. Until the Second World War, most workers were involved in manual work, so even IQ tests were ahead of the game: the part that mattered was your body. The mind then became more valued as technology meant that more people worked in offices. In the 90s, another giant step was taken when employers began to realise that your ability to negotiate your way successfully with colleagues and clients was probably far more important in most jobs than the fact that you had a First in history.

This was called Emotional Intelligence: your ability to understand your own emotions, to empathise with others and to behave appropriately - although, of course, we all know circumstances in which a good but unscrupulous negotiator has made conditions for others worse, if not actually damaged the company's bottom line.

SQ goes a step further. Its proponents argue that the most important quality is your passion or commitment - evidenced, perhaps, by a traditional religious belief, but also by your own private desires, your love of your family and friends, and your commitment to whatever belief system you have. 'You can be spiritually wealthy and be an atheist,' says Danah Zohar, an American-born, British-based physicist and philosopher who, with her husband and co-author Ian Marshall, created the term SQ.

On 1 February, SQ - The Ultimate Intelligence is published by Bloomsbury - the same day that the Cranfield School of Management stages a one-day course on the subject. We are likely to hear a lot more of Zohar and her ideas in the coming year.

'The search for meaning, vision and value is the most important aspect of being human,' she says. 'Dogs and cats have some emotional intelligence, but they don't have SQ. If you have a high SQ, you will become much more productive. There is so much sleeping talent among ordinary workers because managers just assume that they are idiots and machines.'

Companies will become less afraid of constructive mavericks, she believes: too many of them have recruited too many yes-men, who do not ask questions or think independently.

Zohar and Marshall's ideas chime with many other studies: the Institute of Directors' survey of leadership qualities, which highlighted enthusiasm as the most important one; the recent research that discovered greater well-being among people who pray; and the growing belief that happier workers are also the most effective ones.

Harnessing your vision, controlling your own career and expanding your horizons are all themes being taught by workplace motivation experts. MindStore - a Glasgow-based company promoting self-development courses - saw a fivefold increase in demand for workplace talks by its founder, Jack Black, in the last few months of 1999.

'Most people are performing way below their effectiveness levels, in some cases as much as 50 per cent below,' he says. 'But when people fulfil themselves, it is far more enjoyable to go to work, and they enjoy their personal lives more.'

He believes that widespread satisfaction is now possible in the workplace - and even attainable in the next five years 'if work becomes something really enjoyable and meaningful.'

The keys to his approach include setting ambitious goals, focusing hard on ways of achieving them, pushing yourself forward by being positive and believing you will succeed, highlighting the challenges you face, taking in constructive criticism and then moving on.

Sue Knight, author of the Institute of Personnel and Development's book Introducing Neuro-Linguistic Programming , has seen in the past two years a 'phenomenal growth' in interest in NLP - a method, used by MindStore, that encourages people to become more positive in outlook by imagining themselves succeeding and by dropping negativity from their speech and thoughts. (Instead of saying 'I'll try to do X', you say 'I will do X'). So if, for instance, you hate your current job but do not know what would really satisfy you, Knight has this advice to offer: 'The questions we ask of ourselves have a big influence on our unconscious mind. If you ask "Why am I unhappy?" you are sending your subconscious on a search for problems. But if you ask: "What unique skills do I have? What do I really want?" you will start to find out what your unique characteristics are.'

You're not convinced? You think unbridled enthusiasm will leave you at best sounding silly, at worst failing to live up to your promises. But, as SQ's promoters would point out, the only part of the world you can be sure of changing is yourself.

Psyched up but not stressed out

Want to improve the quality of your life? If so, work on minimising the negative effects of any stress at work. You will end up having fewer painful altercations with colleagues, you will feel physically better, and your life outside work will be happier.

Bringing home your workplace bad temper and problems is also likely to depress your partner - male partners are particularly likely to feel anxious at hearing reports of their partner's bad day, according to research published by the University of Hertfordshire earlier this month.

So what are the first things you should do?

'We encourage people to relax their mind and their body for three to five minutes before meetings,' says MindStore's Jack Black. 'You can release some of the tension you have built up and clear your vision to deal with new issues. You will become more open-minded and less aggressive.'

No truck with suspicion and mistrust

If you are a traditionalist, you will think that far too much is claimed for the new management techniques. You may feel that people with real ability and discipline will be able to get the best from themselves without being nannied.

But John Oliver, former chief executive of Leyland Trucks in Lancashire, would disagree with you.

'Back in 1989, Leyland Trucks had a sad history of decline. So we developed the concept of "team enterprise" as a way of improving the empathy of the average employee, so that they would come to work with a sense of excitement rather than drudgery.

'The aim was to empower people by working towards mutually beneficial objectives. From 1989 to 1996 we had phenomenal success: while our parent company went into receivership, we had a buyout and became increasingly profitable.

'But we were a 100-year-old company with a background of suspicion and mistrust. We wanted to do something more. We wanted to start a stress management programme. Jack Black [of MindStore] came to speak to us in September 1996. We persuaded and cajoled about 300 of our workers [out of 700] and their partners to attend. Afterwards we were picking people off the ceiling. The effect was wonderful: it created an energy in the organisation which transformed even the language we used.

'There are lots of personal anecdotes about how it helped people. One person managed to get control of his angina. We were eventually taken over by the American company Paccar - and the "team enterprise" initiative was an important part of that.

'In 1989, we spent £30,000 on team enterprise - and then saved £10 million a year. We reduced the breakeven point from 11,500 to 5,500 trucks. Profits went from non-existent to £15m in 1998. In 1989, we had zero ideas per employee per year. Now we have an average of 22 ideas per employee.'

fields.headline: Agony Aunt
fields.standfirst: Will they still need me, when I'm 63?
fields.trailText: I joined my employers at the age of 23 on the understanding that I could work to 63 and retire with a full pension. Some years ago the rules were changed and all staff have to retire at 60. I was given no recompense for my three lost years of pay and pension. Do I have any comeback?
fields.body:
I joined my employers at the age of 23 on the understanding that I could work to 63 and retire with a full pension. Some years ago the rules were changed and all staff have to retire at 60. I was given no recompense for my three lost years of pay and pension. Do I have any comeback?

Your rights depend on your response at the time. An employer cannot simply make unilateral changes to employment terms, since there is a contract between both parties who need to negotiate any variation.

So if your response at the time was to write long letters, outlining your disagreement with the proposed changes, you may be able to argue now that the change was a unilateral one, imposed upon you, and you might be able to sue for damages in the courts.

But if you did nothing - carried on working and accepting pay rises - you've indicated a form of consent. In these circumstances, your room for manoeuvre is decidedly lacking. Your employer would probably argue that most people are very content with a change that allows them to retire three years earlier than they expected.

You should also contact your union. They should have been negotiating over the change with your employer's personnel and pensions department.

Legal advice by Hammond Suddards

Problem at work?

Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Calling our auditors to order
fields.standfirst: Conflicts of interest raise searching questions, says  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: It's the perennial question: who audits the auditors? Last in the spotlight with the BCCI and Maxwell frauds in the 1990s, the issue has resurfaced in the wake of the TransTec collapse, where a £11 million claim against the company had gone unmentioned in the accounts. And then there was the remarkable finding that - counter to the firm's own rules - nearly half of PricewaterhouseCooper's US partners held shares in companies which were their audit clients.
fields.body:
It's the perennial question: who audits the auditors? Last in the spotlight with the BCCI and Maxwell frauds in the 1990s, the issue has resurfaced in the wake of the TransTec collapse, where a £11 million claim against the company had gone unmentioned in the accounts. And then there was the remarkable finding that - counter to the firm's own rules - nearly half of PricewaterhouseCooper's US partners held shares in companies which were their audit clients.

These cases come at an interesting time for the habitually staid auditing profession. In the US, mounting concern over questions of audit independence and conflict of interest prompted the powerful Securities and Exchange Commission to ask its panel on audit effectiveness to investigate and report back by April. The EU is also examining audit quality assurance. And in the UK, long-simmering divergences of interest between auditors and the rest of the accounting profession may be about to boil over.

To add to these woes, evidence suggests that the incidence of fraud is rising. Precise figures are, by definition, impossible to come by, but forensic accountants believe it could involve as much as £20 billion globally. The independent Fraud Advisory Panel puts the UK total at between £400m and £5bn - a wildly vague estimate, partly explained by the fact that very little of it is uncovered by auditors until long after the event. The Internet dramatically expands the possibilities for chicanery.

Why do auditors seem to make such a poor job of spotting fraud? One factor, says Richard Murphy, a partner at accountant Murphy Deeks Nolan, is a massive expectation gap about what auditing can and can't do. Despite unshakeable general assumptions to the contrary, he says, auditing (like accounting in general) is a subjective, not objective, discipline representing an opinion, not a certainty.

'Put five accountants in a room with the raw figures,' says Murphy, 'and they'll come up with five different profit figures, all legitimate. Accountants and companies understand that, but regulators, users of accounts and governments want it to be black and white.'

The basic function of an audit as currently practised is to confirm that reported transactions actually took place, not to root out dishonesty. Current thinking in corporate governance puts increasing responsibility for the latter on a company's directors.

'Deep down, every auditor knows he is on a hiding to nothing,' says Murphy. 'Every time he signs off a "true and fair view", he knows that another view could be perfectly possible.'

However, while there are limits to what auditors can be expected to spot, particularly when managers on whom they depend for answers (and fees) are bent on deception, unrealistic expectations are compounded by important shortcomings on the practice side. Several audit firms involved in the high-profile cases of the 1990s were judged to be professionally at fault and faced disciplinary action as a result.

Part of the problem, at least in the UK, is the structure of the industry. Auditing is the least profitable, lowest-status area of accounting, a commodity that makes little or no money for the Big Five firms. It is also excruciatingly boring - one former accountant remembers crying at the tedium and humiliation of it.

For both of these reasons, the firms rely for their audit foot soldiers on trainees and newly qualified staff, for whom it is a hated but compulsory part of their training. The same applies to their managers. 'No one stays in audit longer than they possibly can,' says another accountant. 'No partner ever does an audit; few people who work for the Big Five accountancy firms would know how to set about preparing a set of accounts.'

Even if they are bright, bored junior auditors with little grasp of the implications of their work are unlikely to be a match for sophisticated insiders. More importantly, there's nothing in it for them if they find discrepancies. Quite the reverse: except in a few cases, the auditors' duty is to the company which employs them, not to authorities or regulators.

'There are quite strong incentives not to report anomalies, although that would be for the greater good,' says George Staple QC, a partner at Clifford Chance and chair of the Fraud Advisory Panel.

Moreover, an auditing team is unlikely to rock the boat if, on the back of the audit, its sister divisions are about to sell the client some much more lucrative consultancy or corporate finance services. The Big Five assert that they are strong and professional enough to resist such pressures, but others aren't so sure.

Many, including the SEC, worry about the obvious potential for conflict of interest and the shrinking pool of competition. It is almost unheard of for a FTSE 100 company to use an auditor outside the Big Five: just one - PwC - provides auditing services for nearly half of them.

As the audit firms' much faster-growing consultancy counterparts continue to invest in Internet start-ups at full tilt, the issue of audit independence will certainly intensify. This will not only create more problems for regulators; it may also exacerbate tensions within the firms themselves. Andersen Worldwide has for several years been beset by governance problems, and KPMG has been considering floating its consultancy side.

Meanwhile, in the UK, the pressures are being felt throughout the profession. On the one hand, to meet increasingly sophisticated demands, many people believe that auditing needs its own training, qualifications and career path. On the other, the Big Five are adamantly unwilling to give up their stranglehold on the discipline as a low-cost platform for training and selling on their other services.

These diverging interests have put huge strains on the English Institute of Chartered Accountants, and led to a power struggle with rival institutes. Last week Ernst & Young defected to the Scots ICA for its future training needs. 'The Institute is just waiting to blow apart on this issue,' says Murphy.

webTitle: The mother of all mergers  delivers a new era

fields.headline: The mother of all mergers  delivers a new era
fields.standfirst:
The 'suits' from Time Warner wore casuals while the 'techies' from AOL dressed formal. And that's only one element of this historic deal that seems topsy-turvy
Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
fields.trailText: The 'suits' from Time Warner wore casuals while the 'techies' from AOL dressed formal. And that's only one element of this historic deal that seems topsy-turvy.
fields.body:
The Rhiga is a smart Manhattan hotel, hardly on a par with the Four Seasons or the Mercer for flash and brash, but clubby, exclusive and an all-suite affair to boot. So when Steve Case phoned Gerry Levin in October to suggest that his company, America Online, should do business with Levin's Time Warner, the Rhiga seemed the perfect, discreet venue.

Three months later the two men were standing together on a platform in front of the world and describing how they had pulled off the biggest merger in history.

Last Monday, amid the popping flashbulbs and TV cameras - many of which belonged to media outlets now wrapped into this historic $337 billion deal - Levin was the one in the sports coat and slacks while AOL's Case was, unusually for a new media tycoon, soberly attired. This offered 57-year old Levin the opportunity to quip that he was 'welcoming the suits from Virginia', to a ripple of sycophantic laughter.

Case could afford a smile. Not only was the 41-year-old sitting on options worth up to $750 million, he was also taking charge of properties including Time Magazine, Warner Bros films and record labels, and even cable news channel CNN.

Some of the Time Warner executives may have squirmed uncomfortably when they remembered how they treated Case as something of a joke when he used to work media trade fairs, asking anyone who would listen and anyone with a scrap of content whether they would consider his rather unfashionable online service as a vehicle for their brands. More often than not, the answer was 'no'.

Looming large at the press conference was Time Warner's other figurehead, Ted Turner, the man who only a week earlier had been splashed across every US newspaper for his separation from wife Jane Fonda. Clearly marital matters were still on Turner's mind as he enthused about the unprecedented merger between the old and the new media: he said he approached the business with the same enthusiasm and trepidation 'as I did when I first made love to a woman some 42-years ago'. Cue more delighted laughter from the press benches.

Throughout the day the pavement outside Time Warner's monolithic headquarters remained lined with TV cameras. In America, where business is always big news and Net business is the biggest, this was the biggest thing anyone could imagine happening.

In CNN's studios, the influential Moneyline programme struggled to stay on the right side of hyperbole - and failed. Three of Wall Street's most influential analysts enthused about the transformative nature of the deal, breathlessly declaring it the true dawn of a new age. Asked to sum up the deal, Jessica Reif Cohen, chief media analyst at Merrill Lynch, just said: 'Wow!'

Rendering speechless analysts who are paid millions of dollars a year to understand the fast unravelling communications market was the first trick of the AOL/Time Warner deal. But as the sun rose over Wall Street on day two of the biggest merger in the world, a little cold reality was beginning to creep into the picture.

Shares in both companies dropped throughout the day as America's finest financial minds struggled with the ugly question: 'How much is it worth?' Shares continued to fall throughout the week: AOL was falling back because, said some: 'The market doesn't like the fact that it is no longer a pure Internet player - that it has suddenly taken on board all these crummy overheads associated with "old" business.' The sheer size of the deal meant this readjustment took about £16bn off its value. To give some idea of scale, this is like a company the size of BSkyB completely disappearing.

Most of Wall Street had realised what Steve Case had worked out many months earlier: that at some point the ambitious valuations of the Internet were going to have to come down and meet reality. Before that could happen, Case beat his contemporaries by transferring some of that hypothecated value into something real. AOL had managed to secure 55 per cent of the merged company, even though its profits and turnover were a fraction of Time Warner's.

By last Thursday, the financial community had adjusted the price of shares in AOL and Time Warner to a level that reflected a fair valuation. Much more slippage and the whole deal could be in trouble.

Despite the fact that AOL is that rare thing - an Inter net company that makes money - the size of the respective organisations is still massively disproportionate.

Time Warner has 67,000 employees; AOL has 12,000. Time Warner has a turnover of over $26bn; AOL's is just over $5bn. Profits at AOL are $500m; at Time Warner they are $1.19bn. Yet AOL will rule the roost: while Levin remains as chief executive, the man tipped for the top is Bob Pittman, AOL's chief operating officer and Case's right-hand man. He was also one of the founders of MTV - so he's the complete new media man.

But is the AOL/Time Warner deal as significant as the brouhaha suggests? After all, when Time and Warner lumped themselves together in 1989 on the mistaken grounds that cross-media ownership was the way of the future, it took them nearly a decade to recover culturally from the decision. Is this just a repeat performance?

One indisputable fact about the AOL deal is that it proves the Internet is the fastest maturing business ever. It also proves, for those who were in any doubt about it at all, that content is not king, as we were told for the first five years of the Nineties. In fact, distribution is king - and distribution plus content are emperor.

This may seem far removed from media and communications in Europe. It will not affect the Warner-produced content we consume over here - from the Cartoon Network to The Sopranos and reruns of Larry Sanders.

Nor will it have an impact on many Internet users over here - of AOL's 26 million subscribers worldwide, 20 million are in the US. Of the rest, slightly over 2 million subscribe to Compuserve, and a further 3 million-plus belong to AOL Europe - a joint venture with Bertelsmann.

No, the really big effect of the merger is to accelerate what we already knew was happening - that distribution platforms of all media are converging.

It also reminds us that if Rupert Murdoch was minded to sell News Corporation - which he isn't - and Yahoo! was minded to buy it - which it isn't - such a deal would be perfectly feasible.

Does this mean, as US economist Paul Krugman suggests, that the Internet is about to stop being a liberated open system and start being a boring toll-oper ated domain for subscribers only?

Case is clearly banking on this scenario, which would make the deal a blow for the Net purists but a fillip for traditional media companies - awed by the power of the Net but scared by its anarchic lack of revenue streams.

What is certain is that before the deal there was no unifying factor between Time magazine and HBO, the cable channel - but through AOL there will be. In other words, the Internet can easily replace broadcasting as a way of distributing television programmes.

Time Warner, as the second-largest cable operator in the US, may find this doubly useful, as cable delivery of Internet services is now widely believed to be 'the future'.

The types of capability that come from a broadband network mean that those slow, clunky Internet connections will be a thing of the past.

AOL/Time Warner doesn't really represent something new - instead it means that the convergence of television sets and computers has come another step closer, and when it happens, the new company ought to be at the front of the pack. But in terms of a 'viewing revolution', forget it for now.

This deal is the first true merger of new media with old. Others have attempted it - such as the legendary US mogul Barry Diller, whose USA Networks tried to buy Internet search engine Lycos, but that deal fell apart under the strain of trying to agree a value.

Whether or not the AOL merger goes through, there will be other deals of this sort.

Just as the great pioneers of the entertainment industry - the film studios and their flamboyant founders - fell into the arms of newer constructs such as TV networks or record companies, so Internet businesses will meld with newspaper, magazine, TV and film businesses.

fields.headline: Mannesmann set for £4bn Internet float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mannesman is set to make up to £4 billion following the decision by Klaus Esser, the company's chief executive officer, to float 20 per cent of its Internet and e-commerce arms. The windfall is likely to be used to buy a raft of new Internet services for the Mannesmann network of telecoms firms - as well as servicing debt - if Vodafone, the UK's largest network, fails in its hostile bid to acquire the German company.
fields.body:
Mannesman is set to make up to £4 billion following the decision by Klaus Esser, the company's chief executive officer, to float 20 per cent of its Internet and e-commerce arms. The windfall is likely to be used to buy a raft of new Internet services for the Mannesmann network of telecoms firms - as well as servicing debt - if Vodafone, the UK's largest network, fails in its hostile bid to acquire the German company.

Esser announced the move on Friday as part of Mannesmann's defence. The UK's largest mobile phone operator is offering an all-paper deal which currently values Mannesmann at around £85bn. Mannesmann has already announced that it is hiving off its engineering and automotive arms in a bid to turn itself into a focused communications business.

Esser ruled out separating its telecoms interests from its Internet and e-commerce divisions completely. 'I believe it would be wrong to float the ISP business separately. If there is a value, it should be part of the Mannesmann share,' he said.

Vodafone argues that if it were to acquire Mannesmann, the combined company would have the potential to become a global telecoms player. Mannesmann's board argues, however, that on its own it offers its shareholders much greater growth potential.

Last night the two sides were locked in a bitter war of words over which strategy offered shareholders the best return in the long run.

Mannesmann is predicting compound earnings growth for its telecoms arm of 39 per cent between now and 2003. Sources close to Vodafone argue that such predictions could not be made by UK companies because London stock exchange regulations outlaw such long-range claims. 'The truth is that nobody knows how big a business will be in 2003,' one source said.

Esser argued before Christmas that Mannesmann's 'tele-commerce' arm (which specialises in developing e-commerce solutions) would be worth around 10 billion euros (£6bn) if sold privately. Its Internet arm, which includes Europe's third-largest Internet service provider, with 2.6 million subscribers, would be worth around 20 billion euros. By offering 20 per cent stakes in both, Mannesmann would be in line to make around £4bn.

However, the recent activity in the Internet sector, notably AOL's $370bn acquisition of Time Warner last week, has placed a premium on online stocks, and Mannesmann could be on course to make significantly more from an Initial Public Offering given current investor demand.
